HEADLINE: David Durand Is Dead at 83; Was Statistics Pioneer at M.I.T.

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
David Durand, a former professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who was a pioneer in applying statistical tools to problems in financial markets, died on Monday at the M.I.T. Infirmary in Cambridge, Mass. He was 83 and lived in Lexington, Mass.
The cause was aplastic anemia, a blood disorder, his family said. 
 As a professor at the Sloan School of Management at M.I.T., Mr. Durand applied sampling analysis to subjects like consumer loan defaults and farm mortgages.
He Durand developed the statistical explanation for why long-term bonds usually have a higher yield than those with shorter terms. "Everyone understands that today, but he was the first to document it," said Paul A. Samuelson, the Nobel Prize-winning economist and fellow M.I.T. professor. said.
Working in the 1950's, when computers were still primitive, Mr. Durand used punched-card equipment for statistical tabulation. As eagerly as he constructed mathematical models, colleagues and former students said, Mr. Durand used the results as an aid to judgment rather than the final answer. "Frequently this did not endear him to those enamored of a model," said Don Lewin, a former doctoral student of Mr. Durand and now a consultant in York, Pa.
Mr. Durand wrote a textbook on statistical techniques, "Stable Chaos" (General Learning Press) and was for many years an associate editor of Financial Management.
He was reared in Ithaca, N.Y., and received a bachelor of arts degree from Cornell University in 1934. He received his master's degree and doctorate from Columbia University.
Before joining M.I.T. in 1953, he was associated with the National Bureau of Economic Research and the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J.
He is survived by his wife, Edith Durand of Lexington, and a daughter, Marie Durand of Princeton.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Little Change In Treasury Prices in Day

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday in trading buffetted by mixed signals from economic reports and by comments from Federal Reserve officials that suggested the central bank might not be prepared to cut interest rates soon.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 1/32, to 9327/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, slipped to 6.46 percent, from 6.47 percent on Wednesday. But he price of the two-year note fell 15/32 , to 9915/32 , driving its yield up to 5.41 percent from 5.36 percent. 
 An auction of new one-year bills yesterday generated disappointing demand, traders said. The Treasury sold $18.75 billion of the bills at an average discount rate of 4.98 percent.
Treasury prices fell sharply after an unexpected drop in claims for initial unemployment benefits suggested to some market participants that the job market was improving.
Jobless claims fell 23,000, to 359,000, last week, a bigger decline than economists expected. The drop in claims stemmed in part from the Washington's Birthday holiday last week, which gave unemployed workers less time to file, analysts said.
Bonds later pared their losses after a report showing slower manufacturing in the Chicago area eased concerns that the economy was growing fast enough to exacerbate inflation.
The Chicago Purchasing Management Association's report on manufacturing activity fell to 44.9 in February from 50.9 in January, suggesting economic growth is still plodding.
"Numbers like the Chicago purchasing managers index really tells you like it is, which is that the economy really stinks," said Andrew Brenner, senior trader at Nomura Securities International in New York. That suggests bond yields should be headed lower, he said, adding, "I don't know when it will be, but this market will turn around."
But expectations of lower rates ahead were shaken after Robert Parry, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco said he expected the economy would soon pick up steam. That assessment was echoed by Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Federal Reserve governor, who said the economy's fundamentals "are strong."
Taken together, their comments reduced the odds that interest rates would be cut when Fed policy makers meet on March 26, traders and analysts said.
"The Fed will be on hold until we get a clear direction on the economy," said Peter Greig, who helps manage $1 billion of bond funds at Financial Counselors Inc. in Kansas City, Mo.
At the University of California at Davis's Graduate School of Management yesterday, Mr. Parry said: "I don't think we're going to see this slowing continue. I think we're going to see a pickup in the economy."
Mr. Parry also said in an interview with Dow Jones that current monetary policy was "reasonably accommodative." He added, "I'm really quite comfortable at this point with monetary policy."
Separately, Mr. Lindsey said that while economic growth has recently been weak, the "fundamentals of the economy are strong."
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of one-year bills:

HEADLINE: Stocks Down Again, With Dow Off 20.59

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks extended their losing streak into a fourth session yesterday as the market focused again on the Presidential election and the prospects of a United States default in March if no action is taken by Congress to raise the nation's debt limit.
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 20.59 points to end at 5,485.62, which brought its four-day loss to 146 points. 
 In the broader market, declining issues led advances, 1,474 to 900, on active volume of 453.2 million shares on the Big Board. The Nasdaq Composite index was off 7.50, to 1,100.05.
"The political uncertainty has cast a shadow over the market," said Bill Meehan, analyst at Prudential Securities. "As the Presidential campaign rolls around, no one is talking about reining in the deficit."
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin told the House Ways and Means Committee that the Government could default on its obligations by March 21 if Congress did not increase the $4.9 trillion debt ceiling.
"His comments didn't help" stocks, Mr. Meehan said.
The threat of a default has contributed to the recent surge in long-term bond interest rates.
In the bond market, the benchmark 30-year Treasury edged up 1/32 , and its yield held virtually unchanged at 6.46 percent from Wednesday's close at 6.47 percent after climbing early in the day to 6.53 percent -- the highest level in five months. In mid-February, the yield was just 6.03 percent.
After the close, the House majority leader, Dick Armey, said Republican House leaders planned action on the proposed debt ceiling increase next week.
Birinyi Associates Inc., which tracks the market-making program traders, noted that for the first time since Feb. 15, the New York Stock Exchange's curbs on program trading were not activated.
The so-called collars are brought into play when the Dow industrials rise or fall by 50 points.
But stocks were again whipsawed by the wild gyrations of the bond market.
"Bonds set the tone and stocks follow," said Gregory Nie, a technical analyst at Everen Securities in Chicago.
Stocks and bonds fell at the opening on news that weekly jobless claims fell to 359,000, from a downwardly revised 382,000 the previous week, a sign that the economy could be stronger than expected.
Later, the markets recouped their losses on news that the Chicago urchasing managers index for February -- a measure of business activity -- was at 44.9, sharply below the expected 51.5.
The regional data suggested that the economy was weaker then expected, which suggested that the central bank could lower interest rates when the policy-making Federal Open Market Committee meets on March 26.
A broader measure of the economy will come from today's release of the National Association of Purchasing Management index.
Among individual issues, LSI topped the Big Board active list and tumbled 3 7/8, to 27 5/8, after warning that its first-quarter earnings will be weaker than expected.
Other semiconductor equipment makers fell in sympathy, with Applied Materials off 2 3/4, to 35 3/4; KLA Instruments down 1 3/4, to 24, and Lam off 2 1/8, to 36 7/8.
Other initial public offerings also drew buying interest. Engineering Animation, a three-dimensional animation products producer, soared 7 3/4, to 25 3/4, and Indus, a client/server enterprise management software company, leaped 7, to 22. Sithe soared 8 5/8, to 14 1/2, on news that Japan's Marubeni would acquire a 29 percent stake in the company for $15 a share.
Oil stocks rose in response to rising crude prices. Exxon gained 1 1/4, to 79 1/2. British Petroleum rose 2 1/8, to 100 3/8, and Mobil added 1 3/4, to 109 5/8, after the two companies agreed to combine European refining and fuel marketing operations.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell 4.32 points, to 640.43. The American Stock Exchange index was off 4.66 at 562.00.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks lost 1.82, to 342.80. The average share was down 21 cents.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: LOOKING ABROAD;
Forbes Offers View of His Foreign Policy Stands

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29

 BODY:
If Steve Forbes could change the world, he would give Taiwan a seat in the United Nations, split Rwanda into two countries with Hutus on one side and Tutsis on the other, and see to it that the President of Serbia was indicted as a war criminal.
He would also shore up the Mexican peso, make northern Iraq a trusteeship of the United Nations and draw "a line in the water" if China threatened to cross the straits and attack Taiwan. 
 With his ambitious flat tax plan for America, the magazine publisher turned Presidential candidate has been regularly accused of pitching only one issue on the campaign. ("If you ask him about Bosnia, he gives you the flat tax message," Senator Bob Dole said recently.)
But with Mr. Forbes's recent resurgence following primary victories in Delaware and Arizona, and the contest next week in New York, where voters have a habit of bringing up touchy subjects like the Middle East, Mr. Forbes is starting to talk more about what he would do if he won the title of commander-in-chief.
After Cuba shot down two civilian aircraft this week, Mr. Forbes called Cuba's leader, Fidel Castro, a "bloodthirsty dictator" and said that the shootdown proved why the United States had to fulfill Ronald Reagan's "Star Wars" dream of building a defense system in space against nuclear missiles. Mr. Forbes acknowledged that Mr. Castro did not have any nuclear weapons to defend against, but said that he would surely use them to attack America if he did.
Two interviews and more than two decades of magazine columns reveal a candidate with a comprehensive, if idiosyncratic world-view. He even has opinions on why global environmentalists who attack the use of Pampers should be ignored ("They don't want the rest of us enjoying ourselves") and why the United States should not mint one-dollar coins (British one-pound coins "are a pain to deal with").
"People say they don't know where he stands, but he has a paper trail 22 years long," said former Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger, the honorary co-chairman of Mr. Forbes's campaign, the chairman of Forbes Inc. and one of his foreign policy mentors.
Mr. Weinberger insists that Mr. Forbes's written record is a political plus, saying, "It's very good for the public to know."
The candidate himself is not worried that his words will haunt him. "It's fun having your own pages," he said in an interview. "And they're always going to find something on you."
Mr. Forbes sees himself as a Ronald Reagan-style optimist, a believer in old-fashioned principles like global freedom, a strong defense and the unlimited potential of the human imagination.
Indeed, his full-color campaign brochure includes a photograph of Mr. Forbes and Mr. Reagan, who once appointed him to the largely ceremonial job of chairman of the Board for International Broadcasting, which oversees Radio Free Europe. No modesty here. The brochure claims that the global radio station "helped bring down the Iron Curtain."
In his columns, Mr. Forbes has called President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia "Hitleresque," North Korea's leader, Kim Jong-il, "loony" and Syria's Hafez al-Assad a "terrorist," descriptions that he said still fit today.
Years before Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait in 1990, when he was still a friend of the United States, Mr. Forbes described the Iraqi leader as a "gangster" with "a thirst for blood and violence." After the Gulf war was over and the Emir of Kuwait restored to his throne, Mr. Forbes said that the Kuwaiti leader had been more interested in "room service than in governing" and predicted his abdication.
"Too bad you can't sell international leaders short the way you can stocks," he wrote.
Last April he wrote that Pamela Harriman, the American Ambassador to France, was an "A-list natural" should President Clinton ever decide to fill the post of Secretary of State. Just what would make her a good Secretary of State? "She just seems to have more verve and energy than our current one," he said in an interview.
His us-against-them attitude is best illustrated by his determination to use force to defend Taiwan if China attacked the island nation it claims as its own, even though the United States has no legal obligation to come to Taiwan's defense.
He compared Defense Secretary William Perry's recent refusal to state that the United States would defend Taiwan against China to Secretary of State Dean Acheson's statement on the eve of North Korea's invasion of South Korea that the United States would not necessarily come to its defense.
"We have to make clear that we will use force if China uses force," Mr. Forbes said, adding he would "draw a line in the water."
Mr. Forbes insisted he could somehow adhere to the "one China" policy by which the United States recognizes Beijing's claim to Taiwan, and at the same time push for Taiwan to become a member of the United Nations -- a move that Beijing would regard as an act of war.
And in a Forbes Administration, Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, would be welcome to make private visits to the United States, despite the fact that the Clinton Administration's decision to allow him to visit Cornell University, his alma mater, last year caused a major rift with Beijing that has not been mended. He would not be invited to the White House, but Mr. Forbes might agree to meet him on neutral ground like a college campus, "if he receives an honorary degree, and I receive one at the same time."
Mr. Forbes opposes the stationing of American troops on the Golan Heights should Israel and Syria make peace ("Using American troops as a trip wire there would not be wise to do").
He favors the expansion of NATO to include Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary -- but not Russia. "Then you wouldn't need NATO," he said.
There is also a streak of we-are-the-world libertarianism in his writings.
Although he began calling last fall for tougher enforcement against illegal immigrants, a decade earlier he criticized proposals to crack down on illegal immigrants by punishing employers who hired them. "An important portion of this country's prosperity is now dependent on illegals," he wrote. "The American southwest would suffer a depression without them."
In April 1991, he argued in favor of allowing Puerto Rico to hold a plebiscite on its political future, chastising those on Capitol Hill who opposed such a move because the island might vote for statehood.
In his view, there is nothing sacred about international borders. In an April 1991 column, more than a year after the end of the Gulf war against Iraq, Mr. Forbes argued that the ouster of Saddam Hussein was more important than the disintegration of Iraq. "The breakup of Iraq?" he asked. "So what?"
As for Rwanda, Mr. Forbes would have the French take the lead in splitting the country in two, even though the French gave arms and political support to the Hutus in the years before the 1994 massacres, would never be trusted by the Tutsis and have rejected a new peacekeeping role in neighboring Burundi.
But in crafting a foreign policy, Mr. Forbes simply cannot get away from the issue that remains dearest to him: the flat tax. In his writings, Israel's biggest problem seems not to be Palestinian self-rule or the eventual status of the Golan Heights, but the fact that the country does not have a flat tax.
If Israel were to enact a flat tax and combine it with serious deregulation, he wrote last June, it "would instantly have Israel's economy performing the way its legendary army and air force have done since independence."
And which country is a model for much of the rest of the former Soviet Union? "Estonia is particularly impressive," he wrote last August. "It has instituted a flat tax."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Plan to Mix Oil With Oil In Europe

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
In an effort to cut costs in Europe where demand for gasoline has been declining while refining capacity has been increasing, the Mobil Corporation and the British Petroleum Company said yesterday that they would combine their refining and marketing of fuels and lubricants.
If the step is approved by the European Commission, the two companies will create a huge new force that would control about 12 percent of the European fuel market and 18 percent of the lubricant market. 
 Under the agreement, Mobil's red, white and blue trademark will be replaced by B.P.'s green and yellow colors at 3,300 Mobil stations, and 5,600 B.P. stations will carry the signs for Mobil lubricants.
"This is a monumental event," said Fred Leuffer, an analyst for Bear, Stearns & Company, suggesting that other major oil companies were considering similar moves.
He said that most major oil companies had exhausted more traditional ways to cut costs, like layoffs and spinoffs of assets.
The next phase, he added, would be for the highly competitive industry to begin creating partnerships in refining and marketing.
"I think every major oil company is looking at this," he said.
"We're doing this with Mobil because our attitudes are similar," John Browne, the chief executive of British Petroleum, said. "It takes searching after mutual advantages, recognizing that someone else is doing something better."
The combination will be a complex pooling of $5 billion worth of assets -- $3.4 billion from B.P. and $1.6 billion from Mobil. The partnership projects annual sales of $20 billion.
John D. Hervey, an analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said the combination would create a marketing group that would be in the same league with Europe's two refining and marketing giants, Esso and Shell.
The fuels and lubricants business in each country will be run by combined management teams. Other departments, like information technology, human resources, legal and accounting, are also to be merged.
The companies estimated that about 2,000 to 3,000 jobs will be lost from their combined work force of 17,500 -- not including the gas stations -- and that they would save about $400 million to $500 million a year, beginning in about three years.
In contrast to the United States, where fuel consumption has grown as less efficient sport utility vehicles have taken a major part of the new- car sales and people are driving faster, European fuel efficiency is still improving.
Sluggish economies and economic changes in Eastern Europe have also cut demand for oil products.
Meanwhile, Europe has not shut many older refineries, which has caused a surplus of capacity, keeping profits down on refined products.
British Petroleum owns or has an interest in eight European refineries with a combined capacity of 760,000 barrels a day. The company said recently that it would sell its Lavera refinery in the South of France, which would bring its capacity down to 575,000 barrels a day.
B.P. took an exceptional charge of $1.12 billion in the fourth quarter to reflect its intention to sell that refinery and one in Lima, Ohio.
Mobil owns or has an interest in six European refineries with a capacity of 350,000 barrels a day.
Under the agreement, B.P. would control 70 percent of the combined refineries and 8,900 service stations and operate them. Mobil will control 51 percent of the lubricant business and operate it.
Mr. Brown said that European consumers were also attracted to stations that sell more than gasoline, creating pressure to upgrade stations. That is also a strong trend in the United States, where oil companies are building new stations that combine convenience stores with fast-food outlets.
Also the marketing of gasoline is changing rapidly, with customers tending to buy at stations where they have a credit card, especially if it can be used to pay at the pump. Mobil is among the companies that have been aggressive in promoting its credit card and upgrading stations to accept cards at the pump.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Fall in a Shorter Workweek

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for state unemployment benefits tumbled last week, but economists said today that the sharp drop did not signal any drastic improvement in the labor market.
The Labor Department said that first-time applications for unemployment pay fell by 23,000, to 359,000, far exceeding Wall Street economists' forecasts for initial claims of 380,000 in the week. 
 The shortened workweek because of the Washington's Birthday holiday probably contributed to last week's decline, which put the number of applicants at its lowest level since the week that ended Jan. 13, when claims stood at 316,000.
The closely watched four-week moving average of claims, which is considered a more accurate barometer of the labor market because it irons out weekly volatility, decreased by 8,250, to 372,500.

HEADLINE: Power Shopping in Los Angelas;
Bloomingdale's Pushes Into a Crowd

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Standing in the middle of the designer sportswear department at Nordstrom, Lisa Razin ticked off the differences between the department stores in the Southern California bazaar. Bullock's is her place to buy cutting-edge fashion, while Nordstrom is where she goes for cosmetics and party dresses. Robinsons-May has no clear-cut image at all.
And then there is Bloomingdale's, which is about to storm into the Southern California market. "I have no clue about it," said Ms. Razin, 30. "I'm a total West Coast person. I am not sure I need another shopping option. But I do know to know that it's cool." 
 Federated Department Stores Inc., the largest department-store company in the nation, is betting that the Bloomingdale's name, and all that it represents, will be enough to drag shoppers by the tens of thousands out of Nordstrom, Neiman Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue and into its aisles.
The company bought the 82-store Broadway chain last year for $1.6 billion, with plans to change the stores to its own in a pre-emptive strike against other potential West Coast competitors. Federated had already acquired the Macy's chain, with its Bullock's and I. Magnin divisions -- all chains with California presences. Federated plans to convert the Bullock's stores to Macy's.
This West Coast invasion is the most recent and pronounced effect of the consolidation that has reshaped the department-store business over the last decade. The strongest and biggest companies have gobbled up weaker regional competitors, eliminating them from the food chain.
The upheaval has turned department stores, dismissed only a few years ago as outdated, overpriced dinosaurs destined for extinction, into one of the few areas of retailing that is actually gaining ground. By developing carefully honed fashion images and relying on economies of scale in buying and merchandising, the most successful companies have overcome the heavy cost of acquisitions to invade not just the turf of other department stores but also to strike back against the specialty retailers that once threatened to nibble them to death.
And Southern California, which is finally emerging from its worst economic downturn in decades, is ground zero of the store wars. "California is an extremely important state to have a large position in," the chairman of Federated, Allen I. Questrom, said in a recent interview. "It has one of the most dynamic economies in the United States. It is close to the Pacific Rim. And in the long run, it will continue to be a major economy."
Federated's collection of Broadway stores will be sliced and diced, depending on regional demographics. Stores in locations with few wealthy consumers will be sold to companies like Sears and J. C. Penney. At least 40 are to be converted into Macy's -- a name familiar to many Southern Californians because of the chain's presence in the San Francisco Bay area -- that will be aimed at middle-market consumers.
But the big bets will be placed in four prime Broadway locations, Beverly Center and Century City west of downtown Los Angeles, Fashion Island along the coast in Orange County and Sherman Oaks in the San Fernando Valley. There, the Broadway stores will be gutted and turned into Bloomingdale's. (Federated will also open a Bloomingdale's in the Bay Area in Palo Alto.) Federated, which is based in Cincinnati and which last year had sales of $15 billion, estimates that the entire Broadway conversion will cost $525 million, a number that many analysts say is quite a bit less than what it will ultimately take to remodel stores that were perhaps best known for their previous owner's neglect.
For now Wall Street is keeping the leash loose on Federated, overlooking the big debts that give it a highly leveraged balance sheet, in hopes that the expansion will generate a huge flow of cash once it is completed. But the new Bloomingdale's and Macy's stores here will need to turn profits quickly to keep the financiers from turning on Federated stock.
"Federated way overpaid for those stores," said Robert F. Buchanan, a retail analyst at NatWest Securities. "It was too much for an operation that was one foot from bankruptcy court. Given their high cost of entry, I think this acquisition will haunt them for years."
But other analysts believe that the company had little choice if it ever wanted to be a major player in California. "If you're an investor in Federated, you have to look at the long term," said Jeffrey S. Stein, a retail analyst at McDonald & Company Investments in Cleveland. [Federated's stock closed at $30.25 Thursday, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.]
To justify its investment, Federated hopes to break into Southern California by offering jaded consumers a different way to shop. But that will not be easy. Bloomingdale's up-to-the-minute, acid-green spring dresses and distinctive designer lines -- the things that set it apart in New York -- are already well known in the chic West Side and Orange County Gold Coast shopping districts that Bloomingdale's is about to invade.
To make its 59th Street magic work 3,000 miles away, Bloomingdale's will also need to bring to the party everything from its eye-catching fixtures and designer lines to that intangible yet essential something known in the industry as the "shopping experience."
Part of the Bloomingdale's sensibility is to entertain, and there seems to be no better city in which to do that than Los Angeles, which has attracted New York exiles for decades but which thrives on a more casual way of life, where even grocery shopping is supposed to be fun. Though Bloomingdale's has had trouble translating the ambiance of its New York flagship store to suburban malls on the East Coast, its executives believe that its Manhattan fashion shows, presentations on Italy -- covering everything from olive oil to leather sling-back chairs -- and colorful window displays are just what Southern Californians are waiting for.
But like transplanted New Yorkers, exported stores can both benefit from and suffer for their East Coast mystique. "Bloomingdale's has much more of a New York mentality," said Kirk Palmer, a retail consultant in New York. "The institution does not have the same meaning to a California customer. I would say it will be a while before they can approach what they do in East Coast business."
Indeed, for all the common ground between New Yorkers and Angelenos, the Southern California consumer is also very different. Merchandise assorted for the Hollywood-style casual set, which considers jeans at dinner a power statement, will be critical.
"When Bloomingdale's went to Chicago, it was a disaster," said Kurt Barnard, the editor of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report. "Millions flocked to see it, and after they saw it, they went right back to Marshall Field's."
Mr. Questrom of Federated seems to have big Hollywood dreams. A tiny silver bracelet on his right wrist shimmered as he spooned dry oatmeal at a breakfast interview in New York and talked about the important impact of television and movies on the American shopper.
"Everyone is seeing the same movies, looking at the same television programs," he said. "We spend a lot of time thinking about what the shopper wants and what we want her to want. We're the nicer side of life."
Federated's timing is fortuitous. After a protracted recession, the Southern California economy is back on its feet and growing strongly again, much of it because of the bottoming out of the aerospace collapse and the boom in entertainment and technology.
"The California economy is clearly turning around," said Carl Steidtmann, an economist at Management Horizons in Columbus, Ohio. "It is starting to show real signs of improvement, including an increase in retail sales."
Department stores enjoy a particular advantage in Southern California. In a city where it is socially declasse to walk farther than a frisbee can be thrown, the mall department store is de rigueur. And unlike consumers in much of the rest of the country, many Angelenos have the desire to spend a lot of money on fashion.
That's why Southern Californians tend to take their cues from department stores, where an entire look is put together in one place.
"I think there is an expertise in a department store that people here need," the designer Isaac Mizrahi said in an interview a few minutes before he dressed three women in a new line on a stage at the Saks Fifth Avenue in Beverly Hills.
"They rely on department stores to move them in the right direction, to tell them, 'This is what you wear to dinner.' "
Conversely, designers need department stores. Foot traffic is not a big part of Los Angeles shopping: The designer Anna Sui opened a shop in Hollywood two years ago, only to shutter it because there was no parking nearby.
"As a designer, you need that department-store powerhouse behind you," Mr. Mizrahi said.
Equally as important as fashion is the nesting trend. Bloomingdale's and Macy's offer housewares and stylish furniture, popular among baby boomers, with a sensibility like that offered in their clothing aisles.
In the middle market, the Robinsons-May chain, owned by the May Department Stores Company, which declined to comment for this article, is clearly the target Macy's is aiming at. But with the Broadway chain out of the picture -- and no longer undercutting everybody with its fire-sale prices during its death throes -- several analysts argue that there is enough room for Macy's to throw its weight around without damaging its main rivals. "I think the market is going to actually get less competitive," said Linda Kristiansen , a retail analyst at Schroder Wertheim.
Meanwhile, Bloomingdale's is going after the same customers who now shop at upscale stores like Nordstrom; Neiman Marcus, which is owned by Harcourt General Inc., and Saks, which is owned by Investcorp. "These stores will undoubtedly run more promotions and more ads, and do special events that Bloomie's is known for," Mr. Barnard said. "Bloomie's will take some of the spotlight away and they will try to get it back by creating sideshows."
With all that competitive fire among the department stores, the big losers could well be the mall specialty stores. "Specialty stores are going out of business," Mr. Stein, the retail analyst in Cleveland, said. "The vacant stores in the malls are not likely to be replaced by apparel stores, and those sales have to go somewhere."

HEADLINE: Economic Yeast for a Stale Industry;
New York Tries to Stem Loss of City Bakeries

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
The time passed long ago when the ovens of hulking bread factories like Silvercup and Taystee Bread in Queens filled pockets of the city's landscape with the robust aroma of fresh-baked bread. The Silvercup factory, hard by the East River in Long Island City, is now a television studio. Taystee's huge logo in Flushing beckoned to a web of highways before Stroehmann Bakeries closed its plant in 1992 and converted it into a Home Depot.
Since the 1970's, felled by a weak economy, large bakers have been leaving the city for more affordable settings in Connecticut, New Jersey and parts south. 
 "The baking industry in New York City is an endangered species," said Andy Gioe, quality coordinator at Fink Baking Corporation, which has been operating in Long Island City for more than 100 years and has conducted a study of the industry with the Manhattan Borough President's office. "Ninety-five percent of all the bread consumed each year in New York City is baked out of state. If you had more bakeries, you'd have more jobs."
But now the city and state have turned a new and friendlier face to bakeries to stanch the flight, and this week, flanked by loaves of Wonder Bread and Beefsteak Rye, officials gathered to herald a comeback for an industry that once called New York home.
The Interstate Bakeries Corporation was threatening to close its 180,000-square-foot plant at Douglas Avenue and 168th Street in Jamaica, Queens. Instead, it held a ground-breaking ceremony on Tuesday to announce plans to expand its plant and increase the 400-member work force by 100 when a new line of Wonder Bread hamburger and hot dog buns and "heat and serve" rolls is offered in October.
The announcement came after months of arduous discussions with city officials to prevent the company from closing the 100-year-old Jamaica plant. Interstate, whose headquarters are in Kansas City, Mo., acquired the former Continental Baking Company on the site last year. It determined that it could not maintain all its Northeast plants because they were producing more than they could sell, said Charles A. Sullivan, chairman of the company.
After months of analysis, Interstate decided that instead of closing the Jamaica operation, it would close one in East Brunswick, N.J., eliminating 500 jobs when it shuts down tomorrow. "Part of that analysis was who is pro jobs," Mr. Sullivan said. "Who will work with you and who won't. East Brunswick did absolutely nothing, nothing, zero to keep us. New York City did and we generally don't get that kind of reception in other states."
In East Brunswick, Raymond W. Stone, the township's Business Administrator, said he was shocked that Interstate considered officials uncooperative. "We met with them on one or more occasions," Mr. Stone said. "We were almost pleading with them to tell us what needed to be done, but we were assured that it was an economic decision."
In the end, Interstate Bakeries was tempted by a $4.9 million benefits package over 25 years from the city and state, with utility rate cuts promised by Brooklyn Union Gas and Con Edison. Talks were begun by the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation, a nonprofit agency whose officials grew alarmed at hearing the plant could close.
Some 35 years ago, New York City had 370 bakeries employing more than 20,000 workers, according to the Empire State Development Corporation, a state development agency. Today, because of urban flight as well as automation, only 5,900 workers are employed by the city's roughly 200 licensed bakers, which range from mom-and-pop muffin-makers to conglomerates.
Concerned over the dwindling industry, Rudy Washington, Commissioner of the city's Department of Business Services, formed the Baking Industry Development Corporation two years ago. The corporation, which has about 50 members, offers tax counseling, advice on seeking utility subsidies, and ways to wend one's way through the process of acquiring city and state operating permits. The regulations include strict limits on smokestack emission of ethanol fumes, which are produced by leavened bread.
Commissioner Washington formed the agency after the Fink Bakery, a family-owned company, lost a contract to a New Jersey company to supply baked goods to the Health and Hospitals Corporation.
In a bitter dispute, Fink, which had won the contract for 20 consecutive years, was outbid by Harrison Baking of New Jersey. Fink officials argued that they had not received the special consideration usually given to local companies, and urged the city to reopen the process. The city refused.
"It had become so tense that I decided to intervene," Mr. Washington said. "The people at Fink thought that no one in government cared about them because they only provided 400 jobs."
The baking industry pays salaries of $200 million in New York City, which has 40 percent of all bakery employment in the state, according to the Empire State Development Corporation. New York State, once the center of the industry, now ranks second to California in production of bread and other bakery products, except cookies and crackers. Outside the city, which has 75 major bakeries, the industry is concentrated on Long Island (home of Entenmann's), around Buffalo (home to Lender's bagels) and around Albany (home to Freihofer's).
For years, Queens held the title of the baking borough because of its brand-name products like Silvercup and Taystee Bread. In a highly publicized shutdown, Taystee, once the largest bakery in the nation, closed even as the city offered financial assistance. Silvercup shut down in 1975. Bread shipped in from out of state slowly killed off business at the company and it could not compete.
Brooklyn now has the largest percentage of the city's licensed bakers, about 40 percent, according to the study by the Manhattan Borough President's office and Fink. Smaller bakeries struggling to survive have moved to Brooklyn neighborhoods like Brighton Beach, where they serve specialized products to growing numbers of Russian immigrants and the East Indian population in East Flatbush.
Interstate Bakeries produces more than 2 million pounds of bread a week, including Wonder Bread and Beefsteak Rye. Hostess Snack Cake products are also distributed from the plant in South Jamaica, a mostly minority neighborhood that is being revitalized after long being considered a symbol of urban neglect. The expansion will retain a $12 million payroll in the community, and add $2.5 million. The area is a State Economic Development Zone, intended to help distressed communities by giving tax breaks to businesses, in Interstate's case $2 million.
James Ragin, 56, of Harlem, has worked for Wonder Bread since 1965, starting out as a machine operator bagging bread and moving on to a receiving clerk, organizing bulky bags of buck flour, soybean oil and other ingredients.
"Technology has made a big change," Mr. Ragin said. "It was good and bad in a way as far as manpower. Two men used to do the job that now only one does."
Signs of a changing industry can be seen throughout Interstate's clamorous four-story plant in Jamaica: wall-to-wall barrel mixers, ovens as large as an average living room that can bake scores of loaves, and conveyor belts lined with loaves that are automatically thrust into bags and sealed.
A wave of nostalgia swept over William Shroba, 61, on Tuesday as he stood in the garage, which is to be converted as part of the $8 million expansion into the production center for hamburger and hot dog buns. Loaves of bread, cupcakes and pies surrounded the podium, where speakers praised Interstate Bakeries for staying in the city.
"In the 1950's and 1960's, there used to be five bakeries in a 10-mile area," said Mr. Shroba, a truck driver for the company. "I started out in this business when I was 18, and something about it just grows on you. I don't know if it's the aroma or the thrill of knowing that you watched it come off the racks and loaded into the truck for delivery, but it's something about it that I just love."
Mr. Sullivan, the chairman, made a pledge of sorts. "This industry has changed a lot in the 14 years that I've been involved," he said, "but we intend to survive and we're not going to become a Home Depot."

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Brokers are reporting a surge in demand for midpriced apartments in Manhattan.

BYLINE: By Tracie Rozhon 

 BODY:
WHILE the biggest, most desirable prewar apartments on Fifth and Park Avenues have been rising in price for more than a year, real estate brokers in Manhattan are now reporting a surge in sales of midpriced apartments elsewhere.
Bidding wars, multiple offers to buy at the full price and sealed bids have not been seen in this market since the late 1980's. While such interest is not the norm, agents say it is definitely on the upswing. 
 "It's Economics 101: supply and demand, and the inventory has shrunk," said JoAnne Kennedy, president of Hunt-Kennedy's East Side office. "Nobody is saying the market has reached the peaks of 1988, 1989 -- the press shouldn't say that, because sellers will start overpricing and the market will slow down again -- but the good brokers are looking at the last sale of a similar apartment and adding 10 to 15 percent" to the asking price.
Faced with a rise in multiple offers and bidding wars, the Real Estate Board of New York approved procedures for multiple-bid situations last month, according to Deborah Beck, vice president of the realtors group. The new procedures require that the exclusive agent tell the seller of all offers and recommend that the seller inform any other co-brokers that there are other offers. "The dollar amount of competing bids need not be disclosed to the co-brokers," the procedures state.
"This isn't just happening in the million-dollar apartments," Ms. Beck said. "It is particularly evident in the $350,000 to $800,000 level."
Ms. Kennedy said the mid-market "racheted up since Jan. 1." Postwar one- and two-bedroom apartments with ordinary layouts and nonspectacular views are the exception, and are still trading at relatively low figures, Ms. Kennedy said. Dark apartments, even if they are prewar, are another exception, other brokers say, adding that studios and one-bedrooms, while doing much better than they were a couple of years ago, are still not an easy sale.
Barbara Corcoran, head of the Corcoran Group, said brokers were concerned that in a rising market, they were making pricing mistakes.
One such mistake was the price on a medium-sized two-bedroom, two-bath apartment on East 79th Street between Second and Third Avenues.
A floor plan shows a 12-by-22-foot living room, a 12-by-16 master bedroom, a 9-by-11 second bedroom sandwiched between the living room, kitchen and dining alcove, and one main exposure. The building has a doorman, and the apartment had been restored. The maintenance was $1,037, with 75 percent financing.
The sales agent, Constance Fahey, thought it would sell for about $290,000; she priced it at $325,000.
The apartment went on sale on a Thursday. By Friday afternoon, there were two full-price offers. Another customer was ready to bid and later placed a full-priced offer.
Ms. Fahey had advertised an open house for Sunday, so she asked the seller if she wanted to accept one of the offers or wait for the open house. The seller chose to wait.
"A year ago, we might have gotten 10 or 12 people to show up at the open house," the agent said. "We got 60."
And five more full-price offers.
At that point, the seller invited the eight bidders to make their highest and final offer, and to enclose a letter about themselves and whether the transaction would be all-cash.
By Monday night, two bidders had dropped out. Of the six remaining, three were all-cash bids: $359,000, $360,000 and $360,132.

HEADLINE: The Republican Doldrums

BYLINE: By ROBERT B. SEMPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C.

 BODY:
Whatever its outcome, the South Carolina Republican primary leaves a visitor with the powerful image of a political party treading water. This condition is, presumably, reversible before the August convention in San Diego. But between the Iowa primary and South Carolina's, the four major candidates have failed to give their prepackaged platforms the sort of programmatic jolt that might make one or the other a credible alternative to Bill Clinton. Maybe that is why a different G.O.P. winner pops up in each primary.
There is, of course, Pat Buchanan, who surely offers a clear alternative to Mr. Clinton, not to mention his discomfited Republican competitors. But whether he is a credible alternative is another matter. Even in the very state where he helped Richard Nixon launch his Southern strategy, Mr. Buchanan seems stuck with the same 25 to 30 percent of the Republican vote that has been his all along. The base he has built with his forceful defense of bedrock family values and economic nationalism may have reached its limits. 
 The other three seem just as stuck, which accounts for the impression of four guys going backward, taking their party with them. Given a chance to strut new stuff in a one-hour debate yesterday, they produced a few testy exchanges but not one new idea. There was Steve Forbes with his flat tax, Lamar Alexander with a domestic agenda that seems to require the devolution of every known Federal program to the states, Mr. Buchanan with his customary prescriptions on trade and abortion, and Mr. Dole with a promise of better management and an avuncular plea to his colleagues to focus on the task at hand, beating Bill Clinton.
Mr. Dole is most in need of fresh energy and ideas. He is sometimes indecisive, as on the abortion issue yesterday, and he is neither an innovator nor an orator. Take the way he and Mr. Buchanan chose to dramatize the jobs issue. This campaign is about many things -- class, cultural values, leadership style -- but here, as in New Hampshire, it is also about economic fears and hopes. With that in mind, Mr. Buchanan delivered his economic message in a driving rainstorm in front of the Clearwater Finishing Company, a sad, shuttered brick hulk that once provided 1,000 jobs for local textile workers.
Never mind that Richard Gephardt had stood before the same textile plant, preaching protectionism in his failed effort to win the Democratic nomination in 1988. Never mind the little irony that Bob Dole himself unsuccessfully played the protectionist card here against George Bush the same year. This is Pat Buchanan's issue now and he is addressing it with verve, railing against corporate downsizers who have jilted the American worker for cheaper labor abroad.
Mr. Dole, painfully slow in New Hampshire to grasp the potential of Mr. Buchanan's argument, seemed determined to do better here. He made his pitch at a gleaming, humming, high-tech BMW plant that has created 2,000 new jobs in less than three years. But it was not much of a pitch. Surrounded by his handlers of the moment -- including Phil Gramm and Carroll Campbell, the former Governor who did much to bring foreign business like BMW into the state -- Mr. Dole managed a few comments about the dangers of building a tariff wall around America. These comments, inaudible to bystanders, were clearly designed for the evening news -- which paid absolutely no attention.
To anyone who covered campaigns in the 60's and 70's, it was clear that the sound-bite revolution had taken its toll. The situation begged for a fuller response. It is hard to imagine that a Richard Nixon or a Hubert Humphrey or a Bill Clinton would have passed up the opportunity to deliver a weighty, coherent speech containing sympathy for the dispossessed but pointing out the downside of Mr. Buchanan's ideas -- the loss of high-paying export jobs, for example, or the fact that Mr. Buchanan's working-class supporters would end up paying higher prices for shoes and VCR's.
A speech like that would certainly set Mr. Dole's agenda apart from the simplicities offered by Mr. Forbes and Mr. Alexander. It would also be a welcome antidote to Mr. Buchanan's entertaining but unexamined bombast. ROBERT B. SEMPLE Jr.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Blue-Chip Losing Streak Extended on Debt Worries
Blue-chip stocks extended their losing streak into a fourth session as traders reacted to testimony by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin that the United States could default on its debt by March 21 unless Congress raised the $4.9 trillion debt ceiling.
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 20.59 points to end at 5,485.62, bringing its four-day loss to 146 points. The Nasdaq Composite index was off 7.50, to 1,100.05. [Page D6.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed as traders reacted to mixed signals from economic news and Fed officials. [D13.]
 
Farm Program Overhaul Is Voted
The House voted to overhaul American farm programs. The $46 billion measure would end 1930's policies that pay farmers not to plant certain crops and replace many subsidies with fixed payments that would end after seven years. The Senate approved a similar, but slightly more costly bill earlier, and a compromise is expected. [A1.]
 
TV Industry Pledges Ratings
President Clinton summoned 30 entertainment industry leaders to the White House and was rewarded with an industry pledge for a voluntary TV ratings system by next January. Leaders of both political parties have harped on the need for keeping children from viewing shows with too much violence or sex. [A1.]
 
Bosch to Buy Allied Signal Unit
In a $1.5 billion cash deal, Allied Signal Inc. agreed to sell its money-losing light-vehicle hydraulic and anti-lock brake business to Robert Bosch G.m.b.H. of Germany. [D2.]
 
Nippon Telephone Breakup Asked
In Japan, noted for high telephone rates and over-regulation, a Government advisory committee called for the breakup of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, the world's largest telephone company, into one long-distance provider and two local phone companies. But the proposal faces formidable obstacles. [D3.]
 
A Dramatic Leap in Sending Data
Making a dramatic leap in speed, three separate research groups have transmitted information at a rate of 1 trillion bits a second by optical fiber -- that is equal to transmitting 300 years' worth of daily newspapers in a single second. The groups were Fujitsu Ltd., Nippon Telegraph and Telephone and a team from AT&T Research and Bell Laboratories Lucent Technologies. [D2.]
 
Mobil and B.P. in European Deal
Mobil and British Petroleum plan to combine their refining and marketing of fuels and lubricants in Europe, creating a huge new market force and saving $400 million to $500 million a year, in about three years. [D3.]
 
Teledyne Rejects Sweetened Bid
Teledyne rejected a sweetened $1.78 billion bid from WHX, contending it was "worth far more than $32 a share." WHX had increased its offer to that level from an original $30. [D4.]
 
Stroh Brewery to Buy G. Heileman Brewing
Stroh Brewery announced a complex deal to buy the G. Heileman Brewing Company for some $275 million to $300 million. The deal would put Stroh, the nation's fourth-largest brewery, close to third-ranked Adolph Coors. Its 10.1 percent market share is dwarfed by Anheuser-Busch's 44 percent and Miller Brewing's 22.6 percent. [D2.]
 
Trader Settles S.E.C. Changes
A former Bankers Trust trader agreed to pay $50,000 to settle S.E.C. charges that he misled Gibson Greetings on the value of derivatives it bought. The trader, Mitchell A. Vazquez of Greenwich, Conn., also consented to a four-year ban from the securities industry. [D4.]
 
Arrests in Computer Chip Raid
In a sweeping raid that involved more than 500 police and Federal officers, dozens of suspected thieves of computer components have been arrested in Silicon Valley. [A10.]
 
WMX to Buy Brooklyn Company
WMX Technologies' Waste Management unit, the nation's biggest recycling company, agreed to buy Resource N.E. of Brooklyn, one of New York City's largest recycling and trash-collection companies for $200 million. New York is known as a tough market. [B5.]

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEBATE;
As Rivals Take the Stage, Sniping Abounds

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 29

 BODY:
The four major Republican Presidential contenders competed today to deliver the starkest appeals to Southern conservatives in a fast-paced debate that was marked by testy exchanges.
And in a new format, the contenders were asked to critique their rivals' television commercials and defend their own, an exercise that led the candidates to dispense with any pretense of Southern civility as they interrupted and shouted over one another. 
 Senator Bob Dole, who leads in the most recent polls in this state, followed by Patrick J. Buchanan, sharply cut off Steve Forbes after he and the others ridiculed him for supporting tax increases. "Don't malign my integrity here," Mr. Dole snapped, noting that he fought for President Ronald Reagan's tax cuts.
"Well," Mr. Forbes shot back, "it's a typical Washington game."
With no clear national front-runner, the hourlong noontime debate before an audience of business executives, televised nationally this evening by CNN and C-Span, often degenerated into a game of revolving targets. It was perhaps the candidates' best opportunity to score points with South Carolina voters -- from defending the Confederate flag to excluding women from the all-male Citadel Academy -- before this state's crucial primary on Saturday.
Seeking to stand out as the most outspoken firebrand on the stage, Mr. Buchanan, a former commentator, asserted that flying the Confederate flag over the statehouse was a symbol of defiance and courage, not racism. "My friends, if there is room in America for the fighting song of the civil rights movement, 'We Shall Overcome,' then there's got to be room for 'Dixie' as well." He also said, "It didn't fly over slave quarters -- it flew over battlefields."
The others did not touch the question, saying it was a matter for individual states to decide. But they all took issue with President Clinton and argued that the all-male Citadel should not have been forced to admit a woman.
A striking undercurrent that surfaced repeatedly was how resentful Mr. Forbes's opponents have become over how the publishing magnate, who entered the race late, has altered the campaign with his millions of dollars in advertising.
In one of the most bitter clashes, Lamar Alexander criticized Mr. Forbes for asserting in a commercial that the former Tennessee Governor grew rich by using his political connections.
"Steve, you haven't learned a single thing in your whole campaign -- you know that's not true," Mr. Alexander said. He told Mr. Forbes, "You should be ashamed of yourself -- smearing me, smearing the other candidates."
Mr. Forbes replied that "that was a charitable ad -- that ad did not talk about some of those cozy business deals you did as Governor."
"You just wait a minute," Mr. Alexander said, shouting, and pointing at Mr. Forbes. "My ethics have never been questioned." He told Mr. Forbes that "you should go practice your dirty business on a race for the school board before you try for the Presidency of the United States of America."
Mr. Dole intervened, declaring, "Time out! Time out!"
The Senator, in perhaps his feistiest debate performance this year, was also barely able to contain his bitterness at Mr. Forbes. At the start of the event, Mr. Dole gave him the title, "King of negative advertising." The comment only encouraged Mr. Alexander, who piped in, "If Steve is the King, Senator Dole is the Prince."
Between his attacks on his rivals, Mr. Dole tried to play the role of leader, and sought to turn the attention to defeating President Clinton in November.
"I don't know what these other guys are running for," he said. "I want to be President of the United States. I don't want an ad agency, never wanted an ad agency. I don't run a magazine. But I do know how to make Congress work. I know how to reach out to people. I know what the country needs. That's strong leadership. We need to defeat Bill Clinton."
But Mr. Dole's rivals did not spare him, noting that he too was responsible for many negative commercials. Mr. Buchanan said the Senator's commercials attacking him revealed the "hollowness of your campaign."
Mr. Alexander sought to sugar-coat his attacks on the Senator by calling him "one of our finest public servants."
That prompted Mr. Dole to interject, "You keep saying that, but then you have a little hooker in the end there."
Mr. Alexander then said, "Why don't you tell us where you want to take the country instead of calling Pat Buchanan names and distorting my record? While I was keeping taxes low, you raised taxes."
"Amen to Alexander," Mr. Buchanan said.
Mr. Dole then turned to Mr. Forbes, "Steve, you've got to defend me -- someone has to defend me," he said, a plea that brought chuckles from the audience.
But Mr. Forbes only joined in the attack, saying with a smile, "Well, Senator, you've been on the public payroll for 35 years; if you can't defend yourself now, I can't help you."
The debate, sponsored by the South Carolina Business & Industry Political Education Commmittee, moved quicker than others this year, possibly because the format called for succinct answers and because only the top four finishers in the New Hamphire primary were allowed to take part. That led Alan Keyes, one of the long-shot contenders, to protest by staging a hunger strike.
Mr. Buchanan, who was a prominent target at a debate last week in Arizona, today drew less attention, perhaps because his campaign suffered a setback in the voting there. For that reason, and because Mr. Buchanan's barebones campaign has spent far less on advertising than the others, he had more opportunity to press his conservative themes. He promised not to pick a running mate who supported abortion rights, saying the 34 million abortions we've had in this country is the greatest atrocity and travesty and horror in our country's history."
And Mr. Buchanan emphasized his protectionist trade position, saying that 300,000 American jobs have been lost because of trade policies that were "a metastasizing cancer in the belly of America."
But Mr. Alexander accused Mr. Buchanan of being all show, and of supporting a trade policy that would damage this state's economy, which is now more dependent on foreign investment. "You're good at what the problem is," he said, "but you don't have one single solution."
Responding to the only question on foreign policy, the candidates all portrayed themselves as tougher on Cuba than Mr. Clinton, but stopped short of sending American forces there to retaliate for the downing of two private planes.
"If they try to shoot down civilian planes again, they should be put on notice that we are going to shoot them down," Mr. Forbes said. "We should put them on notice right now. They go up, they get shot down."

HEADLINE: A Fighter For Rights Is Treated For Cancer

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT 

 BODY:
His voice was raspy and tired, but Kwame Toure, better known to most Americans as Stokely Carmichael, answered the phone from his hospital bed with the phrase he had used for over 20 years: "Ready for the revolution."
Kwame Toure (pronounced KWAH-may TOO-ray), 54, the fiery civil rights leader who coined the slogan "black power," was released from Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center yesterday, where he had been undergoing tests since Feb. 8. 
 Later, at a news conference at a friend's Harlem home, Mr. Toure's doctors said he had prostate cancer.
"We expect him to do quite well," Dr. Barbara Justice, Mr. Toure's physician, said, adding that he had had radiation treatments during his hospital stay.
Mr. Toure was in New York to help recruit for the Washington-based All-African People's Revolutionary Party when he complained of pain in the right leg. He has been living in Guinea in West Africa since 1969, but word of his illness has brought hundreds of calls from old civil rights hands.
"It's a gathering of the clan," said Judy Richardson, who visited from Washington and had worked with Mr. Toure in Mississippi and Alabama when both were members of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee in the early 60's. Known as Snick, the organization sent hundreds of Northern whites and blacks to do the dangerous and difficult work of registering disenfranchised blacks in the South.
Now, friends from that time are coming together to help Mr. Toure raise money to pay for his medical expenses. William Hall, a friend of Mr. Toure's from the early days, said yesterday that they had started the Medical Fund for Kwame Toure and set up a post office box so friends could write (Bowling Green Station, P.O. Box 386, New York, N.Y. 10074-0301).
Among those who phoned Mr. Toure during his hospital stay were Florence Tate, once an S.N.C.C. liaison; Charles Cobb, a National Geographic writer who went South as a 17-year-old; Robert Moses, now head of the Algebra Project, a program to teach science and math in urban schools; Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington and his former Deputy Mayor, Ivanhoe Donaldson, and Courtland Cox, the director of the Civil Rights Office at the Department of Commerce. Ruth Chambers, an S.N.C.C. veteran who is now a teacher and potter, came from Washington.
A staff member for Representative John Lewis of Georgia, a moderate who headed S.N.C.C. before Mr. Toure did, said he planned to call to wish Mr. Toure well, but there was no indication whether an old schism had been healed. Mr. Lewis had favored integration in the civil-rights movement, while Mr. Toure had taken a stance of self-determination that some believed was anti-white.
Miriam Makeba, the South African singer who was once married to Mr. Toure, also telephoned to inquire about his health, as did his estranged second wife, Marlyatou, a Guinean physician by whom he has a son, Boca Biro, 14.
Yesterday's gathering seemed in many ways a 60's reception. Soft bossa nova played in the background and incense filled the air. Many guests dressed in African garb. Mr. Toure's lean frame was swathed in a flowing white boubou, his shoulders covered in a black jacket. He did not speak to the press at the gathering, and had declined an interview from his hospital bed.
Mr. Toure, whose college degree was in philosophy, has spent much of his life in what he once described as perpetual movement, traveling to African countries, Europe, the United States and the Caribbean, making speeches on Pan-Africanism and third-world solidarity.
Friends say Mr. Toure remains committed to the idea that blacks must work with blacks for their cultural, economic and political liberation. They say he continues to see Africa as a unifying force for blacks around the world despite divisions there.
"He was talking about Pan-Africanism back in the 60's," Mr. Cox said. "Now we call ourselves African-Americans, but he had started that discussion of trying to make sure that African-Americans had a sense of Africa and of their being a party of a total community even then."
Mr. Cox, who organized the seventh Pan African Conference a few years ago, said Mr. Toure had asked him to think about organizing another conference later this year.
"He hasn't mellowed," Mr. Cox said. "He has a tremendous intelligence, commitment and sense of adventure. At the Organization of African Unity, he's given the kind of respect that is due him as a person articulating the Pan-African view. No, he hasn't mellowed at all."
For those, like Ms. Richardson, who came of age during the 1960's civil rights movement, Mr. Toure epitomized the liberation struggle and its evolution from integrationist tactics to self-sufficiency.
Mr. Toure, who was born in Trinidad, was raised in the Bronx. His radicalization came slowly, starting after he graduated from the Bronx High School of Science in 1960. As a student at Howard University in Washington, he brought Malcolm X, with his black separatist message, to campus to debate Bayard Rustin, the socialist who espoused integration.
Fresh out of Howard in 1964, Mr. Toure joined S.N.C.C. and injected a note of militant impatience into the struggle to overturn legal segregation in the South.
He emerged as a dynamic leader. As an organizer in Lowndes County, Miss., Mr. Toure helped raise the number of registered black voters from 70 to 2,600, 300 more than the number of white voters. Disappointed in the Democratic and Republican responses to black demands, he organized the all-black Lowndes County Freedom Organization, taking as its symbol the black panther. The logo was later adopted by the Black Panther Party.
Increasingly, by the late 1960's, Mr. Toure embraced the philosophy that all black people worldwide should work together for their own liberation without white help.
Friends say Mr. Toure's adherence to his ideals is one reason for the outpouring of affection.
"That's why a lot of people are coming together around him," said Mr. Richardson, who now works for Blackside, a black film company that produced "Eyes on the Prize," the public television series about the civil rights movement.
While not speaking during the news conference yesterday, Mr. Toure did say one thing afterward to a reporter.
"I know," he said, "that my people love me."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kwame Toure, right, the former Stokely Carmichael, the 1960's civil rights leader who now lives in Guinea, West Africa, is receiving treatment for prostate cancer in New York City. A colleague, David Brothers, left, was with him at a friend's home yesterday. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times); Stokely Carmichael in 1973. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: U.S. Fixation on Castro May Do Us No Good

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In the crisis over Cuba's downing of two private planes from Florida, too many judgments on United States official responses have been shaped by their impact on the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro, and not on their impact on the United States. 
 Many Cuban-Americans want vengeance on Mr. Castro, his overthrow and influence in any successor regime. Given Cuba's history, that is understandable. But a Castro-based approach is not an appropriate basis for United States policy.
Most Americans know and care little about Cuba. They believe that Mr. Castro has been in office too long, but they are unwilling to pay a big price to see him gone. Their agenda is not the agenda of many Cuban-Americans.
The main United States national interest in Cuba is a negative: that the United States not be drawn into any violent military conflict in Cuba.
If civil war were to break out in Cuba, the pressures for United States intervention would be greater than in Grenada, Panama or Haiti. The costs in blood and money would be large, and occupation would be a morass. The political price abroad would be great.
The United States has had economic interests in Cuba. Some United States traders want to trade, and investors want to invest. Cultural exchange interests should not be ignored, either. The debate on Cuban policy needs to be recast. Let's think first of what's good for the United States, not what's bad for Mr. Castro.
 
COLE BLASIER
Washington, Feb. 29, 1996

HEADLINE: Don't Build Rural Prisons for Urban Criminals

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your Feb. 26 news article on rural New York communities that are clamoring for new prisons: 
 Although African-Americans and Hispanic Americans make up less than 25 percent of New York State's population, they represent 83 percent of the inmates confined in the state's prisons. Seventy percent of those incarcerated in the state's correctional institutions come from New York City.
A distressing blend of politics and economics has developed. Upstate, mainly Republican officials press for harsher sentencing laws and expensive prison construction not because such measures will prevent crime, but because they translate into a job development strategy for rural and predominantly white communities. Low-income minority inmates provide the flesh-and-blood grist for this legislative pork-barreling.
Serious problems result. Prisoners have difficulty maintaining family ties -- an important ingredient in an inmate's ability to cope with the prison experience or to make a crime-free adjustment upon release -- because their loved ones often cannot afford to visit a prison hundreds of miles from their homes. Clashes and racial tensions become inevitable between the white correction officers from small-town backgrounds and the black and brown prisoners from an urban environment.
Prison expansion has too many troublesome consequences for it to be practiced as an economic development program.
 
ROBERT GANGI
New York, Feb. 27, 1996
 
Executive Director, Correctional
Association of New York

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Against the Yen On Outlook for Japanese Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose slightly against the Japanese yen yesterday, bolstered by expectations that Japanese interest rates would remain low.
The dollar gained after the Bank of Japan released its quarterly survey of business sentiment known as the Tankan. The survey indicated that the economy was slowly improving. 
 "The Tankan totally wiped out the recent overblown market expectations for a policy change and restored rationale to market sentiment," said Yuji Shimanaka, a senior economist at the Sanwa Research Institute in Tokyo.
Those expectations had been fanned by Japanese financial officials who surprised the markets last month by saying an increase in interest rates should be considered.
The report "helped to give the dollar some upside," said Dave Glowacki, a senior trader at the NBD Bank in Detroit. "But I think the market was ready for something like that to jump on the dollar."
Indeed, the dollar's advance against the yen has been bolstered by repeated market interventions by the Bank of Japan in recent weeks. Traders estimated that the Japanese central bank had bought several billion dollars in the market to support the dollar against the yen.
The central bank released figures yesterday showing that its foreign reserves jumped $17 billion in February, although it declined to disclose how the money was acquired.
The United States stock and bond markets, which ended the day higher, were an additional source of strength for the dollar.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar settled at 105.41 yen, up from 105.25 on Thursday. The dollar rose to 1.4773 German marks from 1.4730 marks. The British pound fell to $1.5269 from $1.5315.
The dollar rose all week against the mark, partly because of expectations the German central bank would eventually lower interest rates, which would make German assets and currency less attractive to investors.
In addition, some European countries have been showing increased political stability, diminishing the mark's appeal as a safe-haven currency.
The Spanish peseta and the Italian lira in particular strengthened at the expense of the mark.

HEADLINE: Journal;
East Village Story

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
In an age when almost every show-biz event is predigested and presold by the media long before the public can decide for itself, the truly spontaneous pop-culture phenomenon is almost extinct. Almost but not quite. Two weeks ago, at a 150-seat theater in the East Village, a rock opera called "Rent," written and performed by unknowns, came out of nowhere to earn the most ecstatic raves of any American musical in the two decades since "A Chorus Line." And now the world is rushing to catch up: "Rent" will quickly move to Broadway to accommodate the insatiable demand for tickets, even as Hollywood titans fight to bring it to the screen.
"Rent" is all the critics say it is. There's a moment that often comes early in thrilling musicals -- call it the "Something's Coming" moment, in honor of "West Side Story" -- when a performer steps forward, grabs the spotlight and demands what he wants from life, no matter the obstacles. In "Rent," which loosely transposes the story of "La Boheme" to Manhattan's present-day downtown bohemia, that moment arrives when a young, H.I.V.-positive punk rocker sings of how he lives only for "one song/ glory/ one song/ before I go." Such is the naked yearning of this anthem that it would induce chills even if you didn't know that its lyrics proved eerily prescient: Jonathan Larson, the 35-year-old author of "Rent," is dead. 
 The story of Mr. Larson's death on the eve of the triumph for which he had hungered all his life is unspeakably sad. He died suddenly and inexplicably of an aortic aneurysm a month ago, hours before his show's first performance. As Michael Greif, who directed "Rent," recalled in an interview punctuated by tears this week, Mr. Larson had sacrificed his life to his work, waiting on tables for years, sustaining himself with the "sunny belief" that his talent would one day lead to his breakthrough. "He wanted it bad," said Mr. Greif. "It's cruel that he's not here to enjoy it."
Yet the significance of "Rent," the phenomenon, derives not from its author's tragic death, or from what the show may say about the American theater, or from its superficial resemblances to "Hair." For all the talk about how "Rent" speaks for the cyber-AIDS-Doc-Martens Generation X of Alphabet City as "Hair" allegedly did for 60's flower children, Mr. Larson's songs are bigger than their milieu. Stephen Sondheim, who became the young songwriter's mentor, this week recalled how he "welled up" when he first heard Mr. Larson's work on a tape -- in part because it was "generous music," lovingly merging the musical theater traditions of past generations, including Mr. Sondheim's own, with rock.
The night I saw "Rent" at the New York Theater Workshop, few theatergoers in the house demographically matched the castoffs on stage. But neither did the audience seem like the desperately hip on a slumming expedition. People were riveted, as I was, by the raw exuberance of characters who keep fighting and creating and reaching out no matter how strong their fears -- whether of death in a plague or of marginalization in the ruthless new post-industrial economy that frightens many Americans on the lower rungs, not just those living on the edges of St. Mark's Place.
If anything, some of the turn-of-the-millennium fears given powerful voice by the dispossessed bohemians of "Rent" resemble those of what we now call Pat Buchanan voters. Brilliant artists and politicians do, after all, share the ability to divine and then articulate the unspoken hopes and fears of the society around them, moving audiences powerfully as they do so.
But Mr. Larson's artistry doesn't leave the audience angry, as Mr. Buchanan's demagoguery does. The songwriter takes the very people whom politicians now turn into scapegoats for our woes -- the multicultural, the multisexual, the homeless, the sick -- and, without sentimentalizing them or turning them into ideological symbols or victims, lets them revel in their joy, their capacity for love and, most important, their tenacity, all in a ceaseless outpouring of melody.
At so divisive a time in our country's culture, "Rent" shows signs of revealing a large, untapped appetite for something better. It's too early to tell. What is certain is that Jonathan Larson's brief life belies the size of his spirit. In the staying power of his songs, he lingers, refusing to let anyone who hears his voice abandon hope.
