HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Surge on Purchasers' Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities surged yesterday after the nation's purchasing managers reported tough business conditions in February and investors saw yet another reason for the Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates next month.
The 30-year bond rose by 110/32 , to a price of 956/32 to yield 6.36 percent, down from 6.46 percent on Thursday and its lowest yield in more than a week. 
 The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its index of manufacturing activity rose to 45.2 in February from 44.2 in January, with any reading below 50 indicative of a soft manufacturing sector. Economists had forecast a rise to 48.3.
Analysts said the data showed that the economy was still contracting in February although at a lesser extent than in January. Strong new orders and deliveries ran counter to the overall index.
Another survey, the University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for February, was reported at 88.5, down from 89.3 in January, and that also helped the market.
Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors of Columbus, Ohio, said the market got an early lift from overseas buying that was inspired by an article in the latest issue of Business Week; it argues that the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, is leaning in the direction of another easing, possibly as early as the March 26 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee.
"In a strange way," Mr. Chan said, "I believe that one can easily argue that the recent rise in rates does present Mr. Greenspan with an opportunity to ease sooner rather than later because the higher rates recently observed may have dampened the growth outlook for the U.S. economy somewhat."
Mr. Chan said a bullish signal was emitted by the Commodity Research Bureau's index of prices, long considered to be an important minute-to-minute gauge of future inflationary trends. "Although our work questions the reliability of this index as a good long-term barometer of inflation," he said, "market participants love to watch it, and even I had a hard time ignoring the steep 4.05- point decline at midday."
By the close of the market the index had fallen steeply to 244.46, down 4.31 points.
Looking ahead, Mr. Chan said market participants would be concentrating on next week's employment report for February. The nonfarm payrolls, scheduled on Friday, come after January's 201,000 drop amid Government shutdowns and the East Coast blizzard. Virtually all economic indicators over the last two months have been clouded by some aberration.
"Since most market forecasts are incorporating a 150,000 to 200,000 recovery in jobs due to the effects of weather, along with a 75,000 to 150,000 jump due to regular factors, it seems as though almost no employment number will be able to faze the market," Mr. Chan said.
Thomas W. Synnott 3d, chief economist at the United States Trust Company of New York, pointed to the extensive price gains already realized in the market. "The point I would make is that we had a unique combination of circumstances in late fall that powered this extremely strong rally in bonds prices," he said.
He cited reports that the Bank of Japan apparently decided not to permit the yen to decline beyond a certain point against the dollar to prevent deflation in the Japanese economy. "As the market realized that the Bank of Japan in effect was stabilizing the dollar, it created a one-way street for interest rate arbitrage," Mr. Synnott said. And then with strong hopes for a balanced budget agreement in the United States, people were encouraged to buy longer maturities, he said. "The budget agreement we know has not happened, and arbitrage positions are unwinding and the market is back to feeding on itself," he added.

HEADLINE: Survey Finds Sluggish Industrial Activity

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The nation's manufacturing sector slowed for the seventh consecutive month in February, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday, although the rate of decline was down slightly from January.
The survey of purchasing managers at major manufacturing companies showed slight growth in the overall economy last month, the association said, reversing the contraction in January. 
 "Purchasing executives' comments in February on current business conditions continued the pattern of recent months by being more negative than positive," said Ralph G. Kauffman, head of the association's Business Survey Committee.
The association's index of manufacturing activity rose to 45.2 in February from 44.2 in January. Even with that rise, the index remained below 50, which is considered an indication of contraction in the overall economy. A reading above 50 is taken as an indication of expansion.
"This report suggests that the rebound from the blizzards in January is tepid," said Alan Levenson, money market economist at UBS Securities.
The manufacturing sector contracted for the seventh consecutive month in February, with production, new orders, order backlogs and employment all indicating decreased activity. But new orders and order backlogs decreased at slower rates than in January.
"I think basically the purchasing managers are telling us that the factory sector is experiencing what the Fed called very uneven business conditions," said David Munro, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics.
In February, 27 percent of the companies polled reported lower levels of new orders, compared with 32 percent in January. At the same time, fewer members reported diminished order backlogs in February, with the association's index of backlog orders rising to 43.5 percent, the highest level since September 1995, when it was also at 43.5 percent.
In a sign that inflationary pressures remain moderate, the association said only 9 percent of purchasing executives reported paying higher prices, the lowest percentage since an identical number was recorded in November 1992.
And the inventories index fell to 43.9 percent in February from 47.7 percent in January, indicating that inventory reduction is being pursued more vigorously.
The report is based on data compiled from monthly replies to questions asked of purchasing executives in more than 300 companies.

HEADLINE: A Bad Bill on Cuba

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has done many things right and one thing terribly wrong in response to Cuba's shootdown of two unarmed planes flown by Miami-based exiles.
Providing a Coast Guard escort to accompany an exile flotilla to the site of the downing today registers American determination to protect the security of international waters and airspace. Equally important, it minimizes the risk of either the exiles' or Havana's provoking a new incident. The Administration's decision earlier this week to suspend charter flights to Cuba and to impose travel restrictions on Cuban diplomats in this country made clear that Havana had attacked not just anti-Castro activists but international law itself. 
 However, the Administration is about to make a huge mistake by signing into law a bill, sponsored by Senator Jesse Helms and Representative Dan Burton, that aims to coerce other countries into joining the American embargo of Cuba. By dropping his opposition to the bill, Mr. Clinton junks his own balanced policy for encouraging democracy in Cuba and signs on to an approach that will inevitably slow the opening of Cuban society and pick a pointless quarrel with American allies.
The bill threatens foreign companies with lawsuits and their executives with exclusion from American soil if they use any property in Cuba ever confiscated from anyone who is now a United States citizen. Some of its provisions appear to violate international law and trade treaties, and the Administration had been saying since last summer that it would veto the measure unless these provisions were removed.
The United States is the only country that maintains an economic embargo against Cuba, an outdated policy that has failed in 35 years to topple the Castro Government. Trying to coerce other countries to join the embargo is offensive to American allies and unlikely to succeed.
Backers of the Helms-Burton bill believe the Cuban economy has been so enfeebled by the loss of subsidized Soviet trade that the Castro regime can be brought down with one final shove. But Cuba's economy, though hurting, has already revived from the depths of the early 1990's. Its recovery has been built on austerity, limited reforms and new trade relationships with the rest of the world. It is unrealistic to think that a reinforced American embargo would bring Mr. Castro down.
What Havana really worries about is the resurgence of opposition in Cuba itself. Opposition groups have been invigorated by Cuba's widened contacts with the outside world. They are also encouraged by a more supportive attitude on the part of Miami-based exile organizations. These used to view all Cubans who remained on the island, even opposition activists, with suspicion. Now groups like Brothers to the Rescue, the organization whose planes were shot down last week, see opposition groups on the island as a key to political change.
The Castro regime is alarmed by this potential link between domestic opponents and outside support groups, heralded by Brothers to the Rescue's previous airborne leafletting of Havana. Indeed, Havana's concern over this prospect may have been a factor in last week's missile attack against the exiles' planes. Washington should be doing everything it can to promote opposition within Cuba by encouraging more human interchange between the island and the outside world, not less.
The Helms-Burton Act is not an appropriate response to Cuba's murderous deed. It is a wholesale policy reversal that weakens America's ability to encourage democracy in Cuba. Mr. Clinton should return to his original sound position.

HEADLINE: No Caps on Damages for Railroads

 BODY:
The recent rash of train accidents makes this a most inappropriate time for Congress to set limits on the damages railroads must pay to victims of proven negligence. Yet the Senate will soon consider a bill that may include caps on punitive damages, and the House has already approved a measure capping both "pain and suffering" and punitive damage awards. Congress should eliminate these damages provisions before passing the broader Amtrak bill of which they are a part.
Private damage lawsuits give teeth to laws and regulations by compensating those injured by safety lapses and punishing organizations whose negligence caused an accident. How well the protective regulations work is the subject of Senate Commerce Committee hearings into several crashes and derailments, including collisions in New Jersey and Maryland that killed 14 passengers. Senators will also be investigating the effectiveness of agencies like the Federal Railroad Administration. 
 That makes it untimely to enact the House-passed caps on damages above compensation for medical expenses. The House would limit awards for pain and suffering, including such non-economic factors as disfigurement, to $250,000. It would also limit punitive damages, designed to punish gross negligence, to $250,000 or three times the proven economic damages, whichever is greater.
Those ceilings are similar to limits in "tort reform" legislation that has passed both chambers in different forms and has not been moved to a Senate-House conference. Lobbyists for corporations, insurers and other commercial concerns seek relief from litigation on the grounds that lawsuits stifle commerce and industrial progress.
But injured consumers also have rights that need protecting, including financial relief from the consequences of accidents involving faulty products. Those issues demand much more public debate than Congress has given them.
Amtrak needs Congressional reauthorization to help secure its future. The House measure contains a reasonable plan to phase out Federal subsidies by 2002, but Amtrak will then need alternative financing. The Senate is considering a permanent endowment for capital spending. Unfortunately, to move this bill, senators have agreed to sidetrack a meritorious proposal to give Amtrak an annual half-cent per gallon out of the Federal gas tax -- a proposal vigorously resisted by highway and mass commuter transit interests.
It is of paramount importance to find a way to sustain Amtrak. Congress should focus on that question and drop the mischievous idea of capping civil liability. Americans need a rail system that is not only financially secure but safe.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Unexpectedly Strong Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 1

 BODY:
Most auto makers reported strong February sales today, an early indication that the economy may be shrugging off a slow fourth quarter of 1995 and the effects of January's snowstorms.
The General Motors Corporation said sales of its cars and light trucks rose to 399,383 last month, up an unexpectedly large 5 percent from February 1995. The Chrysler Corporation sold 207,839 cars and trucks last month, 20 percent above the previous February. 
 Chrysler had been widely expected to post a bigger percentage jump in sales than G.M. because a much larger fraction of Chrysler's vehicles are mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, all of which are selling well at present. The Ford Motor Company is expected to announce its February sales results on Tuesday, and a company executive said its sales also appeared to have been strong.
Industry executives, car dealers and Wall Street analysts pointed to three reasons for the unexpectedly large rise in sales. Consumer confidence was up in February, suggesting that people became more willing to spend. East Coast car buyers who were snowed in during January returned to dealerships in force. And with the partial exception of General Motors, auto makers were offering hefty discounts, particularly on cars but also on some pickup trucks.
Robert A. Lutz, the president of Chrysler, said earlier this week that some of his company's strength "may have been due to the fact that we put some added incentives on." Chrysler sold more cars last month than it ever has in the month of February.
Auto sales figures are closely watched because they are the first statistics available on the economy's performance in the previous month. The numbers today were consistent with recent surveys showing that consumer confidence jumped sharply in February.
Wall Street was pleased with the results. "This is the kind of positive surprise that you like to see," said Joseph S. Phillippi, an auto analyst at Lehman Brothers. "We thought they would be up, but they're up more than we thought they'd be."
Mr. Phillippi said he was particularly impressed by General Motors' strong car sales because cars have been selling sluggishly, compared with trucks. General Motors' car sales rose 5 percent, as did the company's light-truck sales.
On the New York Stock Exchange today, Chrysler's shares rose $1.125, closing at $57.50, while General Motors' shares jumped $1.375, to $52.625. Ford's shares gained 25 cents, to $31.50.
Mr. Phillippi said Chrysler would soon run short on inventory and might ask its employees to work more overtime this month as a result of the strong sales. If other auto makers follow suit -- General Motors might not because it already has very large inventories -- then the overtime pay could lead to greater spending by the workers and a small boost for the overall economy.
The auto makers reporting today had total sales of 880,707 vehicles last month, up 7.4 percent from the corresponding period last year. The percentage calculations are based on a daily selling rate, because showrooms were open one more day last month than in February 1995.
The foreign-based auto makers posted mixed results today. The Honda Motor Company sold 63,357 vehicles in February, up 19.6 percent from the year before and a record for the month. Sales at the Nissan Motor Corporation rose 8.3 percent, to 57,662. But for the Toyota Motor Corporation, sales slipped eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 76,485. And the Mazda Motor Corporation reported a 20 percent decline, to 19,107.
Auto industry executives predicted at the beginning of the year that the industry would sell about 15 million cars, mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks this year, which would represent a fairly strong but not spectacular level of sales. Some doubt had crept into their predictions when sales slowed in January, but they were a little more optimistic today.
On Ford's outlook for the year, the vice president for finance, David N. McCammon, said he was encouraged by the preliminary figures he had seen as Ford prepares to report on Tuesday. "Just a couple days ago I was up to date; it was going O.K., consistent with 15 million or maybe slightly higher," he said.
Sales of pickup trucks and the Mercury Sable, both of which were recently redesigned, have been particularly good, he added.
Chrysler officials were cautiously upbeat today. "One month doesn't make a year, I guess, but it is definitely a good signal that there is underlying demand out there," said James P. Holden, Chrysler's executive vice president for sales and marketing. "We are comfortable that we don't have a problem going into spring."
Spring is the most important selling season for the auto industry.
Auto dealers had mixed views, with some expressing worries. "It hasn't been the best of Februaries," said John Chapman Morris Jr., a Chevrolet, Oldsmobile and Geo dealer in Fillmore, Calif. He said sales had been sluggish partly because G.M. had been slow in sending cars and trucks to his dealership.
But H. Gary Ackerman, a Ford and Porsche dealer in Las Vegas, Nev., said, "Our February was up about 15 percent over February a year ago."
Two models are selling particularly well, he said, the recently redesigned 1996 Ford Taurus and the 1997 F-150 pickup. "The new pickup truck is just a home run out of the ball park," Mr. Ackerman said. "They have a shelf life of about 24 hours."
John O. Stevenson, a North Carolina dealer with Acura, Honda, Mitsubishi, Jeep, Eagle, Hyundai, Suzuki and Nissan franchises, said sales of new cars slowed as used-car sales rose. "I think what we are seeing in buyers is obviously resistance to price," Mr. Stevenson said. The vehicles that sell well are those offering manufacturer's rebates, he said.
"If the manufacturers stay aggressive and don't think that this spring market is going to happen by itself, the spring market is going to be good," he added.

HEADLINE: Clinton Declares That Colombia Has Failed to Curb Drug Trade

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
President Clinton declared today that Colombia, the world's largest cocaine producer, had failed to cooperate in the fight against illegal drugs, a determination that not only stigmatizes it but also makes the country ineligible for most American economic aid.
In the same finding, Mr. Clinton certified that Mexico, an important free-trade partner, was cooperating with international efforts to stop such narcotics trafficking, even though it has become a major conduit for illegal drugs smuggled into the United States. 
 The determinations were made under a law requiring the President to report each year which countries linked to narcotics are fighting the problem and which are not. The final decisions were made this morning after weeks of heated debate within the Administration over what to do about Colombia and Mexico.
Mexico's certification as cooperative drew immediate criticism from some members of Congress who charged that Mexico did not deserve exoneration because it has not done enough to staunch the flood of drugs through its territory. In this election year, the Clinton Administration has been particularly sensitive to charges that it has favored Mexico because of Mexico's special status as a neighbor and equal member in the North American Free Trade Agreement, and because Washington had arranged for $12.5 billion in loans to shore up Mexico's economy after the peso collapsed in late 1994.
This decision also dismayed law-enforcement agencies, which felt the Clinton Administration had rejected recommendations that Mexico at least be reprimanded because of Mexico's weak performance in combatting narcotics.
Colombia has arrested several important drug cartel members in the last year, but officials here point to evidence of widespread corruption in the Colombian Government and its failure to reduce its role as the leading producer of processed cocaine and a leading grower of coca leaf, opium and marijuana.
The Colombian Government angrily rejected the American action as unjust. In Bogota the Foreign Minister, Rodrigo Pardo, said, "We consider unacceptable this interference in our internal affairs."
The certifications coincided with the State Department's release today of its International Narcotics Control Strategy Report, a 598-page report on the state of narcotics around the world in 1995, with details about what more than 140 countries have done or failed to do about drugs. The United States, the world's foremost consumer of illegal drugs, is omitted.
Belize and Cambodia were added this year to a list of 31 countries identified as major drug-producing or drug-transit countries. Twenty-two of these, including Mexico, were certified today as working sufficiently to solve the problem.
But Colombia joined Afghanistan, Burma, Iran, Nigeria and Syria on the list of countries judged to have failed to cooperate in the fight against narcotics.
Lebanon, Paraguay and Pakistan also failed certification but were only warned, under a provision that lets the President waive the penalties if he decides that doing so is in the "vital national interests" of the United States. Colombia received such a warning last year.
"Some countries may find the results hard to swallow," said Timothy E. Wirth, the Under Secretary of State for Global Affairs, "but we believe we cannot solve problems without first being honest about them and identifying them."
By punishing Colombia, the Administration registered its displeasure with President Ernesto Samper, who is accused of knowingly taking millions in campaign contributions from the Cali cocaine cartel.
President Clinton's spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, denied that the decertification was intended to force the Colombian President out of office. Mr. McCurry noted that "President Samper is under pressure already" from investigations at home.
But Mr. McCurry said President Clinton was aware that "this decision will likely have some impact on the public debate in Colombia."
The certification statement acknowledged that Colombia did make some progress last year, notably the capture or surrender of six of the seven leaders of the Cali drug syndicate, one of whom later escaped. It also praised the national police of Colombia for its ambitious cocaine crop eradication program. But it said that the Government had failed to make progress in other areas and had not increased the penalties for drug trafficking or taken steps to protect the confidentiality of information provided by the United States.
Colombia will not suffer immediate hardship even though its flourishing economy benefits in part from drug profits. Robert S. Gelbard, the Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics, said that the United States assistance to Bogota consists almost entirely of counter-narcotics programs, which will continue if the Colombians want them.
But American business executives investing in Colombia will no longer qualify for credits from the Import-Export Bank or the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. The United States will also vote against any loans requested by Colombia from a half-dozen development banks, including the International Monetary Fund and the Inter-American Development Bank, though this may not prevent such loans.
Mr. McCurry said the decertification of Colombia could affect up to $750 million to $1 billion in Export-Import Bank commitments and $50 million in loans and $540 million in insurance from the Overseas Private Investment Corporation.
President Clinton also retains an option to apply trade sanctions, which could close United States markets to imports of coffee, flowers and other legitimate Colombian goods, Mr. Gelbard said.
As the first President to decertify Colombia, President Clinton scored points with Congress. The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, had prepared legislation to override any waiver given Colombia this year.
His spokesman Marc Thiessen said Senator Helms was extremely pleased that President Clinton had sent "a strong message to Mr. Samper that his collusion with drug traffickers is unacceptable." If President Samper resigned, Senator Helms said, the government that replaced him in Colombia should be given a clean slate.
By contrast, Clinton Administration officials described President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico as honest and sincere in trying to curb his country's involvement in narcotics, despite evidence of a widening role of Mexico in the production and sale of drugs and corruption in Mexican law enforcement.
Mr. Gelbard said an important difference between Colombia and Mexico was that President Zedillo's Government was cooperating while President Samper's had tried to undermine efforts to stop narcotics. "The test of the law is whether there is cooperation on the part of the government," Mr. Gelbard said.
But Mexico's certification was criticized by Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, who said Mexico should have been given the same warning that Colombia received last year.
Mr. Thiessen said Senator Helms, too, felt "the Administration made a mistake" with Mexico and that he and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, would introduce a resolution in the Senate demanding that Mexico be decertified.
Administration officials denied today that the certification process was influenced by political considerations. "We look at what happens as a country either cooperates or fails to cooperate in the fight on drugs," Mr. McCurry said.
The State Department's report on international narcotics sometimes sounded implicitly more tolerant of Colombia and critical of Mexico than the President's certification implied. It said that "the two countries that have struggled the longest against the drug trade -- Mexico and Colombia -- are also those that have had to face the drug corruption that has crept into the uppermost reaches of Government."
The report described Mexico as "the principal transit route for cocaine entering the United States as well as a major source country for heroin, methamphetamine and marijuana." It also said that "drug traffickers used their vast wealth to corrupt police and judicial officials as well as project their influence into the political sector, as recent Mexican investigations have revealed."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Keeping Corporate Score;
In South Africa It's Even Hard to Find the Players

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG

 BODY:
The South Afri can economy is Teddy Roosevelt's nightmare what America might look like if the trusts had never been busted, John D. Rockefeller had won the Standard Oil case and the unions still had to deal with Andrew Carnegie, the autocratic steel magnate.
Nearly 80 percent of private industry is controlled by five super-conglomerates. Cartels in some industries, like diamonds, operate openly. In staples like beer and sugar, one or two producers dominate the market and set prices. Goods that Americans take for granted, from steaks to new cars to televisions, are so expensive that the average South African cannot afford them. 
 The man who rails most loudly against all this is a former sugar-company executive who works out of his home in the Magaliesberg Mountains with an ostrich farm next door and leopards and baboons prowling past his yard. Ninety minutes away, in downtown Johannesburg, the fat book that Robin McGregor puts out each year, "Who Owns Whom," is the standard reference work on South African business.
It is dull reading, and the way he compiles it is prosaic. He buys one share in every company in southern Africa, collecting all the annual reports and poring over them. He also clips virtually every article in the nation's financial press.
With this information, he is able to pierce the ranks of dummy companies -- 450 at last count -- that rich South Africans erect to conceal what they own.
By his calculations, which are widely accepted, more than 75 percent of the capitalization represented on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange is controlled by five corporations: the Anglo American Corporation; the South African National Life Assurance Company, or Sanlam; Rembrandt Group; the South African Mutual Life Assurance Society, or S.A. Mutual, and Liberty Group.
They often exercise that control through bewildering webs of cross-ownership that Mr. McGregor illustrates with charts he calls "organograms." In one common version, the owners of an enterprise will sell off 49 percent, form a holding company to take possession of the remaining 51 percent, sell 49 percent of the second holding company, then repeat the process several times.
If Mr. McGregor's prose can be heavy going, there is nothing dull about what he does with his information. He is a professional gadfly, attacking the evils that he sees stemming from concentrated ownership: price-fixing, excessive secrecy, stultifying bureaucracy, lackluster research, protectionist tariffs.
He is not popular in corporate board rooms. But President Nelson Mandela's Cabinet largely agrees with him. "There's the irony of the new South Africa," said Steve Rubenstein, the research director for Fergusson Brothers, Hall, Stewart & Company, a big South African brokerage firm. "McGregor was a crusader who made a career out of bashing big business, a small operator promoting his own product. Now he's a hero in the eyes of the African National Congress," the ruling party.
Ismail Lagardien, a spokesman for South Africa's Trade and Industry Ministry, calls Mr. McGregor "a constructive whistle-blower" and says "people ought to listen to him more often." The ministry has appointed Mr. McGregor to a panel to draft changes in corporate laws.
One of the changes Mr. McGregor favors -- full disclosure of stock ownership -- would essentially put him out of business. But he says it would be worth it to end the current obfuscation. As an example, he cites Sasol Ltd., a $5.7 billion corporation that turns the country's abundant coal into gasoline and petrochemicals. It was created by the former white-ruled regime in 1979 to outflank any attempt at an international oil embargo and was later sold to private interests.
Recently, it hired Mr. McGregor to find out who actually owns it. "I wrote 250 letters, one to every anonymous 'nominee company' that owned at least 10,000 shares," Mr. McGregor said. "Ten told me who the underlying owners were. About 20 said they wouldn't. The rest didn't bother to reply. It's bloody ridiculous -- the chief executive can't find out who owns his company. If an asset-stripper came in from Europe or America, he could slowly buy the company through nominees, and no one would know he's there."
Mr. McGregor denies harboring any bias against big business, and acknowledges its role in making South Africa a regional economic powerhouse. Instead, he calls himself "anti-concentration." That gives him plenty of leeway to attack South Africa's biggest company, the Anglo American Corporation, which oversees the world diamond cartel, mines much of the world's gold and generates 25 percent of the nation's gross domestic product.
Anglo American, controlled by the Oppenheimer family of South Africa, owns the De Beers and Minorco mining companies; First National, the country's biggest bank; Southern Life, one of the biggest insurers; numerous office parks, and at least one significant player in every sector of the economy. "Anglo is absolutely as much about control as it is about making a profit," Mr. McGregor said.
Like Standard Oil of old, Anglo's core -- mining holdings -- is vertically integrated. "They own their suppliers: steel, tools, explosives, even paint," he says. "Their subsidiaries have so little competition that they aren't efficient."
He argues that it would be far more profitable if it were broken up into smaller companies. "I've said this many times," he adds. "And when I do, Julian Ogilvie Thompson, Anglo's chairman, will say, 'Who is this bloody fool telling us what to do?' And of course, it is bloody arrogant of me. But the effect of all this concentration is that South Africa has built bureaucrats in the private sector. You look at the streets -- people go home at half-past 4 o'clock. There's no competitiveness. There aren't any entrepreneurs."
Michael Spicer, an executive director of Anglo American and a frequent spokesman for big business, says he is "absolutely, fundamentally, 100 percent in dispute" with Mr. McGregor's characterizations. He calls Anglo a "highly decentralized" company where tens of thousands of employees at a subsidiary might report to a mere dozen or so executives at the head office. He denies that Anglo's suppliers are uncompetitive and says he doubts that shareholders would be richer if the company was broken up as AT&T was in the United States in 1984.
Told that some American executives who have worked at Anglo subsidiaries say they find the central control stifling, he said, "Well, I beg to differ." He then trots out a favorite argument of defenders of the corporate status quo here: a country with an economy the size of Belgium's needs mega-corporations like his to compete in international markets.
Mr. McGregor counters by noting that two other conglomerates, Sanlam and S.A. Mutual, have shrunk their head offices and let presidents of subsidiaries operate independently. Their profitability rose, he said.
The son of a British Petroleum plant manager and a paralegal, the 66-year-old Mr. McGregor puts out his annual book himself, as his wife, Anne, and sons Andrew and Simon run McGregor Information Services, a 10-year-old on-line news service that combines the book's data base with information about the companies in it.
A warm man who likes to fix lunch for visitors, he laughs at the suggestion that his book, of which he sells 2,500 copies a year for $120 each, and his on-line service, which generates five times as much revenue, have made him rich, though he is probably on the way there.
If nothing else, he could be kept poor by feeding his three Great Danes. "They're the only ones big enough to hold their own against the leopards," Mrs. McGregor said.
For someone who espouses very American ideas like aggressive antitrust laws and wide-open disclosure rules for publicly traded companies, Mr. McGregor knows very little American business law or economic history.
He has never visited the United States. When first interviewed, he had never heard of 10k's, the annual reports that publicly traded companies in America must publish to relay key information to shareholders. Likewise, he was surprised to hear that executives of publicly traded American companies have to disclose their salaries, and he did not know that many of the biggest American oil companies, from Exxon to Chevron, were spun off from John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil monopoly in 1911.
Perhaps that is not surprising. Most white businessmen in South Africa were educated locally or in Britain. But there is a new wind blowing in Mr. Mandela's Government, with its large quotient of former political exiles. While some of those African National Congress leaders were studying military tactics with the Soviet Army, others were studying economics at Harvard.
Mr. McGregor's interest in piercing corporate veils began when he was managing a small sugar mill in South Africa's Natal province. The owners in London wanted to acquire some of the mill's 22 rivals. "So we went to local mills and said, 'Right, fellows, we want to buy you,' " he said. "They wouldn't tell us who owned them -- and I found it impossible to find out who did. I realized there was an interest in this kind of thing."
Later, a job running a fruit cooperative gave him a taste of monopolistic price-fixing. "I was negotiating for apple cartons with three suppliers," he said. "The quotes I got were the same down to the seventh decimal place. They didn't even try to disguise it."
While Messrs. McGregor and Spicer are of pointedly different minds about the nature of big business in South Africa, they do agree on one thing: the nation's economy will have to undergo a rapid restructuring to adapt to a new business environment that includes increased foreign investment and competition, the privatization of many state-run businesses and the gradual elimination of foreign-exchange controls.
"I think things will go the American way," Mr. McGregor said. "There will be antitrust laws, and the conglomerates will unbundle. There will be major changes."

Chart: "The Inner Circle" shows a look a few of the few vast diverse assets five large South African holding companies have. (Source: Who Owns Whom)

HEADLINE: Bogota Leader Assails U.S. And May End Cooperation

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, March 1

 BODY:
In a televised address tonight, President Ernesto Samper called the United States decision to decertify Colombia as an ally in the fight against drug trafficking "deplorable," and vowed that Colombia would "re-examine and re-evaluate the terms of bilateral cooperation in the anti-drug fight."
Mr. Samper, who is battling for political survival against allegations that he solicited more than $6 million from Cali drug figures to finance his 1994 election campaign and engaged in a cover-up afterward, said that not he, but "the Government, the institutions and the Colombian people" had been "condemned" by the decision. 
 "As President, I will not accept any foreign intervention in the solution of our crisis," he said in an emotional speech. "We Colombians will find a definitive solution to our crisis."
He said Colombia would seek other allies in the fight against drugs. "We are going to seek international support where there exists cooperation with our fight," he said.
"I already have the only certification I need, which is the one issued to me by the Colombian people when they elected me."
His remarks raised the possibility of an open diplomatic conflict between Colombia and the United States, which has been steadily pressing this Andean nation to crack down on drug smugglers, using Mr. Samper's alleged ties to drug traffickers as tacit leverage in gaining cooperation.
The State Department, in a statement explaining the decision, said the strides Colombia had made in dismantling the leadership of the Cali cartel last year were largely the work of two men, Gen. Jose Serrano, the chief of police, and Alfonso Valdivieso, the chief prosecutor, whose successes were "particularly noteworthy given the lack of strong support and commitment from the Government."
But their work may be made considerably more difficult if the Government openly opposes any cooperation with the United States. Colombia supplies 80 percent of the cocaine that ends up on American streets.
"I don't think it'll help the situation," Robert Gelbard, the Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs, said in a telephone interview after Mr. Samper's address. "It would concern us if they tried to take steps to retaliate."
Mr. Gelbard also denied that the Administration had interfered in Colombia's domestic affairs with its decision.
"What we're trying to do is simply focus on the fact that there's been significantly less than full cooperation," he said, adding that Mr. Samper "is trying to use this as a way to rally nationalistic support."
Washington's decision appeared to have taken business and political leaders here by surprise, further demoralizing a country that has been mired in the presidential scandal.
The economic consequences of the decision remained unclear, for the State Department is still studying the fate of trade preferences and of more than $750 million in loan guarantees to Colombia that had been authorized but not yet drawn by the Export-Import Bank. Mr. Gelbard also raised the possibility that the United States would follow up with trade sanctions should Mr. Samper make good on his threat to end cooperation.
Last year, the Administration recognized the weaknesses in Colombia's efforts to eradicate drug trafficking, but granted the country a "national interest" waiver. Today's step gave Colombia the dubious distinction of becoming the first democracy to be decertified. Among Colombians, the injury was far greater than the dollars that may be lost.
"I feel ashamed to be decertified," said Jorge Ramirez Ocampo, executive president of the National Association of Exporters. "It is a very clear blow to us."
Mr. Ramirez, who was in Washington a few weeks ago to lobby for recertification, said decertification "sets back all of us who are trying to build up the commercial, legal economy."
He and others took issue with the decertification process, which they said amounted to interference in Colombia's internal affairs.
In Mexico, though the decision to certify that country was welcomed, the process itself also came under criticism.
In a statement, the Mexican Government said, "Cooperation with the United States ranks very high in our priorities." But it called the certification process itself an irritant to cordial relations.
As if to underscore Mexico's anti-drug dedication, the Government sent army and police forces into several neighborhoods in Tijuana, on the border south of San Diego, and one in Mexcio City, to search houses said to have been used by Benjamin and Ramon Arellano Felix, the heads of one of Mexico's largest drug mafias.
The operations yielded no arrests, though in one house in Tijuana, soldiers found sophisticated radio equipment. In a middle-class residence in Mexico City, the soldiers found several weapons, the Attorney General's office said in a statement.
The magnitude of the operation in Tijuana, which began before dawn when hundreds of helmeted soldiers swept through five of the city's wealthiest neighborhoods, was unusual, and it led to suspicions that the raids might have been timed to attract publicity. Juan Rebolledo, Mexico's Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, denied that, however.
Here in Bogota, the American decision plunged the country into a new chapter of uncertainty.
But Senator Hugo Serrano, a supporter in Mr. Samper's Liberal Party, also predicted that the President would grow stronger, "because the lower classes will rise in favor of him."
Javier Fernandez, president of the National Association of Financial Institutions, disagreed. "The only rational explanation is that the U.S. Government wants to pressure Samper to fall," he said. "It wouldn't bother me if he did."

HEADLINE: RUSSIAN AIDE CALLS FOR HIGHER TARIFF, RENEGING ON VOW

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 1

 BODY:
Contradicting assurances made to the International Monetary Fund only a week ago, Russia's Finance Minister has proposed a broad increase in import tariffs.
The plan, which would raise tariffs by an average of 20 percent, appears intended to boost the political fortunes of President Boris N. Yeltsin by raising revenue for new social spending. It could also placate angry farmers and industrialists hurt by foreign competition. 
 But in trying to soothe a disgruntled electorate, Russian officials have alarmed the I.M.F., which has promised to lend Russia $10.2 billion on the condition that it continues market reforms and reduces trade barriers.
A senior I.M.F. official warned tonight that if it carried out the plan, Russia could jeopardize the loan, which Michel Camdessus, the fund's managing director, described as necessary to insure that economic reforms were "irreversible."
Perplexed Western officials said today that the Finance Ministry plan might be a sign of disarray in the Government, with some Russian officials pushing ways to increase spending while others make commitments to Western bankers.
Alternatively, the plan could reflect Moscow's calculation that the I.M.F. is so determined to help Mr. Yeltsin's re-election that it will loosen its requirements. Less than four months before Russia's presidential elections, polls show the Communist candidate, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, with a clear lead.
In any case, the plan for broad tariff increases runs counter to promises made to the fund.
In a confidential statement on economic policy, which Russia provided to the fund, the Government promised to reduce the average tariff by 1998. It also pledged that the average tariff would not be increased before then, according to Western officials.
With Communists promising to protect domestic producers, Mr. Yeltsin is under pressure to adopt more protectionist policies before the election.
Farmers, for instance, have complained that much of the food sold in Russia is imported. And last week, the Government responded to the concerns of Russian poultry producers, whose sales have declined by 40 percent, by threatening to ban American poultry imports as of March 19, ostensibly because of concerns over the levels of chemicals and bacteria in American chickens.
That move, which would block more than $500 million in annual sales by American companies, has provoked sharp protests from Washington. Concern in Western capitals has risen further in recent days as senior Russian officials have talked of even broader protectionism.
Vladimir G. Panskov, Russia's Finance Minister, sparked the worries by saying on Thursday that his ministry "has proposed to the Government that it raise import tariffs by an average of 20 percent."
Also on Thursday, Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin added his voice to the growing protectionist choir, though without endorsing specific tariff rates. "A range of protectionist measures will be introduced in the field of foreign trade," Mr. Chernomyrdin said.
The United States and the European Community have warned that tariff increases could jeopardize Russia's bid for membership in the World Trade Organization, which is dedicated to free trade.
"Raising tariffs would be a step back from liberalization and would likely prove an ineffective means of strengthening Russian industry, as protectionist measures have proved elsewhere in the world," said Charles Blitzer of the World Bank's Moscow office.
It also worries the I.M.F.
"The I.M.F. is still trying to determine all the facts in the matter," a senior fund official said of the Finance Ministry plan. Before any loan money can be disbursed, it must be formally approved by the fund's board, which is expected to meet by mid-April.
Clinton Administration officials said the United States would have a strong response if Russia followed through with broad-based tariff increases, although they declined to be specific. It is unclear whether the Administration would use its influence with the I.M.F. -- as the largest contributor to the fund it has the single biggest vote -- to push for the loan payments to be suspended if the new tariffs were imposed.
"Most important, protectionism is bad for Russia," Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said. "It is also bad for American business and for the American-Russian economic relationship. We will resist it strongly and will respond appropriately."
Under Moscow's commitments to the fund, Russia may increase some tariffs as long as it reduces others so that the average tariff does not increase. The I.M.F. official warned that a 20 percent increase in the average tariff, as proposed by Mr. Panskov, "could be a serious concern in terms of approval" of the loan.
Some specialists say the Finance Ministry plan may reflect not only growing protectionist sentiment, but also a desperate search for revenue.
Raising revenue to pay for expanded social spending is a serious problem for the Government. That problem has been complicated by Russia's promise to the I.M.F. to phase out tariffs on the export of oil and gas.
But the answer, Western economists say, is to tighten tax loopholes, establish effective excise taxes and strictly enforce the collection of existing tariffs, not create higher ones.

HEADLINE: A Decade of Obsession

BYLINE: By Sam Dillon; Sam Dillon, the author of "Comandos: The CIA and Nicaragua's Contra Rebels," is a correspondent in Latin America for The New York Times.

 BODY:

A TWILIGHT STRUGGLE
American Power and Nicaragua, 1977-1990.
By Robert Kagan.
Illustrated. 903 pp. New York: The Free Press. $37.50.
 Eight months after Ronald Reagan's 1981 inauguration, Thomas Enders, a tall and imperious American envoy, traveled to Managua to deliver a blunt message to Nicaragua's revolutionary head of state, Daniel Ortega, and to a group of his Sandinista comrades: Come to accommodation with the United States or we will smash you. Militarily, if need be. 
 "All right, come on in!" shot back Bayardo Arce, one member of the Sandinistas' directorate, succinctly expressing what became his revolutionary Government's official response to the Reagan Administration's demands. "We'll meet you man to man. You will kill us, but you will pay for it."
 With that encounter, the lines were drawn between Washington and Managua in the harsh struggle that came to dominate American foreign policy in the 1980's. President Reagan and his advisers demonized the Sandinistas, telling the nation that they were converting Nicaragua into a Soviet beachhead on the American mainland and committing virtual genocide against their own citizenry. As a result, the United States spent the rest of the decade obsessed with a country of fewer than four million people and a gross national product considerably smaller than the annual revenues of the Coca-Cola Company.
 Yet in 1990, after losing a free election organized by his Government, President Ortega congratulated his challenger, Violeta Chamorro, and turned over Nicaragua's Government to her. And early last year Mr. Ortega's brother, Humberto, stepped down as army chief. If the Ortegas and their comrades were such unredeemable Stalinists, then how was it that they gave up power so peaceably? Now that the cold war is over and the age of anti-Communist hyperbole has passed, it is possible to ask: How dangerous were the Sandinistas and their revolution anyway?
 These are some of the riddles with which Robert Kagan wrestles in "A Twilight Struggle." During the Reagan Administration Mr. Kagan was a deputy to Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams, and as such helped carry out Nicaragua policy. He has spent the seven years since he left government meticulously researching the struggle between Washington and Managua, which actually began, he argues, during the Carter Administration, a couple of years before the Sandinistas drove the dictator Anastasio Somoza from power, and ended with Ms. Chamorro's 1990 election victory.
 Mr. Kagan has not written a personal memoir, and has tried to avoid being an apologist for the Administration he served. Instead, he has sought the role of dispassionate historian, even if his portrayal of the Sandinistas and their relations with the Soviet Union and Cuba supports the arguments put forward by the Reagan Administration. He argues that the Sandinistas, far from pursuing the non-aligned policies many of their defenders attributed to them, made a clear choice from the beginning of their revolution to put themselves in the Soviet camp, eagerly following in Cuba's path. "We wanted to copy in a mechanical way the model that we knew -- which was Cuba," Mr. Kagan quotes Humberto Ortega as saying in 1991, during one of several interviews he conducted with the former Sandinista army chief.
In another 1991 interview with Humberto Ortega, Mr. Kagan probed the reasoning that led the Ortega brothers and other Sandinistas to throw in their lot with the Soviets just a few years before the collapse of Communism. "Remember, this was the strong Soviet Union," Mr. Ortega answered. "We thought it would last."
 According to Mr. Kagan, it was only after years of attacks on Nicaraguan farms and towns by the contras, the rebel army organized by the United States, that the Sandinistas sought accommodation with Washington and with their neighbors. Even so, he insists, the Sandinistas would never have organized free elections in 1990 had they realized that the balloting might bring their own defeat. Instead, they miscalculated, partly because they were under tremendous pressures to democratize, and not only from Mr. Reagan and the contras, but also from American liberals and the Central American presidents led by Costa Rica's Oscar Arias. Ms. Chamorro's election, he concludes, "was widely recognized as a success for American policy, but who deserves credit for it has been the subject of much debate."
 Mr. Kagan seeks to apportion "credit" for the Sandinistas' downfall evenhandedly. The Reagan Administration's support for the contras was essential, he says, but he acknowledges that the role played by American moderates like Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma also contributed by nudging the Sandinistas toward democratic compromises they would never have accepted as impositions from the White House. He offers backhanded credit to the Bush Administration as well, arguing that "the evident sincerity of Bush's desire to be rid of the Nicaraguan mess convinced the Sandinistas that the risk of the elections was worth taking."
 This attempt to distribute praise is part of what appears to be a broader effort to produce, in effect, a reference work, one that tries to tell the whole story of American-Nicaraguan relations in this century, leaving out nothing of importance. The result is what Mr. Kagan himself calls a "fat" book, and although he thanks an editor for pulling it back from obesity, it has turned out overweight nonetheless: it has six sections, plus conclusions, divided into 65 chapters; the notes alone run to 138 pages.
 The result is an account that is consistently authoritative but only sometimes fresh and occasionally downright ponderous. For instance, Mr. Kagan devotes 18 pages to a detailed retelling of one now-obscure series of Congressional maneuvers in 1983, including this passage: "Before any vote was taken, an amendment to Mica's amendment was hastily drawn up by a New York Democrat, Stephen Solarz, and presented in the name of Congressman Boland. The trickiest proposal yet offered, the Boland-Solarz amendment to the Mica substitute amendment for the Young amendment to the Boland-Zablocki amendment turned Mica's proposal on its head."
 Mr. Kagan has based his research on a reading of the scores of books that have already appeared on the Nicaraguan conflict, as well as on an analysis of thousands of press articles and Government documents and on interviews with key leaders on both sides. The interviews, though not extensive, gave him some groundbreaking insights; his sessions with Humberto Ortega were especially fruitful.
 Mr. Kagan occasionally puts his own policy making experience to good use as well, as when he acknowledges that even Reagan Administration insiders grew skeptical about the central thesis underpinning their policy: that revolutionary Nicaragua was a threat to American security. "By late 1987 the geostrategic aspect of the Administration's Nicaragua policy remained a potent element of its rhetoric," Mr. Kagan writes, "but the genuine fear of Soviet expansion in Central American that had initially inspired Reagan officials in the early 1980's had passed. Reagan officials did not really believe the Soviets under Gorbachev would attempt to establish bases in Nicaragua. They did not really believe the Soviets would deliver MIG's to the Sandinistas, no matter what the Soviets promised. . . . The struggle against the Sandinistas, meanwhile, had taken on a life of its own, independent of the Soviet threat."
 That passage supports the view shared by many of the Reagan Administration's critics, who believed American policy to be driven by a bullying fixation on a pitiful Latin country, rather than by any genuine concerns about American security. And it makes Mr. Kagan seem somewhat opinionated when he concludes about Washington's actions:
 "They were the policies of a great power exercising its will, however harshly or mildly, to enforce certain principles of behavior in both the external and internal affairs of a small, troublesome neighbor. Nothing could be more natural than such behavior by a great power, and Nicaraguans from the Somozas to the Sandinistas have seen American hegemony as the natural, if not necessarily desirable, state of affairs."

LENGTH: 1066 words

HEADLINE: Manhood Under Pressure

BYLINE: By Elijah Anderson; Elijah Anderson is the Charles and William L. Day Professor of the Social Sciences at the University of Pennsylvania and the author of the forthcoming "Code of the Streets."

 BODY:

Speak My Name
Black Men on Masculinity and the American Dream.
Edited by Don Belton.
272 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $24.
 A S America's cities are transformed from centers of manufacturing to centers of service and high technology, and as America's corporations send their low-skill jobs to third-world countries, the black working class is being hit very hard. The resulting poverty has created social breakdown in our inner cities on a huge scale -- the all-too-familiar problems of alienation, drug abuse, violence, teen-age pregnancy, family disintegration, record arrest and incarceration rates, AIDS, homelessness and endemic joblessness. 
 Strikingly, since men are the ones generally charged with the responsibility of providing for the welfare of their families and communities, many people have reached a simple conclusion: There is something terribly wrong with the black man. His moral fiber, his common decency, his very masculinity are being called into question. In any discussion of prisons, welfare, joblessness, family desertion, crime, violence or drugs, his name is invoked. Shopkeepers fear him. Taxi drivers refuse to pick him up. Given these negative associations, it has become easy to grumble that he is the reason for our nation's problems. And some politicians have responded by ignoring economic and structural realities, threatening to turn back a generation of racial gains.
 In these circumstances, black men have begun to stir. Overwhelming numbers of them were willing to be counted in the Million Man March, whatever their feelings about Louis Farrakhan. Clearly, many black men believe the time has arrived to look seriously at themselves and their experience in America.
 In "Speak My Name," the novelist Don Belton has responded to these issues by assembling a group of black male writers to reflect on the social world of the contemporary black man. In the foreword the playwright August Wilson sets the tone by testifying to the positive presence of the African-American male on American soil. He briefly traces black manliness from the accomplished "mule trainer, singer, shaper of wood and iron" to Charlie Burley, a prizefighter he knew, pleading for black males to fulfill the promise of their past. Given the powerful odds stacked against the black man, his mere survival might seem to be his crowning achievement. Yet in reality, Mr. Wilson continues, the black man does something more than simply survive; he thrives. But he thrives on his own terms, no one else's, and often in a style that the rest of the world is ready to view as grotesque.
 The position enunciated by Mr. Wilson sets the stage for what follows. The stories, essays and personal narratives in "Speak My Name," by various authors pursuing various themes, represent a kind of collective testimony bearing witness to the value of black cultural life, with special attention to the black male. They reveal both the complex reality of black men and the many ways in which black men have been integral to American society, contributing much of what we define as "American."
 The list of writers in "Speak My Name" reads like a Who's Who of the African-American literary world: Henry Louis Gates Jr., Amiri Baraka, Walter Mosley, John Edgar Wideman, among many others. Each contributor essentially does his own thing, but while the pieces may be uneven in tone, they are almost all insightful.
 If there is an organizing principle here, it is the following: Black men live in a social world made extremely difficult by the forces of racism, yet they remain ordinary (albeit soulful) creatures, real individuals who are born, eat, sleep, mature, love, pray -- and work -- just like everyone else. To the detriment of the black man, this simple truth is too often ignored by the wider white society, and with this anthology Mr. Belton wishes to set matters right.
 He succeeds admirably. The writers demonstrate the remarkable range of black life. Particularly memorable are Henry Louis Gates's "Playing Hardball" (adapted from his memoir, "Colored People"), Houston Baker's "On the Distinction of 'Jr.' " and Robin D. G. Kelley's "Confessions of a Nice Negro, or Why I Shaved My Head." Many of the articles are being published here for the first time; others are excerpts from previously published work.
 Among the recurring topics are the social scarring associated with growing up black and poor in America, sibling rivalry and the place of the black man in America. There are pieces about the complicated relationship between a young man and a father figure, about the relationship between a young man and his mother, and about a young man's coming of age. The reader is treated to intimate accounts of ordinary black family life, with relationships that succeed and others that do not. At times, male friends stand in for physically or spiritually absent fathers, as at times do older brothers, male cousins or even the man next door.
 AN underlying but persistent concern of the collection is the link between hard work and moral value, and in this regard the contributors seem peculiarly American. Most of the accounts are quite positive, at times even romantic, in their portrayals of how various individuals come to terms with the common struggles of making a living, raising a family and trying to find meaning in life.
 To be sure, some pieces recount personal experiences with prejudice, discrimination and social exclusion. Here, particularly to the unsympathetic or the uninformed, the collection risks sounding like simply a series of personal reflections on racial suffering and male bonding (often with the subtext of good prevailing over evil). But the writers are only acknowledging a reality of America's troubled race relations. The very title of the anthology, after all, is in one sense a challenge to speak the truth.
 At the present time, with so many pressures on the black male, the public dialogue that Mr. Belton hopes for is sorely needed, and I commend him for a job well done. But if we are to make significant progress in understanding what too often seems an intractable problem of this society, it must also be said that it is not enough to present accounts of the world in which the black man lives, struggles and survives. Ultimately, the issues of economics and social structure are going to have to be addressed as well.

HEADLINE: Oprah Buffa

BYLINE: By Mark Hertsgaard; Mark Hertsgaard is the author of "On Bended Knee: The Press and the Reagan Presidency" and "A Day in the Life: The Music and Artistry of the Beatles." He is working on a book about the global ecological future.

 BODY:

HOT AIR
All Talk, All the Time.
By Howard Kurtz.
407 pp. New York: Times Books/Random House. $25.
 What's the difference between Ted Koppel, Oprah Winfrey and Geraldo Rivera? The joke is on Mr. Koppel, because the answer for many people seems to be, not much. According to a Harris poll cited in Howard Kurtz's "Hot Air: All Talk, All the Time," when Americans were asked to name their favorite talk show host, Mr. Koppel was lumped right in with Oprah and Geraldo, Letterman and Leno, even Regis and Kathie Lee. In an interview with Mr. Kurtz, a miffed Ted Koppel castigated the public for its lack of "discrimination." But doesn't that smack of blaming the victim? 
 "Nightline" may have been born during the Iranian hostage crisis of 1980, and it may have staked out the journalistic high ground with globe-trotting investigative reports and hard-hitting political interviews, but in recent years it has been infected by the same fluff-in-mouth disease that has degraded the news media as a whole. The O. J. Simpson trial alone, Mr. Kurtz reports, occupied nearly half the air time of "Nightline" during one seven-week stretch in 1995. As recently as the late 1980's, what made a journalist radical (and rare) was a willingness to challenge the basic assumptions of the political and economic elites whose doings dominate most news coverage. Now, simple intelligence is a radical thing.
 "We have become a talk show nation," Mr. Kurtz announces on the first page of "Hot Air." And although he applauds some aspects of the recent talk show explosion -- talk radio has broadened the nation's political conversation beyond that traditionally sanctioned by the major networks and newspapers, while television programs like "The McLaughlin Group" illustrate that "news doesn't have to be dull" -- he plainly believes the drawbacks outweigh the advantages. Talk shows, he writes, have become "a powerful vehicle that trumpets the most extreme and polarizing views, that panders to sensationalism, that spreads innuendo and misinformation with stunning efficiency." Talk shows are enemies of complexity, fairness and journalistic accountability. What's more, their "collective racket seems to grow more deafening each week."
 Mr. Kurtz, the author of "Media Circus: The Trouble With America's Newspapers," supports his charges with ample reporting, much of it undertaken in his capacity as the media reporter for The Washington Post. That perch undoubtedly helped him secure the interviews with Mr. Koppel, Larry King, Rush Limbaugh and other talk show bigwigs who animate his text. A wealth of anecdotes, personality sketches and behind-the-cameras eavesdropping makes his book smooth and undemanding reading. What is lacking, unfortunately, is depth and rigor. For example, the author seems to believe that only direct quotations require documentation. As a result, "Hot Air" resembles a series of extended newspaper articles whose occasional flashes of insight are undermined by a pervasive superficiality.
 Many of the gravest shortcomings Mr. Kurtz attributes to television talk shows -- their unswerving reflection of the mind-set of official Washington, the astronomical salaries that insulate their regular panelists from the daily realities of average Americans, the unmistakably rightward tilt of their pundits -- have, in fact, long been evident in the news media as a whole. Yet Mr. Kurtz fails to explain how these important flaws have been transformed in the talk show era, and why. Nor can he convincingly assert that talk shows are the new kingmakers of American politics without providing more concrete, checkable facts than he does. Indeed, one could argue from his own reporting that Washington insiders, for reasons of ego, vastly overestimate the true influence of television talk shows.
 In the case of radio, Mr. Kurtz reports that large majorities of talk show listeners voted Republican in a number of 1994 elections, helping the party capture Congress. That sounds plausible. The problem is, there is no way to evaluate this claim without knowing what percentage of all voters listened to talk radio. Likewise, it is interesting to read about House Speaker Newt Gingrich briefing Mr. Limbaugh in order to galvanize his audience against President Clinton's crime bill. But quoting conservatives who orchestrated a barrage of phone calls is not proof that the calls were what defeated the bill.
 The most hard-hitting material in "Hot Air" exposes how David Gergen, Sam Donaldson, William Safire and other pundits routinely accept many thousands of dollars in speaking fees from corporations with keen financial interests in the issues they discuss. The stock defense of the talking heads -- that such payments are a private matter, and in any case have no effect on their views -- "would be laughable if made by a politician," Mr. Kurtz writes. And even if it is mere coincidence that, for example, George Will and Fred Barnes took health industry cash while publicly arguing that the health care crisis was exaggerated, there is a deeper problem, Mr. Kurtz suggests. The journalists' "privileged status invariably skews their view of the world," predisposing them to believe that, like them, most Americans need not worry about rising insurance premiums, decaying public schools or Nafta-inflicted job losses.
 Six- and seven-figure incomes for reporters were unthinkable, Mr. Kurtz notes, "before the unholy union of journalism and televised entertainment." So, one might add, were many other blemishes on our news media. Sympathizing with the decision to replace a "Nightline" story about the Mexican peso crisis with yet another wallow in the O. J. mud, Mr. Kurtz speculates that "ABC executives didn't want too many viewers surfing over to Letterman and Leno." Such tabloid-style maneuvering is a logical consequence of two powerful factors that unfortunately go all but unmentioned in "Hot Air": first, the vastly increased economic concentration within the journalism industry, and second, the deregulation of broadcasting that took place during the Reagan era, which effectively told the industry that it could downgrade news without risking license renewals. Critics warned at the time that deregulation plus oligopoly would maximize profits while impoverishing the nation. But what did they know?

LENGTH: 1195 words

HEADLINE: A Man Who Dreams of Bubbles to Mars

BYLINE: By MICHAEL McGOVERN 

 BODY:
ASK most people what they think of bubbles and they'll recall the sweet summer days of youth, running through the grass, plastic bottle of soap solution in hand, dipping, then lifting the wand to the lips to blow, watching and giggling as one by one the shiny spheres floated, then burst with a splash. For most people, that's pretty much the end of bubbles.
But ask James Ossi of Darien about bubbles and he'll tell you about science, art, Mars, failure, his father, a young man's suicide, architecture, success and dreams. 
 It's hard to put a label on exactly what James Ossi does. He's a scientist whose work has been shown at the Museum of Modern Art in midtown Manhattan, the Humphrey Gallery in SoHo and the Summit Art Center in New Jersey.
And he's an artist whose work has been studied by physics and math students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and displayed in the Boston Museum of Science and Japan's Saibu Gas Museum.
"My favorite thought," said the rather mischievous inventor, when pressed to define himself, "is blowing bubbles on the surface of Mars. I guess I'm a Martian architect, but since there are no Martians, I have no clients, therefore, I am a philosopher." In 1979, after 15 years of what he described as "constant failure," Mr. Ossi finally perfected a marriage of science and art which achieves the impossible -- square bubbles.
Now, another 15 years later, three of these bubble sculptures are on loan to the Maritime Center in South Norwalk, where they will be displayed through March before likely moving on to a permanent home at the University of Florida.
From his home studio-laboratory, Mr. Ossi turns out about one of the bubble-making machines a year, which in their various incarnations have ranged from 8 to 25 feet in height, with over 2,000 pounds of switches, motors and brightly colored wires. He has been selling them to museums and shopping malls for about $65,000 each.
One of his earliest machines sits in the lobby of the physics building at M.I.T. in Cambridge, Mass. Originally purchased in 1981 as comic relief for overly intense students after one committed suicide over a failing grade, the machine now serves an academic purpose as well as being used to study physics, optics, fluid dynamics, math, light, color and area-minimizing surfaces.
It was while he was at the Parsons School of Design in New York in the late 60's that Mr. Ossi first became dedicated to intermingling science and art. The school gave him his own lab in which to indulge his creative fantasies, then inspired by the highly ornamental style of art and architecture known as Art Nouveau, which had been popular in late 19th-century France.
So Mr. Ossi dragged in an old bathtub he'd found on the street and filled it with salt water and liquid polyester, two immiscible liquids.
"I was fascinated with the movement of the two liquids within each other," Mr. Ossi said, "and I decided to bottle it and sell it as sculpture."
After a little tinkering, Mr. Ossi developed a line of rectangular-shaped, brightly colored acrylic sculptures filled with liquid polybutane, which was accepted into the Museum of Modern Art's permanent collection in 1970. Over the next few years, Mr. Ossi sold thousands through art galleries, museum gift shops and department stores, giving the inventor his first taste of artistic success and the inspiration for the bubble machine.
At about the same time, like his father Peter before him, whose paintings hang in the Smithsonian, Mr. Ossi resolved "never to have a boss."
"I think it was in June of my second year at Parsons when I went to visit my father at his studio in Paterson, N.J.," Mr. Ossi said. "There was a small handwritten note on the door which read 'Gone for a ride. Be back in September -- maybe.' I admired his freedom.
"If you fail a course in economics, you are an artist and that's all you can ever be. But if you pass you're a normal person. I'm viewed as an artist in the scientific community and that's a handicap. And by the art community I'm viewed as a scientist. Either way I'm distrusted," said Mr. Ossi, who sometimes describes himself as a "gizmologist."
Mr. Ossi playfully calls the Maritime Center piece "Russian Constructivism Via Venice Beach." Constructivism is for the type of geometry-as-art popularized by post-Russian Revolution painters, sculptors and architects of the early 1920's, and apparent in the machine's exposed steel beams, girders, nuts and bolts. And Venice Beach is a nod to the vivid bubbles, which the inventor says remind him of "the attitude of the bright, Lycra-clad Rollerblading chicks on Venice Beach, Calif."
Each machine is designed, the inventor said, so that every half hour a waterfall starts a new show. The soap solution is forced to the bottom, where air is blown in, propelling bubbles upward through panes of glass set three inches apart.
"Bubbles want to take the absolutely minimum shape they can be," Mr. Ossi explained. "A bubble in air will be a sphere because that's the minimum shape it can be and still encapsulate that much air."
Pointing to a sculpture, he continued, "Here a bubble membrane wants to get from the front surface of the glass to the back -- so it will be a plane."
As the bubbles stretch across the glass, they form a honeycomb of hexagonal cells in which each adjoining angle measures 120 degrees.
The rectangular walls of each cell start out relatively thick -- giving them a clear look. However, as the soap bubbles stretch outward and upward, Mr. Ossi explained, the walls thin to the point where 1,000 lined up side by side could fit in a single groove of a human fingerprint. As light bounces off both the front and rear surfaces of the soapy membranes, the refracted colors mix -- creating iridescent shades rare in nature's palette.
While Mr. Ossi is happy with the joy his bubble creations presently offer in earthbound settings, their future, he said, is in the stars. Scientists are soon going to build a space station, he said, in the classic nut-and-bolt style. "But space is different; there is no gravity, it's hard to turn a nut and bolt there."
"There's no doubt in my mind that we're going out there," Mr. Ossi said, pointing skyward, "but I don't think we should bring post-and-beam architecture."
Take liquid glass up into space in a shuttle, Mr. Ossi said, "add a little air pressure and it's like blowing a balloon in a vacuum." It could have a wall thickness of a few inches and a diameter of about 100 feet, he said.
Spin it fast enough, the inventor suggested, "and it becomes a disk shaped by centrifugal force. Instantly it will break into two objects -- a doughnut shape surrounding a sphere in the middle. Throw away the sphere, let the hollow doughnut cool and harden and there: instant space station! Put an atmosphere in it and spin it at the desired rate to create artificial gravity.
"Studying soap bubbles is a whole area of science, though scientists wouldn't tell you that. But I wonder," Mr. Ossi said as a smile crept across his lips, "if there's anybody working for NASA who started out as a philosopher or a dreamer."

GRAPHIC: Photo: James Ossi -- scientist, artist, inventor -- at the Maritime Center in Norwalk with a machine that makes square bubbles. (David O. Gunn/Darien News-Review)
