SECTION: Section 2; Page 31; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1523 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
Room Enough to Stretch the Imagination

BYLINE: By ANITA GATES 

 BODY:
MARLO THOMAS HAD A LOT to answer for in the late 1960's. Young single women streamed into Manhattan, demanding that real estate agents find them decent apartments they could afford. After all, if Ann Marie, the chronically unemployed actress played by Ms. Thomas in the ABC series "That Girl," could afford a pretty little one-bedroom that was clearly on a town-house block in the East 70's, why couldn't they? Ann was apparently paying the rent with her earnings from waitressing and handing out product samples at department stores.
Middle-class New Yorkers have been apologizing to out-of-town friends and relatives for decades because of what television tells America about local real estate. ("Mom, I really am making $70,000," says the real-life New Yorker. "Lots of people live in one room. With a roommate. In Queens.") 
 Things were different before "That Girl." In the 1950's, on "The Honeymooners," the Kramdens appeared to live in a large, ugly kitchen in Brooklyn, the best they could afford on Ralph's salary as a city bus driver. And on "I Love Lucy," the Ricardos' Manhattan apartment was a pleasant but unspectacular one-bedroom, which they could afford as not-so-young-marrieds because Ricky Ricardo was a bandleader and then a nightclub owner.
Housing has sometimes looked tougher in other cities. Despite Mary Richards's good job as an associate producer at WJM-TV on "The Mary Tyler Moore Show," she lived in a studio, and that was in affordable Minneapolis in the 1970's.
Movies, by contrast, with the advantage of real locations, have shown a little of everything. Woody Allen generally puts his characters in homes they can afford, from a prostitute's one-bedroom in a postwar high-rise to a prosperous actress's rambling co-op on Central Park. On the other hand, few newly divorced women with part-time jobs have the luck of Jill Clayburgh in the 1978 film "An Unmarried Woman." She signs a lease on a light-flooded garden apartment with two fireplaces and great moldings, telling a friend apologetically that it's the best she can afford.
These days, television has become somewhat more realistic about New York apartments, but there are still pockets of fantasy, not to mention some dangerous lapses in home security for these digs.
NBC's "Friends," of course, wins the Ann Marie Award for the 90's. Rachel (Jennifer Aniston) and Monica (Courteney Cox), a coffee-bar waitress and an unemployed assistant chef, respectively, are mysteriously able to afford their funky but spacious Greenwich Village apartment with terrace. (A "spacious 1 BR" with "sun and charm" in their neighborhood was recently advertised for $1,750 a month.) The hope is that viewers will "suspend disbelief," says a series spokesman.
TWO OTHER CHARACTERS IN "Friends," Joey (Matt LeBlanc) and Chandler (Matthew Perry), were sharing a two-bedroom until a few weeks ago. After being offered an apartment with "park views and high ceilings," Joey moved out, announcing, "I'm 28 . . . and I'm finally at a place where I've got enough money that I don't need a roommate anymore."
NBC, which currently has at least five series with New York apartment settings, wins points for greater credibility on the others. The producers haven't made the apartments smaller, darker and more depressing; they've simply given the characters more money.
Jerry Seinfeld (the character) on "Seinfeld" is at least a moderately successful stand-up comic. Recently he surprised his father with a gift of a new car (a Cadillac, no less). Elaine (Julia Louis-Dreyfus) was shocked: "I had no idea you had this kind of money." No wonder. She was standing in Jerry's painfully modest Upper West Side one-bedroom, which has a kitchen along one wall, a bathroom that can be seen from the living room and no real storage space (a bicycle hangs on the wall).
Caroline Duffy (Lea Thompson) on NBC's "Caroline in the City" is also a single, successful New Yorker. She's a nationally syndicated cartoonist whose Midwestern hometown named a park for her, so she can probably afford the loft in which she lives and works. The show's producers say it's in TriBeCa and that the blond-wood staircase leads to Caroline's rarely seen bedroom and a bath. Like many sitcom New Yorkers, and real-life loft residents, Caroline has a kitchen in the living room. It contains a sure sign of her financial well-being: a Sub-Zero refrigerator ($2,850 and up). But why, with even a small loft running to 1,200 square feet, do she and her colorist, Richard (Malcolm Gets), work at a partners' desk in the middle of the living room?
IN SOME CASES, THE NET works have made apartment dwellers a little older and toned down the decorator ambiance. On "The Single Guy," the West Village apartment occupied by the title character (Jonathan Silverman), whose friends are afraid he'll never marry, is refreshingly dumpy. The living room is furnished with an undersize sofa, a television that the cable installer made fun of and a dining table that doubles as a desk.
The tenants' association appears to have the power of a co-op board; not long ago it (briefly) dismissed the building's one doorman, who incidentally wears a uniform that would look more at home on Park and 72d. The creator of the series, Brad Hall, swears the building is inspired by one he lived in on Cornelia Street.
Jamie and Paul Buchman's (Helen Hunt and Paul Reiser's) one-bedroom Village apartment on "Mad About You" seems realistic for a two-career couple in their mid to late 30's. He's a documentary film producer, doing well enough to have had Yoko Ono approach him with a project. She's a public-relations executive, although she recently quit to go back to school. The apartment's rent or maintenance has never been mentioned, but the building's garage recently went condo.
Jamie and Paul clearly took the apartment because of the kitchen. This huge, windowed room, with nooks, crannies and an island (large enough for the Buchmans to have used it for a romantic encounter), belongs in a renovated classic six on Riverside Drive.
The Buchmans share a quirk with their prime-time New York neighbors: they never double-lock their door. Sometimes television Manhattanites don't lock their doors at all. On "Seinfeld," Jerry's apartment door wears an impressive array of hardware, but he never seems to put the locks to use. This is probably for the same reason that other series leave apartment doors unlocked: so the zany next-door neighbor can barge in, without tempo-slowing buzzers and bells.
How can sitcom characters be so careless in the big, bad city? In the case of "Caroline," whose title character recently left for a movie and dinner date without locking up, high security makes the difference, says Tom Azzari, the show's production designer. "It's a secure building with an intercom," he says. "You know who has access. You pretty much know who's there." (Well, yeah, until the pizza guy gets buzzed in by the apartment next door and decides to stop by for Caroline's jewelry on his way out. And as old fans of "The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd" know, you can't even count on a doorman to stop suspicious visitors.)
Building security may be a less serious issue in Metropolis, where citizens can often count on Superman to catch burglars in the act; otherwise the place looks a lot like New York. In all fairness, Lois Lane's apartment has always posed problems for set designers. Lois is just a hard-working reporter at The Daily Planet, but she needs a balcony where Superman can make graceful landings. In the 1978 film "Superman," the designers gave Lois a terrace the size of Montana.
On ABC's "Lois and Clark," the apartment that Lois lives in has one of those glamorous kitchen-in-the-living-room layouts, good closet space (big enough for a visiting robot) but a fire escape instead of a terrace. She reaches it, however, by walking through what look like French doors. (Getting a great apartment was easy for Clark Kent, a k a Superman. He just signed a lease on a dump, then renovated it one afternoon with his superpowers.)
The series that makes the most important statement about Manhattan housing may be Fox's "Ned and Stacey," which was created on the premise that New Yorkers will do almost anything to get a fabulous apartment at below-market-value rent. In the pilot episode, Stacey, a writer for The Village Voice, enters the apartment of Ned, an advertising executive, furious. But she stops mid-rant when she notices the wall of windows looking out on Central Park and the skyline beyond. "Nice apartment," she says. "One bedroom?"
It turns out to be a spacious Upper West Side rent-controlled two-bedroom with large terrace for only $1,500. The primary tenant is an elderly woman who lived there for 30 years, is now in a nursing home and has sublet to Ned under the mistaken impression that he's her nephew. Ned's employer gives promotions only to family men, so Ned is looking for a wife, fast, just for appearances. Stacey sizes up the place, knowing she'll never get anything else like this for $750. She's in her wedding dress before the credits roll.

HEADLINE: Westchester Q&A: Dr. Ronald D. Valenti;
The Juggling Act of Paying for Schools

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
ANOTHER year, another round of cuts in state aid for school districts. This year, Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget cuts general state aid and calls for school districts to pay millions more to educate and transport special-education preschoolers, services that had mainly been paid for by the state and county governments.
With more of the burden of financing education being shifted to property owners -- and organized antitax groups resisting property-tax increases -- school officials know that things have to change. 
 But how? Dr. Ronald D. Valenti, Superintendent of the Harrison schools and president of the Lower Hudson Council of School Superintendents (representing 76 districts in Westchester, Putnam, Rockland and Dutchess Counties), said the answer is multifaceted.
Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Dr. Valenti, who headed the council's study on financing education:
Q. Define the problem.
A. Everyone seems to agree on the problem. If you go back to December 1990, there was a dramatic reduction in state aid to all districts in New York State. At the time, then Gov. Mario Cuomo and the Legislature decided to cut back aid dramatically to districts throughout the state. Westchester districts sustained upward of a 50 to 60 percent reduction in their state aid. This was done because of the dire fiscal straits of the state at the time of a national recession. The fundamental problem is the lack of available dollars from Albany as well as throughout the region to continue to fund education at the appropriate level that is necessary for student learning. Also, there has been a Federal retreat on education. These cutbacks have forced and driven property taxes on the local level higher.
The second component of the problem is the entire inequity that we have in terms of funding school districts. We have a state school-aid formula that no one can adequately understand and a question of whether the property base should be the only source for the funding of education. The property base needs some dramatic surgery if it's going to continue to fund schools. Specifically, we think there is a need for uniform assessment rates throughout New York State. And the tax certiorari problem has to be addressed so that property owners who can claim they have been overtaxed only receive refunds prospectively, not retroactively. Along with that we think senior citizens and wage earners on fixed incomes need some relief.
The third major component of the problem is what everyone calls mandates -- mandates from Albany and/or Washington, but usually Albany, where in effect there are unfunded requirements to carry certain programs or perform certain activities or provide certain services.
When you combine those three things, we find that New York State is really racing down a fiscal collision course.
Q. What are your solutions?
A. Our first solution with respect to state aid is that we insist that the children of New York State receive their fair share of state aid. While there are other legitimate needs in New York -- and everyone knows health services and welfare and prison, and so forth, are legitimate needs -- it's our belief that the children should not be experiencing the brunt of this diminution of resources. We would argue, minimally, to get us back to the levels that we had in December 1990.
Q. But that isn't going to happen, is it?
A. Well, look: we have to take a position. You have to begin somewhere. To give a very specific example, back in 1990, for every dollar we spent in Harrison on education, 12 cents came from Albany. The state has to decide what role it wants to play, and fund it accordingly.
Other recommendations we are making are for building aid and increased assistance with special education aid. We're serving a growing proportion of youngsters who have remedial and special needs and rather than have the state retreat on that front, they have to take a more active and aggressive role in that area.
Also, the last two proposals: We are looking for a regional expense factor to be included in the state-aid formula, to help areas such as Westchester where it's more expensive to live, where teacher salaries are higher to reflect that. And finally, we strongly support efficiency study grants. We're very much committed to cutting out any kind of costs that are unnecessary. And we would like the state to assist districts to find ways to share services in the interest of efficiency and economy. We have done a good deal in this area, but we want to do more.
Q. Of all your suggestions, probably the last one has some political reality of happening, wouldn't you agree?
A. I think the latter certainly has some political reality, but don't forget that related to the others may be relaxation of some of the mandates. For example, transportation aid was a major casualty five years ago. Before then, our transportation expenses were reimbursed about 90 percent. Now we get 5 to 6 percent. We believe one of two things now has to happen: either the state must increase its share of aid for transportation or the state legislation ought to be changed to no longer make transportation a state mandate for children who live two to three miles or more away from the school.
Q. What is your position on school district mergers?
A. We, as school superintendents, have been supporting that notion where a community is prepared to support it. There are superintendents that have really gone out on a limb trying to get a community to take a hard look at it. I think the taxpayers will have to confront that reality if dollars can be saved. There is an awful lot of support here for individual districts. I think it will be a pocketbook issue that overcomes the emotional issues.
Q. Many people still seem to feel that the schools can absorb more cuts -- if the money were better spent, if perhaps there were changes in tenure laws, control of teachers' salaries.
A. I think you have to look at the historical trend. We know that teachers were grossly underpaid if you go back many years ago. Now, over the last several years, the salaries of teachers have been improving and increasing. If you look at recent teacher salary increases, most of the increases that I have seen are in the 2 to 2.5 percent range. I think we've become much more realistic in terms of what the economy can bear. However, fulfilling the mandate of treating teachers as professionals is absolutely necessary.
Q. Most professionals don't have tenure.
A. In my judgment tenure is not protecting the incompetent. It's to protect the academic freedom of a teacher. Following that logic, I know many districts that have taken actions against incompetent teachers, some of them successfully, some of them unsuccessfully. We've fought for changes in the law to make the due process more simplified so that we can address it. I think districts have to be assertive and at times aggressive in going after teachers believed to be incompetent, and an enlightened teachers' union will be supportive of that.
The converse is that in the absence of tenure, would one's academic freedom be challenged? Would a district be able to be arbitrary and capricious with respect to a particular teacher, particularly when that teacher's salary reached a point where the district could say, I could buy two teachers for the price of that one?
Q. Governor Pataki has proposed that school budgets that include an increase not in line with the cost-of-living be passed by a 60-percent majority. What do you think of that?
A. We take very serious issue with his proposal for a supermajority to pass budgets. I would offer him a challenge: if he's prepared to put the state budget out for a public referendum under the same supermajority vote, certainly I would do the same. I have never been able to vote on the state budget nor on the county budget nor on a local budget. The only time people get to vote on a budget is the school district budget. A supermajority requirement is an open invitation for tyranny of the minority.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Superintendent Ronald D. Valenti's office is at the L. M. Kleion Middle School in Harrison. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ART;
Over Their Shoulders, an Iron Hand

BYLINE: By AMEI WALLACH; Amei Wallach's "Ilya Kabakov: The Man Who Never Threw Anything Away" will be published by Harry N. Abrams in May.

 BODY:
IT HAS BEEN TWO decades since the first historical survey of Hitler's official art raised such an outcry that the Frankfurter Kunstverein, which mounted the exhibition, found it necessary to publish a book of the outraged reactions.
Since then, the Soviet Union has crashed, exposing dreary truths about the art of yet another repressive regime. American museums have begun to snap up bargains in Soviet-era Lenin statues. And architectural revisionism has recast the reputation of Hitler's chief architect, Albert Speer. 
 A half century after American troops marched into Buchenwald, a swastika is as likely to decorate a mystery novel as to appall. Only a handful of exhibitions have taken on the explosive issue of whether art in the service of totalitarian regimes can be art at all. Yet "Art and Power: Europe Under the Dictators 1930-45," which is traveling around Europe and opened Tuesday at the Center of Contemporary Culture in Barcelona, received a curiously bloodless response from both press and viewers at its first stop in London this winter.
A review in the London newspaper The European, for example, called it "a collection of vivid images from a cruel but fascinating period in European history" and said, more jauntily, "There is a marvelous line in Hitler's 'Mein Kampf' where he says, with hilarious understatement, 'And I, for my part, decided to go into politics.' "
Meanwhile, Rafael Ramos of La Vanguardia in Barcelona, wrote, "The exhibition navigates through the waters of cultural and political controversy by openly questioning widespread theory that totalitarian and modernist art had nothing in common except a coincidence in time."
The huge compendium of more than 470 paintings, sculptures, film clips, graphics and architectural projects produced in Berlin, Moscow, Rome and Madrid under totalitarian rule has been underwritten by the Council of Europe, an organization formed at the start of the cold war to remind Western European nations of the cultural values they share. Her Majesty's Government was invited to prepare this show because Britain had fended off totalitarian takeover.
In Barcelona, where Generalissimo Francisco Franco's reign ended 21 years ago, "the subject of the exhibition is very, very interesting for the public at this moment," said Berte Sureda, coordinator of the exhibition in Barcelona. "For people in Spain it was very hard in those years, the hardest that we can remember."
In particular, Ms. Sureda expects Jose Maria Sert's monumental painting, "Ste. Teresa, Ambassadress of Divine Love to Spain, Offers to Our Lord the Spanish Martyrs of 1936," to hit a nerve. Sert is best known in New York for the mural he was commissioned to paint as a replacement for Diego Rivera's Rockefeller Center fresco, which had been deemed politically unacceptable because it depicted Lenin. Painted in glazes on gilt, "Ste. Teresa" hung in the Vatican Pavilion at the Paris International Exhibition in 1937.
Nearby, in the Republican Government's Spanish Pavilion, Picasso's "Guernica" expressed his horror at the bombing of civilian populations by Franco's Nationalist allies. In contrast, Sert employed every grandiloquent artifice of drapery and foreshortening to present Christ on His cross, hovering horizontally like a military bomber, welcoming the souls of Nationalist martyrs.
"Art and Power" begins with the 1937 International, at which art and architecture were positioned at the center of the struggle for power, and Albert Speer's German Pavilion and Boris Iofan's Soviet Pavilion faced off on the banks of the Seine. In many ways, Speer and Soviet architects like Iofan steal this show with their megalomaniacal master plans, though these are represented only by drawings and models.
REDUCED VERSIONS OF THE sculptures that topped and dominated their Parisian buildings introduced the "Art and Power" installation at the Hayward Gallery in London: Vera Mukhina's Soviet-era set piece "Industrial Worker and Collective Farm Girl," hammer and sickle held high, steps briskly into the future toward the immutable menace of Speer's eagle, its talons gripping a shield adorned with a swastika.
Even in the films on view -- the 1936 Olympics in Berlin, a 1939 Moscow sports parade that takes a hint from Busby Berkeley -- the esthetic differences between Moscow and Berlin are apparent. Both intended to mislead in order to control. But Soviet art and architecture insisted on vigor and rosy optimism to create a dream of euphoria that would blunt the reality of daily deprivation and death. The Nazi dream was of stability and resolute authority to shroud past economic and political chaos, and the present reality of brutality and war.
This exhibition pits independent artists more interested in examining reality than in controlling it -- Picasso, Miro, Oskar Schlemmer and Kathe Kollwitz -- against the likes of Stalin's court painter, Aleksandr Gerasimov, and Hitler's star film director, Leni Riefenstahl. In London, the organizers seemed to be counting on the differences to be so obvious that they could mix and match without explanatory texts.
Sepp Hilz's "Red Necklace," an academic fantasy of peasant beauty, shared a room with Felix Nussbaum's "Secret," in which bulging eyes and endless corridors, rendered with hyper-reality, suggest culpability and dread. Hilz was collected by Hitler; Nussbaum, an Austrian Jew, was killed at Auschwitz in 1944.
In "Art and Power," distinctions are not always clear between those who served the dictators, those who continued in perilous protest, those who emigrated and those, like Georg Kolbe, who stayed. Kolbe was a lithely classical German sculptor of bronze nudes whose uncharacteristically bombastic "Proclamation" was a focal point of the 1937 German Pavilion. That year, his sculpture was also included in the inaugural exhibition at the House of German Art, where Hitler displayed the art he approved, not in the "Degenerate Art" exhibition in which the confiscated work of most of Kolbe's friends was derided.
When the war ended and Kolbe was reduced to trading sculpture for cigarettes, he made "The Liberated Man," an extraordinary perversion of Rodin's "Thinker," head in hands, in infinite guilt and despair. In the "Art and Power" installation, "Liberated Man" echoes the pose of "Crouching Prisoner in Saint-Cyprien," Nussbaum's firsthand news from the concentration camps.
Totalitarian art is customarily posited as the triumph of muscles over modernism, but "Art and Power," and its accompanying catalogue of essays, suggests a more complex reading of power struggles. Goebbels at first promoted German Expressionism as Nordic Expressionism, suitable as an official Aryan style. In the Soviet Union, Socialist Realism triumphed over the avant-garde artists who had disdained the Realists at the start of the Revolution.
In Italy, Mussolini generally suffered the enthusiasms of the Futurists, and Ambrosi's startling portrait of Il Duce overlays his head on the city of Rome in a filmic dissolve. On the other hand, the independent sculptor Julio Gonzalez indulged in self-censorship, replacing his Cubist totem intended for the 1937 Spanish Pavilion with a stirring, representational peasant woman.
THE BRITISH ORGANIZERS at the Hayward Gallery had invited a consortium of curators to mount shows within shows, in the Guggenheim Museum manner, with a result that sometimes calls to mind divas singing in different keys. Defanged by this evenhanded approach, some of the art and architecture that for so long had been a monstrous secret came across as merely ridiculous to the largely young audience that thronged to the exhibition in London.
"I find some of it quite humorous," said Andrew Eaton, an actor four years out of Oxford. "Over the top," agreed Ilaria D'Elia, an actress recently graduated from the University of London. And Mr. Eaton added: "Hitler's a comic character in Britain. There's a whole song about him."
To Laian Shaw, a university student at Darby, "1930 to 1945," as he dismissively put it, just seems so long ago and far away. "If you consider we are near the end of the millennium, in 50 years there will be a time to do a Yugoslavia show," he said.
In the end, context is essential to an exhibition that asks tough questions about art in the service of power. However hesitant "Art and Power" seems in approaching those questions, they will be thrown into high relief when the exhibition travels to Berlin starting in June. But Lutz Becker, who organized the film portion of the show, would also like the work to be seen in Washington. "That way," he said, "you can contrast it with the Holocaust, the real art of Hitler at the Holocaust Museum."

HEADLINE: STYLE;
Couture Lives!

BYLINE: By Holly Brubach 

 BODY:
Some random thoughts on the recent round of fashion shows in Paris:
A friend sent a note after seeing her first haute couture presentation. "I must admit I was shocked," she wrote, "by the ethics of spending so much money on one outfit while poverty, misery and unemployment surround us on every street corner." This is neither the time nor the space for entering into the perennial debate over the morality of the haute couture. I bring it up only because I'm struck by the fact that though I've heard this objection to fashion a thousand times, I've never heard anyone voice the same outrage over, say, a car. As in: "I've just seen the new Porsche, and I think it's scandalous that in this age of homelessness and destitution . . . ." 
 Karl Lagerfeld's decision to stage the Chanel collection in private suites at the Ritz, rather than on a runway, was unanimously hailed as a return to presentations on a more intimate scale; at such close range, it becomes obvious that the clothes are to a large extent about the workmanship. Designers in Paris seem to feel a sense of responsibility toward the crafts people, coming up with ideas that will keep them employed and their techniques alive. But here in America, when a craft is endangered, we let it die a natural death: if the market can't support it, it's no longer relevant.
Feminist film critics write about the "male gaze" and its power to objectify women. At the men's shows (for spring 1997) that followed on the heels of the haute couture, the male models looked decidedly ill at ease, unaccustomed to being scrutinized the way female models are. Furtive, shy, they shoved their hands in their pockets, took them out, put them in again, their eyes darting from the floor to the ceiling to the exits. The sole exception was Jean Paul Gaultier's models, who, with an air of mock gravity and defiant pride, paraded the red-carpet path laid out between gilt chairs in a suite of rooms in an 18th- century mansion. Titled "Homme Couture," Gaultier's collection offered an outfit for every activity (gardening, horseback riding, bargain hunting) and every occasion (a winter cruise, a gallery opening, a funeral), each with a quaint title and an effusively poetic description. The sheer fuss of it all poked affectionate fun at the haute couture shows we'd just seen -- their fragile magnificence, their precious intricacy, their depiction of Woman-as-Faberge-Egg.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chanel haute couture (CHANEL); Jean Paul Gaultier "Homme Couture." (DAN LECCA)

HEADLINE: The Longest War In the World

BYLINE: By Bill Berkeley; Bill Berkeley writes frequently on Africa. This is his first article for the Magazine.

 BODY:
THE BORDER REGION BETWEEN Kenya and south Sudan is a harsh, dry, fly-ridden semidesert inhabited by nomadic cattle herders. The Kenyan village of Lokichokio sprouts up incongruously, a surreal boom town where growling cargo planes lift off from a world-class landing strip and sunburned Europeans and Americans populate a steadily expanding metropolis of safarilike huts and trailers. Lokichokio is the staging ground of Operation Lifeline Sudan, the United Nations' long-running, $2-million-a-week relief program that year after year brings precious little relief to the famished victims of Sudan's civil war, the longest war in the world.
On a slow afternoon in Lokichokio, a half-dozen jaded relief workers are sipping Cokes in "the clinic," a thatch-roof, gravel-floor canteen with dartboards and a Ping-Pong table. The talk is angry, demoralized, frankly cynical. It is about the Big Men in south Sudan, the myriad chiefs and warlords and rebel faction leaders with whom the U.N. and independent relief agencies engage in an insidious dance. "They use our food to fuel their war," someone says. "It's a racket with the chiefs. It's like a business cartel." 
 The worst offenders are the two main guerrilla faction leaders, Riek Machar and John Garang. "They don't care how many people die," an American laments. "The lesson they have learned is that if you keep fighting, the West will keep feeding you." An exasperated Brit has an idea: "Has anybody said to Garang or Riek, 'Here's a million dollars. Please go away'?"
Sudan has been at war for 30 of the last 40 years, 13 of the past 17 decades. The current round of fighting is entering its 14th year, with no end in sight. The best guess is that 1.5 million have died since 1983; 85 percent of south Sudan's population has been displaced. South Sudanese, with a mixture of sorrow and shame, reckon they've been bludgeoned back to the Stone Age.
Sudan's war is usually explained as a clash between the Arab and Islamic north and the long-subjugated, Christian and animist black African south. There is truth in this view. But another way of looking at Sudan is as a textbook case of big men using little men, a handful of elites endlessly maneuvering for power and booty while millions perish.
For generations of Sudanese, war has become a self-perpetuating industry. Many suffer, but more than a few are benefiting. Politicians, soldiers, merchants, warlords, gangsters and famine profiteers -- all tirelessly jockey for advantage, heedless of the suffering they cause.
Sudan is a laboratory for disorders common to many of the world's intractable sectarian and ethnic conflicts, from Northern Ireland to Afghanistan to the strife-torn republics of the former Soviet Union. Sudan's big men personify a ruinous symbiosis of religion, ethnicity and organized crime. I have come here to meet some of these men: Garang and Riek, and in the northern capital, Khartoum, Hassan al-Turabi, perhaps the biggest man in Sudan -- the cast of characters at the top, on all sides, whose interests and machinations and evasions of responsibility might illuminate the pathology of an endless war.
SLOUCHING LANGUIDLY IN ITS DESERT isolation at the confluence of the Blue and White Niles, dusty, dilapidated, oven-hot Khartoum seems a universe apart from the war in south Sudan. Aside from the moonscape of fetid refugee camps on its distant periphery, where a million displaced southerners languish in humiliating beggary, Khartoum does not have the feel of a capital at war. The edge in its otherwise somnolent air derives from the pervasive presence of informers for Hassan al-Turabi's secret police.
Turabi greets his visitors in a plain stucco villa on a quiet side street near the center of Khartoum, the headquarters of his power base, the National Islamic Front. "Islam is a current," he says. "Islam means submission to God exclusively, submission to a higher power." He is the brains behind the military regime of Gen. Omar Hassan al-Bashir, who seized power in 1989 and has ruled Sudan ever since through sheer terror. Turabi has achieved international notoriety because of his alleged support for terrorists and because of his avowed ambition to lead an Islamist crusade from Algiers to Damascus. But his power is rooted in the skeletal remains of Sudan. It was at a rare moment when peace appeared to be at hand, in the spring of 1989, that Turabi's Islamists took control of the Government and reignited the war. They have scuttled all efforts to end it ever since.
Turabi is a diminutive man with soft hands and a white wisp of a beard. A lawyer by training, with a Ph.D. from the Sorbonne, he speaks with a nervous giggle and has an ingratiating smile. "There is a vacuum now," he tells me. "That vacuum is being filled by an Islamist spirit. I just happened naturally to have been on the track where history is moving." Embittered Sudanese have another explanation for Turabi's years-long, ruthlessly cunning rise to power. "Islamic Leninism," they call it, a vicious little police state operating under a cloak of piety.
Turabi's National Islamic Front is ideally suited to the demands and opportunities of permanent war. It is an ingenious hybrid, a cross between a theocracy and a Mafia syndicate. True believers provide the cannon fodder, in the form of a heavily indoctrinated Islamist militia modeled after Iran's Revolutionary Guards. Meanwhile, an elite cabal of generals, Islamic bankers, arms merchants, currency swindlers, land appropriators, cattle raiders, oil prospectors and outright slave traders -- through the patronage of their godfather, Turabi -- muscle their way into the profits of war.
Sudan's big men have excelled in their peculiar environment by mastering two intertwined requirements of power. The first is the art of manipulating potent symbols, masking one's personal agenda in a larger, legitimizing cause. It must be a cause that justifies extreme measures, and for which people are willing to sacrifice their lives.
The second requirement is to attach this larger cause to the economic forces that predominate in conditions of total anarchy. In the war-ravaged wilderness of south Sudan, where most of the country's natural resources lie, the challenge for the successful power broker is to ride the predatory elements: to harness them, tax them if possible, arm them if necessary and amass enough power to liquidate them before they can liquidate you.
For Turabi, the mask is Islam. Religion has long been the political lever of last resort; economic crises and interminable war have all but completely eroded the legitimacy of the state. In the north, Islam is the one potent symbol Arab political forces have been able to rely on for popular support.
The 19th-century Sudanese nationalist known as the Mahdi first invoked Islam as a unifying force in the popular uprising against Turko-Egyptian rule, which yielded Sudan's first theocratic state. The British, in turn, during their subsequent half-century of colonial rule, cultivated Islamic sects as the basis for rival political parties. When the regime of Gen. Gaafar al-Nimiery began to crumble in 1983, the dictator played the Islamic card, declaring Sharia, or Koranic law. This relegated Sudan's four million non-Muslim southerners to second-class status, starting the current round of war.
War legitimizes an Islamist regime with a cause that faithful Muslims cannot oppose. Turabi's relentless and highly sophisticated propaganda portrays the war as a Western and Zionist plot against Islam. A recent fatwa, or religious decree, exhorted the faithful to jihad, or holy war, on the grounds that southern rebels "directed their major efforts toward the killing of Muslims, the sabotage of mosques, the burning of the Koran and its desecration with filth. . . . Zionists, Crusaders and the Arrogants incited them to do this and provide them with arms and supplies."
Then of course there's money to be made, particularly petrodollars. As far back as the 1970's, Turabi and his allies, deftly applying Saudi-backed financial favors and ideological indoctrination, began systematically insinuating themselves into key institutions, notably the military and the banking system. Through Islamic banks, they now exercise a virtual monopoly on access to capital.
Turabi, alas, is bored with my questions about the war. As we talk, the Sudanese air force is bombing refugee camps in south Sudan, scattering 200,000 into the bush. Turabi would rather not dwell on it. "Now, I'm really not too involved in the south," he sighs, waving aside my questions with his soft hand. A war in his own country, one of the great humanitarian catastrophes of the late 20th century -- but Turabi has bigger fish to fry.
 FROM THE WINDOW OF A 10seater prop plane circling high over south Sudan, the village of Akobo, on the Ethiopian border, appears to be an orderly constellation of circular huts with straw fences. As the plane begins its descent, you see signs of the malignancy that brings us here. Rows of blackened, roofless huts come into view, and the surrounding fields are abandoned. More than 24,000 people have been scattered from their homes recently by internecine fighting among local clans.
A blizzard of flies wafts over us as we disembark on a sodden grass landing strip. Faces press all around: taut with hunger, wide-eyed and expectant, electric with the promise of manna from heaven. Operation Lifeline Sudan has sent this plane to deliver medicine for the local clinic.
The big man in Akobo is Riek Machar, leader of a breakaway faction of the Sudan People's Liberation Army, the South Sudan Independence Movement, which once controlled nearly all of south Sudan but now has lost most of it to the Government. In August 1991, Riek, as he is known, made a fateful bid to seize control of the S.P.L.A. from its founding leader, John Garang. It didn't work. Instead, Riek's failed coup metastasized into a catastrophic war between the Nuer and the Dinka, the two largest ethnic groups in south Sudan. Thousands were slaughtered; several hundred thousand died in the resulting famine. The rebels were split in two, then in three, then four.
"I really don't have any regrets," Riek assures me. We are sitting now in his dirt-floor, mud-wall compound, swatting the flies, guarded by a dozen listless teen-age rebels in shorts and flip-flops, Kalashnikovs slung over their shoulders. Riek is an attractive man in his 40's, smoothly affable, a little cocky. He, too, has a Ph.D., from the University of Bradford in England. He wears pressed fatigues with a red beret and bright red monogrammed shoulder boards that set him strikingly apart from the rabble around us. A barefoot attendant shines the big man's combat boots as we talk.
"Garang was responsible for the ills of the movement," Riek continues. "It's his leadership that was responsible, not mine." A particularly wanton massacre by Riek's troops was "unfortunate," he admits, but it wasn't his fault. "I don't feel responsible for the deaths. We all went to fight for our liberation. So we pay a high price." Riek once promised to investigate the massacre. The result? "If any atrocities were committed, it was not necessarily sanctioned by the leadership." Anybody held accountable? "In a big fight, you don't know who did this. It was a big fight."
If Turabi's mask is religion, the symbolic cover for Garang and Riek is race. Theirs is the cause of black southerners against a historic injustice. At least since the Ottomans instituted slavery in the 19th century -- in parts of Sudan, it flourishes to this day -- northern Arabs have dominated all spheres of Sudanese life: politics, development, the civil service, education. Black southerners do the dirty work -- not least in war. In the Sudanese People's Armed Forces, the Government army, 90 percent of the rank and file are southerners, while 96 percent of the officer corps come from northern or central Sudan. In the first five years of the current war, when three-quarters of a million southerners died, only 3,000 northern government troops were killed. Ninety-five percent of the combatants on both sides were southerners who fought for a variety of reasons, from paychecks to outright coercion.
Still, most southerners readily identify with the southern cause. Garang and Riek undoubtedly believe in it, too. Yet for them it is not just a goal worth fighting for but an inoculation from any personal accountability. Garang, when I ask him about the suffering of south Sudanese, tells me: "The Islamic Arab agenda is the cause of the war and the source of the suffering. It is a choice between slavery and freedom. What is life worth to be at peace when you are a slave in your own country?"
Garang and Riek both talk a good game. Yet they, no less than Turabi, rely on utter ruthlessness to survive in it. Like Turabi they are masters of the Machiavellian arts: of purges and shifting alliances, playing rivals off against one another -- and riding the criminal class. Like Turabi's National Islamic Front, the S.P.L.A. is a well-adapted hybrid, at once a genuine liberation movement and a loose confederation of ethnically based criminal gangs. The 1991 split, with its bifurcation along ethnic lines, was akin to what happens when Mafia dons fall out. When the big man's survival was at stake, ethnicity became useful.
"I was with Garang for eight years," Riek tells me. "I have witnessed the lack of democracy, his dictatorial measures. I have seen the abuses of human rights."
It took him eight years to see the light, but Riek is right about Garang. The S.P.L.A. began its war against the north in 1983 with broad popular support across the south. But its character was shaped by its principal backer, the former Ethiopian dictator Mengistu Haile Mariam, and by Mengistu's backer, the Soviet Union. Garang now discounts his pact with the devil as a "marriage of convenience," given Khartoum's cold war alliance with the West. Based in Ethiopia, the S.P.L.A. never developed the grass-roots support of a classic guerrilla struggle. Across the south in its heyday the S.P.L.A. behaved like an occupying army. Civilians remain the main military targets. All factions seek to destroy communities presumed to be supporting their opponents. In far-flung scorched-earth sweeps, minimally trained, totally illiterate, heavily armed fighters torch villages, steal the livestock and food, plant land mines, conscript the young men and boys and rape the women and girls.
Garang's explicit strategy was to render south Sudan ungovernable, and in that he succeeded. The south today is not only ungovernable but virtually uninhabitable. Garang, to exculpate himself, will tell me that "for every 100 men I recruit, I may have two thieves." He has recruited roughly 180,000 men over the last 12 years. That would mean 3,600 thieves. Heavily armed by Garang and deployed in conditions of absolute lawlessness, many have become powerful thieves indeed.
It was the collapse of Mengistu's regime in Ethiopia in 1991 that precipitated the split in the S.P.L.A. The new Ethiopian regime kicked the S.P.L.A. out, and a power struggle ensued. It became the Nuer chief, Riek, against the Dinka chief, Garang. Khartoum pumped in guns and bribes, doing everything in its power to provoke and exploit ethnic divisions. "Aktul al-abid bil abid," they say in Khartoum. The phrase is from 19th-century Sudan, when Arab slave traders dominated the state and decimated the south by pitting one black African tribe against another. It means "Kill the slave through the slave."
 THREE HUNDRED MILES SOUTH OF AKOBO, John Garang holds court in a makeshift, thatch-roof-and-canvas guerrilla command post in the rugged bush near the Kenyan border. The S.P.L.A. commander is reachable after several hours of bouncing and lurching in a four-wheel-drive along dirt tracks through the remote mountain reaches of south Sudan. After four years of fighting with Riek's breakaway faction and renewed Government offensives, Garang's turf for the moment is reduced to a tenuous sliver on the southernmost frontier with Kenya and Uganda. "Of course, we are not trying to achieve a military victory," Garang tells me. "We cannot win this war."
Garang is a bearish man in pressed camouflage fatigues, charming, smart, even funny. His Ph.D. comes from Iowa State University. He certainly doesn't talk like a thug. He says things like: "The engine which drives the war is injustice. The regimes since independence have failed to evolve a sociopolitical commonality that transcends localism. Governments have moved toward parasitism, Arabism, Islamism."
Yet when I ask Garang about the rampant criminality of troops under his command, he dodges and weaves, blames Khartoum and changes the subject. "We are certainly not angels," he finally admits. "You will hear these charges. You will also hear about the popularity of the S.P.L.A. There are positive things, and there are negative things. There are individuals who rape and steal. But what I want to underline is that it is not the movement."
Does Garang have any regrets? "I don't believe so," he says. "War is regrettable. It results in destruction and suffering. But human beings have gone to war from time to time. People have fought for ideals that are worth fighting for."
The latest news is that Riek is in retreat and that Garang is on the rebound. Garang's forces recently attacked the Nuer village of Ganyliel, killing 210 villagers, including 127 children, according to Human Rights Watch/Africa. In a new offensive, his forces have recaptured parts of the south from which they were expelled three years ago, advancing to within 20 miles of Juba, the southern capital. Garang is being rearmed with help from Sudan's neighbors. Uganda, Kenya, Ethiopia, Eritrea and Egypt all fear Khartoum's support for armed Islamist groups; Egypt, for one, blamed Turabi for last year's attempt to assassinate its President, Hosni Mubarak.
Few doubt that the Clinton Administration has had a hand in Garang's revival -- he passed through Washington just before Christmas. Last month, the Administration withdrew its Ambassador and embassy staff from Khartoum, accusing Sudan of providing sanctuary for some of the world's most violent terrorist groups. The U.N. has warned of economic sanctions unless the Government surrenders the suspects in the Mubarak assassination attempt, and the International Monetary Fund is threatening to expel Sudan for falling in arrears on its staggering $16 billion foreign debt.
The United States and Israel share an interest with Sudan's immediate neighbors in containing an aggressive Islamist regime. So the pressure is on Khartoum, and policy makers may believe that arming Garang could increase it. But surely that is just pouring more fuel on the fire. The big men will adjust their calculations; the little men will keep on dying.
As our truck bounces back through the bush toward the Kenyan border, I find myself thinking not of Riek, or Garang, or Turabi but of a 24-year-old U.N. radio operator named Peter Gatreak, who had been my guide in Akobo. He was a delightful companion, warm and curious, and like so many in this part of the world, physically striking: tall and thin as a toothpick, pitch-black, with huge teeth and four parallel scars across his forehead -- the markings of the Nuer. Like everyone in Akobo, Peter's life has been one long series of uprootings and losses. He was a refugee in Ethiopia for seven years. His father was killed in the war. His mother died from hunger. Aunts and uncles, brothers and sisters, in-laws, cousins, friends -- "so many" also died. "We are suffering indeed from hunger," Peter tells me. He has never been to school. He has no memory of peace. He has no ambitions for his week-old son, beyond, he says, "I hope he will survive."

HEADLINE: L.I. a Key to Future Of 3-State Region

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
LONG ISLAND'S fate is inseparably wedded to the future of a three-state metropolitan region that faces irreversible economic, environmental and social decline over the next 25 years, the Regional Plan Association is forecasting.
The association, with headquarters in Manhattan, said sweeping steps that it outlined last month in a $75 billion plan would avert the decline and make the region globally competitive, instead of a victim of growth and congestion. 
 In broad terms, the plan argues for creating greenswards, transportation changes like new tolls or taxes that would combat congestion, the revival of downtown centers and suburban rezoning to create new centers. The plan also calls for additional commuter and freight rail service, with new regional and national connections.
For employment, the study champions education and job training for an "information-based economy," an increased sense of links between economic advances and social equity in housing and jobs for a region that will be less than half white by 2020 and governmental changes to weld the region into a cohesive economic and social unit.
If even partly adopted, the plan could inspire significant changes in land use, driving, rail service, education, government and life in general on Long Island and throughout the region. It argues for recognition that Nassau and Suffolk, like other counties surrounding New York City, are part of an intertwined megametropolitan region that has to begin to work as one or wither.
Putting the plan into effect would require major support from influential private and public groups, broad public backing and a long series of government actions on virtually all levels.
In one of five "calls to action," the plan proposes reserves for Long Island covering the Atlantic Coast, Long Island Sound, the Peconic Estuary, the pine barrens, farmland and selected open spaces. The reserves, part of a system of 11 reserves that the plan proposes for the entire region, would be intended to protect natural resources and water, as well as provide a natural and recreational setting to retain and attract residents and business.
"To insure our economic foundation, we need to lock in quality of life," the executive director of the group and a co-author of the plan, Robert D. Yaro, said. "What's changed in the world economy is that people and companies are no longer bolted down in a region. Now they can go anywhere, and they will go where the quality of life is best."
The plan organization said that an agreement in June among builders, environmentalists, planners and other officials that created a 100,000-acre pine barrens preserve on eastern Long Island was the prototype for the other reserves, as well as additional initiatives. The association took part in formulating the plan for the pine barrens.
Describing Long Island as choked by traffic congestion, the association advised against building or expanding roads because of historical evidence that such projects only increased traffic. Instead, it suggested the electronic collection of tolls on thoroughfares like the Long Island Expressway, with the money helping to finance road maintenance and mass transit.
The tolls could be collected at peak times, to encourage off-peak traveling, car pools and ridership on mass transit.
The system, which the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway and some bridges are testing, would have roadside or overhead transmitters to bounce signals off sensors on windshields or elsewhere on the front of the vehicle. Computers would debit drivers' accounts, and vehicles would not have to reduce speed.
Mr. Yaro said such an approach, called market pricing, reflected the true public cost of using roads and was similar to telephone or utility rates that varied according to the time of day. "What we use now," he said, "is the old Soviet bread-line approach -- get to the end of the line."
"We are not asking people to throw away their car keys," Mr. Yaro added. "We are simply suggesting that for trips to congested places during peak hours you need to give people alternatives."
The plan predicted a 700 percent increase in the number of employees who work at home, using computers, rather than commuting to central offices.
Mr. Yaro said it was unclear whether such a trend would mean less road congestion or have other unexpected effects. "Nobody really knows what the effect of computers and the Internet will be," he said. "It could be larger than we expect."
He said congestion that delayed commuters and trucks cost an estimated $6 billion a year in the region.
Toll revenues would go to an infrastructure bank, to assure that they would not be diverted.
Mr. Yaro said an alternative would be a 10-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax. "Quite honestly," he said, "the gasoline tax is the obvious one. Gas is cheaper than Perrier. People wouldn't even notice a 10 percent gas tax."
But some critics have begun to speak out about the long-term plan.
"It flies in the face of current political trends," the president of the Long Island Association, Matthew T. Crosson, said. "At a time when people are complaining about excessive taxes the plan proposes tolls on roadways or a 10-cent gasoline tax. People feel they are overtaxed already. So this is a very heavy lift. Tolls on the Long Island Expressway would be wildly unpopular."
Mr. Crosson said the assessment of the future was overly gloomy but valuable as a wake-up call.
The executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, Lee E. Koppelman, said financing for the $75 billion program was within the grasp of the governing bodies without their having to resort to tolls or new taxes. "Seventy-five billion dollars over 25 years is $3 billion a year," he said. "New York alone has a budget of $66 million. What's $3 billion a year to three states?"
Mr. Koppelman said parts of the plan that dealt with Long Island were "the same thing we have been saying and doing for years."
"The importance of the plan is not that there are new ideas," he said. "What they are really saying is that if the Northeast doesn't make investments in infrastructure we are going to be in trouble."
The plan proposed new rail links to provide a "seamless" regional passenger system and expanding freight service. Such steps might include connections for Long Island Rail Road passenger service to Grand Central Terminal, the phasing out of changes at Jamaica, a rail line from Jamaica to Kennedy International Airport and connecting the Port Washington line to the subway tunnel at 63d Street in Manhattan. That line might offer service from 57th Street to downtown, including City Hall and the World Trade Center.
The West Hempstead and Oyster Bay lines would be converted to a Cross-Nassau Light Rail operation,"to provide higher degree of access along a north-south spine through Nassau County."
The proposals for freight include a tunnel between New Jersey and Long Island or a tunnel from New Jersey under Manhattan to Long Island. The plan also suggested examining an increase in freight movements over the Hell Gate Bridge in Astoria.
Long Island would also have "double-stack" container trains.
"There has been a revolution in freight movement in this country," Mr. Yaro said. "Nationally 40 percent of freight is moved by rail."
But the revolution ended at the Hudson River, he said, because of a lack of crossings and because "the Long Island Rail Road is not well connected to the national freight system."
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is pursuing the sale of the L.I.R.R. freight service to a private operator. The railroad cut back on efforts to expand freight service after having suffered financial losses.
The plan is the third by the Regional Plan Association. The group issued its first in 1929, a study that recommended major roads and other public works to accommodate growth outward from the city.
The 1996 effort envisions revitalizing downtown areas like Hicksville and Mineola, refocusing commercial and residential cores near railroad lines and "filling in" decentralized and more recently developed areas like Hauppauge to create full-service regional centers.
The new centers would reduce the average seven car trips that Long Island drivers make daily to shop, go to work, attend school and perform other tasks. The plan calls for educational changes and job training to groom a work force "with the skills demanded by an information-based economy" and to "allow low-skilled, minority and immigrant workers to fully participate on the mainstream economy."
Changes in local governments and regional authorities are required, the group said, to build and manage "a world-class infrastructure," cut regulations and taxes and focus on regional, not purely local, needs.
A globally competitive economy fueled by public investment, a protected environment that offers recreational and amenities and social equity among ethnic groups and income groups would be the foundation for quality of life.
The plan defines the region as 31 counties in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, with 20 million people and a $500 billion annual economy.
The region, the association said, has to function as an aggregate to take advantage of its immense wealth and global significance, and the report added that studies showed that regions suffered when cities in their midst declined.
"Economists," the study said, "recognize that metropolitan regions -- not cities, not suburbs, not even countries -- are the building blocks of the 21st century and that regions that will thrive are regions that have strong centers, as well as healthy suburbs."
Noting that employment in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut region increased 8 percent from 1982 to 1992, as compared to 46 percent in the Seattle-Tacoma and Atlanta areas, the report said:
"The question posed is whether the next 25 years will represent the final chapter in the period of prosperity and momentum that dates to the settlement of Manhattan in the 17th century. The warning is that modest growth in the next few years could mask the beginning of a long, slow and potentially irreversible and tragic decline."
Long Island lost 93,000 jobs from 1988 to 1992, according to the State Labor Department. The diminishing military industries in the recession, coinciding with the end of the cold war, accounted for many losses, planners and economists have said.
The plan proposed steps that many competitors have already taken, Mr. Yaro said. "Virtually all of the recommendations in this plan," he added, "are being implemented in one way or another from Atlanta to Los Angeles to Tokyo to London."
Mr. Yaro, who often visits his father in Southold, said efforts to preserve greenswards on Long Islandwere close to his heart. "I watched this island get paved," he said. "So much of it has been destroyed. And yet so much of it is still here."

HEADLINE: Longer Perspectives on the Moses Epoch

BYLINE: By ELLEN KIRSCHNER POPPER 

 BODY:
USING drawings, models, photographs and original artifacts, many of them never displayed, an exhibition at the Museums of Stony Brook, "Robert Moses and the Shaping of New York," chronicles the life and work of the man who had a profound influence on Long Island life.
Master Builder, or Power Broker? as Robert Caro called him in his Pulitzer Prize-winning biography. 
 Those born after 1967, when Moses' power began to wane, probably do not have much awareness of his influence.
"I was kind of surprised, but people under 35 don't even know who Robert Moses was," said the chief curator, William Ayres, who developed the exhibition with Alison Cornish, director of the Bridgehampton Historical Society.
To complement the show, which is on view through May 12, a symposium of architects, planners, scholars and others will convene on Saturday in Stony Brook to discuss "Robert Moses: The Long Island Legacy.
The conference is being held at a time when planners contend that unless priorities shift toward improving public transportation and preserving open space, the New York metropolitan region may suffer crippling economic decline.
Critics fault Moses for neglecting to provide for public transportation. Defenders credit him with creating Long Island's spacious public beaches and parks.
Mr. Ayres said he hoped that the conference would "encourage meaningful, respectful and thoughtful dialogue about the issues."
"There are people who think Robert Moses was God, especially older people and people who might have worked with him or known him in some way," Mr. Ayres added. "Then you get other people who think he was a demon. Hopefully these people will at least listen to the other side."
In his 50-year career Moses held 14 state, regional and city offices, some concurrently. He built parks and playgrounds, beaches and bridges, highways and housing.
Mr. Ayres said he conceived of the exhibition while working with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on an exhibition about art in the subway. "I stumbled on Robert Moses artifacts that had never seen the light of day," he recounted. "Some wonderful renderings of proposals that the T.B.T.A. had are in this show."
The M.T.A. administers the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, an agency that Moses created.
Mr. Ayres asked Ms. Cornish, who was recently curator of a show about historic beaches of Long Island, to assist him.
The display includes objects like a wood-and-canvas beach chair and an umbrella in the signature green-and-orange stripes of Jones Beach and Moses' signature felt fedora.
It was as president of the Long Island State Park Commission, a post he held from 1924 to 1963, that Moses exerted his greatest influence on the local landscape.
From that tenure stems the legacy of Jones Beach, Heckscher State Park, Sunken Meadow State Park and a scenic network of winding parkways -- the Northern State, the Southern State, the Wantagh and the Meadowbrook -- that connect the parks.
Some critics contend that his work on Long Island also produced one of its most pressing problems, perpetual gridlock on the roadways that were at the core of his designs.
"For mass transportation, Robert Moses had a complete and utter disregard and disdain," Mr. Ayres said. "When he talked about subways his face would go into an absolute sneer."
The failure to plan for public transportation is a major weakness of Moses' work on the Island, said Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. "However," Mr. Koppelman said, "whether one would fault Moses for that -- when I look across the country, post-Henry Ford, this country had such a massive love affair with the automobile that I don't know if you could fault Moses. He was just reflecting the public policy from the national Government on down."
Mr. Koppelman is one of five speakers at the conference who will place Moses in a broad historical and cultural context. "When I grew up, Moses was like the second coming of Moses," said Mr. Koppelman, who both in his current post and also as director of the Suffolk County Planning Commission worked closely with Moses from 1960 until Moses officially resigned and then informally until Moses' death in 1981.
"In 1960 my first relations were when Moses put through the New York State Land Acquisition Bond Act," Mr. Koppelman said. "I prepared the plan for Suffolk County and worked very closely with him and his staff. And Suffolk County got the lion's share of the money allocated for all the counties of the State of New York, thanks to Moses."
Even Moses' harshest critics consider Jones Beach, which opened on Aug. 4, 1929, to be one of his finest achievements. But by today's environmental standards, the park destroyed precious natural wetlands.
"It's unfair to criticize him for that," said R. Marc Fasanella, assistant professor of graphic design and visual communication at Southampton College who will speak on "Moses, Jones Beach and Ecology."
. "Radical environmentalism didn't exist then." Instead, the country was in the grip of a "machine mentality."
Moses dredged the bays and dumped 14 feet of sand on top of the existing beach to prevent washouts, Mr. Fasanella said, adding: "Jones Beach is not a natural landscape. It looks natural, but it is man-made. Moses obliterated the natural landscape, but he kept it public."
The alternative, Mr. Fasanella said, would have been unchecked development similar to that in Long Beach. In the design of the bathhouses and pavilions Moses promoted "the quality of architecture that we should be striving for today," Mr. Fasanella said, commenting: "By current ecological standards Jones Beach is an abomination. But by the standards of his time it was progressive. We have to judge him according to the conservation concepts of his time."
John Kriskiewicz, a lecturer at the School of Professional Studies at the Cooper Union in Manhattan, will discuss "Long Island's Historic Parkways: Past, Present and Future." His talk will focus on the genesis and execution of the parkway idea.
"Moses conceived of the parkway not just as a means to get from point A to point B, but as a linear park," Mr. Kriskiewicz said. He plans to showcase "the designers whose work we enjoy every day but don't even know their names."
They include landscape architects like Gilmore D. Clarke and Clarence Coombs and architects like Herbert Magoon.
"Other areas that suburbanized during the same period have the same problems with the roadways," Mr. Kriskiewicz said, "but they don't have the things that the parkways did give. The parkways did preserve the feeling on Long Island of a rustic, rural simplicity. I often say that without the Long Island parkways Long Island would be New Jersey."
Peter R. Bales, a history professor at C. W. Post, said, "I'll be talking about one of Moses' rare failures," a plan to build a bridge between Oyster Bay and Rye in Westchester County.
"It was supposed to be the crown jewel of his construction projects," Professor Bales said. "But community opposition and changing times made it impossible to do. The days when someone like Robert Moses could have enough power just to build where he wanted to build -- those days were gone."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Port Richmond, S.I.;
Eclectic Housing, Traditional Diversity

BYLINE: By JANICE FIORAVANTE 

 BODY:
PORT RICHMOND is but a country village now . . . A trolley runs along the shore and one runs up [Port] Richmond Ave. . . . Standing in front of this building there are 18 houses in sight."
This excerpt of a note written by 19-year-old Edmund Joseph Nolan in 1904 was found in a citrate of magnesia bottle when the back wall of the Port Richmond Library was torn down to expand the structure in 1938 as a W.P.A. project. (The project also included the recently refurbished Faber Park Pool just north of the library). The letter is exhibited to commemorate the library's 90th year. 
 The description remains accurate regarding Port Richmond's location on Staten Island -- abutting the Kill van Kull on the North Shore.
But today a visitor sees many more houses, several churches, a park, a school and a senior-housing center surrounding the library, and the Martin Luther King Expressway off the Bayonne Bridge defining its western border. Buses have replaced trolleys, but the village square design is preserved.
And so is much of the housing stock. "More than 50 percent was built prior to 1938," said Kathleen Bielsa, housing development coordinator of the Northfield Community Local Development Corporation. Such architectural styles as Italianate, colonial, Victorian, Second Empire, Gothic Revival and urban rowhouse are represented.
The corporation is helping residents take their first steps toward defining some of the area as a historic district, meeting with the borough's Preservation League. The corporation's first forays into historic preservation were quite successful; the senior residence is housed in a former public school building.
The reclamation of this 1891 building, which the Board of Education had abandoned and the city had condemned, began with its becoming a city landmark. The name of the 43-unit Parkside Senior Apartments refers to its proximity to the village square's Veterans Memorial Park.
"I took a tour in the area with the New York City Housing Preservation and Development Corporation, and they were amazed that every block has housing representing different eras from historical to recently built," Mrs. Bielsa said.
The community's commercial strip, Port Richmond Avenue, specializes in home improvement, with such stores as Antique Brass Works and Enjo Architectural Mill as well as cabinet makers, furniture, lumber and home-decorating establishments.
"These stores cater to personalized needs with customized products," said Michael Accornero, vice president of the Port Richmond Board of Trade and owner of Community Hardware.
This focus on serving merchandising niches is hard won for merchants here; before the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge or the mall were built, Port Richmond Avenue was considered the Fifth Avenue of Staten Island.
The Staten Island Mall's location at the gateway of the island's South Shore signaled a shift in population. With housing developments rising in the middle and south end of Staten Island and the declining interest in downtown shopping avenues, Port Richmond saw stores move away or close.
But the area came back with large strip centers, anchored by Pathmark and Waldbaum's supermarkets.
Along the southern boundary of Port Richmond, residents refer to the stores as Port Richmond Center or Forest Avenue Shoppers' Town.
There are many fast-food outlets to satisfy the busy shoppers in the strip centers. But for leisurely dining, perhaps the best-known restaurant is Gene's, serving Italian cusine.
And in the summertime, Ralph's Famous Ices at Port Richmond Avenue and Catherine Street is a mecca for those wanting to beat the heat.
CONVENIENT stores and lower house prices -- about 20 percent less than the south shore's mostly newer stock -- have attracted younger families to the neighborhood. Rachel Gannon, who owns Rachel Gannon Realty, said young families from the South Shore were leaving town houses with no storage space and looking for detached houses with yards. "Single-family detached homes predominate, with two-families and a few semidetached newer homes in spots," she said.
Single-family houses can cost from a low of $79,000 for a "fixer-upper," according to Mrs. Gannon, to as high as $225,000 for "a big Tudor."
Single-family houses now listed or recently sold, said Patricia Turvey Dellomo, owner of Turvey Dellomo Associates, range from $130,000 to $162,000, with two-family houses at $150,000 to $189,000.
These prices are attracting city employees like firefighters and sanitation workers. "They're in their price range," said Mr. Accornero, noting that a fireman and two sanitation workers and their families had moved to his block.
This is reversing the declines of the 60's, 70's and 80's, which hit their nadir 5 to 10 years ago when schools were shutting down because of a lack of students.
Public School 20 abandoned its old building for a new one. St. Mary's of the Assumption Roman Catholic School saw its population plummet from 268 in 1973 to 78 in 1988 and in 1989 the building was converted to an early childhood center for 3- and 4-year-olds. But St. Roch's Catholic School held on and still serves students from kindergarten to fifth grade.
Now grade schools have to cope with crowding.
Cheryl Accornero, Michael's wife, is president of the Parents Association for P.S. 21, which Amanda, 10, and Justin, 7, attend. "When Amanda was in kindergarten, the school's population was 250 and now it's 435," she said.
The school is scheduled to receive prefabricated buildings for September and is considering leasing a Montessori school two blocks away.
ALL the children at our school walk to school -- there's no busing -- so we want to keep kids close," Mrs. Accornero added.
The Accorneros live at 54 Homestead Avenue in a three-bedroom colonial with a frontyard and a backyard for children to play in. "But we also like to use the playground behind I.S. 51," Mrs. Accornero noted.
Intermediate School 51, with 1,200 students, has one computer lab with 33 computers and a computer in the library for research.
"We're getting a second computer room in September, increasing the total to 67," said the principal, Arnold Raffone.
Port Richmond High School added a wing, which opened two years ago, and has been renovating the rest of the school, replacing stairways, tiles, the auditorium, gym and classrooms, even adding new paint to match the new wing, said Robert Mathews, president of the school's alumni association and a former teacher who taught there for 30 years. The school opened in 1928.
"We're in the last phase -- the school will be finished in September," said Charles Appelblatt, the assistant principal. That opening will show off the school's television production studio, robotics lab and universal weight room.
"I'm a great believer in public education and I'm delighted that my children are growing up with Mexicans, Albanians, African-Americans, Asians and Indians," Mrs. Accornero said. The ethnic diversity of the schools reflects the neighborhood's.
Ninety percent of Port Richmond High's graduates go on to college.
Newer immigrants have been attracted to the area by rentals in its older four- and five-story walk-ups as well as by cottage-style one-family homes.
The newcomers follow an earlier influx of Scandinavians who were drawn to the community as shipbuilders during World War I. By the early 30's, many shipyards were forced to close and some Scandinavians returned home. In the 30's, the neighborhood library, referred to locally as the Port Richmond League of Nations, added collections in Norwegian, German, Spanish, Polish and Italian.
In 1937, the Directory of New York State Manufacturers listed 34 medium and large concerns in the Port Richmond area. And by 1942, the shipyards were back, working 24-hour shifts, before their demise in the 50's.
The Scandinavian Lutheran Zion Church, which was built in 1921, was sold in 1966 to become the St. Phillips Baptist Church, with a predominantly black congregation. The area's other houses of worship include Temple Emanu-el, built in 1907, and the Reformed Church, built by the Dutch in 1715, destroyed by fire during the Revolutionary War and rebuilt in 1787. The current structure is its third, built in 1844. Its burial ground dates to 1704.
"This is an area that doesn't give up," said Joan Catalano, executive director of the development corporation."There's lots of community spirit -- it's a community working together." Arthur Cappabianca, the president of the Decker Avenue Civic Association, which was started in 1948, agreed, adding:
"Everybody knows everybody and knows that, if they have a problem, we're just a phone call away."
