HEADLINE: The Continuing Fallout Of Business Downsizing

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
FORECASTS for Connecticut's economy have been as chilly as a gale in winter, with economists anticipating that most areas will be suffering for another year. And economic indicators are only part of the picture. A recent study reveals worsening social problems in the state and a gloomy attitude about the future.
"There's a conspiracy of silence about the real issues affecting people in Connecticut. The decline in social health is greater in the state than it is in the nation," said Marc Miringoff, director of the Fordham Institute for Innovation in Social Policy and author of a report entitled "The Social State of Connecticut '95." 
 The report, commissioned by the General Assembly as a guide for shaping public policy, contains results of a study of the state's quality of life. Indicators like unemployment, wages, health care costs, child abuse and adolescent suicide were used to evaluate social health.
State Representative Patricia Widlitz, a member of the Legislature's Planning and Development Committee, disagreed with Mr. Miringoff's "conspiracy of silence" view.
"I'm not aware of any silence out there," she said. "People are painfully aware of what's happening to things like their health care, which they can no longer take for granted." But, she said, middle-class people have certainly been hit hard by shifting economic forces.
The bright spot, it is agreed, is small business, largely service and information industries, but sometimes farming and related operations, which are attempting to diversify.
Many residents surveyed in the study said their standard of living had worsened substantially, and they expected it to continue deteriorating or stay the same over the next five years. The study found improvement in four categories: infant mortality, teen-age parenthood, average weekly wages and affordable housing. But there were problems in seven other areas: child abuse, adolescent suicide, high school completion, unemployment, health care costs, violent crime and the gap between rich and poor. The study also made the following points.
* Workers face the prospect of stagnating incomes. Though manufacturing wages have risen, manufacturing business has dwindled and is hiring fewer workers. The service sector, where wages are lower, has taken on a steadily growing proportion of the work force since 1970.
* The average per capita cost for hospital care, physician services and prescription drugs has risen from 4.8 percent of per capita income in 1970 to 8.1 percent today.
* The number of people without health insurance rose sharply -- from 9.7 percent of the state's population in 1992 to 12 percent in 1993.
* While the housing market has improved, rental costs remain high. The average monthly rent for a two-bedroom apartment in 1994 was $793, which represents 111.4 percent of minimum-wage pay. Connecticut ranked second highest, behind only Hawaii, in rental costs compared to income.
* The gap between rich and poor is widening, with the difference in personal income between the poorest and richest counties increasing sharply between 1992 and 1993.
There was a connection between the state's economic growth and social health between 1959 and 1973. But a new pattern emerged between 1973 and the present, said Mr. Miringoff. The gross domestic product continues to rise, but social health drops. The greatest distance between economic growth and social health occurred in 1994.
"An encouraging economic forecast doesn't necessarily mean the quality of life increases," Mr. Miringoff said. "You have economic recovery in the numbers, but it's not lifting the quality of life as it once did. This has to be heard by sympathetic ears in the corridors of power. There has to be public recognition of the true condition and a public voice."
The study recommends adoption of a law requiring a council of social policy advisors to the governor, an annual report on the social health of the state and a committee of the General Assembly to conduct hearings on the report.
A bill requiring an annual report on social conditions in Connecticut as well as the council of advisors and the hearings was introduced last year; the bill passed the House but died in the Senate. The Human Services Committee expects to approve the bill again in the current legislative session, said State Representative Christel Truglia, a committee member.
Ms. Truglia said she was not surprised by the report's findings. "I think we are aware of it every day, although we need to be accountable to the public," she said. "A report is one way to do that and to evaluate funding and priorities."
By last October, Connecticut had regained only about 20 percent of the jobs lost during the recession. Other New England states have gained back 40 percent to 140 percent of jobs lost, said Donald Klepper-Smith, a corporate economist for Southern New England Telecommunications.
One reason for the state's slow recovery, he added, is that its industries, including insurance and military contractors, have been particularly vulnerable to continued downsizings and mergers. Another reason is that business costs, which have the greatest influence on job growth, have been nearly 10 percent higher than the national average for the last decade.
In 1993, the study showed, 32.4 percent of the unemployed were out of work for more than 27 weeks. That figure is lower than in 1992 but far higher than in the past. This situation forces more people to accept part-time work because they cannot find full-time positions. In 1993, 26.8 percent of the part-time work force consisted of people who would have preferred full-time jobs. The result is a less stable work force and more insecurity for employees.
Economists say they expect small businesses to play a major role in reviving the state's economy. Over the last three years, small businesses accounted for 86 percent of new, nongovernment employment, Mr. Klepper-Smith said. Most of the growth is in retail and services, as Connecticut shifts from traditional types of manufacturing toward a service- and information-based economy.
But the state lacks an overall strategy for moving the economy forward, said John Carson, president of the Connecticut Policy and Economic Council, a nonpartisan, nonprofit organization that supports various studies. "There's a malaise that has to be broken," he said. "We haven't united behind a leader who will say, 'Enough of this. We're going to put the best heads together and come up with a game plan.' "
Lawmakers fail to focus on ways of dealing with social trends, said State Representative Jefferson Davis, House chair of the Legislature's Planning and Development Committee. "Everybody develops his own narrow political agenda. There aren't that many interested in the total picture."
Mr. Davis said a distance exists among people in general. "They're concerned about their lives and jobs and how to protect what they have.
"It's hard to attract them to a debate about what's happening as a whole."

HEADLINE: 'Portraits in Words' Chosen For Museum Lecture Series

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

 BODY:
EVERY two years the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College offers thematically twinned programs that bring acclaimed speakers to the county. This year, the Yaseen Lecture Series, as the programs are called, will address the topic "Portraits in Words and Images." The painter Chuck Close will speak today at 2 P.M., and the Pulitzer Prize-winning author Doris Kearns Goodwin will speak next Sunday at 2 P.M.
Both lectures will be held in the college's Performing Arts Center. Tickets range from $10 to $18 for the series and from $6.50 to $9 for a single lecture. Tickets may be ordered by calling the Performing Arts Center box office at 251-6200. 
 The Yaseen lectures, which began in 1974, have explored other themes like creativity, futurism, the nature of time and "culture watching." The talks were endowed by the late Leonard C. Yaseen and his wife, Helen, residents of Larchmont who financed a similar series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Patricia Greenhill, manager of marketing and communications at the Neuberger, said the museum wanted to recall the family behind the name. She said endowments like theirs were increasingly necessary today, when cultural groups can no longer count on funds from the National Endowment for the Arts and other agencies. "This may be the only way to get things done now in the arts," she said.
Barbara Yaseen Tiffany, the couple's daughter, described her father as "a very creative man" who essentially invented a new field after the Depression: that of recommending new factory sites to manufacturing companies. "He changed the entire economic geography of the country," she said. "He moved industry out of the North and into the South. He was very innovative."
Ms. Tiffany, a furniture designer who lives in Philadelphia, said her mother's passion for art influenced her father to become involved. He helped begin Friends of the Neuberger Museum of Art, an advisory board, and became the group's first president. "My parents really wanted to do something for the community that would be ongoing," Ms. Tiffany said. "Their vision was toward lectures that would stretch the imagination and that otherwise wouldn't be offered."
Mr. Close, a leading art figure, is known for his large-scale portraits, which that have been executed with grids. Ms. Goodwin is the author of "No Ordinary Time: Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt," for which she won the Pulitzer Prize, "The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys" and "Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream." She will discuss the qualities that make a leader successful.
For more information about the series, the number to call at the Neuberger Museum is 251-6100. ROBERTA HERSHENSON

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
A Leaner Army Leaves a Town Behind

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
TWO miles up the road is a sprawling military base with a budget of more than $1 billion, where 4,750 people come to work every day. But you don't see much indication of this on the main streets of Dover, a blue-collar town left behind in an increasingly white-collar military economy.
Welcome to the forlorn outskirts of today's military-post-industrial complex. In a small town like Dover, which borders the 6,500-acre Picatinny Arsenal in Morris County, the issue of military jobs has largely gone the way of the battleship-gun shells that once were manufactured in Picatinny's shops. 
 "During the 60's and 70's, this town was alive with people who had arsenal jobs," said Anthony Negri, a barber who has been cutting hair in Dover since the end of World War II. "Now, they could shut the arsenal down tomorrow. It wouldn't make a difference."
"The arsenal used to be the major local employer, but that's a long time ago," said Rob Barth, a local graphics designer who had stopped by Mr. Negri's quiet shop to chat. Though his father retired from Picatinny, few people in today's hard-pressed Dover find work there, despite its proximity, Mr. Barth said.
"They're not much into manufacturing anymore," Mr. Negri said.
"Which means you don't need as many hands," Mr. Barth added.
Mr. Barth had chosen his word precisely: hands. The changes that have occurred at Picatinny Arsenal, which has an annual payroll of $280 million, are remarkably like those that have transformed the economy of northwestern New Jersey in the past 15 years.
Manufacturing and other blue-collar jobs disappeared, while new industries hired technicians and scientists and the small-town work force expanded into a region linked by new highways. Today, only about 1,700 of the civilian employees at the arsenal even live in Morris County. (The base has about 100 military personnel.)
And now, in step with the rest of the region, layoffs are on the way. "Sometime within the next 30 days, we are anticipating issuing layoff letters to about 200 employees," said Peter Rowland, a spokesman for the arsenal.
The long-rumored cuts will be across the board, he said. But civil service unions anticipate that clerical, service and maintenance workers will be most affected.
Even more than in the civilian economy, defense layoffs always kick up a furor. As Americans try to arrive at some consensus on how much of a shrinking national budget to devote to the Pentagon, the debate invariably gets sidetracked into the deep political quagmire of jobs. "Both the Administration and Congress increasingly view defense as a Federal jobs program," Lawrence J. Korb, of the Brookings Institution, wrote recently in the policy journal Foreign Affairs.
United States military spending is now about $260 billion annually, and projected to rise while spending on discretionary domestic programs goes down. Last year, all other NATO members combined spent $150 billion on the military, and the Russians spent $80 billion, Mr. Korb said.
At Picatinny, about half the employees now are scientists, engineers and technicians. Most work on major military contracts, some of which are developing high-tech weapons for the global arms market, as well as products for the civilian sector.
"There's a lot of brainpower at work here," said Representative Rodney P. Frelinghuysen, a Republican whose district includes the arsenal. Representative Marge S. Roukema, the Ridgewood Republican who has been a major defender of Picatinny during the recent Pentagon base closings, also extolled the arsenal's "unique collection of research and engineering skills."
Now that the base is losing only a few hundred jobs, there's also a lot of talk at Picatinny of things like facing tough challenges in a global economy.
The military commander, Brig. Gen. James W. Boddie Jr., recently set up a new office to "focus on marketing Picatinny Arsenal and sell its products and services." The base newspaper, The Voice, described the effort as "an extremely broad-marketing campaign using advertising, public relations as well as the World Wide Web" to expand the world market for the arsenal.
It shouldn't be a surprise, then, when a military economy starts behaving like the civilian economy, and the layoff notices go out to beef up the bottom line. As Mr. Negri, the barber in nearby Dover, said with a shrug, "It's just a business."

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 12; Column 4; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 815 words

HEADLINE: Growth When Resources Are Slim

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
MICHAEL AND DALE SMYTH didn't let a bad economy prevent them from fulfilling their dream. After years of dairy farming, Mr. and Mrs. Smyth have established an independent dairy. They own and operate Trinity Farm in Enfield, one of only seven farms in the state that process, bottle and sell their own milk.
Mr. Smyth said he took advantage of a new market that grew out of recent publicity about dairy cows injected with artificial growth hormones. "People are becoming concerned about what they're feeding their kids and are looking for something healthy," he said. 
 Customers arrive at Trinity Farm carrying their own jugs in which to take home what the Smyths' 40 Holsteins have produced. Some 15 specialty grocery stores and several independent food markets have begun carrying Trinity Farm's products, which include whole milk, raw milk, low fat and skim milk, chocolate milk and heavy cream.
Mr. Smyth, who is 47, grew up on his grandfather's dairy farm in Enfield. He recalled that his grandfather, who started the farm in 1912, delivered milk in a horse-drawn wagon. "In the early 1920's, he was one of the first to pasteurize his milk," said Mr. Smyth. "All the local doctors told their patients to buy their milk from him."
Mr. Smyth's father took over the farm in 1950. At the peak of its operation, the dairy delivered milk to 2,000 homes and employed 15 men. After graduating from the University of Connecticut in 1970, Mr. Smyth was ready to take over. But the demand for home-delivered milk was dying out, and small farms were not able to compete with the low prices offered at supermarkets.
His father sold the property in 1974, and Mr. Smyth went to work at other farms in the area. "I had my own business in mind, but I wanted to make sure I had all my skills," he said. He started Trinity Farm in 1984 on another piece of land belonging to his family. He has put up four buildings on the property since then and is able to produce 10,000 quarts of milk a week.
Mr. Smyth found that he was not generating enough income with traditional marketing methods -- selling milk in bulk -- and began looking for financing that would enable him to process, bottle and market some of the milk himself, he said. He applied for loans from agricultural lenders, commercial banks and state agencies. But banks, battered by losses during the recession, were unwilling to take a chance on a new agricultural business. And there was no state financing available.
"The frustration was terrible," Mr. Smyth said. "It puts a lot of stress on the people operating the farms."
Finally, Mr. Smyth found a private investor willing to finance his venture. "The investor looked at the plan and had faith in what Mike was doing," said Francis Barillaro, a business consultant who handles Trinity Farm's financial and marketing operations. "The investor thought it was a risk worth taking, and he felt that Mike would see the project through."
Trinity Farm's new business is only about two months old. "It's been painstaking, but I'm very encouraged by what I see," Mr. Smyth said.
The work is backbreaking, and the rewards do not always seem equal to a day that starts at 5 A.M., when he milks and feeds the cows, and usually ends around 6 P.M.
The Smyths' five children -- Bridget, 24; Daniel, 23; Anne, 17; Peter, 11, and Samuel, 6 -- help out with the chores. And there is a part-time farm hand in the afternoon. Mrs. Smyth, who is expecting their sixth child in September, provides home schooling to Anne, Peter and Samuel.
Among the older children, Daniel is learning to operate the processing plant on the farm, where the milk is pasteurized and bottled. Anne, who plans to enter the animal science program at the University of Connecticut after high school, is raising Suffolk sheep and dairy cows. Peter delivers milk to a dozen regular customers at $1.75 for a half gallon and cares for a team of work steers, which he enters in competitions at local fairs.
"We're trying to make something worthwhile for them to do," Mr. Smyth said. "We certainly won't pay for this in my lifetime."
Promoting Trinity Farm's products has become as important as the farm work, said Mr. Smyth, who adds that he hopes the business will break even after the first year. "We have financing, a plant and good cows," he said. "Now, we have to convince people this is an exciting product."
To encourage new customers, Mr. Smyth drops samples off at food stores and is setting up a dairy counter in one of the buildings on the farm. Dairy farmers recognize the need to diversify in order to survive, he said. Some are opening dairy stores. Others are interested in making cheese or raising crops.
Oddly enough, he said, "Thirty years ago, a dairy like Trinity Farm wouldn't have survived. But now there's a niche of people who will pay extra to have you deliver that glass bottle."

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

MAPLE SUGARING
Teatown Lake Reservation in Ossining has sweetened its maple-sugaring program this year with a dollop of personalization. People who sign up for the program, called rent-a-bucket, will have a sap bucket tagged with their family name and receive a map directing them to its location. 
 Bucket renters may visit during sugaring season to keep tabs on the amount of accumulated sap and watch the process of moving it to the sugar house and turning it into syrup. At the end of the season each bucketeer will receive an eight-ounce bottle of Teatown Grade A Maple Syrup and two tickets to the yearly pancake brunch on March 30. The fee is $30.
Syrup-making demonstrations are open to them and the public today and next Sunday at 1, 2, and 3 P.M.
Those who wish to attend the all-you-can-eat pancake brunch may reserve space at 8:30, 9:45 and 11 A.M. and 12:15 P.M.
Tickets are $7, $4 for children younger than 12. The number to call for reservations or more information is 762-2912. The Teatown Nature Preserve and Education Center is on Spring Valley Road.
 
MUSIC OF BLACKS
A family concert at the Pelham Art Center today at 3 P.M. will trace the history of black music. It will be performed by Vishnu Wood, bassist, and his ensemble of jazz musicians, whose programs are offered under the banner of Mr. Wood's Safari East Cultural Presentations.
New Orleans jazz, the call and response of Southern field workers, the blues and the Caribbean beat make up the four categories covered, along with the instruments used in each. The audience will be invited to join in demonstrations of various rhythms, melodic lines, harmonies and improvisation techniques related to each category. Tickets are $7, $5 for students. Call 738-2525 for reservations or more information. The center is at 155 Fifth Avenue.
 
MIDEAST PANEL
Three scholars who have studied the Middle East will take part in a colloquium on "Muslims, Jews, Christians: Roots of Intolerance" at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers on Tuesday at 4 P.M. Free and open to the public, it will be held in the Francis Ann Cannon Theater. Dr. Bernard Lewis, professor of Near Eastern Studies at Princeton University, will open the proceeding with a talk about "Prospects for Discord and Concord in the Mideast." Dr. Lewis received his bachelor's degree and doctorate at the University of London, and he holds nine honorary doctorates.
His most recent book, "The Middle East: 2000 Years of History From the Rise of Christianity to the Present Day," will be published in May by Simon & Schuster.
"Possibilities for Reform and Liberalization in Islam" will be the topic of Prof. Yvonne Yazbeck Haddad from the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Taught at the Beirut College for Women, Dr. Haddad earned advanced degrees from the University of Wisconsin and Boston University and a doctorate from the Hartford Seminary.
The third speaker, Prof. Fawaz A. Gerges, is a faculty member at Sarah Lawrence. He received his master's degree from the London School of Economics and his doctorate from Oxford University. He and Dr. Haddad are published authors of books on Mideastern values and policies and relations between Mideast countries and the West.
Melvin Jules Bukiet, who teaches writing at the college, will close the program with a reading from his own short stories, a collection of which won the 1992 Edward Lewis Wallant Award for best Jewish-American fiction.
Another program at Sarah Lawrence will take place tomorrow at 5:30 P.M. in Titsworth Lecture Hall, when Kathryn Kish Sklar, a professor of history at SUNY Binghamton, will speak on "The Political Culture of Reform in the U.S. Women's Suffrage Movement, 1900-1920." Dr. Sklar has received 20 fellowships and grants, written many articles and three books on women's rights and political development and served on the editorial boards of American Quarterly, Journal of American History and Ms. magazine.
For more information on either program, call 395-2411.
 
KISS OF THE SPIDER
That nasty, fuzzy little creature called the tarantula, whose bite inspired the frenetic movements of the tarantella, is the basis for I Giullari di Piazza's newest production, "The Dance of the Ancient Spider," to be performed on Saturday at 8 P.M. at Caramoor in Katonah.
Apparently the only troupe in the country dedicated to reviving traditional Italian music, dance and theater, I Giullari creates its own productions and music, using indigenous instruments including the mandoloncello, oud, chitarra battente (Renaissance guitar), Italian bagpipe, shawn and a variety of drums.
"The Dance of the Ancient Spider," in which young girls are possessed by the spider, then exorcized, had its premiere at Lincoln Center last year. Tickets at $12.50 can be reserved by calling 232-1252.
 
'SOUTH AFRICA TODAY'
Waldemar Zastrau, Deputy Consul General of the South African Consulate, will give a free talk on "South Africa Today: Changes, Comparisons and Challenges," tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. at the Rye Y.M.C.A., 21 Locust Avenue.
Over the last two decades Mr. Zastrau has represented South Africa's Department of Foreign Affairs in Rhodesia, Canada and the United States. Call 967-6363 for more details.
 
HISTORY INTO DANCE
Women's History Month will be celebrated at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers today at 1:30 P.M. with a dance drama titled "Fall in Line," performed by the Debra Weiss Dance Company of Nyack, specialists in converting American history into dance idioms.
The story line follows the 72-year effort by American women to get the vote and commemorates the 75th anniversary last year of the 19th Amendment to the Constitution, which gave them that right. The title was taken from a ragtime march composed by Zena Hawn, a New York suffragist.
"Niagara," the second number in the program, is an examination of what prompted Annie Taylor in 1901 allegedly to become the first person and the only woman to go over Niagara Falls in a barrel and live to tell about it. She was a schoolteacher who couldn't swim.
Admission is free with museum admission of $3, $1.50 for people 62 and older and children younger than 13.
The museum is at 511 Warburton Avenue, and the phone number for more information is 963-4550.
 
CANCER STRATEGIES
Families and individuals dealing with cancer may find a program at Wainwright House in Rye helpful. Scheduled on Wednesdays from 10 A.M. to noon through May 1, two-hour meetings will offer strategies for handling physical, emotional, nutritional, legal and family questions.
Doctors, nurses, social workers, nutritionists and clergy and cancer survivors will speak on mind-body techniques to control pain, medical issues and other topics for 45 minutes, followed by discussion.
The fee is $15 a session, and participation in the entire program is recommended.
On April 28 at 2:30 P.M. Dr. Bernie Siegel, whose innovative methods of treating cancer by using the mind are well known, will conduct a program at the Greenwich Library. People in the Wainwright program can attend for $20.
For more information, the number to call is 939-1436. ELEANOR CHARLES

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2208 words

HEADLINE: Let Tigers Dance

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

DATELINE: PRINCETON

 BODY:
I WANT to go to Princeton," says Amory Blaine, the young hero of F. Scott Fitzgerald's "This Side of Paradise."
Over the last 250 years those six words have been uttered, one way or another, by everyone from James Madison to John F. Kennedy to Queen Noor of Jordan to Fitzgerald himself, who romanticized Princeton all the more because he flunked out not once but twice. But Amory Blaine would not have had a Princeton to dream about -- and Princeton would not have a 250th anniversary to celebrate this year -- if Yale had not kicked out a divinity student named David Brainerd. 
 Brainerd is not commemorated by a statue, a lecture hall or a dormitory on the campus that Fitzgerald called a "riot of Gothic architecture." Nor was he mentioned at the opening of Princeton's $3 million, 16-month anniverary celebration last month, which included speeches by Princeton's president, Harold T. Shapiro, and Governor Whitman. But Aaron Burr Sr., who stepped in as Princeton's president when it was six months old and struggling, recorded Brainerd's place in history. "If it had not been for the treatment received by Mr. Brainerd at Yale College," Burr wrote, Princeton "never would have been erected."
Brainerd's sin, in Yale's view, was to criticize a professor. His expulsion angered several Presbyterian laymen who believed that Yale had lost its way in the religious and philosophical turbulence that was buffeting the colonies.
In the 1740's they chose the theologian Jonathan Dickinson to lead what they called the College of New Jersey, and they turned Dickinson's parsonage in Elizabeth into the college's first building. The students moved into Burr's parsonage in Newark when Dickinson died before making a third and final move, to Princeton, in 1757.
Not until a century and a half later, long after Princetonians had played in the first intercollegiate basketball and football games and earned their first doctorates, did the university officially change its name to Princeton.
Only Princeton would celebrate its 250th birthday with an 18-letter word, bicenquinquagenary. (Mercifully, it was abbreviated "BCQ" on bottled water served at an alumni lunch last month.) Princeton is looking forward to fireworks in June, the Olympic torch in July, a commemorative postcard in September and what Dr. Shapiro calls "the centerpiece event" in October, marking the 250th anniversary of Princeton's charter.
To mark the occasion, the university has also published a full-color book, "Princeton University: The First 250 Years," written by Don Oberdorfer, who graduated in 1952 and retired as the diplomatic correspondent for The Washington Post. The first half of the 272-page volume focuses on turning points from 1746 to 1946. The second half looks at changes since World War II, including coeducation and the increasing diversity of the student body.
It is a student body that is less preppy than it used to be but no less loyal: some Princetonians pride themselves on never missing a reunion, and an unusually large percentage of graduates contribute to their alma mater. Already, Princetonians have given $12.7 million toward the university's $23 million goal for this year, which is part of a campaign to raise $750 million by the year 2000.
Even at Princeton, though, money is not everything. Among the gifts received in its 250th year is a specially made 130-pound manhole cover, from the Class of 1945.
Another measure of Princetonians' loyalty: they have the only alumni magazine in the country that comes out as often as it does, though not quite so often as its name suggests. The Princeton Alumni Weekly became a biweekly in 1977 and now publishes 17 issues a year, timed to coincide with the academic calendar.
As if a magazine in their mailbox every couple of weeks were not enough, 4,000 alumni have registered for the university's Tigernet on-line service and will soon be assigned permanent Princeton E-mail addresses. Yes, permanent, meaning lifelong. "No matter where they move," said Luther T. Munford, the chairman of the university's Alumni Council, "Princeton will be able to find them."
Of course, the 250th anniversary has a serious side. Woodrow Wilson, who was a politics professor and president of Princeton before he got into politics, coined the term "Princeton in the nation's service" in a speech during Princeton's 150th celebration. For its 250th, the university said it wanted students and alumni to take part in 250 community service projects.
Mr. Munford said 190 such projects had been arranged so far. The Classes of 1976 and 1981, for example, are selling posters to raise money to save endangered tigers and to support Princeton students and professors involved in conservation and environmental research. The Class of 1948 is raising money for a Red Cross disaster vehicle for the Princeton area and encouraging classmates to donate blood.
JAMES MADISON'S undergraduate years (long before coeducation) convinced him that there was "no place so overstocked with old maids as Princeton." Kennedy wrote in his application that "to be a Princeton man is indeed an enviable distinction" but dropped out because of illness. (When he was well enough to go back to school, he enrolled at Harvard.) Queen Noor graduated as Lisa M. Halaby in 1973.
Presidential candidates? Adlai Stevenson graduated in 1922, Steve Forbes in 1970.
Governors? Thomas H. Kean, who graduated in 1953, succeeded Brendan T. Byrne, who graduated in 1949.
Actors and actresses? James Stewart graduated in 1934, Brooke Shields in 1987. Dean Cain, who was a superb safety on the Princeton football team before becoming Superman on "The New Adventures of Lois and Clark," on ABC, graduated in 1988.
And not a Ph.D. in the bunch. Princetonians take pride in their college -- the undergraduate part of the institution. Harvard has a host of graduate schools that are at the same level on the organization chart as its undergraduate college. Yale, too, puts a heavy emphasis on graduate studies, an important magnet for Federal research grants.
But Princeton's Graduate College is separate from the main campus, a second Gothic fortress beyond the fairways of the Springdale County Club. With 1,700 graduate students, Princeton has the smallest graduate enrollment in the Harvard-Yale-Princeton triangle; Harvard has 6,200 and Yale 2,800. Princeton got $77 million for research from the Federal Government in 1994-95, compared to $234 million for Harvard and $198 million for Yale.
But the tradeoffs between faculty research and teaching, and particularly the labor-intensive teaching of undergraduates, are a perennial concern. Charles Gibson, who graduated in 1965 and is a host of "Good Morning America" on ABC-TV, recalls what he learned when he returned to Princeton on a brief fellowship in 1992.
"You eat with students at every meal," he said. "I spent the time asking them what was wrong with Princeton. There were a lot of things said. They did not have exposure to the star faculty. That was the single most disturbing thing to me, and I thought that, in the long run, imperils exactly what is the great strength of the university."
It is a strength university officials are committed to preserving if not improving. "Our strategic planning process emphasized Princeton's determination to be second to none in both the quality of its scholarship and research and in the quality of its teaching programs," said Dr. Shapiro, an economist with a doctorate from Princeton who was president of the University of Michigan before his installation in 1988. "That process identified a need to do a better job of teaching in several areas."
He has sanctioned expanding freshman seminars, developing new ways to teach science and math to non-majors and revising the general education requirements. The university is setting up a $25 million fund "for innovation in undergraduate education," which Dr. Shapiro said would provide "venture capital for new ideas in teaching." It is also earmarking $12 million for four visiting professorships and $13 million to support jobs, programs and equipment at the Center for Teaching and Learning.
In a report recommending the changes, Nancy Malkiel, co-chairwoman of the university's committee on the course of study, said the center would be a kind of oasis "where faculty come together to talk about, devise and test teaching innovations, where graduate students develop their teaching skills, and where undergraduates draw on new technologies and new strategies for effective learning to supplement the work they do in their classes." It will have an expanded language laboratory, a multimedia computer cluster and a writing center with computer work stations.
Ms. Malkiel's committee also recommended changing Princeton's vaunted distribution requirements -- courses undergraduates are required to take -- for the first time since World War I. Courses have been regrouped by content rather than department, and the requirements for liberal-arts students were expanded to include two more courses.
 
WHAT hits me every single day is how beautiful Princeton is," said Abby Durden, a sophomore from Winston-Salem, N.C. Describing her life in Blair Tower, which looms over the middle of the campus with its arch and its steep steps, she said, "It's like living in a castle in some fairy tale."
Princeton is different from urban campuses like Harvard's or Yale's or Columbia's. Until about 15 years ago, when office parks started pressing in from Route 1, Princeton was still pretty much the splendid, isolated stretch of emerald-green fields woods that Fitzgerald remembered from his undergraduate days before World War I.
"Sordid Trenton sweats and festers" only a few miles from the campus, he wrote in a 1927 essay, but Princeton seemed far away, connected by a little shuttle train from the Penn Central's Main Line in Princeton Junction.
It used to be undergraduate folklore that the only reason Princeton had its own train was that the president of Penn Central lived there. The Penn Central is long gone, but the Dinky, as the little train is called, still bounces to a stop at the edge of campus.
But the boundaries have shifted. "Princeton is the area between Trenton and New Brunswick," said David Knights, director of marketing for the Princeton Forrestal Center, a 2,200-acre office and research park on land owned by the university in Plainsboro. "To a real estate person, when you say Princeton, that includes West Windsor, Plainsboro, South Brunswick and Lawrence. Even if it's just the road into Princeton, the real estate guys want to get Princeton into the name."
Of the Forrestal Center's 100 tenants, only one declined a Princeton mailing adddress. Most months there is a waiting list for mailboxes in the post office across Nassau Street from the campus.
From there, a five-minute walk beneath spires and gargoyles leads to Nassau Hall, which at one time was the college: classrooms, dorms, library and all. It quartered troops during the Revolution, and later served as a meeting place for the Continental Congress.
And it was almost christened Belcher Hall.
Gov. Jonathan Belcher, who issued the university's second charter in 1748, said no. "Just imagine if they had called it Belcher Hall," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, who graduated in 1976. "The notion of legions of Princeton graduates ending a school cheer that way would do something magnificent for the university's stuffy reputation."
WHAT became of David Brainerd, whose troubles at Yale led to it all?
He became a missionary, first in the Berkshires and later in Freehold. His influence on the 18th- and 19th-century missionary movement was felt far beyond his own Presbyterians: John Wesley, the founder of Methodism, published an abridged version of his diaries in 1768. Brainerd died in 1747 at the home of Jonathan Edwards, who later became Princeton's third president. Brainerd, who was 29, was engaged to Edwards's daughter.
PRINCETONIANS have long been fascinated by what Fitzgerald called "the enigma that faced you at the end of senior year as to what Princeton was and what . . . it really stood for." A similar question overshadowed Geoffrey Wolff's 1990 novel "The Final Club," which revolved around a Jewish underclassman in the mid-1950's who was rejected by the school's eating clubs.
The concerns remain: the feeling that Princeton is still male-dominated, and still too white. In other words, the old reputation.
The figures suggest that the mix is changing. Princeton had 350 black students in 1979; the number dipped to 270 in 1988 but has climbed to 300 this year. It enrolled 209 Hispanic students in 1980; the figure went as low as 174 in 1988 but has been rising since 1990 and stands at 277 this year. The number of Asian-American students has tripled in the last 15 years, to 474.
"I'm always aware that I'm from Singapore, because of words or idioms I use," said Keith Tan, a junior from Singapore, "but on the other hand, everyone at Princeton has left home; everyone has made a symbolic break by coming here. I think that freshman year, we all experienced the same feelings of homesickness and loneliness."

HEADLINE: PLAYWRIGHTS AND TV;
Fluidity Is The Key

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While I am happy to have been included in Andy Meisler's discussion of theater professionals who also work in television, I worry about the larger assumptions of his article ["When Theater Turns Out to Be Just a Stage," Feb. 4]. The implication that working in television or film means abandoning the theater even temporarily is not true for me and many others. 
 Theater, film and television are all modes of storytelling, and many of us are fortunate enough to move freely among them without feeling that we've "left" or need to "go back" to one or the other. In fact, if the theater is to avoid a "brain drain," this kind of fluidity is increasingly necessary.
I continue to consider myself primarily a playwright. I also write for television and film. These are states that coexist happily. I haven't gone anywhere.
 
THERESA REBECK
Santa Monica, Calif.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
A Co-op Regains the Road to Financial Recovery

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
ONE fall day in 1990 Rebecca Doggett and her husband, Joseph Thomasberger, bought their co-op at Crescent Park, a 266-apartment building in East Orange modeled on the grand Art Deco style of the Fontainebleau Hotel in Miami Beach.
But recent events have been anything but grand for the couple and other residents at the 18-story white brick building on South Harrison Street. For 1990 was also the year that the sponsor defaulted on its mortgage, pushing Crescent Park into a financial free fall and to the brink of foreclosure. 
 Five years and three legal battles later the co-op is on the road to recovery. Its co-op corporation, Crescent Park Owners, has taken over most of the 160 unsold apartments, refinanced the building's mortgage and won $1.3 million in cash settlements, helping it regain fiscal health.
"There was so much to lose," said Ms. Doggett, now president of the co-op board, "not just financially. People love this building and we just refused to give up the fight." There was also the specter of deconverting to a rental, she said, referring to a 197-apartment co-op in East Orange that never recovered and whose residents lost their investments. In co-ops, shareholders must meet an underlying mortgage on their building as well as their home loans and monthly charges. They can lose their investment through their building's foreclosure, while remaining liable on their home loans.
The plan at Crescent Park is to make improvements and rent the vacant apartments, from studios to three-bedroom units, and switch to selling them in the future. That prospect is helped by signs that the co-op market, hard-hit in the real estate recession when values dropped by 40 percent, has rebounded slightly. "Prices are stable and it's easier to get financing," said Charles Oppler of Oppler-Ketive Realtors in Fort Lee, which specializes in co-ops.
Those involved in Crescent Park's recovery say it could be a model for other co-ops. "The key was perseverance and the resolve of shareholders to gain control of their destiny," said Kerry Brian Flowers, a lawyer with the Woodbridge firm of Greenbaum, Rowe, Smith, Ravin & Davis, who represents Crescent Park Owners.
The co-op form of ownership, while widely used in New York, has struggled to gain acceptance west of the Hudson River except in areas like Fort Lee, where New Yorkers familiar with the concept would be expected to buy. Some housing analysts and real estate lawyers said the financial woes that arose when the mid-80's boom deflated could affect the growth of co-ops in the state.
Those woes included defaults on loans by sponsors, nonpayment of monthly maintenance by shareholders and foreclosures by banks. But advocates of co-ops counter that the concept, though tarnished, is a viable form of ownership.
Since 1978 some 90,000 rental units have been converted to condos or co-ops, with about 25,000 of them co-ops, according to state figures.
New Jersey did not see the same level of sponsor defaults as in New York City, and it is generally agreed that the worst problems are over. How many buildings are still under financial strain is unclear because the state does not monitor them.
But Mr. Flowers said 10 percent of all co-ops were "still struggling with some financial difficulty." Crescent Park, he added, was "a glaring example of what could go wrong."
THE sponsor at the time of the building's conversion in 1987 was Crescent Jersey Associates, a partnership led by Aaron Ziegelman, a New York converter. Over the next three years about 120 of the apartments were sold at an average sales price of $95,000. Of the remaining unsold apartments held by the sponsor about 50 were vacant and the rest leased to rent-controlled tenants.
"In 1990 the problems exploded," Mr. Flowers said. The sponsor, now barred from selling in New Jersey, "dropped off the keys, stopped paying monthly maintenance on its units -- ultimately accumulating arrears of $1.5 million -- and walked away," Mr. Flowers said. But, he added, the co-op had been doomed from the start, and the Achilles heel was real estate taxes.
When the building converted, two wraparound mortgages had been added to a $3.4 million underlying loan from the Beacon Federal Savings and Loan Association -- a tactic used in New York by sponsors to create capital for themselves while adding debt to resident shareholders. A fourth, $2.4 million mortgage was also tacked on for a total of $11.4 million.
But New Jersey's tax system, Mr. Flowers said, allows mortgage debt to be assessed as added value, pushing up real estate taxes, which at Crescent Park went from $250,000 to $1.2 million. "They didn't plan for that and the budget went haywire," he said, adding that slow sales in a soft market pushed the debt-burdened building over the edge.
Beacon filed to foreclose on the building. A year later the S. & L. failed and was seized by the Resolution Trust Corporation. In 1992 the co-op filed for bankruptcy to stay the foreclosure. It also sued to take over unsold units from the sponsor and from delinquent shareholders, as well as for breach of fiduciary duties by the building's former lawyer and management agent, among others.
That case resulted in a 1994 settlement in which the co-op gained control of 140 apartments plus $1.3 million in cash. Half of the 100 shareholders also bought back their home loans and now own their units free and clear, Mr. Flowers said.
"It was the first sign we could win," Ms. Doggett said.
Then under a 1995 bankrupcty settlement the junior mortgage holders forgave $8.5 million in debt in exchange for 20 apartments and Resolution Trust lowered the $3.4 million underlying mortgage, which was due, to $3.25 million, extended it seven years and forgave $2 million in interest. Mr. Flowers said that as part of the reorganization the mortgage would be cut further to $3 million and the taxes reduced to about $250,000.
The co-op, helped by Wilkin & Guttenplan, an East Brunswick accounting firm, also decreased its expenses by $150,000 a year. That, along with the new mortgage, led to a 20 percent maintenance decrease, or an average monthly charge of $844.
To rebuild value at Crescent Park, the co-op hired the Solomon Organization of Mountainside, which owns or manages 3,630 co-op units in the state. In the last six months, 30 of the apartments, from 900 to 2,000 square feet, have been rented for $750 to $1,450 -- all the while "improving the building's economic conditions," said Marc Solomon, a partner. The building has such amenities as a 24-hour doorman, garage parking and Manhattan views.
MR. SOLOMON said an offering plan was being filed with the state and, once accepted, the building would begin sales by the spring of 1997 "if the market calls for it." The goal is to sell units at a price averaging $50,000 so owning one costs little more than renting it, he said, adding "we are leasing to people who are candidates for homeownership and creating a built-in market." The firm will also help buyers get home loans.
Tenants are moving in. Stanley Mims, an education administrator, and his wife, Annette, a teacher, relocated from Atlanta to a 1,800-square-foot apartment. "We wanted space and Crescent Park gave us that and more for our money," Dr. Mims said. "The board is in control, the building is moving forward and its future is secure. We can't wait to buy."
Though encouraged by the leasing pace, Ms. Doggett said she knew there were struggles ahead. "No, we will not recoup our investment initially," she said, "But we are bringing equity back to the building and over time values will rise."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The co-op corporation at Crescent Park has helped the building regain its footing. Rebecca Doggett board president, stood before the building with Eduardo Solar of the board and Nancy Hoing, vice president. (Julio A. Ibarra for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A First-Time Buyer's Primer and Road Map

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
IT won't be too long before pachysandra emerges from hibernation, azalea buds ripen, trees sprout new leaves and a fresh crop of "For Sale" signs appears on lawns across the land.
Indeed, with interest rates low, real-estate brokers are hoping for a bumper crop of home buyers this spring. Among them will be a freshman class of first-time buyers making their maiden voyage on the road to the American Dream. 
 As anyone who has been down that road before already knows, the process of becoming a homeowner is at various times terrifying, mysterious, exciting, daunting, frustrating, confusing, confounding and, for most at least, ultimately rewarding.
"This whole thing seems so overwhelming," said Bart Lucash, a 27-year-old Eatontown, N.J., resident who along with his fiancee Kim Vigus, 21, is in the process of buying what will become the couple's first house -- a three-bedroom colonial in Howell Township.
"It's scary," Mr. Lucash said. "When we came back from signing the contract we just looked at each other and said, 'Can you believe what we just did?' "
More than a few first-time buyers have asked themselves that question after plunging into what may be the most significant investment of a lifetime. Then they wonder: "What happens now?"
Here, then, is a road map and survival guide for those embarking on the road to home ownership.
"Remember this," said David Clurman, a Manhattan real estate lawyer and former chief of the real estate financing division of the New York State Attorney General's office: "Anything you sign could very well turn out to be a binding contract."
In most cases, Mr. Clurman said, a buyer who wants to make an offer on a property will usually be asked by a broker to sign either a binder or a contract. Customs vary from state to state and even within states, Mr. Clurman said.
For example, in New York City, brokers will usually ask a buyer to sign a binder -- a document that contains the essential terms of the offer including price, deposit, down payment and mortgage amount. In other areas of the state, however -- and in New Jersey and parts of Connecticut as well -- a broker will often ask a buyer to sign an actual contract, usually on a form approved by a state real estate board. In most cases, the contract contains a clause that permits both buyer and seller to have the contract reviewed by a lawyer within a certain time period.
 
The Contract
Sign Here Or Lose the House
 
 In either case, Mr. Clurman said, a signed, written agreement that contains all the necessary elements of a valid contract could legally be considered a valid contract even if it is called binder. And while most lawyers cringe at the thought of clients signing any documents without their prior approval, most clients seem to be less concerned than their lawyers.
"They sign them all the time," Mr. Clurman said. "They're so afraid they're going to lose the deal that they'll sign anything just to hold it."
Such concerns are at times, it seems, warranted.
"It's a stressful process," said Cynthia Kaplan, a Westchester County resident who with her husband, Gavin, recently made an offer on a property in Scarsdale. "We came close to the asking price and then somebody else came along and offered even more than the sellers were asking."
The Kaplans, who are now renting a house in Rye Brook, have been scouring the market for nearly a year. And if they have learned anything from the process, Mrs. Kaplan said, it is that the best deals rarely wait around while buyers consult with their lawyers.
"The good houses go fast," Mrs. Kaplan said. "You have to move very quickly."
So, then, what does a prudent buyer do when a deal depends on signing a binder or contract on the spot?
"Fax it to your lawyer," said William Selsberg, a Stamford, Conn., real estate lawyer.
Even if a contract permits an "attorney review period," Mr. Selsberg said, there are strategic reasons for involving a lawyer in the negotiating process early on. For example, he said, sellers who might be inflexible regarding the sale price might nevertheless be willing to negotiate on other matters -- such as repairs or the inclusion of personal property. That willingness might evaporate, however, if over-eager buyers quickly sign a contract just to keep from losing the deal.
"These could be people who have never even negotiated buying a car," he said. "They need someone to keep them calm."
And while the real estate broker may appear to be looking out for the interests of the buyer, the broker's contractual loyalties and responsibilities typically lie with the seller.
Mr. Selsberg said a good real estate contract should include a clause permitting an inspection of the property by a home inspection expert or engineer. The inspector should thoroughly check the house and its systems, including the roof, heating plant, plumbing system, electrical system and structural elements.
The contract should also permit the buyer to have a water and septic test, a termite inspection, a radon test, and a check for the presence of asbestos-containing materials, lead paint and urea formaldehyde insulation. In addition, if the house was ever heated by oil, an inspection should be conducted to check for possible ground contamination caused by leaking underground oil-storage tanks.
Most important, Mr. Selsberg said, the contract should specify what happens if the results of any of the tests are unsatisfactory to the buyer -- preferably giving the buyer the right to cancel the contract.
"If you deal with these things beforehand," Mr. Selsberg said, "you're in a better position to negotiate later on."
Finally, he said, buyers of residential property should also consider obtaining a survey of the property.
"I tell my clients that I'd rather see them live with sheets on the windows if that's what it takes to afford a survey," Mr. Selsberg said, adding that it is not uncommon to find that a driveway or a fence crosses a property line. "I tell my buyers that if they find a problem now, it's the seller's problem. If they find it later, it's theirs.' "
Mr. Selsberg said a survey can cost anywhere from $600 to $1,200, or perhaps more.
Once the contract terms are negotiated, the buyer is usually required to provide the seller with a deposit -- usually expressed in terms of a percentage of the purchase price.
Eric M. Davis, a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in real estate, said that a typical deposit can range from 5 to 10 percent of the purchase price and will usually be held by the lawyer representing the seller. One question that often arises, he said, is whether the deposit earns interest.
"Generally, deposits are kept in noninterest-bearing trust accounts," Mr. Davis said. "But if the anticipated interest is going to exceed $100, then it is advisable to deposit it in an interest-bearing account."
In most cases, Mr. Davis said, "interest follows the deposit," -- meaning that whoever ultimately ends up with the deposit also gets the interest, usually the seller. An aggressive lawyer, however, will attempt to negotiate for at least a portion of the interest to be paid to the buyer.
"It never hurts to ask," he said.

The Mortgage
The Bank Becomes Your Senior Partner
A major question on the mind of most first-time buyers is: "How much can I borrow?"
Gregg Winter, president of Winter & Company Mortgage Services in Manhattan, said that generally, a lender will allow a borrower to spend about 28 percent of the gross household income on "housing expenses" -- a term that generally includes mortgage principal and interest, real estate taxes, hazard insurance, private mortgage insurance (needed when the down payment is less than 20 percent) and maintenance or common charges in co-ops or condominiums. When other recurring debts are taken into consideration -- things like credit cards and car loans -- the maximum limit increases to about 36 percent.
Accordingly, a buyer with good credit and total household income of $50,000 would probably qualify for a mortgage that would cost roughly $14,000 a year, or $1,150 a month. With interest rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages now at about 7.5 percent, that would translate into a mortgage of about $125,000 to $150,000. (It is impossible to be precise because included in the monthly payment are real estate taxes which vary widely.)
In most real estate transactions, the first stop buyers make after signing the contract is a bank or a mortgage company. Typically, the contract contains a "mortgage contingency clause," which gives the buyer a fixed period of time -- typically, 30 to 45 days -- to get a commitment from a lender for the mortgage that will be needed.
"The minute I signed the contract I contacted the mortgage company," said Peter W. Cheng, a media company vice president who is moving from California to an Upper West Side condominium he bought about two weeks ago.
For Mr. Cheng, the mortgage application process was quick and painless.
"I filled out the application, they gave me a list of stuff that I had to send in, I went back to California, sent the stuff in, and a couple of weeks later I had a mortgage," he said.
For many first-time buyers, however, the process can be intimidating, confusing and often frustrating.
"A lot really depends on the down payment," said Margaret Scott, president of Mortgage Advisory Services, a Manhattan mortgage broker. Buyers who can afford a down payment of 20 percent of the purchase price, she said, will have an easier time than those putting less money down.
"There are a lot of first-time buyer programs around," Ms. Scott said, explaining that there were mortgages available for buyers who can put up as little as 3 percent of the purchase price as a down payment.Such mortgages,, however, typically take longer than the conventional loan process.
"That can be very discouraging to a seller," Ms. Scott said, explaining that sellers typically prefer buyers who will be applying for conventional financing.
Moreover, Ms. Scott said, a buyer whose down payment is less than 20 percent of the purchase price will usually have to obtain private mortgage insurance -- which insures the lender for the difference between the lower-than-usual down payment and the 20 percent typically required.
Such insurance, she said, can cost a buyer several hundred dollars a year.
"It's roughly the equivalent of adding three-eighths of a percent to the interest rate of the mortgage," she said.
First-time buyers often turn to adjustable-rate mortgages because they appear to cost less. Such mortgages are usually 30-year loans with interest rates that can increase after an introductory period of one to 10 years.
While such mortgages contain rate caps, Ms. Scott said, buyers should think long-term. If they plan to keep the house beyond the introductory period, it might be advisable to pay a slightly higher fixed-interest rate to avoid higher payments if interest rates rise.
One of the most common sources of confusion for first-time buyers, Ms. Scott said, involves the issue of points.
"It makes for wonderful cocktail party conversation to say, 'I paid no points on my mortgage,' " she said. "But there are times when points can be a good thing."
A point, Ms. Scott explained, is equal to 1 percent of the amount being borrowed. Most lenders charge a specific number of points in conjunction with a specific interest rate for a loan. (The mortgage broker typically earns one point out of the total charged by the lender.)
Usually, the higher the number of points charged, the lower the interest rate, and vice-versa.
"There's a rate-point trade-off," Ms. Scott said. "If you're going to be in your dwelling for three years or less, I recommend that people pay as few points as possible. But if you expect to be there longer, you might want to pay more points up front to get a lower interest rate, which, in the long run, will save you money."
In addition, she said, points are tax deductible in the year they are paid.
Neil Bader, chief executive officer of Skyscraper Mortgage, in Manhattan, said that it takes about two and a half weeks for a borrower to get a firm mortgage commitment from a lender.
That, however, assumes that all of the required paperwork -- including credit reports, income verifications, income tax returns, and property appraisals -- gets to the lender on time.

The Closing
The Final Act With a Large Cast
Once the commitment is issued, the stage is then set for the lawyer representing the buyer to order title searches and other documents required by the bank to schedule a closing.
"The most misconceived notion among buyers and sellers alike is that the closing date is written in stone," said Ronald Sher, a real estate lawyer in White Plains.
Ordinarily, Mr. Sher said, to avoid spending a client's money unnecessarily, a buyer's lawyer will hold off ordering the title search until the mortgage commitment is issued.
In most cases, however, the commitment is only good for 45 to 60 days, after which the interest rate set in the commitment could be subject to change. Additional credit reports involving additional time and expense may be required, or the commitment itself can expire.
As a result, the coordination of receipt of the title search with the commitment expiration date and the closing date set in the contract often ends up being something of a juggling act.
"Normally, you don't end up closing on the date specified in the contract," Mr. Sher said. "In most cases, both parties are entitled to a reasonable adjournment."
The title search, Mr. Sher said, is usually conducted by an agent for a title insurance company who searches through official records to ascertain whether there are any claims against title to the property.
Potential claims, he said, can include rights of previous owners, court judgments against past and current owners, and existing easements and rights of way that give others the right to use or traverse portions of the property.
If the title insurance company determines that title to the property is clear -- that no other parties have rights that supersede the rights of the current owner -- the company will issue a policy of title insurance to both the buyer and the lender.
"The title policy is essentially an insurance policy covering the bank and the owner in the event someone else claims title to the property," Mr. Sher said. "If the title is found to be defective by a court, then the title company pays the bank and the owner for their loss up to the purchase price of the property."
Additional coverage -- which insures the market value of the property as opposed to the purchase price -- is also available, Mr. Sher said.
When the closing date is finally set, the buyer's lawyer will typically advise the buyer to revisit the property on the closing date and inspect it closely. When the day of the closing arrives, purchasers should come prepared for some heavy-duty paperwork.
"I tell my clients to be ready to sign as many as 100 pieces of paper," said Mr. Davis, the Manhattan lawyer. "And there are also a variety of payments that have to be made."
In fact, Mr. Davis said, one of the primary purposes of the closing, aside from the seller signing the deed and the buyer signing the mortgage, is to account for the various payments and adjustments that must be made.
Included in the charges a buyer would typically pay on the day of closing, he said, are the balance of the down payment, adjustments for real estate taxes, charges for title insurance and the title search, hazard insurance, lawyer's fees, and the fees due to the mortgage company.
That can include points, prepaid interest on the loan, tax and insurance escrows, appraisal fees, credit report fees and even fees that may be required to pay the lender's lawyer for preparing or examining the buyer's paperwork.
"In many cases, I have my clients come to the closing with 10 or 20 checks," Mr. Davis said. "And some have to be certified." Generally, Mr. Davis said the amount that the buyers will have to bring to the closing, not including the balance of the down payment, can range between 2 and 10 percent of the purchase price, with most about 5 percent.
The last thing that's done at the closing, Mr. Davis said, is the tying up of loose ends before the money and the deed are exchanged.
Included in that category are all the things that have been otherwise overlooked -- like the chandelier the buyer thought would stay and the seller thought would go.
Or the oil in the tank that the buyer thought would go and the seller thought would stay. Or the dings in the wall that mysteriously appear only after furniture is moved.
"It doesn't matter whether you are talking about a million-dollar mansion or a studio apartment," said Mr. Davis. "Buying a home is an intensely emotional experience. So the best way to have a smooth closing is for everyone to check their emotions at the door."
 
Getting the Seal Of Pre-Approval
WHEN shopping for real estate, nothing makes sellers more eager to negotiate than a buyer with an all-cash offer. But since such a luxury is out of the question for most first-time home buyers, the next best strategy is to have a mortgage commitment in place before sitting down at the bargaining table.
"It's called pre-approval," said Neil Bader, chief executive officer of Skyscraper Mortgage Company in Manhattan. "It's like saying to a seller, 'Hey, I'm a serious buyer.' "
There is a difference between pre-approval for a mortgage and pre-qualification -- another term used widely in the industry. Pre-qualification, Mr. Bader said, typically refers to situations where a mortgage broker or real estate broker, using income figures provided by a buyer, estimates the maximum mortgage that the buyer should be able to obtain.
A pre-approval, on the other hand, means more than just "maybe."
"A pre-approval is an actual certificate that the bank will give you to certify that you qualify for a certain mortgage amount," Mr. Bader said.
A pre-approval, however, is not the same as a mortgage commitment because before a commitment can be issued the bank must be able to appraise the property being mortgaged.
"But it can certainly be used as a tool," Mr. Bader said. "From the seller's perspective, it's almost as good as cash."
 
The Added Hurdle in Co-op Buying
WHILE co-ops are homes in the same sense that houses are, the process of buying a co-op is distinctly different.
"Most co-op contracts of sale contain two conditions," said Eric P. Gonchar, a Manhattan real estate lawyer. "One is that the purchasers obtain a written loan commitment within a certain period of time and the second is board approval."
The first condition is usually no more onerous for co-op buyers than for others. The second, however, is something else indeed.
"I always advise my clients in writing that when they're not buying from an original sponsor, they're always subject to board approval and that there is always the possibility that the board can deny that approval," Mr. Gonchar said. "I also advise them that their rights are very limited when that happens."
Accordingly, Mr. Gonchar said, prospective buyers of co-ops are faced with the cumbersome distinction of having to do everything usually required to buy an apartment without knowing whether they will be permitted to buy it or not.
For example, Mr. Gonchar said, a co-op buyer must hire a lawyer to review a contract of sale and then conduct a "due diligence" examination of the co-op's books, records, by-laws and proprietary lease. At the same time, the buyer must apply for a mortgage and then submit to the board an approved commitment along with an array of highly detailed and personal information and an application fee of as much as $500, which may or may not be refundable..
Then they buyer must wait for an invitation for an interview, which may or may not come. "A purchaser who has been declined can always challenge a board decision by starting a lawsuit against the co-op," Mr. Gonchar said. "But the case will probably be lost unless they can prove discrimination based on factors such as race, color, creed, or sexual preference." Typically, he said, rejected buyers adopt a more realistic approach. "They accept the decision reluctantly and move on," he said.
 
Buyer's Agents vs. Seller's Agents
THERE is one professional whose efforts and influence follow and sometimes carry the deal from beginning to end: the real estate broker.
But who is the broker working for?
"There's an inherent anomaly here," said Eric Davis, a Manhattan real estate lawyer. "Although most brokers are technically working for the seller, they usually develop a greater rapport with the buyer."
That unusual relationship, however, can at times present problems.
For example, a broker who has developed a relationship with a buyer might know things that the buyer might not want a potential seller to know -- like how much the purchaser is actually willing to spend. The broker, however, more often than not has a duty to disclose such information to the seller since most brokers are really working for the seller.
As a result, 44 states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, have adopted some form of "agency disclosure rule" under which a real estate broker must disclose to a customer whether that broker is a "seller's agent" who is working exclusively for the seller, a "buyer's agent" who is working exclusively for the buyer or a "dual agent" who is essentially working as a middleman for both buyer and seller.
Hiring a broker as a "dual agent" may have its own built-in tensions.
"It's hard to serve two masters," said William Colavito, a Manhattan lawyer who is chairman of the real property section of the New York State Bar Association. "Just as it would create a problem for a lawyer to represent both sides in a transaction, it could create the same problem for a broker." Generally, Mr. Colavito said, a buyer would get the most protection and the best advocacy by dealing with a buyer's broker. One consideration, however, is that in some circumstances the buyer might have to pay the buyer-broker's commission directly, rather than the typical situation in which the broker's commission is paid by the seller.
The solution?
"Caveat emptor," Mr. Colavito said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Peter W. Cheng (right above) (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times) buyer of Upper West Side condominium, at recent closing. Bobby Ben-Simon shows Scarsdale house to Cynthia Kaplan. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times) (pg. 11)

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Charity-Care Retread: The Jobless Fund, Again

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The moribund proposal to raise the cigarette tax to help pay for hospital care for the poor might actually have been more politically palatable than the latest proposal making the rounds of the State House: continuing a regressive payroll tax on employees and higher unemployment insurance-tax rates for employers.
No matter what they do, the Republican majority can't seem to get away from the word "tax," which is part of the reason the cigarette-tax proposal dried up. But unlike a tax on smoking -- which at its best carried with it a sense of promoting better health -- the current proposal turned out to be a retread of an unpopular idea vociferously rejected by an unusual alliance of business and labor. 
 The Legislature rejected the cigarette-tax increase in December, in part because its leaders felt it would reflect badly on their anti-tax stance. But in the two months since then, lawmakers have come up with nothing to replace it except a plan very much like the one that expired Dec. 31 -- taking another $1.1 billion in tax revenues intended for the unemployment insurance fund for charity care. (The legislation would gradually reduce the state's dependence on the fund over the next four years, after which charity care would be fully paid for from the state's operating budget.)
Both the business community and organized labor have considerable political clout and they are unhappy that the Whitman administration and the Legislature have failed to come up with alternatives, as promised, to cover the cost of the state's annual $400 million charity care bill.
While all sides agree that New Jersey's decision to pay for hospital care for the poor is good social policy, business and labor leaders question whether continued reliance on the unemployment fund is good fiscal policy. The state has diverted $1.6 billion from the unemployment fund for hospital care for the poor from 1993 until the state's authority to use the fund expired on Dec. 31.
While Governor Whitman's proposal to raise cigarette taxes by 25 cents a pack would have generated only about $125 million a year, it would have reduced reliance on the unemployment insurance fund, making it possible for business and labor leaders to consider supporting a smaller diversion. But Republican lawmakers refused to go along with the cigarette tax because their fellow Democrats would not agree to also vote in favor of it. (Democrats have been reluctant to support any tax increase since they were badly punished by the voters for approving former Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 million income tax increase.)
But lawmakers and Mrs. Whitman now find themselves battling charges that continued dependence on the unemployment fund amounts to a hidden payroll tax on both employers and employees.
Governor Whitman gained national attention by cutting income-tax rates as part of her effort to reduce the tax burden on residents, as well as create a more competitive business climate in New Jersey.
Yet the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, which represents 14,000 companies around the state, contends that its members have been hit with higher unemployment-insurance tax rates since the state first began to use the unemployment fund to pay for charity care. Unemployment-insurance tax rates are determined by the level of reserves in the fund, which pays about $1.2 billion in unemployment benefits a year. The fund's cash balance has fallen from $2.8 billion in 1991 to $1.7 billion this year, which employers say has resulted in higher tax rates.
Workers, meanwhile, argue that the $331 million in payroll taxes they paid last year should be used to increase unemployment benefits or provide for an extension of benefits for those having difficulty finding a job.
To win labor's support, legislative leaders are now considering 13 more weeks of unemployment benefits for out-of-work New Jerseyans for a total of 39 weeks.
New Jersey is one of only four states that imposes a payroll tax to help cover the cost of unemployment claims. It is a regressive tax, with workers paying .625 percent on the first $18,000 earned in taxable wages. So, employees earning $20,000 and $100,000 pay the same amount, about $112.50 a year. That totaled $331 million last year alone in payroll taxes from workers in New Jersey. None of that money went to pay for unemployment claims. All but $13.7 million for a state job training program was earmarked for charity care. Since the state first began using the unemployment insurance fund, workers have paid a total of $900 million in payroll taxes for health care for the uninsured.
During that same time, the state's employers contributed a total of $3.2 billion toward the unemployment fund since 1993, with $700 million allocated for charity care.
As the debate over how the state will fulfill its obligation to pay for charity care, hospitals have continued to provide medical treatment to the uninsured without payments from the state. Some hospitals have imposed a hiring freeze and cut back on supplies and payments to vendors to make ends meet. The state missed its first payment this month and lawmakers and Governor Whitman are under pressure to find a quick solution before the next payment is due, March 16.

HEADLINE: STAY ON THEIR BACKS

 BODY:
Paul R. Krugman's "Stay on Their Backs" (Feb. 4) was a breath of fresh air. The idea that suddenly, out of nowhere, American industry has found the philosopher's stone to substantially increasing productivity strikes me as farfetched. Computerization has been going on for years. 
 What is new is the firing of thousands of middle managers. This has temporarily boosted corporate earnings, just as bloodletting would temporarily cause a dieter to lose weight. Whether corporations are now lean and mean or really lean and sick remains to be seen.
 
JOHN VICTOR
Stonington, Conn.

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: NONFICTION

BYLINE: By TERRY TEACHOUT 

 BODY:

THE SWORD OF IMAGINATION
Memoirs of a Half-Century of Literary Conflict.
By Russell Kirk.
Eerdmans, $34.99.
 Russell Kirk's "Conservative Mind" (1953) was the first full-length survey of the history of Western conservative thought since Edmund Burke. As such, it played a key role in the postwar revival of conservatism in the United States, and is still the best book of its kind. Nothing Kirk wrote, said or did between the publication of "The Conservative Mind" and his death in 1994 at the age of 75 was of comparable influence, partly because his brand of conservatism (in which economic considerations played virtually no part) became increasingly unfashionable on the American right and partly because many of his contemporaries found his personality uncomfortably quirky. These quirks are on display throughout "The Sword of Imagination," an autobiography written in the third person and clotted with coyly self-conscious archaisms. Kirk clearly thought himself a great man, and had little patience with those who disagreed. The result is a memoir whose immodesty borders at times on megalomania: "Why, from time to time a good many people told him that chiefly he had set in motion a train of ideas, that he had reminded a generation of the existence of permanent things in morals and politics, that he had struck the errors of socialism a dolorous blow and had chastened liberalism's presumption." Anyone seriously interested in the early days of the conservative intellectual movement in this country will need to read this book, but few will be able to do so without squirming. Terry Teachout
