SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk 

LENGTH: 6964 words

HEADLINE: THE DOWNSIZING OF AMERICA: In the Workplace Musical chairs;
The Company as Family, No More

SERIES: THE DOWNSIZING OF AMERICA: In a College Class, Success and Insecurity -- Second of seven articles.

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
It was an icy, pastel day and in the harried midmorning hours the sidewalks were clotted with workers parading into One Chase Manhattan Plaza, a sterile tower of ponderous coolness just off Broadway and hard by Wall Street. On the ground floor of the Chase banking headquarters sprawls a bustling branch that employees reverently know as the Mother Branch.
A bushy-browed man with a brisk manner who works at the Mother Branch looked around uneasily. "We approach that building with trepidation," he said. "It all seems like a quiz show. Who will win? Who will lose? Do you know the missing letters of the puzzle so you can come back to play again next week?" 
 It was not the place he wanted it to be or had known it to be. Within a matter of weeks, the tower will no longer be a headquarters of anything, because the Chase Manhattan Corporation is in the final throes of being swallowed by the Chemical Banking Corporation. The combination will be presided over from Chemical's Park Avenue headquarters and will constitute the country's largest bank, handling $1 trillion a day. And as these things go, it will also mean 12,000 fewer people will have jobs. It has become a numbingly familiar economic drama in recent years, but the script still has shock when it comes to one's own company.
All of this was testing the man's faith. A co-worker sidled past him, a small bouncy woman with glistening cheeks. She gave a cordial wave and called, "Talking to your headhunter?"
"I wish," the man said.
"Well," she said. "Welcome to another deflating day at Downsize Manhattan Bank."
Like many organizations, Chase is a workplace in transition, a company in which old certainties about work no longer apply. The change is carrying a heavy price. A huge insecurity complex has taken root in the bank's employees. The deracinated workers feel forlorn, if not outright hostile. They are baffled about where their loyalties should lie -- and where their employer's loyalty lies. Anxiety stalks the corridors.
To be sure, quite a number of workers also express optimism, an optimism sometimes a front for blinkered denial that they themselves are at risk. Some younger workers think an employer does not owe them much beyond a desk, an ID card and a paycheck. They are ready and willing to play a game with unclear rules. Certain irrepressibly assured individuals of all ages see something hygienic about downsizing, a boldly efficient way to cleanse sloth and make it more certain that the patient will survive -- so long as they remain untouched.
 
Farewell, Mother Chase
 Employees called it Mother Chase. It began in 1799 as the Manhattan Company, not to lend dollars but to supply treated water to a New York swept by yellow fever. With its spare capital, it opened a bank. In 1955, the company merged with Chase National Bank, the bank of the Rockefeller family.
Jobs used to be as secure as civil service posts. But it has been clear for at least a decade that banks are a capsizing industry. They have been buying and merging with each other, first sporadically and now in a veritable stampede, hemorrhaging jobs in the process. Just four years ago, Chemical itself united with Manufacturers Hanover.
The stewards of these banks invoke the need for efficiencies to stave off rival banks as well as retailers, car makers and brokerage houses that offer their own credit cards and banking-type services. They speak of the speed of technological change and the importance of holding the fickle attentions of Wall Street. Rarely do they address the extent to which consolidations result from lost revenues due to inferior management.
Burdened with sluggish performance, Chase has been cutting its payroll since the mid-1980's, from a high of 47,480 in 1986 to the current 33,500. Pressure on the bank intensified when Michael F. Price, a mutual fund manager, became Chase's biggest shareholder last April and admonished Chase to elevate its stock price. Four months later, Chase sold itself to Chemical for $10 billion, a deal expected to be consummated by March 31.
Within three years, management predicts, 100 of the two banks' 480 branches will be shuttered and about 16 percent of 74,000 jobs will cease to exist. Although the new entity will bear the more illustrious Chase name, Chemical is clearly in command.
Indeed, many profoundly depressed Chase employees interpret the deal as a sellout by senior management, the death of the company they cherished. Thomas G. Labrecque, Chase's chief executive, has already been demoted to president of the new entity, which will be led by Walter V. Shipley, Chemical's chief executive.
One joke going around Chase:
Question: What do you call a Chase worker who is downsized?
Answer: Chemical waste.
 
'No More Santa Claus'
With mechanical efficiency, the woman leaned across her desk, gathered up some loan papers and arranged them. She drew a deep breath and slowly let it out.
"It's not the bank I started to work for," she said, insisting on the anonymity that most fretful employees demanded for their insights about their unraveling situations. "They used to call it Mother Chase. They don't call it that anymore. Everything is about insecurity, not making enough."
Throughout the Chase rank and file, there is a vitriol more often associated with the Internal Revenue Service. Its seeds were planted before the merger, during the years task forces were judging the necessity of jobs and co-workers were going out the door.
Like many others, the loan woman did not think the layoffs at Chase would come out fairly. In her words, "It's not only how well have you done your job, but how well you did your political piece."
She was not political. That worried her. "Chase has always been my identity," she said. "Chase is part of my name. But I'm not going to roll over and die because I don't work for the new Chase. Yet if this keeps up, who's going to go to work anymore. Why bother? Why get out of bed?"
Wrestling with their gloom, workers have begun to seize on customs in the most improbable places. One couple, shaken by the Chase tremors, recently concluded that America might have to become like India, where extended families rather than corporations minister to people.
"You feel like you want to work in Japan or Sweden," the loan woman said. "A place where they take care of their people and their crippled. It's like a lost era here. It's like growing up. There's no more Santa Claus."
 
A New Value System
Chase, in the lingo of human resources, no longer wants to be a parent to its employees. It wants to be their best friend.
In step with other large companies, Chase has replaced a paternalistic organization that guaranteed a job and a raise and a pension with one that tries to assist the employee by sharpening skills that will enhance career success, but will not guarantee anything. In the mid-1980's, it simply discontinued perks like employee picnics, as well as a sacrosanct monetary benefit, a profit-sharing plan to which the bank usually contributed 15 percent of a worker's salary. That benefit was replaced by plans that tended to be less lucrative and involved a lower contribution from Chase. And the company began contracting out many jobs -- guards, messengers, check processing.
Not surprisingly, employee discontent escalated, and Chase concluded it had to do something. To a certain extent, it felt the solution lay in a coffee cup.
In early 1993, Chase did something many companies were doing at the time: It engaged everyone in a mass exercise to compose a statement of values and goals. It called the effort Vision Quest. Chase thought this would make employees feel warmer about the company and their role in it. The result was a set of five not unobvious "criteria for winning" -- customer focus, respect for each other, teamwork, quality and professionalism.
The rather nebulous goal decided on as a new leitmotif was to appeal to the bank's three constituencies -- the worker, customer and shareholder -- and to become the employer, provider and investment of choice. "We spread that vision statement all over the world," John Farrell, the head of human resources for both the old and new Chase, said. Managers beseeched their charges: "Live the values" and "Link to the vision."
Mr. Farrell scooped up a styrofoam coffee cup and twirled it in his fingers. The five precepts were inscribed right on the cup. The cups are stacked at coffee stations throughout Chase. The idea was, every time you had coffee you drank the values, too.
The expression "employer of choice" was converted into a spread of programs, including stock ("Vision shares") for every employee, flexible work arrangements and, most notably, Career Vision. Begun in 1994 as the embodiment of the new covenant between employer and employee, Career Vision offers self-assessment tests, career forums, training in skills like teamwork, and a network of workers who will let you trail them to learn about another area. The intention of this approach, much in vogue among corporations, was to shift the burden of managing a career onto the employee. The company's role would be to offer workers tools to expand their skills so they remained valued employees, whether at Chase or elsewhere. Anyone at any level could use the tools, but none were mandatory.
Now there are Career Development Centers, like the one at Two Chase Manhattan Plaza. There are counselors at the ready. There is a makeshift career library, actually just two stout bookcases containing tapes, Chase training manuals and self-help career nostrums: "Swim With the Dolphins," "Knock'em Dead," "Anger at Work," and "Don't Shoot Yourself in the Foot."
All of this, though, means a chameleon-like change for workers, one particularly tough for longtime employees having trouble accepting the justness of it. Chase could not yet say whether it was succeeding.
Clearly, though, this approach is having a hard time. A lot of employees regard it as "happy talk" intended to mask the fact that their jobs are being pillaged.
A goodly number of workers are openly bitter about what they see as a cartoon substitute for security and decent benefits. And with their jobs in doubt, they felt uncomfortable spending days away from their duties trying to psychoanalyze themselves. As one Chase vice president expressed it, "Career Vision is like the Energizer Rabbit clickety-clacking through Bosnia."
 
A Survivor's Cynicism
In effect, he has become a white-collar factory worker. Punch him in. Watch him run when the evening bell sounds.
He is a business analyst at Chase, 10 years with the company. He has been through smaller downsizings in 1987 and 1991. One of his groups was entirely eradicated. The sepulchral air was getting to him.
Even though he will probably keep his job, he has been transformed. One disturbing truism of the new workplace is that downsizing has an insidious effect on survivors, too. "The merger has eliminated for me a certain motivation and all risk-taking, because this boy was a risk-taker," he said. "I went into areas that no one else wanted to go into. I did a lot of confrontation and tried my best to make it constructive and change things. I shoot for the moon and I settle for a little rock. I'm not doing that anymore. We've all become soldiers. We will obey whatever is said and will not challenge. Since the merger, it's just a 9-to-5 job for me."
A manager in another department said the mood had changed in other ways too: "People are a lot less amenable to being absorbed into the work culture. It's pay me, don't play with me. Don't give me an employee picnic. They're acting like independent contractors. And they're more suspicious of management. Employees are less willing to participate in employee surveys, even though they're anonymous. They feel they are coded in some way."
Recently, the business analyst has rooted for his deeper satisfactions elsewhere. His hobby is photography, so he has settled on a quest to establish a local arts center in his New Jersey town. He now sees that as his driving focus.
Burned out of corporate life. He is 43.
 
The Art of the Layoff
There is an actual Merger Office. Not a physical room per se, but a "virtual office" of some 20 people from the two banks. Chemical's chief administrative officer, a man named Joseph Sponholz, presides over its workings. It is this entity that concerns itself with the monumental arcana of stitching together the two huge companies, and for this it relies on a tool it calls MOM.
MOM is the Merger Overview Model, computer software that keeps track of everything that has been done and has to be done. On a minute-by-minute basis, it wrestles with an equation that is supposed to produce $1.5 billion in savings over three years and eliminate 12,000 people.
Mr. Sponholz, as MOM's daddy, gave a sense of the routine, which he likened to preparing for D-Day. First "mapping" teams with representatives from both banks compiled facts about the Chase and Chemical departments that could be used to plan their integration. These were supposed to be stark facts, with no subjective judgments, the whole point being to get Chemical and Chase people doing things together without animosity. Other integration teams, then, did the harder stuff: Managers were put in place, starting from the top and moving down the pyramid, and business integration plans were hashed out. Some of the most important early decisions had to do with technology. Branches, for instance, cannot be merged until it is decided which check-clearing system to use.
In the early going, Chemical seemed to have the winning hand. Deposits systems: Chemical. Statements and ATM's: Chemical. Check processing: Chemical. It was decided that the trading floor would be consolidated at Chemical's headquarters. The final count, however, was 16 groups of Chemical systems, 15 Chase and 10 joint.
Judging the human beings themselves was trickier. Chase executives call eliminated people "saves," an affable-sounding notion resonant of the achievements of relief pitchers. In this case, it denotes savings to the company, thus positioning laid-off people as a corporate asset. Chase hopes to get a third of the saves from layoffs, a third from retirements and a third from attrition.
To weed out the people, managers have received a 26-page booklet entitled "Companywide Guiding Principles For Selection." It stipulates criteria like employee performance, "value to the organization" and "skills important in a merger or rapidly changing environment." It frowns on seeking a balance of people from the two banks "for the sake of balancing alone."
On the delicate matter of diversity, Chase management says it knows that the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sees a red flag if the makeup of a downsized department deviates more than 3 to 4 percent from the original demographics. Hence Chase's wish is that the layoffs not breach that barrier.
Managers readily admit, however, that there is no distilling human emotion from such an imprecise process, and that politics and long-term ties figure in the equation.
The selection booklet offers sample fill-in-the-blank scripts for meetings with "non-selected" employees, like "Today is your last day with the company. Please turn over your files on the ABC project to (name of employee) and spend a few minutes bringing him up to speed." It suggests that the message be terse and unapologetic, and the whole nasty matter be wrapped up within 5 to 10 minutes. Precautions: Be sure to restrict access to confidential files and computer systems; if strong reactions are anticipated, alert security and medical.
Other tips: avoid terminating people on their birthday (alas, managers confessed they have not bothered to research birthdays) and look for signs of anxiety among employees -- i.e., withdrawal, unshaven appearance, weird habits. An employee relations counselor gave an example from another downsizing company: For weeks, a man sat in his office with the lights turned off, clutching a newspaper.
At the moment, most layoffs are still in the indefinable future, though some workers have gotten notice. The severance packages are sweet as these corporate arrangements go: three weeks' salary for each year of service, 26 extra weeks of pay for those who have 25 years with the company, plus a $2,500 grant that can be applied to any sort of training, including ballroom dancing.
Throughout Chase, there is a clear expectation that it will experience carnage heavier than at Chemical. Time will tell. For the first 300 management positions that were named, Chemical said the score was 53 percent Chemical, 47 percent Chase. But among the positions of power, the breakdown is closer to 60-40 in Chemical's favor.
Mr. Sponholz said he was cognizant of the current jitters and swarm of rumors. "We learned last time that employees get very anxious," he said. "So being as open and forthright as we can be is very important. We're doing a lot of communications."
 
Gallows Humor
The news comes right to every employee's desk, in a neat, multipage newsletter entitled Merger Update. They can have it on paper and by e-mail.
The missives appear roughly every other week. Some contain an opening message signed "Walter" for Walter Shipley and "Tom" for Tom Labrecque. There are also town meetings. There is also a 24-hour hot line for merger questions. There are voice-mail messages from senior officers before key announcements. There are seminars. One subject: "What is a merger?"
To many workers, however, the material is saccharine and platitudinous, and it never tells them what they really want to know: Do I have a job?
Employees, listening to the hollow sound of impermanence, have put their own mordantly black spin on things. They refer to the hotline as 1-800-PINK-SLIP. When Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover merged, employees referred to the combination as Comical Hangover. Around the office coolers at Chase and Chemical today, workers are calling the new union Chasical or Chi-Chi's. And, feeling the need to amplify on the incomplete communiques, they have distributed sardonic Merger Updates of their own.
One mock memo, ostensibly from Mr. Labrecque, under "Frequently Asked Questions":
"Why am I facing layoffs, why is my career in ruins, why can't I sleep at night?"
"Your largely insignificant life is being sacrificed to bring into existence the best banking and financial services company in the world, bar none, without par, without equal, post no bills, void where prohibited."
And: "When will I know if I'm being laid off?"
"You, you, you, is that all you care about, you? Please understand that we need to think about 'us,' which probably doesn't include you. It's about time you started to think about the greater whole, buddy. . . . It should be an honor to be laid off."
Advice on how to insure a job at the new Chase: "Take your boss to lunch. Buy him/ her a gift (under the $250 limit, please). Tell him/her over and over again that your only hope, dream and aspiration is to serve for little or no pay and work inhuman hours to make this place the best banking and financial services company in the world, bar none, without par, without equal, post no bills, void where prohibited."
 
Washed Up at 29
Fast-food lunch at the South Street Seaport with a young, emphatically pragmatic woman with a rather short employment history as a second vice president with Chase.
Eating pizza with a glazed look, she gave the crucial shape of her department, similar to the form many Chase departments were taking. The newly named boss was from Chemical. Of the 10 people directly beneath him, 6 are from Chemical, 4 from Chase. Her odds, she reasoned, were not outstanding. "I'm fairly new," she said. "So if they do last-in, first-out I'm dust."
Gripped by lassitude, her productivity had dropped. She felt implacable despair.
Until recently she had two roommates, and she saw their lives as a modern corporate allegory. All three are 29, and all three graduated from college anticipating long and prosperous business careers. In the last few years, all three have been downsized. "Here we are, all having been in the same boat," the woman said. "We've all lost jobs, and we're not even 30, an age when you're supposed to be highly desirable at corporations. I'll never forget the day my roommate came home with her boxes. The same day she was notified, she had to clear out. She was 25."
Everyone in her department, she said, is punchy and touchy. "If you come in five minutes late from lunch," she said, "they start, 'Oh, were you out on an interview?' " Someone recently circulated a fictitious memo outlining the latest Chase early-retirement program. The age requirement had been lowered. Eligibility began at age 35.
She finished her pizza. She wanted to walk. "I think there is going to be a backlash," she said. "Maybe not this year, maybe not next year, but there's going to be one. People aren't going to give 100 percent anymore. I see this with a lot of my friends. I'm not going to be like my dad and work till 10 o'clock at night and never see the kids. What for? So I'll be thanked with a pink slip?
"I think it all has to do with Wall Street. Every day, there's that stock price staring at you. If it's too low, managers say, 'Why let's get rid of some more people and watch it rise.' I wish corporate executives could see all the faces of these people they're downsizing. I wish they could see them shopping for food and putting their kids to bed. All they seem to care about is the bottom line. And therefore all of us are nothing but Social Security numbers."
For months now, a good many Chase employees have been using their work phones to quite openly and shamelessly market themselves to recruiters, searching for escape hatches. A month after her pizza lunch, the young woman herself bailed out of her wobbly encampment to a new job with a smaller company in another state.
 
The View From the Top
On an easel in his office, Tom Labrecque keeps three stick-figure drawings of the sort children accomplish in art class. Actually, they are the dabblings of Chase workers. During the Vision Quest exercise, everyone was asked to sketch the "ideal state" for Chase. People drew Chase castles with merry figures dancing about them, Chase boats sailing to a future celebrated by dollar signs, people crossing the "Vision Quest bridge."
Mr. Labrecque chose three to keep on display as reminders of the dream.
Mr. Labrecque said he appreciated the churning emotions of employees. But he said that plenty of people shared his optimism, and that the uglier part was the unfortunate cost of a seismic transition to what he believed would be a healthier environment. "Since 1985, we've been going through a secular change as great as the Industrial Revolution," he said. "And we don't know how it will turn out. But I think the assumption that it will turn out to be a negative is a wrong bet. And yet that does not take one minute away from the micro-negatives that are going on."
He acknowledged the primal anger about the dimensions and frequency of layoffs, but said that this was an unnatural phase because companies had misguidedly deferred layoffs for so long: "If you've got 15 years worth of backlog in downsizing, the downsizings will be more severe."
And he recognized generational divides: "The people under 35 are much more flexible than the people who are over 45."
He said that workers who find the new world unpalatable would have to leave the company. There was a Chase person thinking of opening a plant store, someone pondering becoming a park ranger, someone contemplating life as a missionary. Mr. Labrecque thought this was splendid. He said he had heard from severed people who were working for charities at half their banking pay. He said they were happy.
Mr. Labrecque is an imposing man who gives off a steely-cool, confident demeanor. Asked if he felt emotion over the forsaken jobs, he fell silent for a moment.
"I wouldn't be human if it didn't affect me," he said. "I've been working these issues for 35 years. I've faced a lot of crises. In the service, I was one of two people finishing the amputation of somebody's hand because no one else was there. Does that affect you? Sure it does. But if you're doing what you think is right for everyone involved, then you're fine. So I'm fine."
 
Bad-News Bearers
One Chase worker related the experience of her downsized friend. The human-resources representative who delivered the fatal decision accepted her corporate ID and told the woman she would have to cancel her free checking account. Then she handed her some paperwork. With a weak smile, she explained that it was an application to start an account of her own with the bank.
"Don't you dare," the woman said, shooting her a death look. She threw the application at the functionary and stomped out.
Not all human-resources people, of course, are so oafish. How, then, do the executioners live with themselves?
A human-resources representative who has given scores of workers the news spoke succinctly: "Thank God for Budweiser."
Another: "It's like a police officer or a fireman. You find a dead body in a building, you can't take it personally."
Another, who had dismissed 500, was more expansive: "At first, it hurt in the stomach in the morning. It may seem callous, but after a while there's a sort of numbing. You go through the steps without getting too emotional. And you think to yourself, 'When will my day come to be on the other side of the desk?' That, in the end, is how you live with it. You realize that everyone's day will come on the other side of the desk."
As for his own future, he was reasonably sanguine. He knew his department would lose people. "I know what needs to be done to survive. Just be quick on your feet. I've laid the groundwork over the last three years in terms of networking. I've made sure I know the right people. I've made sure I was a generalist, not a specialist."
But in the new world, he felt he had another important qualification on his resume: He had eliminated hundreds of people with nary a complication. "We had only one lawsuit in the group I was responsible for," he said. "It was dismissed after one hearing. That record counts in my favor." A good man, in other words, in a corporate storm.
 
War Stories
Many Chase employees have been through rounds of layoffs, but not a big merger, and mergers are entirely different beasts in the trauma they unleash. As Chase people have talked to more and more Chemical people, they have gleaned some sense of how this all goes. Chemical employees, after all, did the drill with Manufacturers Hanover.
To wit:
The head of one group at Chemical notified the employees beneath him that after the reorganization jobs would be eliminated. Right away, a secretary in the group began bringing to work issues of Guns and Ammo magazine. She would point out to her boss particular weapons being advertised and say offhandedly: "What do you think of this? Wouldn't it be a good gun to get?"
A bluff? Serious stuff? A few weeks later, the staffing decisions completed, the secretary was among those let go. A human-resources officer broke the news to her in a cold sweat, with an armed guard outside the door. As it happened, there was no gun or violence. The secretary simply cried.
Elsewhere in Chemical, a group of 15 people was downsized to one. The woman who was left felt incredible guilt. "I cried for two days," she said. "Some of these people were my dear friends. One was very bitter at me, because he had more tenure." For five months, until she was transferred, the woman attempted to tackle the work of the 15. She toiled through 16-hour days. She reported each morning to a work area designed for 15 people. She sat alone, surrounded by 14 empty desks, feeling as if she were in one of those creepy end-of-the-world movies.
The Purge in Legal
The lawyers heard first. The news came Dec. 13, two days after Chemical threw a Christmas party for the Chemical and Chase lawyers. How absurd the party seemed now. There were Chase and Chemical lawyers fawning over the senior managers. Little did they know, it was too late. The decisions had already been made.
Of Chase's 126 lawyers, 38 were told that their Chase careers were over. Chemical dismissed 15 of its 150 lawyers. And so they became the first department to be fully downsized. Or almost fully downsized. It seemed evident to the lawyers that too many managers were kept, doubtlessly to smooth the transition, and that some of them would eventually vanish as well.
Being fired is always the same, but each person takes it in his own way. Some ego-bruised lawyers began to chatter in denial of the truth. Some left at once, banging doors behind them. Many felt that a disproportionate number of women and workers with flexible hours had been eliminated.
It was also noticed that youth seemed to carry weight. A group of eight lawyers was eliminated except for one man, the youngest. "We heard at the beginning that Chemical wanted a staff that would carry it into the 21st century, and that meant young people," one lawyer said. "It's depressing when people look at you askance because of your age -- and your age is 40."
Chase said the statistical reality was this: of the 53 eliminated lawyers, 30 were women and 30 were older than 40. The proportion of women fell by three percentage points. The number of lawyers over 40 actually rose by one percentage point.
To the survivors, the place seemed suddenly cold. People felt remorse for those who hadn't made it: a pregnant woman, a woman on maternity leave, a woman who had just adopted a child, a man with three children.
A biting joke made the rounds: "The good news is you have a job. The bad news is you have a job."
The lawyers found Career Vision and the Chase determination to be the "employer of choice" all so irrelevant now. "Yeah, employer of choice," one said. "Some choice. I assume they're not still holding those career workshops and all, are they? What's the point? Who would go?"
 
Modern Re-education
The Managing Your Career workshop was being held in downtown Brooklyn in the big Metro-Tech building where some 6,000 Chase employees work. Fourteen Chase vice presidents had assembled for a basic offering in the Career Vision program.
The workshop extended over two days, and much of this part dwelled on self-administered psychological tests intended to afford the takers a sense of who they are and what work situations best suited them.
The facilitator gave a spiel: "When we started doing this course, people thought it would be to provide everyone with a new job. That really is not something you should expect. What you should expect is to learn something about yourself so you can go out there and do the right thing for yourself."
There was some rustling and murmuring in the room.
With a crisp cheerfulness, she went on to state that one of the objectives was to develop strategies for anticipating and adapting to change. "Nothing could be more relevant right now," she said. "Change is it. We're knee-deep in it."
There was more rustling.
The facilitator suggested a little experiment. "Take a piece of paper and sign your name," she said.
When everyone had finished, she asked, "How was that?"
"Easy," someone said.
"Comfortable," replied another student.
"Like duck soup, like falling off a log," the facilitator said. "O.K., now put the pen in your other hand and sign your name."
Everyone struggled.
"How did that feel?" the facilitator asked.
"Terrible," a woman said.
"Imagine if you had to write with your left hand in your job all day," she said.
"I think I would type," someone said.
The facilitator explained that the exercise was intended as a metaphor for those who had not managed their career well enough so that they did not fit their job. But it could have been a metaphor for the work environment at Chase. The instability and pervasive paranoia made them feel as if they were writing with the wrong hand.
Now people went over their scores on a test based on the typology of Carl Jung that intends to identify a person's style. The facilitator went around the room. People spoke of being I's (introverts) and E's (extroverts). They were F's (feeling people) and T's (thinking people). They were also to rate their jobs to see if they possessed extroverted jobs or feeling jobs or whatever, then determine if they matched.
One woman said: "I took the test several times and came out an F. That's the reason I kept taking it, because at work I definitely operate as a T."
The facilitator said, "How do you feel about that?"
Watch Your Back
One way employees at Chase have tried to hedge their bets is to establish their own informal networks through the bank and the larger world of work. They keep lists of people with whom they try to keep in touch.
Networks, though, have been buckling under the strain. People are getting tired of fielding calls from colleagues in pursuit of work. Moreover, with companies constantly downsizing, it is colleague against colleague in a Darwinian struggle. The person at the next desk may be your co-worker and teammate, but he is also your competitor if bodies must go in your department.
A middle-aged man with wavy hair and a creased face told of how for years he has taken lunch practically every other day with a fellow worker in his department. They relished gossiping about the office, denigrating their boss and complaining about the woeful states of the Jets and Giants.
These lunches continued after the Chemical merger was announced, spiced now by hectoring. ("Heard from benefits lately?" "Checking out the trailer park?" "Get the 5-year-old a job yet?") But then the man said he began to hear disturbing speculation. His department was likely to incur severe hits. He began to think of himself and his colleagues as the "walking dead."
He confided these developments to his wife. She told him to watch his back. The next morning, he noticed his friend in their boss's office, chuckling about something. His first thought was that he was politicking. Could it be that he was bad-mouthing him? He worked himself into a nervous lather.
Later, he pleaded other commitments when the subject of lunch came up. The pair ate once a week for a while, and the conversations were more strained. Then they stopped having lunch altogether. The friend did not protest. Apparently, he had drawn similar conclusions.
Now they were both watching their backs.
 
The New Company Man
Is there a modern corporate employee, someone who accepts the new ways? What does he look like? How does he sound?
There are many paths into banking. Matt Hoffman came by piano.
He is 35, grew up in Indiana, went to college in upstate New York to study music. For two years, he was a pianist in New York, doing gigs, playing at a restaurant, accompanying an elderly and abusive man who wanted to keep his voice in shape.
The pace was too much. He decided to enter the business world. He began as a teller at a Westchester bank. He was always a self-starter. On his lunch breaks, he didn't loiter with other tellers. He went and interrogated the mortgage people and the loan people, learning new things, and this led to swift promotions. He moved to another bank as a business development officer and, five years ago, to Chase. He is a cluster manager overseeing several branches in Westchester.
He never sought security in corporate work, and thus the merger doesn't especially throw him. He has embraced Chase's career assistance and thinks he has sharpened his abilities, become a resilient worker. His background has given him an emphatically 90's outlook on work. "I feel my job is to do the best that I possibly can, but my whole area could look totally different in five years through no fault of Chase. I can't imagine any corporate entity owes anyone a career."
By virtue of his background, Matt Hoffman is perhaps the archetypal corporate man of the future. His introduction to the world of work was a terrain where his paycheck depended on how well he sold himself each day. Nothing was guaranteed past tomorrow. No one could assure him that he would be taken care of in declining years.
He has imported that mindset into banking and, currently, into Chase, and he has found the fit to be all too perfect. For an odd reality of the new work environment is that the turbulent world of the freelance classical pianist is more like than unlike the world of the corporate employee. He, too, has to sell himself every day, and he, too, doesn't know if the gig will be there tomorrow.
There are indeed other modern employees, usually young, who have seen this future and in some way accepted it for what it is.
Look at Richard Fischer, a Chase customer representative in Bardonia, N.Y. He goes from work to school, pursuing his M.B.A. with Chase paying the bills. He sincerely feels the merger will offer him more. "I feel I have a lot to offer Chase," he said. "If it came down to it, I'm not afraid of rolling up my sleeves and being a teller again." He was a business administration major in college, and learned about the future. "I remember we did a case study of banking," he said. "It pointed out that before you turn 30, you change jobs six times." He is 24.
A fair number of feisty, high-octane people at Chase relish the merger. They assume (not necessarily correctly) that they will retain their jobs and their roles will swell in importance. As one finance person put it: "There are a lot of people in their 20's who are saying to those who are unhappy, 'Don't screw up my opportunity to be somebody and make a lot of money in this bank.' There's a generational animosity."
Throughout the bank, people are scrambling to position themselves. Donald Skelton, a safe deposit manager, is planning to go to college for the first time at night this summer, at the age of 46 -- assuming he is still employed. It was a rude awakening to him that after 25 years at Chase he makes less money than his daughter, who just graduated and began a computer programming job.
The crucial question is how far can you push these resilient people before they, too, break? How hard can you work them? How many times can they bounce from company to company and still smile?
 
The Last Hope
The end of the line is actually any of three floors -- the 5th, 11th and 12th -- at 640 Fifth Avenue, near Rockefeller Center. These belong to the New York office of Right Associates, the nationwide outplacement firm. It is something of a human recycling bin, where downsized Chase workers take up residence as they begin what Right counselors call their "marketing campaign."
Right Associates offers elaborate services -- career counseling, networking sessions, one's own office, secretarial assistance -- at a cost to Chase of 16 to 20 percent of the employee's compensation. Unemployment may appear to be the great leveler, but there are hierarchies even among the jobless. The better your former job, the more luxury accorded you while you are without it.
With no outplacement operation of its own, Chase sends everyone -- from tellers to what are known as the K.E.'s, or key executives -- to Right. What they get there depends on rank. The lowest levels merit counseling and a cubicle for three months. The K.E.'s get a private office on a separate floor and more elaborate nurturing for a year. Everyone, however, earns secretarial help. For the first time in their career, laid-off people like tellers have a desk and phone of their own, plus an underling to type letters.
Andrea Eisenberg, the account manager for eliminated Chase workers, said she had gleaned certain traits about these people. They have strong networks. They are intelligent. And, despite the recurrent dire news about the shrinking banking world, almost to the person they wish to remain in banking.
Another characteristic, she said, is that they are in shock. "Even though there's all this going on," she said, "they're surprised it happened to them."
Looking in on the cubicles on a chill, gray day around Christmas, Nancy Geffner, the head of the office, remarked: "This time of year, we have to watch people carefully. No job, other people happy -- you know."
By now, one middle-aged woman had come close to spending as many days at Right Associates as she had at Chase. She was downsized early last year.
She had passed through mourning and was well into acceptance. "If someone says, 'Gee, Chase was wonderful for setting up all those employee programs,' that gets me going," she said. "But after the initial detoxification period, you get over the anger. I wouldn't recommend Chase to anyone, but I'm over the anger."
She cleared her throat. "I've changed," she said. "I used to think that having a stable job reflected on your moral integrity and your being a solid human being. Now when I see people doing flaky things to make money -- say, opening a muffin stand -- I say, 'Go for it.' We were talking about this in one of our groups here, of thinking outside the box. Someone said, 'Hey, there is no box.' "
She mentioned that she keeps a collection of the Chase coffee cups inscribed with the Chase values in her kitchen as some sort of comical reminder of the day that catapulted her into outplacement. "I look at the cups and laugh," she said. "They're funny now."
Does she use them?
"Oh, no," she said. "I never drink out of them. They probably leak."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Maddux Battles Inflation One Batter at a Time

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.

 BODY:
Ken Griffey Jr. or Frank Thomas could hit 62 home runs this year, and the number would not be as mind-boggling as one Greg Maddux has achieved the past four seasons. In an era of e.r.a. inflation, when earned run averages are soaring, Maddux has permitted 1.98 earned runs per nine innings compared with 4.00 for other National League pitchers.
Maddux has not only been twice as good as his peers, but has also been remarkably better than the rest of the best. Among pitchers who would have qualified for the e.r.a. title in either league each of the past four seasons, the lowest e.r.a.'s after Maddux's are 3.12 for Kevin Appier, 3.17 each for Randy Johnson and David Cone and 3.21 for Tom Glavine, an Atlanta Braves teammate whose admiration for Maddux is boundless. 
 How does Maddux do it? What places him in a niche all his own, far below the madding crowd?
Glavine, who shares clubhouse space with Maddux, said he is running out of answers to the question. But among the reasons he and other Atlanta Braves pitchers provided, this one was the most intriguing.
"He has a tremendous ability to notice things that are going on during the course of the game," Glavine said. "He'll notice a guy moving up half an inch in the box on him, or he can watch a guy taking warm-up swings on deck and have an idea what he thinks that guy's going to look for based on his warm-up swings."
Little wonder that Maddux is so far ahead of other pitchers. Many of them aren't even sure what batters are looking for when they're swinging in the batter's box. But the winner of four consecutive Cy Young awards has many other telltale attributes as well.
"I guess it was Warren Spahn who said the art of pitching is upsetting the hitters' timing," Glavine said. "Greg does that as well as anybody. He's the epitome of throwing off a hitter's timing. That's what you need to do, and that's what he does."
Mark Wohlers, the Braves' matured young closer, who was needed to save only 4 of Maddux's 19 victories last season, said he believes his celebrated teammate's success begins with his game plan.
"He'll map out a game plan with the catcher a day or two before he pitches and he'll stick to it," Wohlers related. "Some guys, if things aren't going well right away, will try to adjust maybe too quickly, maybe go away from their strengths. He realizes what his strengths are and sticks with them."
Expanding on that theme, Glavine said Maddux resists the urge to try to do too much in a particular situation.
"When you have the bases loaded or second and third and two out," Glavine said, "some guys try to turn it up a notch and try to be a little more perfect or throw better pitches than you may be capable of throwing. That's a natural tendency sometimes. But he doesn't seem to do that. It doesn't matter what the situation is. He never tries to do more than he's capable of doing. He always stays within himself, and he stays effective that way."
Maddux, who last season became the first major league pitcher since Walter Johnson in 1918 and 1919 to have a sub-1.70 e.r.a. in successive seasons, does not overpower hitters. His fastball generally travels from 83 to 86 miles an hour, an eminently hittable speed. But try hitting it.
"He can't just sit there and pump fastball after fastball and not worry about changing speeds or locations," Glavine said. "If he did that, he'd get killed. He's gotten the absolute most out of his ability to locate the ball and change speeds. Guys get up there and maybe get comfortable because he's not throwing hard. They may be thinking he's going to give me a fastball and I'll just sit on that fastball; I can hit the fastball.
"But instead, maybe he throws a changeup or curve or slider and they never see the fastball they're looking for. Their approach might be right, but Greg might not pitch them that way and then they end up getting themselves out. Then they're really frustrated. I've seen that happen a lot. Once he gets ahead of you, you're pretty much out. Guys don't hit very well against him when they're behind in the count."
Using a fastball, slider, changeup and, with increasing frequency, a curveball, Maddux throws each pitch at different speeds, with any count and to any spot he desires, inside corner, outside corner, up, down. "I'm not sure I've seen him throw the ball down the middle of the plate," Wohlers said. And he masks the type of pitch he throws by not varying his delivery in any way.
"He throws everything for strikes any time in the count," the reliever said, then illustrated that statement with an example from a game in San Francisco a couple of years ago. The Giants, losing to the Braves, 1-0, had the bases loaded with two out and Dave Martinez was the batter.
"I was thinking he might throw a change," Wohlers said, "but I don't think he would. Sure enough he did and he struck him out. He's that confident in all his pitches."
Wohlers added: "I'm not sure if anyone's perfect, but he's darn close when it comes to pitching."

HEADLINE: SPECIAL PLEADERS: A periodic look at lobbying.;
Lawyers and Lobbyists Help Guide Effort By Republicans to Speed Drug Approvals

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
Within days after the Republicans won control of Congress in 1994, some gay rights groups saw an opportunity to win speedier access to new, unapproved treatments for AIDS by rewriting Federal drug laws. They knew just whom to call for help in drafting the legislation: Peter Barton Hutt, a Washington lawyer who is one of the nation's leading experts on food and drug laws.
A few months later, drug company executives decided that they also wanted major changes in the laws governing the work of the Food and Drug Administration. Their trade association, the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, asked Mr. Hutt to help draft legislation for Congress. 
 About the same time, the Grocery Manufacturers of America started to write legislation that would speed up Food and Drug Administration approval of food additives, especially substitutes for fat and sugar. They also sought guidance from Mr. Hutt, a former chief counsel for the F.D.A.
When Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, the Kansas Republican who is the chairwoman of the Senate committee overseeing the issue, began rewriting the food and drug laws, she had no shortage of advice from these regulated industries and patient advocates. Yet her staff also consulted Mr. Hutt.
In shaping this major legislative initiative, which could mean speeding up approval for new, potentially lifesaving drugs and food additives, Mr. Hutt and specialists like him have come to epitomize the power of Washington lawyers and lobbyists. Their influence is so ubiquitous that the professionals charged with writing the legislation call them for advice, knowing that they are paid handsomely to steer the legislation in favor of their corporate clients.
Republicans on the Senate Committee on Labor and Human Resources and the House Commerce Committee, joined by some Democrats, have concluded that Congress must revise the F.D.A. laws to give patients swifter access to new drugs and devices.
Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland, said the growth of medical knowledge was outstripping the Government's ability to regulate it. "We have a smokestack regulatory framework in an era of cyberspace knowledge," she said.
But the F.D.A. Commissioner, David A. Kessler, said many of the proposals in Mrs. Kassebaum's bill would undermine consumer protection.
Jane B. Williams, a health policy adviser for Mrs. Kassebaum's panel, said of Mr. Hutt: "I talk to him all the time. He's extremely helpful. I've always felt like I could talk to him not as a person who was representing a particular industry, but as an expert in the field." Ms. Williams, a former director of Congressional affairs at the Health Industry Manufacturers Association, which represents makers of medical devices, said that when she started working for Mrs. Kassebaum in 1993, "Peter was kind enough to come in and give me a sort of introductory course, like F.D.A. 101."
Now, she said, the Senator makes decisions about the substance of F.D.A. legislation, and the bill is drafted by Senate staff lawyers. But Ms. Williams said she sometimes asked Mr. Hutt to review proposals and "tell me if I've done anything here that is really dumb."
Mr. Hutt, 61, a partner at Covington & Burling, a Washington law firm with decades of experience advising the nation's biggest food and drug companies, describes himself as merely "a technical scribe," but that understates his role. People who have worked with Mr. Hutt say that even as he translated his clients' policies into legislative language, he helped define and shape those policies.
Mr. Hutt is not the only one influencing this legislation. Few bills have generated such intense lobbying. Patrick S. Korten, deputy vice president of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, said: "If you're a drug lawyer in Washington and have not had some input into this bill, you should consider some other line of work. At least 60 or 70 lawyers have dipped a pinkie finger into it."
Jeffrey I. Nedelman, vice president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, said: "The House and Senate committee staff asked us for ideas. They asked us to suggest specific legislative language."
The products regulated by the F.D.A. account for 25 percent of the nation's economic output. And while lobbyists do not get everything they want, their influence is pervasive.
They have so penetrated the legislative process that before the Senate committee held hearings on F.D.A. legislation last month, the lobbyists obtained copies of confidential briefing papers prepared for Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, by members of his staff. The papers described the Democrats' strategy and catalogued the arguments they would make against the Kassebaum bill.
The Republican consensus that the F.D.A. laws must be revised is shaped by several factors: the development of products that promise medical breakthroughs, the growth of the biotechnology industry and the emergence of patient-advocacy groups as an influential force in the debate over health policy.
Senator Bill Frist, a Tennessee Republican who is a heart surgeon, said, "In this increasingly complex scientific world, where the half-life of knowledge is growing shorter and shorter every day, it's going to be impossible for the F.D.A. to maintain in-house the full range of expertise and experience that will be needed."
The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, says the average time required for the approval of new drugs has fallen in the last decade, to 19 months from 33 months. But F.D.A. officials acknowledge that they have not had similar success in speeding the approval of devices and food additives.
The agency has accelerated the process of reviewing AIDS drugs, but patients with other life-threatening conditions contend that those drugs receive preferential treatment.
Ellen L. Stovall, executive director of one such patient group, the National Coalition for Cancer Survivorship, said: "The accelerated approval process has not had nearly as significant an impact on cancer. People who are sick and dying should not have to depend on political pressure and favoritism to get expedited approval of medications."
Drug companies do not always get a warm reception in Congress. Some lawmakers agree with President Clinton, who accused the companies of "price gouging" in 1992 and 1993. The companies are much more effective when they present their arguments in tandem with patients.
Drug companies contribute substantial sums of money to patient-advocacy groups, but those groups insist that they are not unduly influenced by the money. Mrs. Stovall said her group received nearly one-third of its annual income of $730,000 from drug and biotechnology companies that make anticancer drugs. "We couldn't exist without that kind of funding," she said.
Other patients' groups express concern about potential conflicts of interest. Derek Link, a spokesman for Gay Men's Health Crisis, which provides social services to people with AIDS in New York City, said: "If you take money from drug companies, you don't necessarily become a puppet of the industry, but it does influence your decision-making process. F.D.A. reform is a big issue in this Congress because the drug industry put it on the agenda."
Patients are so effective as lobbyists that some lobbying firms have hired patients as full-time employees. One firm, Medical and Research Communications, also known as Marc Associates, hired a 37-year-old man with hemophilia, Val D. Bias, to help lobby on legislation favored by the National Hemophilia Foundation.
Mr. Bias said the firm "recruited me because I have hemophilia and would be a good spokesman." Randolph B. Fenninger, executive vice president of Marc Associates, said: "Val knows the issues in a way that you and I will never understand. He walks the walk and talks the talk."
Samuel D. Turner, a lawyer for the Coalition for Cancer Survivorship and other patients' groups, said: "There has been a real sea change in the last five years in the attitude of companies. They realize that it's important to build alliances with patient groups, to enhance their image and to be more effective politically."
Mrs. Kassebaum's bill would set strict deadlines for the F.D.A. to act on new drug applications and would expand access to experimental drugs and devices for people with life-threatening diseases. Companies could disseminate preliminary data suggesting that a drug approved for one purpose might have other beneficial uses that had not been approved by the F.D.A. or verified in clinical trials. If the F.D.A. failed to rule promptly on new drugs cleared for sale in Europe, the products could be automatically approved for sale in the United States. If the agency repeatedly failed to meet statutory deadlines, it would have to sign contracts with outside experts to perform reviews.

HEADLINE: Serbian Chief Moves to Suppress Opposition at Home

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, March 3

 BODY:
In the three months since signing the Dayton peace accords, President Slobodan Milosevic has been promoting himself internationally as a guarantor of peace in the Balkans. But inside Serbia, he has been working to suppress political opposition and reassert state control of the economy, diplomats and economists here say.
Expectations that Mr. Milosevic, who has kept the red star on the spire of his palace, might encourage market reforms and democratization as have former Communists elsewhere in Central Europe have not materialized, they say. 
 In moves intended to cement his grip on power, his Government has stepped up harassment of the opposition, nationalized a private television station and banned the American-financed Soros Foundation, which was subsidizing independent newspapers.
New laws discourage privatization and recent efforts by the respected central bank governor, Dragoslav Avramovic, to end Serbia's big state monopolies and liberalize trade were scoffed at by the Government.
Indeed, at his Socialist Party convention this weekend, where nearly 2,000 loyal delegates listened to adulatory oratory and re-elected him party chairman nearly unanimously, Mr. Milosevic confirmed a course that looks like a retreat to the country's Communist past. In one of the most startling throwbacks, the Cuban delegation received the loudest applause of the visiting dignitaries.
No one mentioned Mr. Milosevic's dream of a greater Serbia that fueled the four-year Balkan war and instead of a grander Serbia yielded economic ruin at home, international isolation and hundreds of thousands of refugees.
Dragan Mrdarevic, a convention delegate from southern Serbia, where the economy was badly hit by economic sanctions during the war, echoed the upbeat mood, saying, "To survive the sanctions was a victory in itself."
Ivan Torav, a columnist for the opposition daily Nasa Borba, wrote on Saturday that the President had managed to manipulate public opinion so that he emerged as the "winner despite all the defeats."
At the convention on Saturday, Mr. Milosevic was hailed in an extravagant video on the auditorium screen that showed a utopian Serbia in the year 2000, replete with high-speed trains, splendid new cities and computerized industry.
Outside, on the streets of Belgrade, the reality was starkly different.
The Government is so broke that it has been unable to pay pensioners for the last two months. The lifting of international sanctions in December has yet to spur industrial production. Unemployment remains at about 50 percent and is likely to increase as money-losing factories shut down.
The economic picture is bleak for a number of reasons, economists said.
First, under the Dayton accord, Serbia cannot qualify for the international financing it needs until it demonstrates full cooperation with the war crimes tribunal in The Hague. Also, like the rest of Central Europe, Serbia must make serious steps toward privatization.
In remarks to the party convention, Prime Minister Mirko Marjanovic revealed the Government's apparently confused notion of a market economy.
"Our first efforts will be a speedy build-up of a market economy," he said. "In the functioning of a modern market economy, the state has an unavoidable and important role."
Economists said one reason for the Prime Minister's enthusiasm for state monopolies was that he is general manager of Progres, Serbia's largest state-run export company and the leading importer of Russian natural gas. The prospects of a market economy were further diminished at the convention, they said, by Mr. Milosevic's selection of a first deputy for the party: Nikola Sainovic, who was Prime Minister during the four-digit inflation of 1992.
Many Western businesses, including major auto, telecommunications and pharmaceutical companies, have sent executives to Belgrade in the last few months eager to do deals now that sanctions have been lifted. But a Western diplomat noted that "they are turning and running."
A new law that allows the Government to reimpose state control over private companies is one of many discouraging factors, the diplomat said.
An American pharmaceuticals executive, on her third and probably last visit, said local hospitals had great need for her company's products but no money or financing to pay for them.
Thanks largely to his almost total control of the media in Serbia, diplomats estimate that Mr. Milosevic holds an approval rating of about 50 percent.
Since signing the Dayton agreement, he has moved methodically to strengthen his hold. On the one hand, Socialist Party leaders have been ordered to recruit new members; on the other, provincial leaders of opposition parties were mobilized into the army.
At the party gathering, delegates spoke of the need for "nonparty pluralism," a phrase favored by the President's powerful wife, Mirjana Markovic, who is vehemently critical of the opposition.
Her party, the Yugoslav United Left, which has become an ardent admirer of China, has won growing influence in the Socialist Party and is described as the fount of most of the Socialists' ideas.
In December, the Government outlawed demonstrations in the center of Belgrade, a pre-emptive move to stop a demonstration planned for this Saturday on the fifth anniversary of a violent confrontation between the army and students over the state control of the news media.
"Will Milosevic turn Freedom Square into Tiananmen Square?" asked Vuk Draskovic, the leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, which is organizing the demonstration. "They are saying, 'You can have your rally but outside Belgrade.' "
The abrupt nationalization in January of the private television station Studio B removed the main outlet for news about the opposition parties, Mr. Draskovic said. "After Dayton, he completely closed state TV to the opposition parties and now all the mass media are in the hand of the Socialist Party."
Two weeks ago, the Supreme Court ruled that the Soros Foundation, which sponsors several provincial newspapers as well as financing imports of medicine, was illegally registered.
The major opposition newspaper, Nasa Borba, remains under pressure because of Government controls over the newsprint market. The paper publishes articles from Western agencies and newspapers but has a circulation of only 20,000, mostly in central Belgrade.
Nasa Borba's former editor, Gordana Logar, said she was disheartened but not surprised by Mr. Milosevic's attempts to strangle the independent media and by his emphasis on a neo-Communist ideology in the Socialist Party.
Such moves, she said, confirmed that Mr. Milosevic never was the fervent nationalist he professed to be. "He is in the middle of implementing his dreams of being in power in an authoritarian and socialist society," she said.

HEADLINE: TRACK AND FIELD;
A Runner Bears Ethiopia's Fragile Hopes

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia

 BODY:
As the sun rose over the lip of the National Stadium, and wood smoke wrapped the high-rises and tin-roofed shanties of the capital in a gauzy cocoon, the world's greatest distance runner arrived for his morning workout. In a taxi.
It's not that Haile Gebrselassie, at age 23, could not afford his own transportation. He is the holder of five world records, and a prohibitive favorite to win gold medals at 5,000 and 10,000 meters at the Summer Olympics in Atlanta. He will earn about $500,000 this year, an amount unfathomable to most residents of Ethiopia, one of the poorest countries on the world's poorest continent. 
 His Mercedes-Benz is parked for safekeeping in the showroom of a local dealership. Another Mercedes has just cleared customs. They are prizes from his racing victories. But Gebrselassie will not drive either luxury car. Not now. He doesn't even have a driver's license. When he uses a car, his brother ferries him in an aging Peugeot.
"Don't laugh at this, but if I start with good cars and good houses, I'm afraid I will lose my winning," Gebrselassie said. "If I have a good car, maybe the car becomes more important than my running."
Still vulnerable to devastating cycles of drought and famine, Ethiopia's most reliable and remarkable harvests have been distance runners such as Gebrselassie, who did not lose a single race in 1995 and has set two indoor world records in recent weeks.
The East African running boom, which spread like a great herd migration to Kenya and beyond, was launched by Ethiopia's Abebe Bikila, who won the 1960 Olympic marathon in Rome, running barefoot and collecting Africa's first gold medal.
Forty days after an appendectomy, Bikila repeated his marathon victory at the 1964 Tokyo Olympics. Wearing shoes this time over the 26.2-mile course, he broke the world record and still had enough energy to perform a calisthenics routine.
Mamo Wolde won the 1968 Olympic marathon for Ethiopia, Miruts Yifter took the 5,000 and 10,000 meters at the 1980 Moscow Games and Belayneh Dinsamo set the current world record for the marathon in 2 hours 6 minutes 50 seconds in 1988 in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Derartu Tulu became the first black African woman to win an Olympic gold medal when she took the 10,000-meter race at the 1992 Summer Games in Barcelona, Spain.
Gebrselassie lives in a modest house on the outskirts of Addis Ababa, and he routinely goes to bed by 9 P.M., awakening by 5:30 or 6 A.M. Even visits with his girlfriend have been limited this Olympic year, he said, lest "my big heart is for her, not my job." This tenacious dedication has elevated Gebrselassie into a compelling national hero, one who does not flaunt his wealth and who maintains an affecting kinship with his fellow Ethiopians, spiritually if not financially.
"You must do as your people do," he said. "If my people are poor, I must be poor. People ask me, 'Why don't you find a personal coach or a private car?' I can't. Then I won't be part of my people."
As an 8-year-old, Gebrselassie listened on a transistor radio to Yifter's accomplishments, and he ran out among the sheep and cattle on his father's farm in the southern highlands, pretending that he, too, was a famous runner.
Fifteen years later, he can emulate Yifter's accomplishments in Atlanta. He stands only 5 feet 3 inches and weighs 130 pounds, but Gebrselassie is perhaps the most visible symbol of achievement in a country that struggles for direction. Five years after rebels overturned the Marxist dictatorship of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, Gebrselassie is a galvanizing figure in a nation riven by 80 ethnic groups and a dozen languages.
Nine months after Ethiopia's first elections, ethnic tensions are raw and old wounds from the Mengistu regime are still open. Mamo Wolde, the 1968 Olympic marathon champion, is in jail, linked to a killing as a member of Mengistu's revolutionary guard, but not charged with a crime. Gebrselassie's older brother, Tekeye, once a marathoner, has sought asylum in the Netherlands for political and economic reasons.
But Haile has remained loyal to his frayed country and, in return, Ethiopians have invested in him this obligation: to demonstrate measurable success for a nation known most acutely for the failures of famine, civil war and dictatorship.
"Before Abebe Bikila, we were not known at all," said Wolde Meskel Kostre, Ethiopia's Olympic track coach. "He brought Ethiopia to the world. Then we had famine, and the Government killing people. Now, the first question I get is, 'How can you run, you have no food in your country?' If Haile wins, then the whole world will see Ethiopia again. They might help us."
It is a heavy weight to carry on one pair of narrow shoulders.
"If Haile loses, people will say, 'Oh, no, Ethiopia has lost everything,' " Meskel said.
Recently, as he led visitors through the capital's bustling market, Gebrselassie reluctantly agreed to be photographed in the streets crowded with vendors and beggars and donkeys carrying heavy loads of hay. Someone who thought he was exploiting this desperate commerce for publicity shouted in Amharic: "Why do you show this part of Ethiopia? Just go to Atlanta and run."
He had carefully guarded against displays of self-importance, and this insult wounded him visibly. Several hours later, the normally ebullient Gebrselassie seemed withdrawn and distracted.
"I am still thinking about this morning," he said.
This humility exists, however, alongside a keenly developed sense of destiny and fulfillment rarely evident in a tattered country where 95 percent of the residents rely on subsistence farming. Since he was a boy, Gebrselassie has kept a world atlas at his home, memorizing the names and places of countries and capitals, eager to travel and be recognized for his prodigious talent.
Where other East African runners remain as faceless in the West as they are successful, Gebrselassie has separated himself with a certain spirit and charisma, and a smile as wide as most of the victory margins in his races. He has taken courses to improve his English, and in whatever language, he has not been afraid to speak his mind.
Last year, bungling by the track federation left the Ethiopian team stranded overnight in the Athens airport en route to the world cross-country championships in Durham, England. First, Gebrselassie helped provide hotel rooms for the 32-athlete contingent. After the championships, he returned home and led a protest through the streets of Addis Ababa to the Prime Minister's office. A number of federation officials were replaced.
If anyone seems poised for the challenge of fulfilling his country's Olympic expectations, it is Gebrselassie. Haile means "my energy" in the Amharic language, he said.
"Ethiopia gets its energy from Haile Gebrselassie," he said.
One hundred miles southeast of Addis Ababa, the geometric hillside fields of the Arsi region bear a hazy resemblance to Switzerland, even in the dry season. Situated on a plateau around 9,000 feet, Arsi is an area fertile with grains like barley, wheat and corn, and with runners like Gebrselassie and Tulu.
Horse-drawn carts replace the mini-bus taxis of the capital, stucco buildings of the villages yield to conical huts of the countryside and gravestones need not be encumbered by metal cages to prevent theft or defacement.
Women and children herd cattle and goats along the two-lane ribbon of road and donkeys carry loads of grain and firewood. Eucalyptus trees and cactus sprout from the rolling, dun-colored landscape. Mounds of teff -- the millet from which the spongy, national bread called injera is made -- squat in the harvested fields like giant corn muffins.
Just before the village of Assela, a four-wheel-drive vehicle leaves the road and bounces along for half a mile through the wheat stubble, coming upon the remains of a thatched-roof hut. This is what is left of where Gebrselassie lived with nine brothers and sisters until he was a teen-ager. The surviving hut served as the family kitchen. The living quarters, made of timber walls packed with mud, are gone, as are the family members, dispersed to Addis or nearby Assela.
As children, Gebrselassie and his brothers tended the crops with oxen and wooden plows and walked up to four miles to haul drinking water from wells. His mother died during childbirth when he was 10, and the children were raised by an older sister. The family farm was larger than many in the country, but the Mengistu regime nationalized the land, slicing away part of the family plot as if it were a birthday cake.
Lacking electricity and, thus, television, Gebrselassie followed sports through a battery-powered transistor radio. When he learned of Yifter's double victory at the 1980 Moscow Games, he said, it left him intoxicated with his Olympic dreams.
"I wanted to be famous," he said. "I wanted people to talk about me."
He ran or walked six miles to school, and to this day, his coach said he can see a slight hitch in his form, a crook in his left arm, which developed from Gebrselassie's carrying his books clutched tightly to his side.
The family could afford one pair of racing shoes, Haile said, and he shared them with his older brother, Tekeye, and a younger sister, Yeshi. Mostly, like other kids, they ran barefoot. But their father, Gebrselassie Bekele, discouraged the sport, believing that it had no practical use for his children, whom he wanted to become doctors, teachers, clerks, anything but runners.
"Don't listen to the radio, go out and look for a job," Haile's father told him, but the son did not listen.
He became a national schoolboy champion at 3,000 meters and, by age 20, he won the 1992 world junior championships at 5,000 and 10,000 meters. Josephat Machuka, a Kenyan challenger, became so frustrated when he was passed near the end of the 10,000-meter race, he slugged Gebrselassie in the back of the head.
"I was so happy, I could almost have died," Gebrselassie's father said of his son's victories. "I stopped telling him about the uselessness of running."
He has set five world records in the last nine months -- 8:07.46 for two miles, 26:43.53 for 10,000 meters, 12:44.39 for 5,000 meters, 13:10.98 for the indoor 5,000 and 7:30.72 for the indoor 3,000 -- running with effortless grace, his head perfectly still, striding like a sprinter on the balls of his feet, his barrel chest jutted forward as if in anticipation of breaking the tape at the finish.
The stunning 12:44.39 that Gebrselassie ran last Aug. 16 in Zurich lopped nearly 11 seconds off the previous 5,000-meter record. He seemed to be carried along on some invisible current as he ran the equivalent of three 4:05 miles, covering the final four laps of the 12 1/2-lap race in a searing 4:00.4.
No one begrudged Gebrselassie two victory laps; many considered this to be track's greatest distance performance, given the 5,000's demands on speed and endurance.
"He ran through a mental barrier, almost like the four-minute mile," said Sydney Maree, the American record holder at 3,000 meters.
Bob Kennedy, America's top 5,000-meter runner, came within a second of his personal best at 13:03.37 in Zurich, but finished 19 seconds back in fourth place.
"Haile looks like he's out there for a fun run," Kennedy said.
Days earlier, Gebrselassie had employed the opposite strategy to win the 10,000-meter race at the world championships in Goteborg, Sweden. He conserved his energy for six miles, then used a blistering kick reminiscent of Yifter, his childhood idol, to cover the final 200 meters in 25.3 seconds. It is this tactical versatility of a boxer that impresses Yifter, the ability to come out punching in one race and to play a patient rope-a-dope the next race.
"Haile is good, not only with his running, but with his brain," Yifter said.
Of course, Gebrselassie has not made a serious attempt at the national pastime: the marathon. Actually, he did run one as a 16-year-old, coming to Addis Ababa for the first time and finishing in an impressive 2 hours 52 minutes, but still he returned home with blistered thighs and a punctured ego. He will try the marathon again, perhaps in two years. Some believe he could run 2:04, breaking countryman Belayneh Dinsamo's world record of 2:06:50 by more than two minutes.
"He will shatter it," said Mark Plaatjes, the 1993 world champion from Boulder, Colo. "He will go through the first half in 62 minutes and be jogging."
In the forest above Addis where he trains, Gebrselassie paid a visit recently to the Orthodox Christian Church called Entoto Mariam. A celebration of the Virgin Mary was under way. Women wore traditional white dresses and scarves, dozens gathered in the solitude of prayer and beggars pressed forward until they were waved away by a man swinging a rubber hose.
This is where Menelik II was crowned emperor in 1882. After the Olympics, Gebrselassie said, he will do something special for the church. Exactly what, he would not say. Already he has been generous. He built a house for his father in Assela, where, because of him, the family can afford to rent a harvester for its fields. Two sisters and a brother live with him in Addis. To friends and children who cannot afford them, he provides running shoes.
"Many people know that Ethiopia is poor," Gebrselassie said. "When I break a world record, maybe people get to know something else about Ethiopia, something good. We can't make planes or cars, we don't have the materials. We do what we can."
Interlocking Olympic rings hover above the stands at the National Stadium. Inside four rings are likenesses of Ethiopia's Olympic champions: Bikila, Wolde, Yifter and Tulu. A question mark is encircled by the fifth ring. Who will be the next gold medalist? The country is counting on Gebrselassie. He is counting on himself.
"If I get Olympic gold," he said, "they will talk the same about Haile Gebrselassie and Abebe Bikila."
