HEADLINE: POLITICS: STEVE FORBES;
Forbes Battles State Party Regulars in New York

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
After a third-place finish in South Carolina, Steve Forbes began campaigning in New York yesterday needing a strong showing in the state's Presidential primary on Thursday.
But his aides say he is finding that the same Republican Party machine that tried to keep him off the ballot is also undermining his efforts to assemble a staff, forcing him to rely on a few renegade Republican consultants and a cadre of young rookies, many of whom joined by simply calling a toll-free number. 
 Nearly all of the state's Republican leaders are supporting Senator Bob Dole, and they have made it clear that they consider Republicans who work for Mr. Forbes to be turncoats who may face retribution.
So the Forbes campaign has had to scramble to fill several of its key posts. Its director in New York City is a 22-year-old, Michael Muller, whose last job was as an aide to a Democratic Assemblywoman. The director in western New York, Moria Reynolds, is also 22 years old.
Ms. Reynolds is a Canadian who became an American citizen in 1992 and registered to vote only after seeing Mr. Forbes on television three months ago. Explaining the hostility that she has felt from party regulars, she recalled that when she visited a local Young Republicans club recently, she was assailed for discussing Mr. Forbes.
"They told me to shut up," she said. "They told me that this was no place to be talking about politics. And it was a Young Republicans meeting!"
Thomas L. Slater, one of only two experienced Republican advisers running the campaign in New York, acknowledged that "the only way that we were able to do this was to find a lot of people who have never been able to participate in politics before."
For many years, Mr. Slater ran political operations for the Republicans who control the State Senate, but since signing on with Mr. Forbes, he too has been an outcast among party leaders.
"Anyone actively involved in politics before that," he said, "was pretty much barred from being able to help us."
Dole officials dismissed such complaints, saying they and state party officials never pressured people to shun the Forbes campaign. They also said that when they challenged Mr. Forbes's nominating petitions in court, they were merely trying to insure that his campaign followed the rules.
"These are just the final desperate cries of negative campaigning from a candidate who has clearly set a benchmark for mudslinging," said Kirill Goncharenko, a spokesman for the Dole campaign in New York, which is closely linked with the state Republican Party.
New York Republicans have not encountered this situation before. Until this year, the New York Republican primary had never been contested because the state party had successfully used ballot rules to keep all challengers to the party's favored candidate out of the race.
But the Forbes campaign spent $1 million to defeat the state party and get his name on the ballot. And with that triumph behind them, Mr. Slater and other campaign officials emphasized that they can beat the party machine again, even with a makeshift staff.
With the state campaign heating up, Mr. Forbes is trailing Mr. Dole by up to 25 percentage points in the latest polls. But as in other states, the Forbes campaign is hoping that television advertisements and appearances by their candidate will make the difference.
The ads may prove to be even more important in New York because of the campaign's weak organization. The campaign said it plans to spend at least $1 million on television advertisements between Saturday and Thursday, including a half-hour block of time for a call-in show for Mr. Forbes.
Political consultants and executives at television stations in New York City said that as far as they could tell, the Forbes campaign had purchased only a small number of advertisements over the weekend, suggesting that the campaign was either holding its fire for a final barrage or was not really committed to spending so much money.
Yesterday, Mr. Forbes was trying to get his message across to New Yorkers on news programs, and found himself on the defensive on WNBC's "News Forum." The moderator, Gabe Pressman, asked whether the loss of the deduction for mortgage interest and for state and local taxes under his flat tax plan would be "a blow" to New Yorkers.
"Just the opposite," Mr. Forbes said. "The Heritage Foundation did a study of my flat tax, not somebody else's variation. It found that the average family would have a tax cut of at least $1,300.
"The thing you have to remember is the flat tax gives you a tax cut," he added. "You get more exemptions, generous exemptions."
However Mr. Forbes tries to reach voters with that message, the strength of his campaign staff could still be an important factor in the primary because of the timing. The primary is on Thursday because Tuesday, the traditional Election Day, is a Jewish holiday, Purim. And since this is also the first contested Republican primary in New York's history, campaign officials worry that many Republican voters may not know or care about the balloting.
The state party, whose tentacles reach from Staten Island to hamlets near the Canadian border, is expected to push hard for Mr. Dole, setting up phone banks, telling local Republican officials to make the rounds and even helping bring some voters to the polls. Many of the Forbes campaign's New York workers have little if any such experience.
The Forbes campaign's difficulty in signing up prominent Republicans could also create problems in the voting booths. In New York, ballots list the names of the candidates -- and the delegates who want to represent them at the Republican National Convention in San Diego.
The Dole delegates and alternates are mostly members of Congress and the State Legislature; those for Mr. Forbes and the other contender in New York, Patrick J. Buchanan, are not widely known. So it is possible that voters who are not particularly pleased with Mr. Dole might still pull his lever because they like the delegate who is linked to him.
The Forbes campaign also stumbled a bit last month by shutting its state headquarters for nearly two weeks as it focused on the Delaware and Arizona primaries, both of which Mr. Forbes won. The campaign now concedes that closing the office, in Albany near the Capitol, was a mistake, and last Thursday, Robert Mark Penna, the other Republican consultant attached to the New York campaign, reopened it.
"Welcome to the zoo," Mr. Penna said after he flicked on the lights in the barren headquarters, which was once stocked with all the materiel for modern-day political warfare: television sets and computers, phones and fax machines, voter lists and maps.
"I'm sure there isn't even a pen in this place," he said.
Mr. Penna spent the next few hours returning phone calls and instructing two volunteers, the only other workers in the office, to send out boxes of Forbes pamphlets (inscribed with "Steve Forbes Will Change Washington").
"I'm desperate for help," he barked at one point into his cellular phone. "What's your name again? Where do you live?"
Mr. Penna, who also worked for Republicans in the State Senate, said the campaign hoped some voters might be angry with party leaders, including Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Gov. George E. Pataki, for trying to kick Mr. Forbes and other candidates off the ballot and for discouraging local officials from aiding Mr. Forbes. The backlash, they said, might help their candidate.
"For those New York Republicans who are interested in open access and a voice, this is an opportunity for them to exercise that," Mr. Penna said.

HEADLINE: New York Gets $8 Billion In Mortgages

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In a broad plan intended to raise the historically low level of home ownership in New York City, Fannie Mae, the nation's largest provider of mortgage loans, is making $8 billion available and changing its rules so that more New Yorkers of all incomes qualify for loans.
The five-year investment program, to be announced today by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and senior officials of the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, has been developed by the lending agency to supplement a nine-year-old housing rehabilitation program in which the city has spent $4 billion to build and renovate housing, selling most of it to people who could not otherwise afford houses or apartments. 
 But Fannie Mae intends to go further, extending its lending plan to middle-income and even affluent New Yorkers. While most Government-subsidized housing programs are limited to low-income families, the Fannie Mae mortgages will be available to people making $75,000 a year and even more.
"The investment plan reflects New York City's unique housing market and needs," said James A. Johnson, chairman of Fannie Mae, "including the low rate of home ownership compared to other parts of the country and the resulting strong reliance on rental housing."
The level of home ownership in New York City has always been low compared with the nationwide level. While 60 percent of American families own their homes, only 29 percent of New Yorkers do, according to city records.
Most of the mortgage lending that will be extended under the Fannie Mae program -- $7 billion -- has been designated for people who buy and live in one- to four-family homes, cooperative apartments or condominiums. With an assortment of new mortgage programs, applicants will be able to qualify with down payments as low as 5 percent, even 3 percent in some cases; be given credit for more of their projected rental income than is now accepted when they apply for financing, and qualify more easily for loans to fix up the property they buy.
The other $1 billion is earmarked for loans to developers who rehabilitate or build rental apartment buildings.
Bankers say Fannie Mae's influence over mortgage lending policies is immense. Fannie Mae, created by Congress in 1968 as an independent shareholder-controlled agency that buys loans from banks and savings associations, does not directly negotiate loans with borrowers. But it provides local lenders with the rules about the kinds of mortgages it will buy from them.
Such rules typically cover how much income an applicant must have, compared with the price of the home and how much down payment is required. And since lenders rely on Fannie Mae to take over almost all the mortgages they extend, bank executives say any change in the agency's rules is almost automatically reflected in local lending policies.
Fannie Mae said most of its mortgage loans would be made in New York City, but some of its new programs would also be offered in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland counties.
"We recognize that the housing issues facing New York City do not stop at its borders," Mr. Johnson said.
The agency said the five-year program, to begin immediately, would increase the home financing it extends in New York City by 12 percent a year. Perhaps more important, by changing the qualification rules, the plan should help buyers and builders in poor neighborhoods.
"The timing could not be more critical," said Deborah C. Wright, the city's Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development. "With budgets under pressure at all levels of government, this will allow us to stretch our dollars further."
Still, some experts said the plan might not be as big a windfall as it first appeared, since Fannie Mae was not offering its mortgages at lower interest rates than would otherwise be available to home buyers.
In contrast, under some Government-subsidized programs, particularly those available in the last decade to builders who rehabilitated multifamily housing, interest rates have typically been about one percentage point below the prevailing rate.
And for people hoping to buy homes with down payments of less than 20 percent, lenders say the Fannie Mae plan will not relieve them of the requirement to buy mortgage insurance as part of their monthly housing payments, which can add thousands of dollars to their costs over the term of the loan.
"If you can't afford conventional financing, you probably won't be able to afford these Fannie Mae programs," said one Manhattan banker familiar with the program, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
Fannie Mae's program for New York City and its suburbs is part of the agency's broader 10-year plan to commit $1 trillion in mortgage loans to 25 cities and poor rural areas. Although Fannie Mae executives said the New York program was its largest, since it would be offered over five years, one announced in Chicago last year is almost as big: $10 billion over seven years.
But housing experts say the New York initiative comes at a critical time because the city's own 10-year housing program, which has won wide praise since it was inaugurated under Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1987, is being squeezed by shrinking budgets and fiscal conservatism.
"This program is an attempt to keep the economic benefits of housing development on track at a time when government subsidies are being cut back," said Kathryn Wylde, president of the New York City Housing Partnership, one of the largest participants in the city's housing program.
The success of Ms. Wylde's group in creating new housing illustrates the city's unusual approach to its housing problem. Acting as a go-between, it has taken over vacant city-owned lots at no cost, arranged financing for developers and not-for-profit neighborhood housing groups, and created 13,000 new single-family homes over the last 10 years in neighborhoods as diverse as the South Bronx, East New York and Williamsburg.
The city's $4 billion housing program, while providing Ms. Wylde's group with vacant lots, has also paid for the renovation of hundreds of blighted, city-owned apartment buildings. In most cases, those have been turned over to community groups to be operated as rental property for low-income tenants, or offered for sale as cooperatives.
But city funds for the program are being reduced. Although Mayor Giuliani said last year that he would support committing $300 million a year to the program, that level of spending is far below the $700 million a year that was spent in the late 1980's.
"New York is unique among American cities in the amount of its own tax dollars that it has committed to housing," said David Jeffers, Fannie Mae's vice president for corporate communications.
"We are going to support the city's efforts in any way we can," he said.
In addition to increasing the money it makes available in New York City and the suburbs, Fannie Mae said it would establish a local office in the city to work with lenders on such things as lending policies in poor areas.
In part, the agency's increased financial commitment to New York and other big cities results from pressure on banks and savings institutions to lend more aggressively to members of minority groups, recent immigrants and others who have traditionally had difficulty buying homes.
That pressure has increased in recent years because of the Community Reinvestment Act, a Federal law that gives borrowers and community groups greater access to the lenders' records, and allows them to challenge or even block bank mergers and branch closings and other business moves when the banks' lending practices in poor areas fall short.
While acknowledging lenders' need to offer more loans to low- and middle-income home-buyers, Fannie Mae executives said Mayor Giuliani and his advisers, who were consulted about the New York City program, insisted that it also provide new benefits for more affluent buyers.
The rules for the five-year plan allow families with incomes up to $75,570 to qualify for mortgages on cooperative apartments, with down payments as low as 5 percent and with no restrictions the co-ops' locations. In cases of people buying one- or two-family homes, Fannie Mae said it would not impose income limits.
"It is very important that we encourage economic integration," Ms. Wright said. She said the Fannie Mae rules were written to help people who wanted to move to neighborhoods where most residents were less affluent than they, including members of minority groups who want to invest in the neighborhoods where they grew up.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Concerns on Gambling Bill

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
Some New Jersey lawmakers are worried that gambling legislation scheduled for debate in the United States House of Representatives on Tuesday could lead to higher taxes and stricter regulations for Atlantic City casinos. 
 The bill, which would create a Federal commission to study the social and economic effects of the gambling industry, has more than 140 co-sponsors and the backing of House leaders. Representative Frank A. LoBiondo, a Republican of Linwood, said the gambling industry has nothing to fear from an objective study, but he and others worry that the commission would be biased against Atlantic City. "The people behind this bill are morally opposed to gambling and would like nothing better than to see it completely eradicated," said Roger Gross, editor of Casino Journal, a gambling newsletter based in New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Free Advice for All

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla.

 BODY:
The makers of Advil are now suggesting that Tylenol may ruin your liver. I suspect Tylenol will soon blaze back with a campaign to hint that Advil rips out your stomach lining. That will give the boys at Bayer aspirin the chance to repeat both competitors' warnings, and to call for unity against the common enemy, headaches.
Thus does advertising art follow political life. Forbes's negative ads weakened Dole for Buchanan, whose rise scared even the Christian Coalition. This resulted in Dole's South Carolina win, enabling him to call for unity in zapping Clinton's failures. 
 Advice to Buchanan: Drop the gun-toting pictures and lock-and-load rhetoric; it stirs up the nuts. Use your famously scornful oratory to take on foreign-agent Farrakhan and Clinton's fear of losing black support by investigating his billion-dollar Libyan tie. You have no black support to lose, and this would thoroughly discombobulate those of us in Israel's Amen Corner.
Advice to Forbes: Keep popping the press. "The pundits were wrong!" you cried in glee after buying up a third of Arizona's G.O.P. As you lose primaries to come, most of us will be happy to have you remind readers of our certainty from Day One that neither a rich novice nor a nativist demagogue has any chance of nomination.
Advice to Alexander: Hang in there. If you aspire to be the party's insurance policy in case Dole stumbles, redirect your campaign away from Dole while you denounce Buchanan's extremism and Forbes's nutty ideas. In that regard --
Forbes is now trying to revivify his flat tax as a tax cut for the middle class; if this is not to produce a horrendous deficit, where are his ideas to slow spending growth? And "the dollar should be as good as gold" is his code phrase for a return to the gold standard -- ask Forbes if this would not boost interest rates to Carter-era levels once he plunged the country into red ink.
And a slew of advice to Dole:
1. Don't forget the theme that helped get you off the floor. This is a fight for the "heart and soul of the Republican Party." Despite today's euphoria, you will be upset in several states, and weak showings will be magnified by scrap-lovers as major derailments; you are still months away from a unity pitch.
Remember that Buchanan's boast to his "movement" is that he will force you to keep an extreme anti-abortion plank in the platform and will have a veto over your pick for a pro-choice running mate. Such concessions would guarantee your election defeat after what would be branded your "surrender in San Diego."
But nothing you can do in appeasing the nativist, populist, isolationist fringe will stop Buchanan from making a smasheroo bolting speech in prime time. He hopes to combine with Ross Perot if those two can ever settle on which one is to head their third party.
2. Your willingness to talk about your war wounds and hospital struggle will be effective as long as it appears reluctant; make the point about being in the real "crossfire" for the next few weeks and then move on. Obvious and repeated refusal to wave the bloody shirt better reflects the modest Dole character and will score more points than waving it.
3. For God's sake, memorize a simple two-sentence position on abortion and be ready for any question in a joint appearance that begins "If your wife were being raped . . ."
4. Revivify the balanced budget. The media have become bored with deficit reduction; voters have not.
5. Pose the question: In today's showbiz politics, can a doer defeat a talker? This will undermine the strength of Buchanan and Clinton, and provide a rationale for the diffident Dole style. When confronted by ABC's Sam Donaldson for your referring to yourself in the third person, you popped up with an endearing "Gets the name out."
6. Don't get snookered by the "vision thing" to compete with Clinton's double vision. With a Republican Congress in place, America needs not so much a President with more vision as a President with a signing pen.
Today's G.O.P. has more vision than it knows what to do with; the trick is to make real the vision of balanced budgets, local empowerment and global engagement. Brandish that pen you carry to keep your fingers from splaying: Clinton will veto; Dole will sign.

HEADLINE: Meyer Schapiro, 91, Is Dead; His Work Wove Art and Life

BYLINE: By JOHN RUSSELL 

 BODY:
Dr. Meyer Schapiro, University Professor Emeritus at Columbia University, multidisciplinary critic and historian, galvanic teacher, lifelong radical and for more than 50 years a pre-eminent figure in the intellectual life of New York, died yesterday at the Greenwich Village house that had been his home for more than 60 years. He was 91.
As an academic, Dr. Schapiro excelled in two completely different fields. It was as a historian and elucidator of Romanesque sculpture that he made his name in 1931. He also wrote on 19th-century and early-20th-century art -- from Courbet and Cezanne to Mondrian and the Abstract Expressionists -- in ways that gave new dignity to the discussion of modern art. 
 But it was not in his nature to function as a specialist within any one particular discipline. Even less was he a satrap of the seminar with specific "turf" of his own to protect. It was, in fact, the very essence of Meyer Schapiro that he never conceived of any aspect of art, of belief or of language in isolation. He regarded all forms, schools and systems of knowledge as interrelated and interdependent. As far as he was concerned, he had been put on earth to know, and to make known, the correspondences between them all. And he addressed himself not to the insider, but to the generality of intelligent human beings.
An archetypal Jewish immigrant, Meyer Schapiro arrived in the United States at the age of 3 from Lithuania, where Jews were subject to periodic and odious harassment. It was in New York, the fulcrum and heartland of immigration, that he lived out his life. New York made him welcome, nourished his fiery and agile intelligence, and made it possible for him to master one discipline after another with a speed and a thoroughness that have had few parallels in our century. What New York had given him, he gave back many times over.
The painter Robert Motherwell said in 1974: "It was in order to study with Meyer Schapiro that I came to New York, which was the single most decisive factor in my development. He introduced me to European artists in exile here from the war in the 1940's, and this was the second most important factor in my orientation. I have great admiration for him as a sage, though I disagree with him on some judgments. I admire him as an irreplaceable man and as an extraordinary representative of the unique greatness of New York City."
William S. Rubin, formerly the director of painting and sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art, said: "Few art historians have the eye and mind of a Meyer Schapiro. And none of those shared his extraordinary humanity. So when Meyer Schapiro communed with great art, he saw kinds of things that eluded the rest of us."
Hilton Kramer, the editor of The New Criterion, said: "In my generation, one of the key points of entry into the life of art in New York was the experience of hearing Dr. Schapiro lecture on modern painting at the New School for Social Research. Those lectures, always crowded with artists and writers, were dazzling performances that left one in no doubt that the great work of the modern painters stood at the very center of life."
In lecture hall and seminar, Dr. Schapiro would sometimes start from a prepared text or with a purpose that he summarized at the outset. His speech at such times might be plain and straightforward to the point of hesitation. But before long an almost perceptible halo of cerebration began to wreathe his head. As he took off into an empyrean to which he alone had access, ideas and intuitions crowded in from every quarter. At such times, all present were drawn into a magic circle that he had been tracing since the late 1920's. It could have been overwhelming, but such was the intellectual courtesy behind it that those in his audience left the room convinced, for just a minute or two, that they were as clever as he was.
As to the general direction of his work, he himself defined it when, in 1973, he was given an award by the Art Dealers Association of America. "The study of art history" he said, "presupposes that art is a universal and permanent feature of civilized life, and that what we do to preserve it, and to discriminate the best of it, will contribute to future enjoyment as much as to our own."
"Our concern with the work of art, however touched by vanity or greed, is a homage beyond self-interest," he continued. "Through it we surmount, if only at rare moments, the limitations of our striving, possessive selves and, as an old poet says, 'into glory peep.' "
 
A Remarkable Memory For Scholarly Detail
All his life, Dr. Schapiro had a capacity for total recall. No matter what subject was raised in general conversation, he could usually name not only the necessary books on the subject but the chapter heading and even the page reference that was most appropriate. In this regard, he was rarely faulted. Equally remarkable was his visual memory for works of art that he had once seen and never forgotten.
When the sculptor Jacques Lipchitz was newly arrived in New York from Europe during World War II, he spent an evening in Dr. Schapiro's company. The talk turned to the great collections of tribal art in the Musee de l'Homme in Paris, and in particular to a piece that he had especially admired. To help Lifschitz recall it, Dr. Schapiro took a sheet of paper and drew, from memory and to scale, not only the piece in question but every other piece that had been in the case with it some years before. He did not see this as anything out of the ordinary.
Artists and writers prized in particular the unexpected and far-ranging connections that he could summon up when in their company. The French painter Fernand Leger was not given to mystical observances of any kind, and when Dr. Schapiro took him to the basement of the Pierpont Morgan Library during World War II he may have wondered what was in store for him. But it was thanks to Dr. Schapiro that Leger found, in an 11th-century illumination from the Beatus Apocalypse, an important element in the vocabulary of his later paintings. This was one of many occasions on which Dr. Schapiro dealt with living artists on an inspired basis. Another was a well-known occasion in 1952 on which he convinced Willem de Kooning that his "Woman I" was not a failure, as Mr. de Kooning had supposed, but a success from which other successes would surely come.
More recently, the point was put with ideal concision by R. B. Kitaj, the American painter, who now lives in London. "Meyer Schapiro was here," he wrote. "Like having Plato in the living room!" But then, there were few people who came within his orbit and were not changed for the better. For those who worked with words, he was the speaker they most wanted to hear and the reader they most wanted to please. Irving Howe, the editor, critic and commentator, once said in that context, "To gain even his conditional approval for something I have written has been the single highest reward to which I could aspire."
In 1974, on the occasion of Dr. Schapiro's 70th birthday, 12 of the leading artists of the day made original lithographs, etchings and silk-screens that were sold in an edition of 100. The proceeds were given to a fund for the endowment of a chair in Dr. Schapiro's name in the department of art history and archeology at Columbia. The artists were Jasper Johns, Ellsworth Kelly, Alexander Liberman, Stanley William Hayter, Roy Lichtenstein, Andre Masson, Robert Motherwell, Claes Oldenburg, Robert Rauschenberg, Frank Stella, Andy Warhol and Saul Steinberg.
 
A 3-Year-Old Immigrant Gets a New First Name
Meyer Schapiro was born in Siauliai, Lithuania, on Sept. 23, 1904. He was the son of Nathan Menachem Schapiro and Fanny Adelman Schapiro. The descendant of Talmudic scholars, Nathan Schapiro in first youth abandoned the Orthodox Jewish traditions in which he had been reared and became influenced by the Jewish Socialist Bund and the Haskala, an Eastern European enlightenment movement that welcomed Western secular learning.
In 1906 Nathan Schapiro immigrated on his own to the United States, where he found work as a teacher of Hebrew at the Yitzcak Elchanan Yeshiva on the Lower East Side in New York. After only a year, he had saved enough money to send for his family. While Nathan's son was being processed on Ellis Island for entry into the United States at the age of 3, his name was changed from Meir to Meyer. With his family settled in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, Nathan Schapiro prospered as a paper-and-twine jobber. His intellectual interests were uncommonly varied. Yiddish was the first language in the family home, but he kept up with literary (as distinct from spoken) Hebrew, secular Bible studies, the theories of Darwin, books on language, the contemporary socialist press and much else.
While a pupil at Public School 84 in Brooklyn, Meyer Schapiro was encouraged by his parents to let his curiosity run free. He read, drew, took and developed photographs, mastered electrical gadgetry and did not disdain sports. Like many another brilliant Jewish student at that time, he found a second home in the Hebrew Settlement House in Brownsville, where he was the only child in an evening art class that was taught by the painter and etcher John Sloan. In 1975, at the 75th-anniversary celebrations of the settlement house, he pointed to the medal that his wife, Dr. Lillian Milgrim, was wearing around her neck. She had received that medal from the settlement house for teaching at its Sabbath school, Dr. Schapiro said.
While at Boys High School in Brooklyn, he received very high grades in Latin and mathematics, attended lectures on anthropology and economics at the Young Peoples' Socialist League, and worked summers as a Western Union delivery boy, a warehouse packer, an electrical-supply assembler and an adjustment clerk at Macy's.
In 1920, at the age of 16, he graduated from high school. In September of that year he entered Columbia College as the holder of both a Pulitzer scholarship and a Regents scholarship. Already convinced that he would never make the grade as a practicing artist, he chose an undergraduate curriculum that included Latin, living languages, mathematics, ancient and modern literature, anthropology, philosophy and art history. The poet and English professor Mark Van Doren remembered Meyer Schapiro as a Columbia student with "thick, curly black hair, eager white cheeks, darkly rolling eyes" and "a passion to know and make known."
Still not yet 20, he received his bachelor's degree with honors in art history and philosophy. What he called his "sense of the deep connections of art with the totality of culture" was already shaping the direction of the life's work that was to come. Both anthropology (under Franz Boas) and architecture tempted him, meanwhile, and art history as then taught at Columbia seemed to him almost derisory, based as it was on courses given, in his view, by "men who had never really conducted investigations after writing their Ph.D. theses."
But art history remained the discipline that would best satisfy both his love of learning and his love of art. Turned down by the department of art history at Princeton -- a rejection that he attributed at least in part to his being Jewish -- he settled for graduate work in art history at Columbia. The next years were decisive for his career on two separate counts. One was the fact that the distinguished medievalist Ernest DeWald had moved from Princeton to Columbia. The other was that Meyer Schapiro taught himself German (by way of Yiddish) and was thus able to read the seminal work of two great scholars, Wilhelm Voge and Alois Riegl.
 
An Abbey in France Reveals Its Secrets
From Voge, he learned to study the emergence of the monumental style in 11th- and 12th-century Europe. From Riegl, he learned the correspondence between changes in art and the development of individual perception from one stage of life to another. Fired up by these revelations, he chose as the subject for his doctoral dissertation the cloister and portal of Moissac, an abbey in southwestern France that had been built about A.D. 1100 and had long been well known for its Romanesque sculptures. Those sculptures had always been regarded primarily as rudimentary way stations on the road to Gothic art and the work of anonymous artisans who wished only to dedicate themselves to God. But in 1922 the French art historian Emile Male argued in his book on 12th-century religious art in France that on the contrary, they marked "the very inception of the modern tradition in sculpture."
Five years of research, much of it on site in France and elsewhere, went into the doctoral dissertation, which was accepted by Columbia in 1929. Dr. Schapiro's research went far beyond the implications of Moissac itself. Medieval church history, liturgy, theology, social history, illuminated manuscripts, folklore, epigraphy, the analysis of ornament and national characteristics (real or imagined) all were pressed into service and synthesized. As a result, what had been thought of as antiquarian artifacts were seen to have a completely different character.
"A new sphere of artistic creation," Dr. Schapiro called it, "without religious content and imbued with values of spontaneity, individual fantasy, delight in color and movement, and the expression of feelings that anticipate modern art. This new art, on the margins of religious work, was accompanied by a conscious taste of the spectators for the beauty of workmanship, materials and artistic devices, apart from religious meanings."
In 1928, before his dissertation was completed, he was appointed a lecturer in art history at Columbia. That year he also married Dr. Milgrim, a pediatrician. As of 1931, when part of his dissertation appeared in The Art Bulletin, his exceptional stature was widely realized. "For the first time," one scholar recalled, "Meyer treated a set of Romanesque sculptures as art, rather than as documents." The rest of Dr. Schapiro's teaching career was spent primarily at Columbia, where he became assistant professor in 1936, associate professor in 1946, full professor in 1952 and University Professor in 1965. Named University Professor Emeritus in 1973, he went to Columbia once a week to teach a graduate class on "Theory and Methods of Investigation in Art."
He also lectured at New York University from 1932 to 1936, and at the New School for Social Research from 1936 to 1952. His lectures at the New School had a particular importance for artists and writers, in that they coincided with the development of a New York school of painting that was to win widespread international acclaim. Meanwhile, European modernism was still little known in the United States, and when paintings by Picasso, Georges Braque and Joan Miro arrived in New York they were often seen literally out of context. Dr. Schapiro at that time performed a public service by validating them in intellectual, historical and moral terms that were a revelation to many in his audience.
During the 1930's, the Schapiros' home in Greenwich Village was much visited by members of the radical left, and Dr. Schapiro became a contributor to The Marxist Quarterly, The New Masses, The Nation and The Partisan Review. It was, however, noted by the novelist Saul Bellow that "Meyer never took part in any of the quarrels and backbiting and vendettas. . . . He was the one person in the Village against whom no one had anything terrible to say."
 
Speaking a Great Deal But Publishing Little
For many years, Dr. Schapiro was reluctant to publish (or, in some cases, to republish) his lectures and papers. An annunciatory quality had always been fundamental to his performances on the platform and in the classroom. The printed page ruled out the new insights that came crowding in -- or so it seemed -- on the spur of the moment and in the heat of exposition. For this reason, his output in print between 1931 and the late 1970's was almost absurdly small in relation to his reputation as both an art historian of the first rank and the most inspiring teacher of his time.
"Vincent van Gogh" (1950) and "Cezanne" (1952) were treasured texts, but brief. "Words and Pictures" (1973), likewise brief, applied the new science of semiotics to the study of medieval illuminated manuscripts. Other writings had almost a clandestine circulation. But in 1977 George Braziller began publishing a four-volume series of his selected essays and lectures. "Romanesque Art" came out in 1977, "Modern Art: 19th and 20th Centuries" in 1978 and "Late Antique, Early Christian and Medieval Art" in 1979. The fourth volume, "Theory and Philosophy of Art: Style, Artist and Society," was published in 1994.
The former pupil of John Sloan painted and drew for much of his life. In 1987 he was persuaded by Rainer Crone and Elizabeth Ferrer of the art history department at Columbia to exhibit his work in the Wallach Art Gallery in Schermerhorn Hall. The 65 drawings and paintings, dating from 1919 to 1979, touched lightly on portraiture, landscape, family subjects, the all-embracing horror of World War II and the potential of abstraction. A self-portrait drawing made when he was 16 was a sure guide to his ardent nature, and as testimony to his gift for personal loyalty there were two portraits of Whittaker Chambers, the former Communist whose testimony was instrumental in the perjury conviction of Alger Hiss.
In 1966-67 Dr. Schapiro was Charles Eliot Norton Lecturer at Harvard University. In 1968 he was Slade Professor of Art at Oxford University. In May 1974 he was a visiting lecturer at the College de France in Paris. In May 1975 the alumni of Columbia awarded him the Alexander Hamilton Medal for distinguished service and accomplishment. In 1976 he was elected a member of the National Institute of Arts and Letters.
In addition to his wife, Dr. Schapiro is survived by two children, Miriam Schapiro Grosof of Manhattan and Ernest Schapiro of Washington; two grandsons; a great grandson, and an older brother, Morris Schapiro.

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on March 4 about Meyer Schapiro, art critic and historian, misidentified the settlement house in Brownsville, Brooklyn, where he attended an evening art class. It was the Hebrew Educational Society, not the Hebrew Settlement House.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Venezuela Again Opens to Foreign Oil Concerns

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela

 BODY:
Venezuela, a petroleum-rich country that is currently starved for cash, is moving to vastly increase its crude oil production.
This is good news for private foreign oil companies, which, 20 years after all foreign oil operations were nationalized, are rushing back to the South American country at Government invitation to help prospect for crude. And Clinton Administration officials are praising Venezuela's plans because the production surge will insure that Venezuela, the No. 1 petroleum supplier for the United States, will have plenty of capacity to satisfy America's growing energy appetite. 
 But Venezuela's program to double crude production over 10 years is bad news for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the group that Venezuela helped found in 1960. Whether Venezuela's increases in production will send world prices tumbling is in dispute. But they underline OPEC's rising inability to enforce the production quotas that are the organization's principal tool for stabilizing crude prices, industry analysts said.
"Venezuela is saying, in effect, 'forget OPEC,' " said Chris K. Skrebowski, editor of Petroleum Economist, a London-based publication that monitors the world oil industry. "Venezuela is already producing far beyond its quota, and now they're publicly and cheerfully saying onward and upward. They haven't left OPEC -- they're just not paying attention to it any more."
For several years, Venezuelan production has been creeping upward, and it has surpassed its daily OPEC production quota of 2.4 million barrels every year since 1993. Last year, Venezuela pumped more than 2.7 million barrels of crude each day, nearly 400,000 barrels over its OPEC quota. And now Petroleos de Venezuela, the state-owned oil company, has begun a sweeping 10-year, $60 billion investment program aimed at increasing crude production above five million barrels a day by 2005, said Juan M. Szabo, the company's exploration and production coordinator.
These plans, under consideration since 1992, are moving off the drawing boards just as the country's broader economy is sliding into its worst crisis in years. Standard & Poor's has downgraded Venezuela's credit rating to B from B+, criticizing the Government for failing to reduce its fiscal deficit.
"The outlook is negative," Standard & Poor's said.
Andres Serbin, a political analyst who is often critical of President Rafael Caldera's policies, called management of the country's energy policies by Petroleos de Venezuela executives "an island of coherence within the ocean of disorder that characterizes the Government's economic policy."
Petroleos de Venezuela's production plans include three major initiatives. The biggest brought executives from 60 foreign companies to Caracas recently for a public auction of exploration and production rights to eight promising oil regions, scattered across the country. Those areas, totaling 4.5 million acres, are estimated to contain at least seven billion barrels of medium and light crude; if those estimates pan out, the new oil will increase Venezuela's proven reserves to 72 billion barrels. By comparison, Saudi Arabia's reserves are put at 255 billion barrels.
Thirteen of the 60 bidders, including Amoco, Mobil, and Conoco, a unit of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, emerged as winners. The terms to which they agreed were extremely advantageous to Venezuela, analysts said -- the Government's share of profits from any oil discovered would range from 88 percent to 92 percent. That compares with the approximately 50 percent share the United States Government taxes away from domestic American crude producers.
But foreign executives expressed enthusiasm at getting a shot at business in Venezuela anyway.
"We're just delighted we had a chance to participate," said John Williams, president of the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company, which won rights to explore a vast tract of swampland in the Orinoco River delta east of Caracas.
Mobil reported its winning bid in an advertisement on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times that praised Venezuela for encouraging outside investment and said the nation's "importance in the petroleum sector is too crucial to ignore." Mobil is a partner with Veba Oel A.G. of Germany and Nippon Oil Ltd. of Japan in a consortium that bought rights to explore 445,000 acres onthe southeastern shore of Lake Maracaibo.
"In terms of long-range economic development, this oil opening is probably the single most important event this year for the U.S. in Latin America," Jeffrey S. Davidow, the American Ambassador to Caracas, said.
The 13 foreign companies are expected to invest $11 billion in Venezuela before production in the eight new fields reaches a peak in 2005, Mr. Szabo said in an interview at the state company's towering headquarters in Caracas.
That investment will be overshadowed, however, by Petroleos de Venezuela's spending on the company's own expanded exploration and drilling activities, which Mr. Szabo estimated would reach $33 billion over the same 10 years. Foreign companies working on special projects aimed at extracting and refining extra-heavy crude and liquefied gas are expected to invest an additional $16 billion by 2005, he said.
Mr. Szabo insisted that Venezuela's production goals were consistent with OPEC policies.
Over 10 years, world oil needs are likely to rise from the current daily level of 69 million barrels to more than 80 million barrels, and only a handful of Middle Eastern countries and Venezuela, all OPEC members, are in a position to increase production to meet the demand, Mr. Szabo said. As a result, Venezuela should be able to negotiate a sizable increase in its OPEC quota, he said.
Venezuela's decision to open the oil spigot has, however, irritated several of its OPEC partners, several experts said.
"The Saudis and several other OPEC countries have talked to them," said Paul Huebert, an international energy analyst based in Washington. "If OPEC can't even keep major producers like Venezuela in line, then the organization is in trouble."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Generally Moves Lower But Advances Against the Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the German mark yesterday, but it ended lower against the Japanese yen and other major currencies in thin trading.
The mark came under selling pressure as traders speculated that the German Government would cut interest rates again to bolster the weak German economy. Lower rates would make investments denominated in marks less attractive. 
 "The mark was sold rather heavily most of the day," said Stephen Flanagan, senior foreign exchange dealer at Credit Agricole. "The market is becoming rather sensitive to German economic figures and the potential weakness they may show."
The German Government is expected to issue fresh data this week pointing to a weak economy.
The dollar rose to 1.4780 marks in late trading in New York, from 1.4773 marks on Friday. But it fell to 105.15 yen, compared with 105.41 yen on Friday.
The British pound rose to $1.5275 from $1.5269.
The Italian lira surged to its highest level in 13 months against the mark, which also helped the dollar against the mark, dealers said.
"We heard talk of overseas buying in Italian bonds, which caused the lira to strengthen against its trading partners," said Philip Vasan, managing director of foreign exchange derivatives at CS First Boston. "That was one more factor that helped the mark weaken."
In turn, the dollar was able to recoup ground lost against the mark in Asia and Europe early yesterday.
The yen rallied against the mark and put pressure on the dollar as Japanese investors continued to shed dollar-based assets as the March 31 end of the Japanese fiscal year draws closer.
But the dollar held close to 105 yen for most of the day, bolstered by rumors that the Bank of Japan was buying dollars in the open market whenever the price neared 104.50 yen. A rising yen makes Japanese exports more expensive abroad.
Still, the dollar was not as strong as it had been in recent weeks, and some traders noted lingering concerns over the stalled efforts to balance the Federal budget.
"The dollar should have been putting in a better performance, given the weak news coming out of Germany and the obvious signs the Bank of Japan has no intention of seeing the yen appreciate," said Chris Widness, international economist at Chemical Securities.

HEADLINE: Consumer Spending Drops As Income Growth Slows

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
The growth in personal income slowed in January after increasing in 1995 at the fastest pace in five years, and consumer spending fell for the first time in three years, the Commerce Department said today.
The report, which said personal income grew an anemic one-tenth of 1 percent, to $6.25 trillion in January, from $6.24 trillion a month earlier, provided additional evidence of the economy's weakness as the year began. 
 But many analysts said the sluggishness was due mostly to the blizzard and the Federal Government shutdowns.
"We hit a bit of a pothole earlier this year, but it was weather-related," said Stephen S. Roach, an economist with Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. "While January was weak, all signs point to a fairly significant rebound in February."
The January gain in personal income was the smallest since last August. However, an advance of six-tenths of 1 percent in December, helped raise incomes for all of 1995 by 6.1 percent -- the highest gain since a 6.7 percent increase in 1990. That growth far outpaced last year's inflation rate of 2.5 percent.
The department also reported that consumer spending fell five-tenths of 1 percent in January, to $5.01 trillion from $5.03 trillion. It was the third drop in five months and the largest since a decline of six-tenths of 1 percent in August 1992.
"January was a tough month," Mr. Roach said. "The weather and the Government shutdown had a detrimental impact on almost everything we were measuring."
Donald Straszheim, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, agreed that the economic expansion, now five years old, had hit "a soft spot" but would escape a recession in the near future.
"The U.S. economy enjoyed eight-year-long recoveries in the 1960's and 1980's, with soft landings embedded in the middle," he said. "We think it is happening again."
For all of 1995, consumer spending, which represents about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, rose only 4.8 percent, down from 5.5 percent in 1994.
Disposable income -- income after taxes -- rose three-tenths of 1 percent in January after jumping seven-tenths of 1 percent a month earlier. And Americans' savings rate -- savings as a percentage of disposable income -- was 5.3 percent, highest since a 6.3 percent rate in December 1993.
Spending on big-ticket durable goods such as cars and computers fell 5.3 percent in January. But outlays for nondurable goods such as food, fuel and services edged up two-tenths of 1 percent.
The income and spending figures were not adjusted for inflation. When adjusted, disposable incomes were unchanged after rising six-tenths of 1 percent in December. Spending fell eight-tenths of 1 percent, erasing an advance of eight-tenths of 1 percent the previous month.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Investors Scramble to Sell As Strong New Year Rally Dims

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Gold prices fell yesterday to their lowest levels in two months as a New Year's rally that had carried the market to six-year highs faded, and disappointed investors scrambled to sell.
"People were getting impatient, and the price of gold wasn't going anywhere," said Greg Drury, director of precious metals at Mitsui & Company in the United States. 
 At the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, gold for April delivery tumbled $5, to $395.20 an ounce, the lowest since Jan. 3 and off nearly $25 from the six-year high of $419.60 reached on Feb. 2.
With energy and grain prices also falling, the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities dropped 0.85, to 243.61.
Other precious metals prices also fell. May silver lost 12.3 cents, to $5.417 an ounce, and April platinum dropped $4.80, to $408 an ounce.
Dinsa Mehta, managing director at Chase Manhattan, said the gold market seemed overbought recently, but traders and analysts said there was no fresh news behind the selloff.
Bullish investors had focused on expectations that gold mine output would remain stagnant while buying in the fast-growing Asian economies would continue rising. But the continuing strength in the stock market deflated expectations that investors would move into hard assets like gold.
Crude oil prices fell further, casting doubt on whether the energy sector would mount a late winter rally.
April crude lost 24 cents, to $19.20 a barrel, and April gasoline declined 1.02 cents, to 58.73 cents a gallon at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Grain prices fell, hurt partly by moves by two large poultry producers to reduce output, partly because of the high cost of chicken feed made from corn and soybeans.
The approach of the South American soybean harvest also weighed on prices, with March soybeans falling 8 cents, to $7.2025 a bushel at the Chicago Board of Trade. March corn fell 4 cents, to $3.8925 a bushel, and March wheat declined 3 cents, to $5.1225 a bushel.

HEADLINE: Clinton Urges Action on Bills to Create Jobs and Lift Incomes

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: TAYLOR, Mich., March 4

 BODY:
President Clinton today responded to the anxieties about job security that are rippling through the Republican Presidential race by repackaging his legislative program as a "growth agenda" that will "keep creating jobs and raise incomes" to allow all Americans to compete in the new global economy.
Appearing before a cheering, flag-waving crowd crammed into a public works garage in this blue-collar suburb of Detroit, the President listed his economic achievements, noting that his Administration had cut the Federal deficit in half and fostered new jobs in three years. 
 "But we must do more," he said, "if we're going to create jobs and raise incomes and give these people who are being downsized a chance to go right on with their lives and raise their children and live with hope and dignity instead of frustration and a sense of failure."
The President called on Congress to pass several languishing pocketbook measures, including an increase in the minimum wage, tax deductions for post-secondary school tuition, and Federal vouchers to pay for worker retraining, and a bill that would make health insurance more accessible.
"Congress must do its part," Mr. Clinton said, challenging the Republican-led Congress to act in the next 60 days to pass this program, which he labeled a "growth agenda."
"It's a long way from now until the election, but every week between now and the election the American people will get up and go to work, they still have to pay their bills, they still have to educate their children, they still have to try to keep their dreams alive."
Mr. Clinton's speech in this politically crucial industrial state illustrated the balance he is trying to strike on the critical battleground of the economy at a time when Republicans have started to refer to the "Clinton crunch" of stagnant wages.
Mr. Clinton gave a rhetorical nod to the growing chorus of Democrats who want to see a more populist attack on corporations. Acknowledging public concern about rounds of layoffs by companies seeking to raise their stock prices, Mr. Clinton said, "We need people to really think about whether it's the fair and right thing to do when you see these downsizings."
"If they have to do it to keep the business afloat every American can understand that," he added. "But no one should lose a job for short term considerations that are not necessary for the long-term well-being of the profitable enterprise."
But the President did not take the next step advocated by Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and Congressional Democratic leaders and propose using the tax structure to reward corporations that give their workers job security or profit-sharing or better pension plans and health benefits.
Instead, Mr. Clinton held out economic growth, and measures to promote growth, as the antidotes to worker anxiety and to a politics of class warfare.
"We are not a people who object to others being successful; we do not resent people amassing their own wealth fairly won in a free enterprise system," he said. "The only thing we resent is when every American who is doing the right thing and working hard and playing by the rules doesn't have a chance to be treated fairly."
Mr. Clinton made no mention of Patrick J. Buchanan, the Republican candidate who has most sought to capitalize on worker discontent with a platform of protectionism and tariffs on goods from Japan, China and developing nations.
But providing a clear counterpoint to Mr. Buchanan, the President pointed to the upsurge in the American auto industry and attributed it in part to the opening of markets in Japan.
"Our auto industry is back," Mr. Clinton said, drawing applause in this state where the auto industry is a lifeline. "The world's best workers are making the best cars, and once again, for the first time in 15 years, our auto industry is leading the world in sales and progress and profits."
The President noted that in the last year American auto exports to Japan had increased 37 percent.
Most of Mr. Clinton's day in the Detroit area was devoted to campaign fund-raising. At a luncheon that had been rescheduled from the autumn because of the funeral of Israel's slain Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, Mr. Clinton brought in $700,000 for his own campaign and for the Democratic National Committee.
He then moved on to a more exclusive affair for about 100 people in the Detroit suburbs sponsored by David Hermelin, a real estate developer. Mr. Clinton's aides said the stop was expected to raise $1 million for the coordinated campaigns of the state and national Democratic parties, and the Democratic Congressional campaign committees.

HEADLINE: The Real Zyuganov

BYLINE: By Adrian Karatnycky; Adrian Karatnycky is the president of Freedom House, which monitors democracy and human rights. He is the co-author, with Nadia Diuk, of "New Nations Rising: The Fall of the Soviets and the Challenge of Independence."

 BODY:
Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist Party leader who is the current favorite to win Russia's presidential elections in June, tries hard to sound like a reasonable man.
At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, last month and in recent meetings with American business leaders, he has insisted that he believes in private enterprise balanced by a strong social safety net. He has written in The New York Times that he wants to live in peace with the United States. 
 Such conciliatory statements have led many Westerners to call him a social democrat. Others have expressed doubts: If he's a social democrat, why is his party full of Communist hard-liners who backed the 1991 coup against Mikhail Gorbachev?
So is Mr. Zyuganov an agreeable social democrat or troglodyte Communist? On the basis of his writings, he emerges as neither. He is a more worrisome figure: a conservative traditionalist, a Russian nationalist, a proponent of pan-Slavic reunification.
In the last year, Mr. Zyuganov has produced a series of books bearing ponderous titles like "Beyond the Horizon" and "I Believe in Russia," which exude a sort of mystical nationalism. All posit a millennial struggle between East and West that began in 1054 with the schism between Orthodox and Roman Catholic Christianity.
Orthodoxy's fight against Catholicism and Protestantism is based, says Mr. Zyuganov, on the fact that the West has "broken loose from its original cultural-religious traditions," largely because of the Industrial Revolution, which accelerated moral decline.
There are, of course, the usual villains. In "Beyond the Horizon," which was issued last summer, Mr. Zyuganov writes of the "ever more perceptible influence of Judaic dispersal, whose influence consistently grew by the day, even by the hour" and so contributed to the decoupling of the West from its Christian moral roots.
His convoluted prose echoes the stereotypes and conspiracy theories prevalent in traditional anti-Semitic tracts: "The Jewish diaspora, which traditionally controlled the financial life of the continent, began expanding its own market by becoming the bearer of the controlling packet of shares in the complete industrial-economic system of Western civilization."
Mr. Zyuganov saves his greatest venom for liberal democracy, which he blames for most of the ills of the modern world. He is remarkably kind to Stalin, who, he says, restored the Eurasian tradition to the center of Soviet life.
Although he avoids passing judgment on Stalin's crimes, he clearly admires the leader's national Bolshevism. Mr. Zyuganov suggests that Stalin "understood the urgent necessity of harmonizing new realities with a centuries-long Russian tradition."
If only Stalin had lived a few more years, Mr. Zyuganov sighs, he would have restored Russia to its former greatness and saved it from the "cosmopolitans" who have ruled it in various guises since his death.
In an ominous declaration of his ambition to extend Russia's territories, Mr. Zyuganov writes approvingly of Alexander III, the 19th-century Czar whose reign saw Russia's "southern border expand by 1,000 kilometers toward Afghanistan."
To prepare for a new expansion, Mr. Zyuganov favors a strategy of turning inward in order to to cast all resources and effort toward "internal evolution." By this, he apparently means that a self-reliant Russia could exact its international influence on its own terms.
Although he purports to be a Communist, he makes little mention of Marx and Lenin. Rather, he elegizes Russia as the "idealist nation," the "dreamer-nation," the "mobilizer-nation."
Some Westerners say that we should view his rhetoric as nothing more than election year hyperbole. To be sure, Mr. Zyuganov may be attempting to cunningly straddle the Red-Brown spectrum with the aim of building a Communist-nationalist coalition to propel him to the presidency. But his writings, which outline a comprehensive, coherent philosophy, suggest something more than political expediency. They show a genuine commitment to the extreme ideas he advances.
What would a President Zyuganov mean for the West? He speaks with a dangerous moral absolutism that resembles the ideological didacticism of Soviet Communism. He aggrandizes the Soviet Union's historic role as the rival of the United States. And he places himself at the center of an epic struggle against the secular. As President, his top international priority would be to bring the territory of the former Soviet Union under Russian rule and build close relations with the Islamic world and China.
Thus, while Mr. Zyuganov may not be a Communist, he is something worse. Neither Red nor Pink, Mr. Zyuganov is White -- the latest incarnation in a centuries-long tradition of Russian nationalists who celebrate Orthodox Christianity, Slavic unity and imperial expansion.
On policy matters, he is quite specific. He opposes the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which he says is a conspiracy of big-business interests. He rails at the United Nations and the threat of a foreign-dominated world government. He despises the International Monetary Fund and says the international financial system is cheating the little guy.
As for domestic issues, he believes that abortion is immoral and should be banned. He is tough on crime and contemptuous of what he regards as a fundamentally corrupt political establishment. He complains that the average worker has seen his standard of living erode. He believes his nation is God's country, steered by a unique moral vision, but he worries that the secular and commercial values of consumerism have degraded the nation's spiritual purity.
Does all this sound oddly familiar? Discontented Russians aren't the only ones with whom such ideas are finding resonance. Perhaps it's time for a candidates' summit: Patrick Buchanan, meet Gennadi Zyuganov.
