PUB-DATE: March 5, 1996

SECTION: Section A; Page 17; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 3463 words

HEADLINE: THE DOWNSIZING OF AMERICA;
More Than Money, They Miss the Pride a Good Job Brought

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: TORRANCE, Calif.

 BODY:
The wedge-shaped B-2 Stealth bomber sliced through the brownish-blue California haze. Robert Muse lay back on the hood of the pickup and watched it fly, like a boy gauging the progress of his paper airplane.
"Some of me may be in that plane," he said. "My parts. I helped make it fly." 
 The jet was executing what aircraft workers call a flyover, a low-altitude pass, staged so employees at the Northrop Grumman Aircraft Division could view their creation against a canvas of clouds. Mr. Muse was laid off from his job as a machinist two years ago, but he came to the flyover anyway, to be part of it.
Even now, so long after his job disappeared, he thinks of himself as an aircraft builder. The emptiness of that image of himself has been the hardest thing to accept, harder than the loss of the good money and benefits, harder than the fact that he now rides around town in a 16-year-old Datsun with no spare tire in the trunk.
For 28 of his 47 years, Mr. Muse was one of the most skilled and exacting blue-collar workers in America. Now he is a maintenance technician at half the $20 an hour he used to get. The hands that once sculpted complex components out of exotic metals now feel their way through air-conditioning ducts, trim tree branches, unclog toilets. "I do what needs doing," he said.
He is grateful for the new job because the paycheck allows his family to hold onto a three-bedroom home on a still-safe street in Torrance, just south of Los Angeles, and pays the bills, as long as they eat a lot of hot dogs and buy nothing they can do without. But the take-home pay, less than $350 a week, is more like the kind of money he made when he was a young man with no responsibilities, when the only thing he had to worry about was the gas in his car and drive-in cheeseburgers on the weekends.
He has been laid off before. But like other blue-collar workers who would lose their jobs when business was bad, he always knew there would be a call-back. What is different now, what is different for so many millions like him, is that this layoff is forever. He is left to adjust to his whittled-down dignity or live in the past.
He does a little of both.
"I know nothing is for sure in this life," he said. "But I spent 30 years at it. That should count for something. Now there's just a void."
Much of that empty space is filled with bitterness, anger. In March 1994, his company decided it could buy some parts cheaper than its own people could make them, and closed the machine shop. One moment, in the last, desperate months, sticks like a fish hook in his memory.
"A vice president walked into the meeting hall and said, 'Even if you work for nothing, you're still too expensive,' " Mr. Muse recalled.
Now, instead of company medical benefits and enough of a pension to pay for a dignified retirement, he has plaques for excellent work, certificates for perfect attendance and a transistor radio.
Here in California in the last 8 years, about 1 in 3 aerospace workers has been declared too expensive. In 1988, there were 707,000 aerospace and high-technology workers in the state; last year, the work force had slipped to 473,000, a loss of 234,000 jobs.
Up and down the streets of Torrance and Long Beach and other places where these workers made their homes, "For Sale" signs stick up like weeds. Through the trickle of laid-off workers still coming and going, the blank windows of union halls stare out on the rubble of what used to be manufacturing plants. Middle-age men who used to set rivets can now can recite the daytime TV schedule by heart.
Mr. Muse's older brother, 50-year-old Roy, was laid off by McDonnell Douglas in June 1993. He's watched so much "Oprah," he told his brother, "I began to hate men."
Another brother, 46-year-old Larry, still works in the industry but has been told his job will be history, too, someday soon. When he and his brothers congregate, drinking beer and talking airplanes, he only has to look across the kitchen table to see his future.
"It's a little like the plague," Robert Muse said.
For as long as they have been a family, he and his wife, Nancy, and their daughters, Vicky, 23, and Carrie, 17, have lived comfortably, neither rich nor poor. The layoff has created economic hardships they have never known.
But beyond even that, there is an uncertainty, a dread that if it happened once it can happen again, and drive their standard of living ever lower.
"You get scared to spend a penny," Mrs. Muse said. "Even though he has a job, you get scared he won't. You don't plan for the future any more. You live day to day."
The layoff, one Northrop manager assured the workers in those last days, was purely business, nothing personal. Mr. Muse has tried to see it that way, too, to try to lay it to rest.
He cannot.
For nearly a year, he and his family went without health insurance because they could not afford the $600 monthly premiums. He gambled no one would get sick or be hurt, and he won. But he hated it, because of the constant worry, because it was degrading, a poor man's tactic to cheat a basic working man's responsibility.
His older daughter lives with her baby and boyfriend in a dangerous neighborhood, because it is the best they can afford on their own low-paying jobs.
He wants to help them move to a better and safer place, but there is no money for it now. His worries, and his guilt, pile higher and higher.
It is personal, he says.
"It's like the company telling you that you're no damn good."
 
The Boneyard
Northrop Grumman's modest flight museum occupies a corner of the company's plant in nearby Hawthorne, monument to the soaring -- and dubious -- achievements of the industry. There is a lean fighter jet, which never flew a mission, and the stubby, radio-controlled flying bomb, which looks as if it was designed for Porky Pig.
Robert Muse walked through the boneyard of rejected, abandoned planes, pointing to a strut here or a panel there, reciting little facts about stress tolerances or heat resistance, information that used to be so vital, now just useless numbers rattling around in his head.
Across the parking lot, now mostly deserted, is the machine shop where he used to work. He used to have security passes, but the company took them away on his last day. He would have liked to have kept them, as souvenirs. It is hard not to live in the past if that is where so much of your happiness resides.
"It'll just eat you up, if you let it," he said.
He is a tall, lanky man who likes to wear cowboy boots and western shirts, to sip slow on a cold beer and flick through the channels while scratching his dog's ears. But he loved to work, because while anyone can handle the remote control, not everyone can take it apart, add a little bit of wire and a piece of tin foil and use it to open garage doors and dim the lights in the hall.
Unlike many other blue-collar workers, Mr. Muse did not simply inherit his father's place on the assembly line. His father was a straight man for magicians, the one who would volunteer from the audience to be sawed in half.
Robert Muse had no showmanship in him, but he could have told you how the tricks worked. After high school he went to work in the aircraft industry. In 1966, Douglas Aircraft hired and trained him to run a turret lathe. He was laid off in 1971, but back then a layoff was only an inconvenience.
"If one company laid you off, you were sure someone else would pick you up quick," he said, "We called it the merry-go-round."
Four months later, he was making precision parts for Northrop. The job lasted 22 years.
The work, to a layman, sounds impossibly precise. "The cellophane on a cigarette pack is four times thicker than the margin for error on some parts," he said. It was natural that the people who did the work would be proud of it, he said. They were the blue-collar elite. Not just anyone could do the work. The math alone left some people dumbfounded.
"There was a feeling of, 'I'm doing my job, and I'm doing a good job. So why should it ever go away?' " he said.
On a blind date, he met Nancy, who had grown up around planes herself: her father was a pilot, her mother, a stewardess. They got married, bought a house and then, 16 years ago, moved up to a nicer one. They had two children along the way.
He volunteered for the company fire department and was the safety monitor, environmental monitor and secretary for the employee involvement group. In his spare time he souped up a 1964 Chevelle and outran Corvettes from light to light on Hawthorne Boulevard. He voted Republican, in part because Republicans were usually hawks and hawks voted for the military contracts that allowed him to be an aircraft worker.
As the Soviet Union splintered, and the implications for the defense industry became clear, the relationship between management and workers at the plant became colder, more confrontational. But even then, management assured him that his job was safe, that he would be able to retire with a company pension and health plan.
"They said, 'Don't worry. Your jobs are fine.' Go out and buy your houses,' " he recalled. "They lied to us," he said, to keep the skilled work force intact and producing, "dangling that lollipop in front of us."
But in the months before his layoff in March 1994, with their jobs clearly on the chopping block, the machinists took it on themselves to try to save the machine shop. Through harder work, less waste and rising desperation, they sliced costs, increased production, even volunteered for pay cuts.
"We told them, 'Look, we did it. We saved you money,' " Mr. Muse said. "Then they took it all away from us."
The last weeks, after the layoff was announced, were the worst, because so many workers refused to believe it was over.
"He made the comment to us several times that we shouldn't give up hope, that people are saved at the last minute," Mrs. Muse said. "He told us that sometimes, on your last day, people walk up and say, 'We found you a job.' "
The Chevelle sits in the garage now, gathering dust. "I can't afford the insurance," he said. "But I keep the registration up. I'll bring it back to life. Someday."
He is still a Republican. He is not much stirred by social issues -- he is a "live and let live" kind of man -- but he still believes in a strong defense, in building planes. Even though he is coming to terms with his life, there is still a glimmer of hope that, someday, the plants will come to life again, and that they will need him.
 
What Money Can Buy
The graffiti signal a change from Robert Muse's quiet neighborhood to the one his daughter Vicky comes home to after her part-time job at Sears. Mr. Muse looked out from his car window on treeless streets and boxlike apartment buildings, at the sidewalk where a young man traded little packets of fleeting happiness for crumpled cash.
"She lives here," Mr. Muse said. "Can you believe it?"
Over the days, as he talked about the layoff and what it had cost, he fluctuated between sadness, bitterness and anger, usually short-lived, beaten back by natural cheerfulness. Before his layoff, he was an infectiously happy man, said his friends and family, and the ghost of that is still here. But as he stared out on the street, he was disgusted, helpless: "I don't want to cry about it. But I feel like I've been stabbed in the back."
No, the heart.
 
Brothers
It takes a lot of Old Milwaukee to take the edge off three big men's fears.
The Muse brothers, all large, middle-age men with beers in their fists, sat at Robert's kitchen table and talked about the future as if it were a box that they were afraid to open. Together the men represent three stages of a journey now common throughout blue-collar America.
Robert has come the farthest: After his layoff, there was never any question that he would have to find work immediately. He took a job crawling under houses to install wiring for security alarms. It was hard, dirty work, and one day he had to share the crawl space with an unidentified, long-dead animal that had elected to tunnel under the house to die. The stench gagged him. "I thought, surely I can find something better than this," he said.
A year ago, after training in computer and electronics repair, he was hired as a maintenance technician at a company that builds solar panels. Some days he works on electronics and computers, some days he cuts weeds. He does the work with a smile, but it is all teeth, no heart.
"It's work, man," he said. He cannot even afford to stay true to a particular brand of beer. "Now, I just drink what's on sale."
Roy Muse worked for McDonnell Douglas for 29 years and was laid off six years short of qualifying for full pension and benefits, including health insurance, which he regrets more than anything. He has kidney problems, and has had to spend thousands of dollars to continue his old health insurance. Now his savings are down to nothing.
At 50, he is training to be a medical technician, in the hope of landing his own low-paying job in a growing industry. Nowadays, the Muse brothers said, it seems like all growing industries are built with the labor of low-paid and desperate people. Even so, Roy says, the competition with other retrained people is so tight that he is not sure of finding a job when his program is done.
He and his wife have three sons. Their house, their future, hang on his finding work soon. His wife has a low-paying, part-time job to help them survive, but some bills go unpaid. His unemployment insurance ran out a long time ago.
"You know you've always heard about bills piling up?" he said. "Well they do. They do pile."
Their baby brother, 45-year-old Larry, already has a layoff notice in hand from his company, also an aircraft manufacturer. "They keep stringing me along," he said, but quickly adds that he is not complaining, that he prays the company will find a place for him. "I'm still dedicated," he said, "I'm still loyal."
Unlike his brothers, whose families and nostalgia tie them down to Southern California, he is willing to move. He has been married four times, and has learned not to get attached to one particular house. He will chase work wherever it takes him. Most recently, he has been assigned to a four-month tryout with a branch plant in Lake Charles, La. "I kind of like Louisiana," he said.
Larry Muse did some quick arithmetic to calculate how much of their collective lives they had devoted to the industry.
"Seventy years," he said. "Right here."
"It was a good ride," Roy said, "wasn't it?"
Robert nodded. "Till they don't want you any more," he said.
 
Wife and Mother
The Muse house would disappoint a thief: the one obvious treasure, a big-screen television the size of a refrigerator, is too heavy to steal conveniently. Yet this modest house, so neat and clean without so much as a cushion out of place, is a museum of irreplaceable things. There is a sculpture of a child's handprint preserved in clay, and an engraved plaque with a jet plane covered in fake gold. Over their kitchen table someone has pinned a yellowed slip of paper with a priceless poem from third grade, or was it second?
"What we had was wealth," Nancy Muse said, as she stood with one foot on the immaculate beige carpet of the den and one on the gleaming linoleum of the kitchen. This is as much her world as the factory was his, and the change brought into her life by the layoff has been as painful and demeaning as what her husband endures.
"There ought to be a law against it, against taking it all away," she said. "Don't they have any conscience? Don't they care?"
She has been the backstop for the deprivations and disappointment her family endures, because she runs the house. Mrs. Muse has had to look her 17-year-old daughter in the face and tell her that promises made over a lifetime about college had been turned to lies by the layoff.
"We always told her, 'You have to go to college,' and we always told her we would help," said Mrs. Muse, a tiny, quiet woman who tends to let her husband do the talking until the conversation curves into an area where she is the expert. "Now she's a senior and it's time for us to make good on it, but all we can do is say, 'Well, uh, well. . .' "
Over the years, the Muses put away about $60,000 for their retirement. They had planned to use some of that money for Carrie's college. The plan was, as their children eventually left home, they would not only restore any missing savings but add to the nest egg, maybe even have $100,000 by age 65. It is the stuff motor homes are made of.
Now they try to hoard the $60,000 for their old age. But they fear emergencies will peel away the little they have, and they can add nothing to it because this new job pays so little. When he is 65, he will draw a tiny pension from Northrop, but it won't even pay the electric bill, Mrs. Muse said. They are afraid of growing old with nothing to live on except Social Security, and are aware that, barring some miracle, it is precisely what will happen.
"I'm not sure what's going to happen to us in the future," she said. Every time she thinks of it, she added, "It's like a kick in the stomach."
Carrie, she says, is working hard to try and win a scholarship, and while it makes her proud it also breaks her heart. For Carrie and her generation here in Southern California, there is little choice. The option of the good-paying blue-collar job is an antiquity. It is either college, which cannot guarantee a good job anymore, or minimum wage.
In her high school, Carrie said, the layoff of a parent is so common that there is little sympathy left.
"It's like, 'So your dad was laid off. Big deal. Mine's been laid off a year,' " she said.
Still, she suspects but does not know how deeply it hurts her friends; behind the dismissive bravado, she says, "We just keep it to ourselves."
Mrs. Muse accepted her role as wife and mother a long time ago, not because she did not want to work -- after all, she says, raising children and managing a home can be a hard and thankless job -- but because she wanted to be there as her children grew up. She is nearing 50 and is willing to work for wages for the first time in her life, but there is nothing in the job market her dignity could stand.
"People who had years of college can't find anything," she said. "The only thing I could get is Burger King, and I don't need that crap."
So she takes the paycheck her husband gives her and tries to work miracles with it. She walks grocery store aisles looking for the cheapest brand. If a store has a sale on turkey, they will eat turkey four times a week. Dixie, their dog, used to eat what the family ate. Now sometimes there is nothing left, so she eats dog food.
"The food prices increase, the utilities go up, but we have so much less to work with," she said. Their house payment is $550 a month and their utilities run $250 a month. They spend about $400 a month for groceries and other basic needs. Then there are the big expenses they have to make sure they put aside for, like $1,400 a year in property taxes and $740 for car insurance. What is left from their income of $1,500 a month is pocket change.
The family across the street is in the same bad shape, as are two or three families down the block. One family just packed up in the dead of night and left, abandoning their house to the bank and leaving their friends to wonder whatever happened to them. Other families just split apart. She hears about them at the supermarket.
That will never happen to them, she said. He is not going to give up the one part of his life that is still good; she depends on him more than ever to provide, to keep them in a house, in a warm and safe place. You could not pry them apart with a tire iron. Like the plague, as Mr. Muse said, the layoff affects each family differently, ripping some apart as it cleaves others tightly together.
The whole family, along with uncles Roy and Larry, went out for dinner one night last fall at a neighborhood restaurant, a place where a steak and shrimp go for $6.95. They talked about the changes in life, how Robert only gets a haircut now when he badly needs one, and how Roy is going to have to work for several months as an unpaid intern when he finds work, if he does. Carrie talked about how bad Christmas had been, how "we used to get lots and lots of presents," and never knew it was a luxury.
As she talked, her father dipped his head toward his plate, as if to say, I'm sorry.
Then the three Muse brothers -- a maintenance man, an aspiring X-ray technician and one last aircraft worker desperately trying to hold on to a fading way of life -- started to talk about planes.

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Displays Its Muscles And Some Warts to Wall St.

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Declaring that "the world is coming our way," Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the chairman of I.B.M., said yesterday that the company's traditional strength as a global maker of sophisticated systems would make it a major power in the era of network computing, which is being fueled by the rapid growth of the Internet.
 Mr. Gerstner and two of his lieutenants gave an unusually lengthy three-hour exposition of I.B.M.'s strengths and weaknesses to a group of Wall Street analysts and major investors in New York. The overall message was that the company's leadership in network computing in the years ahead would more than make up for disastrous missteps in the last 15 years, during the era of personal computers.
"The industry is coming back our way," Mr. Gerstner said. "It's coming back to our sweet spot."
He later added, "Everything you have been reading and hearing about the Internet plays to our strengths."
Though the afternoon presentation was generally praised by analysts, I.B.M.'s stock price plunged even as Mr. Gerstner was talking. After trading as high as $121.25, the stock closed at $116.125, down $2. It was the stock's fourth straight losing session on the New York Stock Exchange, after it had reached a five-year high last week.
But I.B.M.'s shares fell during a general selloff of technology-related stocks, and traders and analysts were hard pressed to point to anything Mr. Gerstner had said that might have justified I.B.M.'s decline.
"I thought it was a pretty positive meeting," said Steven Milunovich, an analyst at Morgan Stanley in New York, who saw the presentation. "The only thing that I can think of that might have affected the stock was that he said the PC business was weak in North America -- but all the large computer stocks seemed to reverse."
Mr. Gerstner described a future in which computing power would migrate from the personal computer to the powerful computers known as servers, which handle corporate data bases and, in Mr. Gerstner's view, will be host to the network-based services of the future. He predicted that the economics of the business would change as software was bought by subscription rather than as a retail product for the personal computer. As a result, digital transactions on the network will "skyrocket." I.B.M. will benefit, he added, because "we are the server company."
That vision directly contrasts with the view espoused by Mr. Gerstner's bete noire, the Microsoft Corporation, which is the leader in personal computing software and one of the greatest beneficiaries of I.B.M.'s mistakes in the 1980's. In Microsoft's view of the future, computing power will be shared between the personal computer and large-scale systems.
But Mr. Gerstner clearly saw the coming changes as a way to outmaneuver Microsoft. "The best thing about this model is that I.B.M. isn't forced to say that 'oh my God, we've got to go fight someone who has 60 percent of the market,' " he said. "We already tried that game."
In the future, he added, I.B.M. would be tailoring an increasing number of network-based services to the needs of specific industries. One example was an announcement made yesterday that I.B.M. would set up a network for three major health care providers covering eight states, including Colorado, Ohio and Montana, would link doctors, patients and hospitals. The network would, among other things, automate paperwork and make records easily available as patients move between hospitals.
Such initiatives are closely tied to I.B.M.'s fast-growing services business, which helps institutions and corporations set up computer systems or sometimes run a client's operations for a fee. With $12.7 billion in sales last year, the services division is now second only to hardware as I.B.M.'s largest source of revenue and makes I.B.M. the biggest computer-services company in the world.
Mr. Gerstner reiterated his strong commitment to services that directly meet the needs of I.B.M.'s customers who are looking for solutions and are often confused by today's computer technology.
"Until we make computers that work like toasters, it is going to be a great business," he said.
Also yesterday, I.B.M. announced that it had acquired Data Sciences Ltd., a British computer concern, for $145 million. I.B.M. said it hoped to use the company's 1,700 employees to expand its services in Europe.
Mr. Gerstner also said that I.B.M. completed its $743 million acquisition yesterday of Tivoli Systems Inc., a maker of software that manages networks made up of different types of computer hardware. The purchase strengthens I.B.M. product offerings in a key area as I.B.M. tries to revitalize its software business.
Though he spent most of his time outlining I.B.M.'s strengths yesterday, Mr. Gerstner, who is known as a tough critic within the company, acknowledged several shortcomings. He said that I.B.M. had missed major opportunities and had performed poorly in the areas of software, data-storage devices, and networking hardware -- a multibillion-dollar business that I.B.M. could easily have dominated.

HEADLINE: Reversing Field, Ford Will Aggressively Cut Costs

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 4

 BODY:
After months of dismissing concerns that its cars have become too expensive, the Ford Motor Company has reversed course and begun an aggressive cost-cutting campaign that includes the elimination of 6,000 product engineering jobs.
Ford officials said today that the company planned to reduce its product development staff to 23,000 from 29,000 in the next few years, mainly by cutting the number of engineers who are hired on long-term contracts but are not on the permanent payroll. Some of the shrinkage in staff will also come through retirements, possibly including an early retirement program, and by not replacing people who leave. 
 Chris Vinyard, a company spokesman, confirmed that Ford would be reducing its product development staff but said that "we don't contemplate anything that would be characterized as a layoff" for career Ford employees.
The cutbacks at Ford are part of a broader shift in attitude among Detroit auto makers. After years of pushing up car and truck prices faster than inflation, they have decided that the affordability of their products has become a problem, and are taking steps to correct it. That new consensus here is good news for car buyers, but could jeopardize industry jobs.
The shift is most evident at Ford, whose chairman publicly dismissed affordability concerns just two months ago. But executives at the Chrysler Corporation and the General Motors Corporation have also been taking numerous steps to cut costs. "You've got to be conscious of what you're putting on the car," said John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive.
Ford has gone the furthest the last few weeks in releasing details of its cost-cutting plans, trying to address Wall Street concerns. These are among its latest steps:
*No longer painting the insides of ashtrays on the Explorer, for a saving of 25 cents on each of the sport utility vehicles.
*Using a single carpet fabric for its car trunks instead of seven fabrics, for a saving of 90 cents a car.
*Using a single cigarette lighter instead of 14 different lighters on various models, for a saving of 16 cents a vehicle.
All of these cost-saving steps sound small. And for any given vehicle, they are. The unpainted Explorer ashtrays shave just 25 cents from the production cost of a sport utility vehicle that sells for close to $30,000. But with the Explorer ranking as the nation's third-best-selling vehicle, the paint saving on ashtrays adds up to $99,000 a year.
Ford is also taking much bigger longer-term measures. The company is expanding the use of computer-aided design techniques to reduce spending on prototype vehicles to $700 million next year from $1.1 billion in 1994. And Ford is gradually reducing the variety of car engines and underbodies that it produces while changing the sheet metal on top in more ways so as to continue offering a full range of models -- a change that could save billions of dollars early in the next century.
Ford hopes to sell cars for less and increase its profits by reducing its costs. To be sure, auto makers have tried for decades to look for ways to save a dime on a car here or a nickel a mini-van there. And some pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles continue to sell very well even when loaded with costly options.
Yet both the wisdom and effectiveness of the deeper, more aggressive cost-cutting programs remain unclear. When pressed, some auto executives concede that they do not really expect to meet their ambitious targets of reducing their parts purchasing costs, for example, by as much as 5 percent a year. And seemingly small changes that might appear to save money can end up as money losers if they prompt customers to buy a competitor's vehicle.
Japanese car companies have already learned this. Sales of the Toyota Corolla suffered in Japan last year, for example, when the company made many seemingly small design changes.
The issue for American auto makers now is whether cost-saving decisions will mean that millions of bland cars and trucks end up rolling off assembly lines. Even worse, auto makers could omit features that consumers never mentioned as important until they had to do without.
Ford officials now concede, for example, that they erred in deciding not to put a driver's side sliding door on their Windstar mini-van. Chrysler added a door to its mini-vans, luring thousands of buyers who loved the convenience. "I have a saying now: when in doubt, add a door," a top Ford official who spoke on condition of anonymity said.
Given the tension between enticing consumers and saving money, some Wall Street analysts question whether the auto companies can really cut their costs deeply.
Ford and Chrysler have each set a target of reducing parts purchasing costs by 5 percent a year. But executives at the two companies acknowledge some misgivings about whether the targets are realistic.
Thomas T. Stallkamp Chrysler's vice president for procurement and supply, said that the company had a target of a 3 percent reduction last year, but managed only a 1.5 percent cut. Chrysler raised its target to 5 percent this year anyway.
Ford's financial planners decline to say what cost reductions are included in their business forecasts, as opposed to the target they set for managers. But David N. McCammon, Ford's vice president of finance, strongly suggested in an interview that the planners were not expecting a 5 percent drop. "We are always more conservative in our planning on profit projections," he said. "We won't be in financial trouble if we miss them some, but we do count on making much of it."
General Motors has not tried to rally its employees around a specific cost-cutting target, and its executives question the wisdom of doing so, given the many quality changes often involved in cost savings.
"A lot of people kid themselves with these big numbers that they throw out that they're saving," said J. T. Battenberg 3d, president of Delphi Automotive, G.M.'s immense auto-parts division. "When you ask the price question, you have to ask, 'How many engineering changes?' "
As so often happens, American car companies are belatedly following the example of Japanese car companies. Alarmed by the yen's rise against the dollar in 1994 and early 1995, Toyota, Honda, Nissan, Mazda and other Japanese auto makers redoubled their efforts to shave costs.
Ford has an advantage in cutting costs now. The company has just finished redesigning nearly half its product line, and has less need for engineers. By a curious coincidence, it was the dollar's sharp rebound over the last year that helped persuade Detroit auto makers to begin pursuing their own more aggressive cost-reduction strategies. The dollar has risen 32 percent since touching a low of 79.85 yen last spring.
A Ford official said that the company became more convinced of the need to cut costs after estimating that recent exchange rates made even the Chrysler Neon uncompetitive. The Neon has set a new standard as an American small car with low production costs.
The other two reasons for Ford's new emphasis on cost control were the weak sales of the new Taurus sedan and Ford's abysmal lack of profits from automotive operations in the third and fourth quarters of 1995, the Ford official said.
While Ford began its cost-saving program more than a year ago, the program has become a higher priority in recent weeks.
The question is whether this year's stepped-up cost-cutting will produce next year's cheap-looking car. Ford skipped putting a holder on the inside of the 1996 Ford Taurus doors. "One of the first things I noticed when getting into the vehicle was, where's the map pocket?" a senior Ford official said.
Many consumers had the same reaction. Other car companies continued building map holders in their car doors. And their dealers were quick to point this out to would-be Taurus buyers.

HEADLINE: Dow Registers Rise of 63.59; Passes 5,600

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices lurched sharply higher yesterday, pushed by a number of large computer-driven buy orders and another good day in the long end of the bond market.
At the close of a hectic session, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 63.59 points, to 5,600.15. With only about 30 minutes of trading left yesterday, the blue-chip average was up as much as 90 points. At that point, it lost about half of its gain, only to scoot upward again near the close. 
 "At one point the Dow was up 90, and then the next minute it was up 45, and it all happened in a flash," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation. "But over all, you have to say it was a good day." The day's climb furthered a 50.94-point advance on Friday, and the Dow has now advanced 2 percent the last two sessions, nearly making up the 2.5 percent decline of the first four days of last week.
The downdraft that swept technology stocks lower on Friday continued yesterday.
Compaq Computer, which sparked Friday's wholesale selloff after it announced sharp price cuts, lost 1 3/4 yesterday, closing at 40. Hewlett-Packard fell 1 1/8, to 94, and I.B.M., fell 2 late in the day to close at 116 1/8.
Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the chairman of I.B.M., speaking to Wall Street analysts and investors, asserted that the company's traditional strengths as a global maker of sophisticated systems would make it a big power in a coming era of network computing being fueled by the rapid growth of the Internet. [Page D4.]
Among active Nasdaq issues, Cisco Systems fell 1 3/8, to 44 1/8, and Sun Microsystems lost 1 1/4, to 47 3/4.
Otherwise broad market averages generally reflected the improved tone. The Standard & Poor's 500 index, which represents about three-quarters of the value of all American stocks, rose 6.44 points, to 650.81, extending Friday's gain of 3.94. The New York Stock Exchange's composite index rose 3.69, to 348.87, and the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 3.60, to 567.04.
Volume on the Big Board was 417.3 million shares.
One index that lost ground was the Nasdaq composite, which fell 1.20, to 1,084.88, as technology stocks, which were battered on Friday, failed to recover.
Bond prices in the long maturities improved for a second straight day, after a weak consumer spending report for January and declines in both gold and oil prices.
The report renewed talk of the possibility of yet another cut in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve, whose policy making Open Market Committee meets on March 26.
Despite the weak consumer spending report, a reading that was heavily influenced by the bad weather in January, expectations of faster economic growth helped to push up prices of big retailers.
Lowe's, the home-improvement chain, jumped 3, to 35, after the company said February sales in stores open more than a year rose 9 percent. Home Depot, a Lowe's competitor, rose 3 3/8, to 47 5/8.
Aside from cyclical stocks like retailing, defensive issues like beverages, drugs and health care also did well.
Drug stocks climbed after treatments development by Eli Lilly and Abbott Laboratories cleared regulatory hurdles. Eli Lilly jumped 2 1/2, to 64 1/8, while Abbott advanced, 1 5/8, to 43 7/8.
Among the day's biggest losers was Alumax, whose shares tumbled 7.6 percent after news over the weekend that Kaiser Aluminum had withdrawn its takeover bid valued at $2.2 billion to $2.5 billion. Alumax, which rose after Kaiser's offer of $40 to $45 in cash and common stock, fell 2 3/4 yesterday, to 33 1/2, in very heavy trading.
The market's solid advance the last two sessions has probably calmed some nerves, but analysts said they expected conditions to be volatile for the foreseeable future.
"I expect the market to remain choppy," said Gail Dudack, investment strategist at UBS Securities. "This advance, which began in November, started on a foundation of a balanced budget agreement, good corporate earnings and lower interest rates. All of those assumptions are very debatable at this point."

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
UConn and Notre Dame In Showdown for Title

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH 

DATELINE: STORRS, Conn., March 4

 BODY:
The UConn Huskies are right where all of the Big East expected them to be: in line to win a third consecutive conference tournament and gain an automatic bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association 64-team tournament field.
The 29-3 Huskies, the defending national champions, tonight advanced to the final game against third-seeded Notre Dame on Tuesday with ease. 
 UConn's Kara Wolters scored 22 points in 23 minutes in top-seeded UConn's 83-51 drubbing of Pittsburgh at Gampel Pavilion tonight.
In the other semifinal, Notre Dame (22-6) stopped Seton Hall, 69-58, setting up the expected match between the tournament's only nationally ranked teams.
Beth Morgan led Notre Dame with 16 points. Katryna Gaither had 12 points and a team-high 10 rebounds. Seton Hall's top scorer was Sandy Mitchell with 15 points.
The Irish have already lost twice to UConn, but gave the Huskies a game before succumbing, 86-79, here Feb. 24. Notre Dame Coach Muffet McGraw conceded, "We're at a major disadvantage."
"Connecticut has had two days off, and we've had two tough games," McGraw said, referring to UConn breezing through its first two games.
"But," cautioned Jennifer Rizzotti, UConn's senior guard and the Big East player of the year, "you never expect it to be easy. They're going to have some pretty athletic kids, pretty talented kids. So we have to make sure we contain their better players."
One of those top players, Gaither, stated flatly after scoring 12 against Seton Hall, "I'm ready, and more determined than the last time."
UConn seems ready, too, riding a 15-game winning streak thanks to a relentless defense and the fast-break conversions that helped break open both its tournament romps, against Rutgers and Pitt.
"They're just so physical that even if you play them fresh, when your 40 minutes are up you're just thoroughly exhausted," said Stephanie Petho, who led the Panthers with 13 points.
Wolters, UConn's junior center, dominated against the overmatched Panthers, not only scoring at will from the middle of the key but also blocking six shots, one short of the tournament record.
"She leaves her heart, her soul, her guts all out on the court," said UConn Coach Geno Auriemma. "That's why she's a special player."
Wolters, making the middle of the key her own on offense as well as defense, has rained turnaround jumpers, scoring a total of 43 points in 41 minutes of play in two games.
"She has nice, soft hands," said Kirk Bruce, the coach of the Panthers (6-24). "All she has to do is catch it and score. She makes the same play over and over."
The unassuming Wolters refused to call herself a controlling force.
"I just feel comfortable because of my teammates," Wolters said. "They make it so easy for me, getting the ball in up high."
The same sort of economy and excellence that Wolters has shown has also marked Connecticut's tournament play in general, up and down the bench, something Rizzotti said should leave the starters fresh for Tuesday.
"Our subs came in and did a great job," she said. "The game was in control and they kept it in control."
Bruce said, "They're so deep they can go to any of their non-starters and still get great performances."
UConn showed its ability to thoroughly dominate by taking an immediate 16-2 lead over the Cinderella Panthers, the first No. 13-seeded team ever to make the semifinal round in Big East tournament play.
The Huskies built their lead to 43-23 by halftime, as Wolters poured in 16 points, 6 in the final two minutes of play. The Huskies then started the second half with an 18-2 spurt.
 
REBOUNDS
GENO AURIEMMA and JIM CALHOUN, coaches of UConn's nationally ranked women's and men's teams, respectively, are among the finalists for the 1996 Boost/Naismith college basketball coach of the year awards. UMass men's coach JOHN CALIPARI is also a finalist.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Gerstner Declares I.B.M. Is Poised for Leadership
Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the chairman of I.B.M., told Wall Street analysts and investors that the company's traditional strength as a global maker of sophisticated systems would make it a major power in the era of network computing, which is being fueled by the rapid growth of the Internet. The message was that I.B.M. would more than make up for its disastrous missteps adjusting to the era of the personal computer. [Page D4.]
 
I.B.M.'s stock has suffered from AT&T's decision last week to pull out of a venture linking users of Lotus Notes via AT&T phone lines. But two AT&T rivals are growing with Lotus services, and others also see an opportunity where AT&T failed. [D4.]
 
The Compaq Computer Corporation and two of its rivals, Digital Equipment and Hewlett-Packard, announced steep price cuts yesterday, reflecting intense competition in a slowing personal computer market. [D4.]
 
Campbell Soup to Name Officer
Campbell Soup, after a year without a chief financial officer, will name Basil L. Anderson, an architect of Scott Paper's downsizing, to the post today. But David W. Johnson, Campbell's chief, said, "We aren't working on downsizing; we're focused on long-term growth and our vision for the future." Market Place. [D10.]
 
When Only the Image Remains
James E. Sharlow, who lost his $130,000-a-year job in January 1993 when the Eastman Kodak plant he managed was shut, and his family in California's San Fernando Valley still appear to resonate with prosperity. But the layoff has eroded his dreams of retirement and stolen his family's long-range security. [A1.]
 
Two years after his job disappeared, Robert Muse still thinks of himself as an aircraft builder. The emptiness of that image has been the hardest thing to accept. [A17.]
Times Mirror Cashing In Netscape
Times Mirror is cashing in one of the best investments in its history, Netscape, the Internet access company. Its stake, purchased 11 months ago for less than $4 million at a private offering before Netscape went public, is worth $92 million. [D2.]
 
Income Growth Stalls
Personal income grew just one-tenth of 1 percent in January, after a strong gain in 1995, and consumer spending fell five-tenths of 1 percent in the month, for its first drop in three years. But many analysts say that February results should show a rebound. [D2.]
Treasury securities were mixed as traders waited. The 30-year bond rose 13/32 to a price of 9519/32 for a yield of 6.33 percent, down from 6.36 percent on Friday. [D17.]
 
More Cost-Cutting at Drug Maker
Pharmacia & Upjohn, the recently merged drug maker, said it would close 40 percent of its worldwide plants, saving $300 million a year by 2000. [D2.]
 
Hertz to Sell Used Cars
Hertz said that it would open 39 used-car lots to sell cars driven by its rental customers for 7 to 12 months. [D7.]
Infinity Gets 12 More Stations
Infinity Broadcasting agreed to buy a dozen radio stations from an affiliate of the investment partnerships Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Granite Equity Partners, for $410 million, bringing its total to 46 stations. [D6.]
 
Venezuela Doubling Oil
Venezuela plans to double its output of crude oil over 10 years, to the delight of private foreign oil companies, which are rushing back to the country at the Government's invitation, 20 years after all foreign oil operations were nationalized. Among the American companies taking part are Amoco, Mobil and du Pont's Conoco. [D9.]
 
Burnett Cites 'Best Commercials'
The Leo Burnett Company is coming out with its own list of "the 100 best commercials of all time" -- a matter which is sure to stir debate. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Mixed Data On Economy Cloud Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, as the bond market wrestled with conflicting economic signals and changing perceptions on the economy's outlook. Many traders and investors believe the Federal Reserve still intends to cut interest rates, with the timing uncertain.
The 30-year bond rose 13/32, to a price of 95 19/32 for a yield of 6.33 percent, down from 6.36 percent on Friday. Some analysts said that after the recent selloff in bonds, it appeared that much of the bad news the market anticipated -- real or imagined -- might be behind it. 
 Traders say the market is priced fairly at these levels after being somewhat overpriced the last few weeks, and they are not looking for any sharp moves before reports Thursday on durable-goods orders and Friday on nonfarm payrolls.
Gold and oil prices, considered indicative of possible inflation, were down yesterday and helped keep bond prices steady.
P. Christopher Leary, senior vice president and portfolio manager at SunAmerica Asset Management, said: "I think today the market put the proper perspective on commodity prices, as the contract-month change brought gold down, and you saw some nice declines in petroleum products. The growing belief is that we are coming to the end of peak-usage season and are through the worst of the winter months. The lower stockpiles have time to replenish."
Mr. Leary said that in the last couple of weeks, the market had a number of weighty issues to deal with, all seeming to fall into place at once. There was the testimony by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, that was interpreted as negative to bonds, and the record quarterly refunding by the Treasury, adding a heavy supply of debt to the market. "Dealers were also changing positions because of a variety of debt issuance," he said, "and you had a rather sharp increase in gold." This, he said, tested "the fortitude of the long end of the market."
"I think the market is priced fairly," Mr. Leary said, adding, "I think that we still can test 5.75 percent on the long bond by the summer, and really the second quarter is going to be the make-or-break point for the economy, to see whether we are in a long cycle of moderate growth or whether the possibility of recession will emerge."
David Ader, managing analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said a March survey of portfolio managers showed most thought that the rise in interest rates was nearly complete. "They are not turning negative for the longer haul," he said, "and believe that the current economic climate is still conducive to lower rates."
"Position adjustments are substantial," he said, and "now most of the investors believe that yields have reached the upper end of their current range, and intend to sit back and see if they are correct."
Yesterday's trading session began with reports that December and January personal income had risen six-tenths of 1 percent and one-tenth of 1 percent, respectively. December personal spending rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, but personal spending in January fell five-tenths of a percent.
Rates were mixed at the Treasury's weekly auction of bills, with good retail demand for a three-month bill producing an average rate of 4.89 percent, up three basis points from a week ago. Demand was below average for the six-month issue, with the rate unchanged at 4.80 percent from the previous week.
Elsewhere in the fixed-income market, the Sprint Corporation's cellular unit, 360degrees Communications, sold $900 million in senior notes in two parts yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.
The sale, part of a planned spinoff from its parent, included $450 million of 7.125 percent noncallable senior notes due in 2003 at a price of 99.695 to yield 7.181 percent -- about 135 basis points more than a Treasury security with a comparable maturity. For the second part, the cellular company sold an equal amount of 7.50 percent senior notes due in 2006 at a price of 99.769 to yield 7.533 percent -- 157 basis point above a comparable Treasury. This issue is callable when the yield is about 30 basis more than a Treasury.
While the securities are split-rated -- investment grade BBB+ by Duff & Phelps Credit Rating, low investment grade BBB- from Standard & Poor's, and below investment grade Ba-2 by Moody's -- there was strong demand from investors who normally buy high-grade bonds but sometimes dabble in lower-rated issues with an eye toward their potential gains from upgrading.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: A Florida Congressman With a Fighting Spirit Will Retire

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
Representative Sam M. Gibbons, a 76-year-old Floridian who led efforts for civil rights and open government in the House in the 1960's and became Speaker Newt Gingrich's chief denouncer in the 1990's, announced his retirement today after 34 years in Congress.
In 1995, after the Republicans won Congress, he battled them as the Ways and Means Committee's senior Democrat, criticizing Mr. Gingrich and his allies for "baloney," "blackmail," "ineptness," for "whimpering and whining and complaining" and for "behaving like dictators." 
 Today, Mr. Gibbons said it was time for a change after 49 years in public service, which began with 5 years in the Army, punctuated by a parachute landing behind German lines the night before D-Day.
He said he would not run again and expected to teach, serve on nonprofit boards, and work for simplification of the tax system and the re-election of President Clinton. "This is a midlife turning point for me," he said.
Mr. Gibbons's early prominence faded during more than two decades on the Ways and Means Committee, where he concentrated on complex trade issues.
But he returned to the limelight when he became its chairman in mid-1994 upon the indictment of his predecessor, Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois. As chairman, he pushed a national health insurance bill through the committee, although it never came up on the House floor.
Next year Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan will be the ranking minority member, a largely ceremonial post as long as Republicans are in control. But if the Democrats win the House back, Mr. Rangel will become chairman, a position of great influence that he would be expected to use on New York's behalf.
In a news conference in the committee's grandiose, cavernous hearing room, Mr. Gibbons rehearsed a varied career, saying: "The worst vote I ever cast in all of the 44 years of legislative life was on the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution. I have always regretted it. That plunged 55,000 Americans to their death."
But he had a harder time choosing among accomplishments, talking about trade, civil rights, poverty, Medicare and House rules changes. He spoke most warmly of his earliest years, when, as a freshman from Tampa, he was a floor manager for the 1964 Civil Rights Act. "We did get things done in those days," he said.
Mr. Gibbons's voluntary retirement from the House is the 40th in this Congress, and his seat is likely to be a battleground. The 39th came earlier in the day, when Representative Toby Roth, an 18-year Wisconsin Republican, said he would not run again. Twenty-six of the retirees are Democrats and 14 are Republicans.
Mr. Gibbons said he was proud of his record in fighting for free trade. Markets "are not perfectly open, and they never will be," he said, "but they are far more open than when I began." After he had ended his news conference, he agreed to take one more question, and when it was on trade with Chile, he leaped into the subject, saying the United States should make a pact with that country.
His role as a reformer of House rules was to push for openness. In 1966, he got the House Education and Labor Committee to meet in open session to vote on bills. He wrote the first formal rules for that committtee and later for Ways and Means. In 1970, with Representatives James G. O'Hara of Michigan and Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, he led an effort that ended the practice of anonymous voting on the floor of the House.
Under that system, known as a "teller vote," members would walk down the aisles and be counted. But they would face the back of the chamber, away from the Press Gallery, and be largely unrecognized. Starting in 1971, all votes on amendments were taken electronically and roll calls published.
Mr. Gibbons's procedural experience and his civil rights credentials enabled him to lead a fight against Representative Adam Clayton Powell, an exceptionally autocratic committee chairman in a day of autocratic chairmen. In 1966 his efforts stripped Mr. Powell, who was black, of much of his authority to run the committee.
He blamed the bad manners of today's House on a growing tendency to curtail debate under both parties. He said, "When people are limited in what they have time to say, they tend to raise their voices and use invective." He admitted he had enjoyed the last year, when he repeatedly denounced Republicans.
"I go with happy memories, a fighting spirit, a lot of thanks, and no regrets," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 8, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about the retirement of Representative Sam M. Gibbons, Democrat of Florida, referred incorrectly to a bill that he managed on the House floor as a freshman in 1964. It was the Economic Opportunity Act, not the Civil Rights Act.

HEADLINE: Wells Fargo Said to Be Ousting Economists

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 5

 BODY:
Wells Fargo & Company will dismiss its entire economics research department upon completing its takeover of First Interstate Bancorp on April 1, individuals at the banks said today.
Wells Fargo has said it expects to cut annual operating costs by up to $700 million after the merger. The 20 or so economics jobs would be a tiny fraction of the job cuts envisioned. The total cuts could eventually be 10,000, one of the largest reductions in United States banking history. 
 But the dismissal by Wells Fargo of its own economics staff along with First Interstate's is unusual and shows how determined the bank is to cut costs. Large banks have historically employed economists to help guide management decisions.
Employees said all departments at the banks were under review, with special scrutiny of headquarters staff not directly involved with bank customers. Wells Fargo is based in San Francisco and First Interstate has headquarters in Los Angeles.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed as Traders Focus On Global Interest-Rate Outlook

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed yesterday, fading slightly against the German mark but holding steady against the Japanese yen.
The mark staged a tentative rally, ending several days of weakness. But the gains occurred on limited trading volume, and foreign-exchange dealers still expect the dollar to rise in coming days. 
 "We had seen some selling of marks in previous days and we saw some profit taking out of those trades," said Kevin Lawrie, global foreign exchange manager at Mellon Bank. "From here the dollar should be inching up ever so slowly."
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar was at 105.25 yen, up from 105.15 yen on Monday. The dollar fell to 1.4758 marks from 1.4780 marks. The British pound rose to $1.5300 from $1.5275.
Interest rate forecasts continue to drive currency trading. Most analysts foresee an imminent cut in German short-term rates, which would make German securities less attractive.
United States interest rates, meanwhile, appeared likely to remain steady after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, suggested in a speech yesterday that the economy was stronger than official data showed. Mr. Greenspan's comments weakened the American bond market, which has been expecting a rate cut, but they strengthened the dollar.
"That was somewhat of a bullish statement," said Diego Giurleo, vice president at Royal Bank of Canada. "It suggests perhaps we're not ready to cut interest rates in the U.S."
Still, the dollar hit strong selling pressure at 1.4820 marks. That produced a selloff to near 1.4750 marks, the level at which the dollar spent most of the New York trading session.
"People were looking for a lot of topside and when it failed to materialize, we had a correction," Mr. Lawrie of Mellon Bank said.
Against the yen, the dollar continues to draw modest support from speculation that the Bank of Japan was staying in touch with currency dealers in an effort to support the dollar below 105 yen.
The currency markets have been subdued recently as traders are reluctant to take new positions before Germany releases employment data today and the United States issues its report on employment on Friday.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Show Surprising Strength

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
Factory orders jumped unexpectedly in January and backlogs surged, the Commerce Department said today, offering evidence that manufacturing might be picking up after months of weakness.
The rise in January orders of five-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $311.1 billion, fanned concerns among investors that the Federal Reserve might be less likely to cut interest rates later this month. 
 Most private economists had expected a decline in orders because of severe winter storms that closed some plants temporarily in January. Not only were orders stronger than expected, but December orders were also revised upward, to a 1.7 percent increase from the previous estimate of a 1.3 percent gain, the department said.
The January increase in factory orders was the fourth in the last six months. The rise in backlogs was the biggest in more than six years, the department said.
Order backlogs grew for the fifth consecutive month, rising 1.7 percent after a gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent in December. It was the biggest jump in unfilled orders in more than six years, since an identical 1.7 percent gain in December 1989.
"Barring a disappointing employment report on Friday, we seem to be moving through Alan Greenspan's 'soft patch' in the economy successfully," said Robert Dederick, an economic consultant with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "So the case for a Fed easing is no longer certain."
Mr. Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and other policy makers are to meet on March 26 to consider whether to lower interest rates for the fourth time since mid-1995.
Economic growth slowed sharply at the end of 1995 but bad weather and the shutdown of the Federal Government, which delayed the collection and release of data, have made it difficult to assess the economy's condition early in 1996.
The financial markets are eagerly awaiting the release of February employment data by the Labor Department on Friday. Economists surveyed by Reuters predict that 326,000 jobs were created last month, more than making up for 201,000 lost in January.
The factory orders report showed fairly broad manufacturing strength, with more orders in January for expensive durable goods and nondurable goods like food and clothing. Analysts said companies were investing in new plants and equipment despite slower consumer spending.
Mr. Dederick of Northern Trust said, "We always wondered whether business would crumble in the face of weakening consumer demand, but it appears that business is continuing to spend for its own account" by buying new machinery and computers to become more efficient.
The increase in orders for industrial machinery and equipment was the largest, rising 5.7 percent after falling 2.6 percent in December.
The biggest drop in orders occurred in transportation goods, which fell 3.4 percent after a 12.3 percent jump in December. The department said there were large declines in orders for new aircraft and parts in December. Excluding transportation, orders jumped 1.2 percent after a slight rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in December.
"It is quite an encouraging figure," said David Sloan, senior economist at IDEA Inc. in New York, of the latest report. "The gain was modest but it wasn't led by transport, the usual erratic factor."

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Durable Goods Ordered" shows manufacturers' total new orders for durable goods from Aug. 1994 to Jan. 1996. "Factory Orders" shows manufacturers' total new factory orders from Aug. 1994 to Jan. 1996. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Fearing a Toehold for Gay Marriages, Conservatives Rush to Bar the Door

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 1

 BODY:
Fearful that a court case will lead to the sanctioning of marriages of lesbian and gay couples in Hawaii by the end of 1997, conservatives are campaigning across the nation to insure that the recognition of same-sex marriages will not spread to other states.
California is one of 19 states considering measures that would deny government recognition to same-sex marriages performed within the state or elsewhere. South Dakota and Utah have already enacted such laws. And a Defense of Marriage Act is being drafted in the United States Senate. 
 The legislative battle has picked up momentum in recent months as more conservatives have become convinced that they must act before Hawaiian courts pave the way to civil marriage rights for couples of the same sex. They envision a time in the not-too-distant future when lesbian and gay residents of their own states will fly to Hawaii and return with official marriage licenses. If they do not act and that should come to pass, their states will be left with an obligation under the United States Constitution to recognize those marriages.
It is too early to predict how many of the measures precluding same-sex marriages will be passed. Some have already been killed or tabled.
What brought the same-sex issue to the fore was a 1993 ruling by the Supreme Court of Hawaii that the denial of marriage licenses to three homosexual couples amounted to unconstitutional discrimination on the basis of sex -- not sexual orientation -- unless the state could show a compelling reason for the denials. That question is expected to be taken up by a lower court in August.
Even though the Hawaiian Legislature passed a bill in 1994 affirming marriage as intended for "man-woman units" capable of procreation, conservatives and civil rights advocates expect that the state will be unable to convince the courts that it has a compelling interest in denying marriage licenses to couples of the same sex.
The conflict in many Statehouses will be fierce. Conservatives see themselves in a fundamental crusade to preserve the traditional family structure as it has been understood through history. They argue that it is not only morally necessary to do so but also that it is in the best interest of children, who benefit from having both a mother and father.
Lesbian and gay couples are seeking the economic and legal benefits of marriage for their long-term relationships, which can involve the rearing of children. The benefits of civil marriage -- as distinct from a union recognized by a religious authority -- include the right to hold joint parental custody, obtain family insurance and health benefits, file joint tax returns, inherit property automatically and visit a spouse or child in a hospital.
Many of these couples are so eager to wed that they are already planning their flights to Honolulu, even though it could be a year or two before Hawaii begins issuing licenses, if it does so at all. Nowhere on the mainland is the interest in Hawaiian marriages for same-sex couples as palpable as in California, which has a large homosexual population and is a gateway to Hawaii.
Laurie McBride, executive director of the Lobby for Individual Freedom and Equality, a lesbian and gay group here, said, "California is going to have literally thousands of couples who are going to come back from Hawaii expecting their marriage to be treated with the respect and dignity given every other marriage."
When Ms. McBride was asked whether she and her partner of 11 years, Donna Yutzy, would be among those couples, she answered, "In a heartbeat."
The issue of same-sex marriages, almost unimaginable a generation ago, has become so potent that it is affecting the Republican Presidential campaign. A "marriage protection" rally in Des Moines on the eve of the Iowa caucuses drew Patrick J. Buchanan in person, as well as written support from Senator Bob Dole, Steve Forbes and former Gov. Lamar Alexander.
"It strikes at the very core of who we are as a people," said Jay A. Sekulow, chief counsel at the American Center for Law and Justice in Virginia Beach, Va., which is headed by the religious broadcaster Pat Robertson. "Marriage defined as a man and a woman has been around more than 6,000 years and has served most cultures very well."
"The Supreme Court has set the highest standard with the 'compelling interest' test," Mr. Sekulow said. "It may well be, by the end of the year, that there are same-sex marriages in Hawaii."
Such marriages would have to be recognized in other states under the United States Constitution, which says that "full faith and credit shall be given in each state to the public acts, records and judicial proceedings of every other state."
Alarmed at that possibility, legislators on the mainland are seeking an exemption from the "full faith and credit" provision on the grounds that same-sex marriages would violate the public policies of their states as defined by law. They are backed by conservative groups like the Christian Coalition, Concerned Women for America and Eagle Forum.
"My concern is that a limited number of judges in Hawaii will be dictating public policy in California," said Assemblyman William J. Knight, a Republican from the Antelope Valley, outside Los Angeles.
Mr. Knight introduced a bill that would invalidate "any marriage contracted outside this state between individuals of the same gender." It was passed by the Assembly, 41 to 33, on Jan. 31.
Mr. Knight's bill was opposed by Assemblywoman Sheila James Kuehl, Democrat of Santa Monica, and other Democrats who consider it to be discriminatory. The withholding of marriage rights, Ms. Kuehl said, has been a familiar tool used to "deny the humanity" of minorities.
She said she hoped that the bill could be stopped in the Senate Judiciary Committee, where it goes next. Meanwhile, Mr. Knight has introduced a second bill specifying that California's marriage laws apply "only to male-female couples" as a matter of public policy that cannot be changed by the courts.
Legislation is also pending in Alabama, Alaska, Colorado, Georgia, Idaho, Illinois, Iowa, Kentucky, Maryland, Missouri, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia, Washington, Wisconsin and Wyoming, according to the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, a gay and lesbian group. In Hawaii, further legislation is being considered, including an effort to amend the state constitution. Measures have failed to reach the floor in Maine, Mississippi and New Mexico.
Evan Wolfson, senior staff attorney for the Lambda group, said, "Religious extremists are trying to shut down the nation's discussion on how the denial of marriage rights harms real-life couples before most Americans have even had a chance to think about it." Mr. Wolfson is a co-counsel on the Hawaii case.
Staff members in the United States Senate are preparing a Defense of Marriage Act to define marriage in Federal policies and acts of Congress as the legal union of one man and one woman, said Robert H. Knight of the Family Research Council in Washington. He has been shown drafts of the bill but would not identify the prospective sponsors.
"If defending marriage is likened to offensive action, then so be it," Mr. Knight said. "The onus should not be on those defending marriage but on the tiny minority of people who are attempting to radically redefine it. I, for one, won't submit to the tactic of portraying tradition-minded Americans as radicals and close-minded bigots."
In Illinois, State Senator Peter G. Fitzgerald, a Palatine Republican who has introduced a bill adding same-sex couples to the list of those who may not be married under state law, said it was necessary to act now.
"To not pass this bill is to change our marriage laws fairly radically, if Hawaii changes its laws," Mr. Fitzgerald said. "If we were to act after Hawaii, I don't believe we could constitutionally strip marriages retroactively of those vested rights."
Last month, Gov. William J. Janklow of South Dakota, a Republican, signed a law defining marriage as a relationship between a man and a woman arising out of a civil contract. "We put in statutory law what I believe the majority of people in the state believe has always been the definition of marriage," said the bill's sponsor, State Representative Roger Hunt, Republican of Brandon.
But Barry Wick, president of a group called Free Americans Creating Equal Status, said: "The government of this state has allowed the legislation of hate and the creation of a second-class citizen. This second class of citizen is defined by love."
The conservative campaign has forced lesbian and gay groups to focus suddenly on an issue that was not a priority a year or two ago, compared with things like job and housing discrimination. Indeed, the goal of marriage is far from universally embraced among homosexuals.
But the fight has been joined. A group called the Freedom to Marry Task Force of Northern California recently collected 1,600 letters in the heart of San Francisco's largest gay neighborhood, opposing Mr. Knight's bill. They delivered them to Ms. Kuehl on Wednesday. Marc Gofstein, a task force member, said, "When we stand there with the Freedom to Marry banner, people swarm over."


GRAPHIC: In the next year or two, as a result of an anticipated court decision, Hawaii might issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, which other states would have to recognize under current law. Conservatives have mounted an effort in many states to enact laws to prevent any such recognition, as well as other measures that would effectively ban same-sex marriages.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
With a plan to become a nine-story store, Warner Brothers will double its Manhattan retail space.

BYLINE: By Mervyn Rothstein 

 BODY:
THE Warner Brothers Studio Store at 1 East 57th Street, a 15-floor building at Fifth Avenue, is growing from 30,000 square feet on three floors to 75,000 square feet on nine.
As part of the expansion, the exterior will be refurbished. The store, which opened on Oct. 27, 1993, will remain open during construction, with the new floors expected to be ready this fall. 
 "We've enjoyed great success, and we want to expand on that success," said Peter Starrett, president of Warner Brothers Studio Stores, a unit of Time Warner Inc. There are 137 of the studio shops worldwide, and 25 more are to open this year.
Mr. Starrett said the new floors at the Manhattan store would primarily be additional retail space but would also include "entertainment features." He declined to elaborate.
The lease on the new space is for 10 years, he said, and the lease for floors one through three was revised to give the store the entire site for the next 10 years. "We also have four five-year options," he said, "so we control the space for 30 years."
"The deal," he said, "made sense from an economic standpoint, because although the capital cost of converting office space to retail is high, the rent value for the additional floors is very competitive."
Mr. Starrett declined to give financial details. But a person familiar with the deal said that adding the 45,000 square feet, which more than doubled the original space, increased the rent by just 25 percent and that the rent for the additional floors was comparable to office rather than retail rents in the area.
Joseph Fabrizi, a director at Cushman & Wakefield, said rents for office space around Fifth and 57th generally ran from $35 to $40 a square foot.
 
Sports Club Moving In
 The space once occupied by the Atrium Club in the Galleria at 115 East 57th Street has been taken over by the New York Health and Racquet Club.
The club has leased 41,000 square feet -- part of the 6th and all of the 7th, 8th and 9th floors. The 57-floor building off Park Avenue has commercial space on the 3d through 16th floors and condominium apartments above.
Michael Laginestra of the Edward S. Gordon real estate company, who represented the landlord, Laszlo Tauber & Associates, said the lease was for 15 years, with options for 5 more years. The deal, which involved Mr. Laginestra and his colleagues Helene Saren and Alissa Finerman, was valued at $15 million.
Greg Manocherian, the managing partner of New York Health and Racquet Club, said he planned to reopen the space "in the next couple of months," as a subsidiary called the HRC Spa. The opening will follow more than $1 million in renovations, he said.
"We will have a full spa," Mr. Manocherian said. "We are upgrading the dining areas and will offer a low-fat, health-food and spa diet. We are also replacing the existing wall tile in the pool area with granite."
The Atrium Club opened in 1975 as a luxury social club with a gymnasium and a dining room. It closed suddenly on Feb. 1. The club's management said the closing was forced by "economic realities" including changes in the tax laws governing deductions for business entertaining and the increasing competition from "super gyms" like Reebok and Equinox on the Upper West Side.
Mr. Manocherian said that letters were being sent to the Atrium Club's 1,500 members informing them of the new spa.
Mr. Laginestra said he was also about to close three other commercial leases in the building, totaling about 18,000 square feet, making the office space about 80 percent occupied.
 
Investment Firm to Midtown
 Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe, an investment banking firm, has leased 21,000 square feet -- one and a half floors -- at 320 Park Avenue, a 35-floor, 656,000-square-foot office building at 50th Street. The 12-year lease was valued at more than $13 million.
Robert B. Emden, executive managing director of Grubb & Ellis New York, who represented Welsh, Carson with his partner, Elliot Klein, said the investment firm would move in July from 1 World Financial Center, where its lease is expiring. It had occupied about 12,000 square feet there.
"They wanted to get out of downtown, and they wanted to move to midtown, where they will be closer to hotels and where they can also entertain their clients more easily," Mr. Emden said.
