HEADLINE: Start of Charter School Shows Flaws in Concept

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

DATELINE: PHOENIX

 BODY:
The campus is 18 portable buildings in a muddy vacant field and the classrooms contain 1950's desks and chairs. There is no gymnasium, food service or library. The school almost closed in December when it ran out of money, and it was recently cited by the state for accounting procedures so lax it could be shut later on.
Charters, innovative schools that operate autonomously with public money, like Valley Academy here, are this year's hot concept in public education. But the bargain-basement campus and makeshift finances at Valley Academy and at some other Arizona charters are a reminder that reality can be a lot messier than the rosy visions of charter schools as scrappy entrepreneurial innovators. 
 Valley Academy's problems highlight two related issues dogging the charter process: whether states will provide enough money for them and whether the parents and teachers who start them can develop enough business savvy to run them.
Arizona has been one of the most aggressive states in moving into charter schools, with 46 opening in the last school year as the program got under way. They have a total enrollment of 7,500. None of the schools have gone under.
But only an interest-free $100,000 loan from a state legislator who has children in the school kept Valley Academy alive. And organizers admit that they were unprepared for some of the challenges.
Valley Academy, with a back-to-basics philosophy, has lost more than 100 students from the start of the school year. It now has an enrollment of about 485.
"We had good ideas about education," said Vicki Coulter, one of the founding teachers, "but I don't think we had enough people who knew what it took to run the school as a business. I think it's going to work, but I think it's going to be rough, and it's going to be rough for more than one year."
In the last few years, 246 charter schools have opened around the country, many of them small, concentrating on basic education or lessons focused in science, art or music. They operate as public schools dependent on state money, but with almost complete autonomy as far as hiring, curriculum and how they spend their money. Proponents say charters can provide cheaper, more innovative education if allowed to operate outside the established education bureaucracy.
In December, New Jersey became the 20th state to allow independent groups to set up charter schools and authorized the establishment of up to 135 in the state.
A recent study by the Hudson Institute, a conservative research organization based in Washington, said the majority of the 35 charters visited in seven states offered distinctive, varied programs, with excellent, sometimes unconventional teachers and committed, involved parents.
But it also said that many of the schools operated in "what could charitably be termed minimal facilities." And it said many faced enormous business problems that would inevitably result in the closing of some of the schools.
"We expect some charter schools to fail, possibly even within the next few months," concluded the report issued in January. "Some of these will fail for educational reasons, but most such losses will be because of economic and business difficulties."
Valley Academy, with kindergarten through 10th grade, is an example of how chaotic the charter process can be. The school is the only one in Arizona that started its campus from scratch rather than adapting existing buildings. Its squat gray portable buildings were put up in just a month, and the school opened a month after the other public schools. Only recently was the school given a temporary certificate of occupancy.
Rob Hamblin, who was among three of the school's six board members who resigned in February after continuing disagreements among parents, said: "They allowed us to do a lot of things that were not normal. We could have been shut down at any time."
The school was on the brink of closing when it ran out of money in December, and its long-term economic future remains in doubt.
A state auditor's report released in February about Valley and two other charter schools concluded, "We have serious concerns about the current financial management and accountability of the charter schools we reviewed, which in turn raises the question as to their long-term viability."
On Valley Academy, auditors found that documentation of expenditures was haphazard and overall financial controls were "practically nonexistent." The state gave the school 90 days to correct the problems or risk being closed.
On the other hand, organizers of the charters say many of the problems are the result of underfinancing and poor planning at the state level. And even if all the schools are not floundering to the same degree as Valley Academy, they face similar problems.
The state appropriated just $1 million, later augmented by $635,000, as start-up money for its 46 schools, far less than what it costs to start a single public school. That left schools spending operating money to renovate and maintain buildings rather than to pay teachers or buy books.
Gregory Miller is the principal and chief executive of the Dragonfleye Charter School, which has a science program and a 300-animal zoology laboratory in an abandoned college building in an area of warehouses and strip shopping centers here. He puts the overall financial picture this way:
"If we're running charter schools for two-thirds or three-quarters of other schools, I think that's possible, but we can't do it for less than half. If you want to say we're doing this too much on the cheap, you won't get an argument from me."
Charters in Arizona contend that a number of changes in the state laws are needed for them to survive. The charters cannot sell bonds or raise taxes like other public school districts. To compensate, they want to be able to borrow money, which would mean they would have to be chartered for 15 years rather than 5. They also want to be designated as the owners of their assets like buildings and supplies, most of which are now owned by the state, so they can use them as collateral for loans.
They also want a waiver from a state law prohibiting schools from carrying over 3 percent of their money to the next year, to help them build up a contingency fund for building, maintenance and major purchases.
"As things stand now, we're a hybrid that's the worst of both worlds," said Eddie Farnsworth, executive director of the Benjamin Franklin Charter School in Mesa. "We can't levy taxes like public schools, but we can't go to the private marketplace to raise funds either."
State Senator Mary Hartley of Phoenix, who is also a member of the local school board, said the state moved too quickly into charters, failing to establish appropriate guidelines. "I think if there had been a more structured environment, fertile soil to plant schools in, they could have flourished," she said. "Instead we planted them in the middle of the highway and they're being run over."
But others say the charters exist because the public schools were not providing what parents wanted. And even Valley Academy, for all its problems, has a passionate corps of parents and students who say the education there is better than the schools they came from.
"When there was a rumor in December that we were closing, the kids literally started crying," said Ms. Coulter, the academy teacher. "It's been frustrating, and it's been wonderful, but the education part is working. It's the other part we need to work on."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The campus of the Valley Academy Charter School, the only one of 46 new innovative independent schools in Arizona that did not move into existing buildings. Flaws have been pointed out in the system that was to have provided better education for less money than regular public schools. (Jeff Topping for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: I.R.S. Offers Companies a Deal in Contract-Worker Disputes

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
The Internal Revenue Service said yesterday that it would offer discounts of up to 87.5 percent on the payroll taxes owed by employers who were found to have improperly paid employees as independent contractors.
But a leading lawyer in the contentious field of worker classification said the I.R.S. deal was no bargain. 
 When companies hire employees, they must pay half of the Social Security and Medicare taxes, as well as unemployment and disability taxes, which together can equal 10 percent of salary. But when companies retain independent contractors, those taxes are supposed to be paid by the contractors out of their fee.
The I.R.S. says its studies show that many independent contractors, however, do not pay all the taxes they owe and that auditing these individuals is costly and inefficient compared with auditing companies with many employees.
The last official I.R.S. estimate put the number of workers who are improperly treated as independent contractors at more than three million, but experts say the number is much higher and has grown rapidly in recent years with widespread layoffs at major employers. Construction companies, newspapers, advertising agencies and computer makers are among those being examined by the I.R.S. in worker classification audits.
Commissioner Margaret Milner Richardson said yesterday that at the end of a worker classification audit companies would be given a chance to agree with the I.R.S. about which independent contractors were really employees.
If they agree, she said, the service will limit its claim for back taxes to one year, instead of the usual two, and will settle for as little as 25 percent of the taxes owed. That works out to an 87.5 percent discount compared with a full tax bill for two years and will be available without the expense of hiring accountants and lawyers to negotiate.
"This is a big difference," Mrs. Richardson said of the new policy and added that the I.R.S. could make claims as far back as six years.
The I.R.S. may also waive penalties, said Frank Keith, the senior I.R.S. spokesman.
"This program is voluntary," Mr. Keith said. "You can say no and challenge our view."
But Harvey J. Shulman, a partner at the Washington law firm of Ginsburg, Seldman & Bress, who specializes in worker classification cases, said the service's new program "is not different than many of the deals now being offered and it retains the same tactics that many small-business owners have been complaining for years are extortionary."
"The fact of the matter is, the I.R.S. has all the leverage," Mr. Shulman said. "If you don't take their deal, and the assessment is a half- million dollars, they will place a lien on your business for a half-million dollars. And if you are a small business, that means you are out of business before you can even get to court. The I.R.S. approach is like the guy who says, 'I won't kill you if you will let me cut off your ear.' "

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Drop on Weakened Rate-Cut Hope

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities slumped yesterday, as hopes for a quick cut in interest rates were weakened by a strong factory orders report and by comments by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan.
Trading was fairly light with many market participants looking ahead to Friday's report on employment for February. The market was pressured by selling of intermediate-maturity securities by large hedge funds, traders said. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 19/32 of a percentage point, to 95. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.38 percent, from 6.33 percent on Monday.
The bond market was surprised by a Commerce Department report that factory orders rose five-tenths of 1 percent in January. Many economists expected a decline of five-tenths of 1 percent because of a blizzard that closed some plants temporarily that month. The report raised fears that the economy could snap back more strongly than anticipated and bring on a surge in inflation.
Comments by Mr. Greenspan caused bonds to extend their session losses. He told a meeting of the Independent Bankers Association of America in Las Vegas, Nev., that "we may be underestimating the growth of our G.D.P. and productivity."
His comments bolstered the view of those in the market who see the economy growing fast enough to keep the central bank from lowering short-term interest rates further. A number of traders say that a cut in rates in the coming months has already been priced in by the market.
Another report yesterday also pointed to a pickup in the economy. A Johnson Redbook report showed retail sales up 1.9 percent for the four weeks ended March 2, just barely below a reading of 2 percent last week, suggesting that retail activity has held steady.
"The two weeks in a row of strong sales was enough to take the wind out of any attempt to rally in the market," said Bill Gamba, senior vice president and head of Government bond trading at Cowen & Company.
"I still think the sentiment is bullish, but I think we may be seeing a little long overdue correction in bonds," Mr. Gamba added.
In the municipal market, New York City sold $1.25 billion of general obligation bonds yesterday.
Yields on some of yesterday's bonds were around five basis points more than other comparable top-rated securities. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. It is not uncommon for investors to want a premium for increased risk; on Thursday, Moody's Investors Service strongly criticized a preliminary budget proposal by New York's Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani. The ratings agency warned that the city's ratings of Baa1 could be lowered.
New York's ratings are already among the lowest for a major American city. Only Detroit, Philadelphia and Washington have lower ratings.
New York City's 10-year bonds were tentatively set at 5.8 percent, or 120 basis points more than triple-A-rated general obligation debt, according to Bloomberg Fair Value Analytics.
In the largest part of the debt offering, the city negotiated the sale of $900 million of fixed-rate tax-exempt securities through J. P. Morgan Securities, at a price to yield a maximum 6.275 percent for a bond due in 2024. The underwriter also sold $190 million of tax-exempt variable-rate securities at the close of the market. However, they have not been priced yet.
In addition, the city sold $160 million of taxable bonds through Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, at yield spreads over Treasury securities that ranged from 56 basis points in 1997 to 84 basis points in 2003.

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Rise by 5.6%, With Ford's Flat in Month

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 5

 BODY:
Auto sales rose 5.6 percent last month, assuaging industry and Wall Street fears that the industry was heading for a stiff downturn.
The Ford Motor Company reported nearly flat February sales today. Ford said its car sales fell 4.7 percent while its truck sales -- buoyed by its redesigned F-150 pickup -- rose 5.5 percent. Over all, Ford sales slipped one-tenth of 1 percent last month. Sales of the Ford Taurus and its sibling, the Mercury Sable, fell 3 percent despite $600 rebates. But Ford was encouraged because the slip came as Ford reduced sales of the two cars to fleets by 26 percent, while retail sales of the cars rose 45 percent in February, said Joel H. Pitcoff, Ford's market analysis manager. 
 All together, auto makers sold 1.21 million cars and light trucks in the United States in February, up 5.6 percent from the month a year ago. Car sales rose 2.3 percent, to 694,154, while sales of pickups, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles jumped 10.2 percent, to 520,213. Ford was the last major auto maker to report February sales. Many companies released their auto sales figures last Friday.
Wall Street took Ford's sales dip in stride, overjoyed at the upturn in what many had feared was a slowing industry. In fact, on a seasonally adjusted basis vehicle sales in February clicked along at a 15.8 million annual rate compared with a 14 million rate in January and 15.9 million rate in December.
Last month "certainly came in much stronger than anyone was anticipating," said Jack V. Kirnan, a Salomon Brothers auto analyst. "The snapback probably does relieve some of the fears that many of us felt," after seeing January's weak sales.
In a striking development, Honda surpassed Toyota in car sales in February. Honda sold 61,212 cars, up 20.4 percent from the period a year ago. Meanwhile Toyota's car sales dropped 6.4 percent, to 51,353.
Analysts said it was too early to tell whether Honda would begin outselling Toyota month after month. But Scott F. Merlis, an auto analyst in Westport, Conn. said, "Honda has demonstrated the capability of running neck and neck with Toyota." He said there were several factors behind Honda's strong sales in February: "The driving force was the strength of the Civic, new products in the Acura line and low interest rate financing on the Accord."
Toyota sold 793,971 cars last year, well above Honda's 740,487 cars. Each month Toyota typically outsells Honda.
Of course sales varied around the country, and auto dealerships had mixed results in February. Many dealers predicted strong spring sales, however.
Sales have been slow on Long Island, where Michael L. Lazarus sells Saturns, Land Rovers and Volvos from his nine dealerships. "We haven't had a single weekend without snow," and that slowed sales of Saturns and Volvos last month, Mr. Lazarus said. By contrast, Land Rovers have sold briskly because of the poor weather, he said.
But he believes the sluggish sales now could help make for strong sales in spring -- the critical auto selling season. "Customers tell us that they are waiting" to buy, Mr. Lazarus said. "I think it is going to be a good spring."
Other dealers agree. Craig R. Caldwell, general manager of a Dublin, Calif., Ford dealership, said "cautious optimism" best described his outlook for spring sales. "Business was good in February," he said, with his store's car sales up 10 percent and truck sales up 58 percent from sales in February 1995.
In his dealership, Ford's F-150 pickup "has been a tremendous hit," Mr. Caldwell said. Customers "love the looks of it, and they love the performance and the utility of the 3rd door," he added. The pickups are selling almost as quickly as they arrive in his showroom, he said. He said Ford Explorers continued to be popular.
By contrast, the redesigned 1996 Taurus has been disappointing. "The Taurus is just O.K.," Mr. Caldwell said. "The people that own them like them -- I think it's a matter of time."

HEADLINE: John W. Wright, 83, Headed Money-Management Company

 BODY:
John Winthrop Wright, the founder and chairman of Wright Investors' Service, an investment management and advisory service company, died on Monday at Saint Vincent's Hospital in Bridgeport, Conn. Mr. Wright, a resident of Fairfield, Conn., was 83.
The cause of death was a heart attack, said Barbara Albright, a vice president at Wright. 
 Mr. Wright began in securities analysis by evaluating his own stock portfolio, and then started Wright Investors in 1961, developing it as an investment advisory service for Wall Street firms. He had a strong belief in conservative investments based on extensively researched companies. In a 1981 article in The New York Times, Mr. Wright was quoted as saying, "There's a lot of difference between gambling and investing," and characterized most stock traders as gamblers. "I have nothing against it," he added, "but that's not the business we're in."
Today, Wright manages $4 billion worth of investments for corporate, municipal and union employee benefit funds, single-country equity funds, endowment and charitable funds, bank trust departments, and individual clients.
The company also publishes weekly economic reports for its clients -- mostly banks and brokerages -- discussing general trends and making specific stock recommendations. In 1985, Wright Investors founded the Worldscope Database, a subscriber service offering information on 13,000 companies, some of it dating to Mr. Wright's original 1960's research. Since 1990, Worldscope has been jointly owned and operated by Wright Investors and the Primark Corporation.
The bulk of Mr. Wright's investment capital came from the sale of the Wright Power Saw and Tool Corporation, which he founded in 1947 and sold in 1954 to Thomas Industries of Louisville, Ky. After he sold the tool manufacturing company, he was a senior partner for four years in Andris Trubee, a financial consulting firm, and managed the bankruptcy of Rototiller Inc., from 1958 to 1959, before devoting himself to managing his own investment portfolio in 1960.
Mr. Wright graduated from Amherst College in 1933, and worked for various banking corporations before World War II. He was an active duty commander in the U.S. Naval Reserve from 1940 to 1946.
Mr. Wright, who was regarded as an expert on the stock market, was interviewed for articles in numerous publications. He testified before various Congressional committees and started the Committee on Developing American Capitalism, an organization devoted to promoting free enterprise and examining public economic policy.
Mr. Wright is survived by his wife, Mildred.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 730 words

HEADLINE: Budget Paralysis in Albany

 BODY:
New York's State Legislature is in a bind. It cannot decide what to do about Gov. George Pataki's proposal to close a $4 billion budget deficit by relying on more than $2 billion in projected savings from Congressional actions that are not close to enactment and may never occur. Rather than face reality and find alternative ways to reduce the deficit, the legislators want to defer a decision by adopting a three-month temporary budget, with the hope that Washington will come to the rescue.
That is a bad idea. Delay would weaken the state's finances for no good reason. The rescue Mr. Pataki wants is unlikely to happen on time, and would be harmful to the state if it did. 
 There is one obvious route out of the current mess. The hole facing the Legislature as a result of Congressional inaction is almost exactly the size of the $2.3 billion in tax cuts that are scheduled to take effect in the next fiscal year. Many lawmakers who voted for the tax cut last year would now like it to be rescinded, but they are afraid to say so in an election year. Even so, New Yorkers need to confront the fact that the next stage of an income tax cut will force deep reductions in aid to education, mental health programs, the State and City University systems, and Medicaid payments to hospitals, nursing homes and community health centers that care for the poor and elderly.
To his credit, Governor Pataki placed his own spending proposals on the table last December, a month early, to prod the Legislature into adopting a budget by the beginning of the fiscal year on April 1. But it was overly optimistic for him to assume that Congress and the White House would agree to sweeping Medicaid and welfare changes incorporating more Federal money for New York than is allowed under the current law. It is now anybody's guess whether President Clinton and the Congressional Republican leadership will be able to overcome their current impasse on budget issues before the fall election.
Passing a three-month budget is advertised by Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, as a sensible response to the possibility that Congress and the President might agree on a budget by the summer. But building a temporary budget bridge to nowhere will almost certainly cast a shadow when Albany issues bonds for important transportation projects in late spring, possibly raising interest rates on the state's debt. Moreover, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani of New York City and the leaders of every other locality in the state will have to draw up budgets without knowing what to expect from Albany. Sharp cutbacks in services are almost certain to result.
Some of Mr. Pataki's aides argue that the key to saving the New York budget lies in Senator Bob Dole's wrapping up the Republican Presidential nomination in the next few weeks. According to this theory, he and President Clinton might then both seek a compromise on the Federal budget to defuse some of the harshest issues in the fall campaign and enhance their credentials as effective leaders. But one can just as easily imagine that both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole would find it distasteful to make important concessions in these sensitive areas.
In the end, the Legislature's faith that a budget compromise in Washington will serve New York's interests may be misplaced. The path that Mr. Pataki has outlined would yield some $2.4 billion that could be applied to deficit reduction -- but only by imposing nearly $3 billion in cuts in Federal, state and local spending on Medicaid that supports the vast network of hospitals, nursing homes, community health centers and home-care attendants across the state. There is room for some cuts in a state with the highest Medicaid costs in the country, but the $3 billion proposed by the Governor is too steep to be absorbed in one year without destroying a vital part of the state's safety net for middle class and poor alike.
A better way to proceed would be to work with Congress to institute managed care for Medicaid to keep the growth of costs under control. Sooner or later, it should become obvious to both Democrats and Republicans who thought a state tax cut could be enacted without much pain that the cuts, instead, will cause extreme hardship for the elderly, the young, the sick and the poor who depend on the state for their well-being.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 508 words

HEADLINE: A Bad Way to Fight the Drug Trade

 BODY:
Influencing the behavior of countries involved in the production or shipment of illicit drugs is no easy matter for the United States, but the problem is exacerbated by a clumsy law the President must exercise every year. It requires that the State Department annually compile a list of delinquent countries, and that the White House decide which deserve punishment and which can go unscathed.
It is often hard to see why some countries are exempted from censure while others are not. This year, for example, Mexico was not singled out for American sanctions, even though it serves as the transit point for 70 percent of the drugs flowing into the United States. Colombia, home of some of the biggest drug cartels, was designated for sanctions. 
 While President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico seems to be making a concerted effort to combat the drug business, in contrast to the Colombian President, Ernesto Samper, who is accused of taking campaign contributions from drug lords, neither country is a model of drug enforcement. The reason Mexico got a pass from President Clinton is that the United States has far closer economic and political ties to Mexico than Colombia.
There ought to be a more consistent way to conduct American foreign policy. The law is a blunt instrument for fighting the international drug trade. In Bolivia and other Latin American countries, the threat of American sanctions has led to brutal military crackdowns in drug-growing areas and alarming human rights abuses.
In the case of Mexico, the inconsistency has already caused resentment in the international community. It is clear that the United States, having bailed out the Mexican economy and signed the Nafta treaty to create closer trade ties, was not prepared to jeopardize its investment by naming Mexico a drug pariah.
In Colombia, the economic impact of sanctions will probably not be great, but the diplomatic repercussions could be serious. Some members of Congress clearly hope the punishment will hasten Mr. Samper's downfall, but the judgment against Colombia could generate nationalistic sympathy for the embattled President. Honest and courageous figures like Alfonso Valdivieso, the Colombian prosecutor general who has pursued drug corruption, and Gen. Rosso Jose Serrano, the national police chief, may now be more isolated than ever.
The law should be more nuanced. One idea is to have graduated sanctions. Clearly Colombia, an imperfect but struggling democracy, does not belong in the same pariah category as drug-exporting dictatorships like Myanmar and Iran. Another constructive approach would be an effort to deal with the problem on a regional basis, perhaps through the Organization of American States.
As long as the United States is the largest consumer of illegal drugs in the world, suppliers will find a way to do business here. But American efforts to fight the flow of drugs into this country should not be hampered by a law that substitutes posturing by Washington for an effective strategy to combat drugs.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Hometown Feels Less Like Home

SERIES: THE DOWNSIZING OF AMERICA: In the Community, Fraying Bonds -- Fourth of seven articles.

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio

 BODY:
To Wall Street and the world, it was the National Cash Register Company. Then, it was modernized, computerized, streamlined down to NCR. But in Dayton, the company was always just "the Cash."
The Cash got rich selling its cash registers to the world, and it rewarded its workers with good livings and unrivaled benefits, and its hometown with a firm hand of civic guidance and millions of dollars of good works. They were all bound together -- the company, the workers and the town. To a lot of people here, Dayton was the Cash, and the Cash was Dayton. 
 "NCR was part of Dayton's soul," George Bayless, a 58-year-old banker, said as he drove past the vacant swath of Main Street where 30 yellow-brick NCR factory buildings once stood.
As a boy, Mr. Bayless learned to swim in the big pool in the park that NCR's founding patriarch, John Patterson, built. He played French horn in the NCR band. And when he graduated from high school in 1955, he marched down the aisle of NCR Auditorium, just as generations of high school graduates had before him, and would for two decades more.
Nearly all of it has vanished in the steep decline and takeover of NCR: the buildings, 20,000 jobs, even the NCR name; the security, the middle-class aspirations, the way of life. And today, as its faraway corporate parent, AT&T, prepares to break into three pieces, the future of Dayton's hometown company is profoundly unsure.
The same could be said of the future, and the present, of the entire town. For Dayton was always much more than just the Cash. Daytonians invented and manufactured many of the staples (and a few of the quirky incidentals) of American prosperity -- the cash register, of course, and the airplane, but also the automobile self-starter and the pop top. And companies like Frigidaire, Delco, Dayton Tire, Huffy Bicycle and Esther Price Chocolates joined with the community in an unwritten social contract crafted on a foundation of profits and jobs, plenty of jobs.
Now, this test marketer's vision of average America is deep in mid-passage between two economic eras: the old era of making things and of job security, and the new one of service and technology, takeovers, layoffs and job insecurity. And the entire cloth of society, which most people in Dayton once wore so comfortably, feels as if it is out of style and could just wear out.
Everything, seemingly, is in upheaval: not just the jobs and lives of tens of thousands of people, but also the big corporations, the banks, the schools, the religious and cultural institutions, the old relationships of politics and power, and, especially, people's expectations of security, stability and a shared civic life.
"Now that there are only a few big hometown companies left, people are less certain about the community, too," said Brad Tillson, publisher of The Dayton Daily News, which itself is owned by an out-of-town company these days. "It creates tremendous uncertainty in people's lives. The tie between individuals and the community is less certain, and more fragile. It's scary for everybody."
All workers may be replaceable. Not so volunteers. When one man, Vinnie Russo, left NCR in the turmoil after the takeover -- he felt he had little choice, he said -- and found a new job in Louisville, the 85 boys of Pack 530 lost their Cubmaster; a new one has yet to sign on. With most women working, it is harder to find people to help in the schools and libraries. Churches are losing members. So are service organizations; people say they cannot leave work for meetings, even if they last only an hour. In a town with a tradition of charity, the United Way has missed its $20 million goal by $1 million in each of the last two years.
It can be confusing, living in Dayton in 1996. Like much of the Rust Belt, this sprawling region of nearly a million people is not as rusty as it was 15 or 20 years ago. Many of the economic indicators are, if not exactly dazzling, at least promising. Unemployment is low. There is plenty of work available, even if many of the jobs do not pay what the old ones paid. Dayton has not, of late, undergone the staggering layoffs of, say, the aerospace industry in Southern California.
"By most of the traditional criteria, Dayton is doing pretty well," said Mr. Tillson, who sits on the board of the Miami Valley Economic Development Coalition, which was formed in 1994 to help guide Dayton into the new economic era. "But people just don't feel that way."
They know that thousands of jobs -- middle-management, government, blue-collar -- have disappeared, and that more could go at any time. The anxiety is everywhere. From the mostly white East Side to the mostly black West Side; over coffee in the new $300,000 homes of suburban Centerville, in the classrooms at John Patterson High School downtown: the conversation inevitably returns to the loss of jobs, the fear of losing jobs, the decline of the middle class, the rise of the global economy, the end of the American dream.
"Downsizing -- I hate that word," Chuck McElligott said one evening, recalling the feelings of all the people he knew who had lost their jobs. " 'You just blew my life away, and you're telling me I was downsized.' "
And yet, Dayton is not falling apart. People here talk a lot about their communal ability to work things out, and the civic physics of Dayton today is indeed a constant push and pull. So while out-of-town journalists may have dismissed Dayton as an unlikely backwater setting for the Bosnia peace talks, people here thought it the perfect place.
Dayton's arts organizations may be getting less corporate money, but with that threat as inspiration, the Dayton Art Institute has raised a record $18 million in two years, including $11 million from individuals.
The city's public schools may be struggling to prepare their students for the needs of the new economy, but Sinclair Community College is confidently busy -- virtually 24 hours a day, 7 days a week -- training, or retraining, 65,000 local residents for these post-industrial times.
Chuck McElligott and his family are also working hard to cope in the new economy. Mr. McElligott, 55, a one-time University of Dayton football star, lost his job five years ago when the graphic-design company where he had spent 23 years shut down, partly because of the problems at NCR. He considers himself lucky to have found another job, even if it is for longer hours and less pay. His wife, Armonde, gave up her volunteer work at the library and got a paying job, teaching school. College for Charlie, the youngest of their three children, was going to be tough to afford.
But last fall, the future seemed full of possibility for Charlie, a senior and the best player on the football team at suburban Oakwood High School. He had cardboard boxes stuffed with letters from interested Big Ten schools.
In the second game of the season, he broke his pelvis in two places. Football was out for the rest of the year. And so, it became quickly apparent, was the football scholarship.
Mrs. McElligott recalled her son's reaction at the hospital, when the doctor described the seriousness of the injury. "His eyes welled up, but he didn't cry," she said. "Then he looked at us, and said, 'O.K., we've got to think of Plan B.' "
This is what Dayton feels like right now: All the people, and all the institutions, are groping for Plan B.
 
'The Cash' Was No More
History, local history, is also part of the conversation here. People may sometimes feel as if their community is in danger of splitting apart, but history is still what they own together.
Never, according to that history, did Dayton's people and institutions pull together more fiercely than during the flood of 1913. The flood killed 300 people and wiped out scores of businesses. Luckily (or was it destiny?), the National Cash Register Company was on high ground. Overnight, the company was transformed into an emergency shelter and hospital, as well as a printing plant for The Dayton Daily News. From the waters of the flood, and a vast common effort, modern Dayton was born.
In the decades that followed, the Cash boomed, and so did Dayton. While Detroit made cars, Akron made tires and Pittsburgh made steel, Dayton made all that and more. They called it "the city of a thousand factories." There were not just NCR, General Motors and Chrysler, but Dayton Press, Dayton Tire, Dayton Malleable.
"How did I feel about my future?" asked 53-year-old Kathleen Stewart, whose father, a Hungarian immigrant, worked in one of those factories and raised a family of 10 in a housing project. "I felt lucky. I was from Dayton. All you had to do was grow up. There was money everywhere."
She went straight from high school to the NCR plant to the middle class. "I was making $3.50 an hour," she said. "That was big money in those days. The company treated you like you were family."
By the 1970's, though, this city that had thrived on its mastery of technology was in danger of being done in by it. In deep financial trouble, NCR belatedly embraced the electronic age. It began carving out a niche selling automated teller machines and computer systems linking department stores. It also moved its manufacturing south, and abroad, where labor was cheap.
Twenty-thousand NCR jobs were lost, and soon the layoffs were echoed all over town: General Motors, 10,000 jobs, half of them at the Frigidaire plant, which closed; Chrysler, 5,000 jobs; Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, 3,000; Dayton Press, 3,000 more. By the mid-1980's, a third of Dayton's manufacturing jobs had been lost, about 50,000 in all. The city, and the society, that rose from the flood were effectively gone.
And a new Dayton began to emerge. In the churning of businesses opened, downsized and taken over, thousands of jobs have disappeared; many, many more have been created.
But that is only part of the story. Most of the new jobs, or at least the ones that do not require a college education, have been in lower-paying retail and service work. Indeed, median family income in Montgomery County, which includes Dayton, rose only about $1,000 between the 1980 and 1990 Censuses, to $36,069, from $34,903. And the unions, which once helped keep wages high, have lost much of their membership, and more of their power. The local A.F.L.-C.I.O., for example, had about 70,000 members in 1975 and fewer than 50,000 today.
Then in 1991, the Cash was no more. AT&T acquired the company in a hostile takeover. It was a disastrous marriage. The company lost a half-billion dollars in the first nine months of 1995 alone.
"You knew things were changing, but when AT&T took over NCR that was the landmark that proved it," Ms. Stewart said. "People can't depend on anything for the future. Anything can change in a New York minute."
Around Dayton, nothing so symbolized the unease with NCR's new identity as much as the name change, to AT&T Global Information Solutions. It felt as if some outsider had summarily renamed the town.
Today, Dayton is trying to re-create itself yet again. A new wave of small high-tech companies dot the fringes of town, working on computer projects with Wright-Patterson. And so everyone here is asking the chronic question: Can this cradle of invention reinvent itself well enough to make up for the losses of the past?
When Ms. Stewart returned to work after getting divorced, the best job she could find was at an electronic engraving company, where she took home $14,000 last year. When her refrigerator broke in early January and she could not afford a new one, she made do with a cooler and garbage bags buried in the snow outside her back door.
Her 25-year-old son, David, is trying to negotiate the new world as best he can. He makes about $8.50 an hour, including commissions, working nights at one of the big new service businesses, the Victoria's Secret Catalog company. There, hooked up to a telephone and a computer and surrounded by blow-ups of celebrity models, he sells Savoy robes and Miracle bras made abroad to customers from all over the world.
Mr. Stewart says he may enroll at Sinclair. What does he want to study? "Something with a guaranteed job." His other plan is to leave Dayton, and go south.
 
No Commitments
Karen Myers is 40 years old, a lawyer and the mother of three. Her husband, Robert, is a pediatrician. Her father-in-law worked for the old NCR. They live in a new neighborhood of custom-built homes in Centerville. Family by family, she says, her community is being taken apart.
"Many of these kids I see are on their fifth or sixth move because the company keeps saying, 'We're not making enough money; we need to downsize more,' " she said recently. "It used to be military families. Now it's modern life. It really hurts the child's ability to develop those long-term commitments. It's devastating to the sense of community."
Some 100 houses in and around Centerville were on the market last fall, after G.I.S. announced its latest round of 1,300 layoffs.
Mrs. Myers is on the board of the Centerville United Methodist Church, a medium-size church.
"I see people moving to the mega- , super-sized churches," she said. "I don't see them moving because the churches offer more services. They're able to attend without commitment. You can go and be one of the many and be invisible."
Mrs. Myers was talking over coffee and muffins with her neighbor, Mary Ellen Knecht. Mrs. Knecht and her husband, Mark, who quit his job at G.I.S. last fall for more satisfying and lucrative work, have four children.
"We are the new homeless," said Mrs. Knecht. NCR had moved her family from Indianapolis to Wichita, Kan., to Dayton to South Carolina and, four years ago, back to Dayton. Each time, they bought a house with a 30-year mortgage.
In South Carolina, Mrs. Knecht was president of her Methodist church women's group. She sang in the choir. She helped set up computer labs in the schools.
Now, she said, "I'm not building anything here. I attend church. I haven't joined. When they pass around the attendance card on Sundays, I want to write down: 'I'm moving.' "
Now the family was planning a move to Virginia. Mr. Knecht has been living there since October, when he took a job with a software company called DataFocus.
Sipping her coffee, Mrs. Myers said: "My husband has been clipping articles out of Pediatric Journal on the effects of moving on kids."
Mrs. Knecht asked: "What do they say?"
Mrs. Myers: "You don't want to know."
 
'The Safety Net Was Us'
Monday mornings, Cinda Woodward rises early, very early, so she can send her husband, Jeff, off at 5:30 on the first leg of his weekly commute -- the 90-minute drive to the Cincinnati airport. By noon, he arrives in Gainesville, Fla., where he goes to work as the chief financial officer for Gold Standard Multimedia, an electronic health-care publishing company. He rents a small apartment where he eats, sleeps and exercises on a NordicTrack. Thursday night he is back at the Gainesville airport.
"I've rationalized it to myself that I'm gone three nights, and home four nights," he said cheerfully.
Mr. Woodward left his Dayton job at Mead Data Central last May after it was acquired by Reed Elsevier P.L.C., a Dutch-British conglomerate, which eliminated 400 jobs.
He is one of the new nomad dads. They have been laid off, transferred or, like Mr. Woodward, they have simply decided to leave, dissatisfied with what their corporate lives have become. Now, they commute by plane to new jobs that they consider no more permanent than the old ones. Three of Mr. Woodward's former Mead co-workers have become nomad dads, too. One commutes to Manhattan, another to New Jersey, the third to Chicago.
"I'd rather be the one to be the nomad than drag the whole family around the country," Mr. Woodward said, adding that at 48, he considers himself fortunate to have the education and the financial flexibility to adapt to the new world.
Against his commuting grind, Mr. Woodward is trying hard to hold onto the family life and community that he says anchor him in the world. And so at 10:30 on a Saturday morning in early January, after a week made even more grueling than usual by a blizzard, he was at choir practice at the Oakwood United Methodist Church.
The sun was streaming through the stained-glass windows. Cinda and their 18-year-old daughter, Leslie, were in front, raising their voices in strains of "Agnus Dei." Leslie's brother, Paul, 14, would have been there, too, but he had basketball practice. Mr. Woodward was at the lectern. He is not just a member of the choir, he directs it.
He never considered giving up the choir, he said later. Neither, apparently, would any of the other 20 regulars. They all showed up that Saturday. "The choir is like an extended family," Mr. Woodward said. "This is how you keep in touch."
But across Dayton, scores of other people are too exhausted, or frustrated, or just too plain busy, to keep in touch. "No one," said Kathleen Stewart, "has time to eat dinner together anymore." Everywhere you go, you meet working mothers who used to stay home, people with two jobs who used to have one, high-school students who have taken jobs to help out their families and prepare themselves for the future.
Mr. Woodward said he became concerned in the early 1990's when, as Mead's representative, he headed the planning and allocations committee for the Dayton United Way.
"It has gotten harder to recruit people as volunteers," said Mr. Woodward, who had to give up his United Way position after he left Mead. "A lot of the women have gone back to work, and because of that a lot of the guys have picked up bigger child-care responsibilities. It spreads around, and makes everyone less available."
Business leaders and politicians used to clamor for invitations to lunch at the Sertoma Club, which helps the poor. Today, the club is down to 50 members, its influence is at an ebb, and speakers are hard to find. The Rotary Club is having membership troubles, too, and so Rotarians no longer must attend 60 percent of meetings or face expulsion.
"Did you ever read de Tocqueville?" asked Mr. Bayless, who would never consider missing one of the weekly Sertoma lunches. "One of his points was that Americans in 1831, they associated together. There were all these associations.
"It was one of the things that made America work, that made it unique. The safety net was not just government. It was us."
 
View From the West Side
Job losses and economic uncertainty are hardly news to blacks in Dayton. Few blacks ever got on at NCR, and the jobs they did find, usually in Dayton's hot, dirty and dangerous foundries, were never guaranteed.
"We were always the last hired, first fired," said Lloyd Lewis Jr., a black State Representative. "We'd do it every five, six years. They'd lay off the bottom of the work force, then hire them back."
Dayton, which is 40 percent black, has long been racially segregated. Blacks live on the West Side, whites on the East. When Mr. Lewis, who is 69, graduated from the University of Dayton with a business degree in 1948, NCR offered jobs to all his white classmates but not to him. He was fortunate. He escaped the foundries by going to work in his family's Goodyear tire franchise, and today he lives in a middle-class West Side neighborhood.
A lot of Dayton's black foundry workers made it to the middle class, too. But no one ever talked about downsizing factory and foundry workers -- black or white.
"Downsizing -- that's a middle-class term," said Mr. Lewis, who two years ago retired as an assistant vice president of the Dayton Power & Light Company. "Now it's affected the white middle-class middle management, where no one ever thought it would go."
And while plenty of middle-class blacks are also being hurt, they do not feel betrayed the way so many whites do, Mr. Lewis said.
"We never had it to be betrayed," he said. "It's just like the Depression. People jumped off the top of skyscrapers. Black people didn't commit suicide. You couldn't commit suicide jumping out of a basement."
The Rev. Raleigh Trammell came north from Georgia in the 1950's and created his own job, making sandwiches for factory workers. For rich and for poor, he said, "Dayton was a work town."
Today, inner-city Dayton is not the work town it used to be. With little to replace the foundries, unemployment is around 15 percent, compared with 4.8 percent in the county. To people there, who have little mobility, the new jobs, in the suburbs and outlying areas, might as well be four states away.
The day before Christmas, Fred Sampson, 49, and Joseph Atkinson, 20, were earning a few dollars at Mr. Trammell's church, loading crates of oranges for poor families.
"What happened to all those places?" Mr. Atkinson asked, referring to the shut-down foundries.
"Cheap labor," said Mr. Sampson.
 
Power Leaves Town, Too
"It was a white boys' club," said Mr. Tillson, the publisher, describing how power and politics used to work in Dayton.
The white boys were the corporate executives. They ran the town through its city manager, mayor and city commission. These days, though, the white boys' club is mostly gone.
"Power is distributed now," said John Moore, who went to work at Wright-Patterson as a clerk in 1946, and eventually became the first black personnel director there. "There are more people at the table." Mr. Moore, who is retired, is chairman of Sinclair Community College.
The waning of the white boys' club made it easy for Willie F. Walker, president of the Dayton Urban League, to introduce himself to John Granzau, chairman of Standard Register, at a 1991 reception for a new banker in town. At lunch a week later, Mr. Walker made his pitch. He needed two community workers for an inner-city neighborhood. The price: $60,000 over three years. After another lunch, this time with the chief executive, Mr. Walker had his workers.
But today, stories like that are less common. The entire community, black and white, has less access to corporate power and money. More of Dayton's top executives are accountable to headquarters somewhere else, and, what with global economics, a lot of them aren't even in Dayton half the time; they're on airplanes.
David H. Ponitz, the president of Sinclair, told of one local executive who had been trying for six months to get $50,000 from his company's out-of-town headquarters for a community project.
"There used to be more C.E.O.'s who could make immediate decisions on community issues," Mr. Ponitz said. "Now there is more checking with corporate offices outside of Dayton to get those same decisions. And they usually come at a lower level of interest, and a lower dollar level."
Frederick C. Smith, the retired chief executive of Huffy Bicycle, recalled a 1993 luncheon with Jerre Stead, then the chief executive of AT&T's new acquisition. Mr. Smith, along with five other local business and community leaders, had been summoned to the old NCR private dining room.
"Jerre Stead walked in at precisely 12 o'clock," Mr. Smith said. "We were all in coats and ties. He came in a cardigan sweater. He let us know he was sandwiching us in between meetings with Business Week and Morgan Stanley. He talked for one hour almost nonstop and left at precisely 1 o'clock.
"I went home later and told my wife I didn't understand a word he said. It was all about the information highway and globalization and 'It's a new world.' " Dayton scarcely came up in the conversation, Mr. Smith said. "Jerre Stead didn't know a thing about Dayton."
Last June, Mr. Stead left to head a software company in Virginia. He was replaced by Lars Nyberg, a Swede who had never lived in America.
Given the changes at G.I.S., it is not surprising that the United Way missed its goal the last two years. In 1995, with a $400,000 corporate contribution, the company remained the fund's biggest corporate giver. But as its work force fell to 3,500, from 4,500 in 1992, employee contributions fell to about $840,000, from about $2 million, according to Jim Keeney, the regional A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s liaison to the United Way.
Now, as the company prepares to be cut loose from AT&T, it is planning a rescue strategy based on a return to its business roots: computer systems for stores, banks and big companies. And, said the chief financial officer, John Giering, it remains committed to Dayton. "We are still very supportive of the community," he said.
Mr. Nyberg has begun to be more visible around town. He attended a Rotary lunch in December, and held a community reception in January.
"I think as time moves on, and we become a public company," Mr. Giering said, "Lars will be spending more time in Dayton."
 
Where Have the Banks Gone?
George Bayless was alone in his office in Dayton's fading downtown. Nobody was in the adjoining offices. After yet another "consolidation" last fall, Mr. Bayless was the only person left in his department at National City Bank. "Is it a permanent job?" he asked. "As permanent as any job is nowadays."
Mr. Bayless has had an intimate association with Dayton's banks over the years. In the last decade, he has had to get used to a lot of changes. Gem Savings & Loan Association, where he started out as a teller 36 years ago, was merged into the Cleveland-based National City Bank. Mr. Bayless, who was then a purchasing officer with his two daughters just barely through college, says he was lucky to keep his job.
Mr. Bayless ticked off the other changes: "Winters Bank became Bank One. Third National became Society, which became Key Society, which is headquartered in Cleveland." Third National was where he opened his first savings account, when he was 10 years old and a paper boy. Today, there is one locally owned financial institution in town, Citizens Federal, a savings bank.
With the loss of the hometown banks, small-business owners say it can be harder to get a loan. But more than that, out-of-town ownership is another blow to the sense of Dayton as a distinct hometown.
Kathleen Stewart is not looking for a loan, and she has no money to invest. For her, it comes down to trust. "I've dropped banks," she said. "They all changed names so many times." Now, she uses a credit union.
Mr. Bayless has a new title at the bank these days. He is the business recovery coordinator. In the event of a disaster -- "a fire, say, or something like the Oklahoma City bombing" -- it would be his job to come up with Plan B. In that sort of disaster, he said, he would know how to help people -- "whereas, the economy, people's attitudes, you can't repair those disasters."
 
Studying for an Edge
If there is one institution that is trying to prepare Daytonians for the future, it is Sinclair Community College. Sometimes it seems as if every other person in Dayton is either enrolled at Sinclair, taking a class there or planning to do so. They are studying everything from computer graphics to medical data processing to advanced manufacturing. More than 20 percent of the students have undergraduate degrees and are back to learn new job skills; many have been laid off. Sinclair's nine downtown blocks of modern, rectangular buildings -- with numbers instead of names, and no ivy anywhere -- are a pure statement of utilitarian purpose.
"This is everyone's hope, right here," 35-year-old Tommy Weems, a business major, said as he walked to his car after classes.
Mr. Ponitz is considered one of the most important people in town. When he arrived 20 years ago, Sinclair had 7,000 students. Today there are 65,000. Their average age is 32. At $31 per credit hour -- one third the cost of tuition at Ohio State -- Sinclair is the least expensive college in the state.
"You have to understand what the new reality is," Mr. Ponitz said. "The new reality is that you have to know something that somebody else doesn't know, but that is not enough. You have to keep growing dramatically if you're really going to keep a job."
At 10 o'clock one night, Rob Lind and 11 other men who are trying very hard to adjust to the new reality were gathered around a computer in a classroom in Building No. 11. They are learning to be machine-tool operators, and today that means they have to know computers. Class meets Monday through Friday, 10 P.M. to 7 A.M.
Mr. Lind, who is 32, had already put in his usual 9 1/2 hours at the garage where he has been a mechanic for 14 years, making $11 an hour without benefits. "I can go anywhere from here and make $15 an hour," he said.
Last semester, Mr. Lind, who gets by on about three hours sleep, earned a 4.0 average. "I didn't want to crawl around under cars my whole life," he explained.
 
In Search of an Identity
When a man loses his job, his identity is shaken. The same could be said for a town when it loses the old way of work.
"What is Dayton's identity now?" Mr. Bayless asked as he drove by the vacant, snowy expanse that once was the Cash. He paused a long moment, then shook his head. "I don't know."
As it gropes for a new identity, and with the centennial of powered flight just seven years away, Dayton is getting ready to celebrate its own hometown heroes -- the Wright brothers. The old West Side bicycle shop where they began to develop the first airplane will become the centerpiece of the Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park. "We're trying to gather around this flight thing," Mr. Bayless said. "We're trying to work out an identity based on that."
Speaking of history and identity, in January, G.I.S. had news that was received here as a small victory. "Drawing upon a 112-year history," Lars Nyberg announced, "we begin to build our exciting future by renaming our company -- NCR."

HEADLINE: The Street Cop In Pin Stripes

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
Lou Matarazzo takes off his gun, a snubnose .38 he is packing under his pin-stripe suit, and slips it into the drawer of his burnished horseshoe desk.
"Guess I won't need this for a few hours," he says with just a flicker of bravado, enough to insure that the gesture does not go unnoticed. 
 Mr. Matarazzo, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, might say the gun shows that -- despite the corner-office view of the Brooklyn Bridge and the closet stocked with red wine -- he is still a street cop. He may wear tasseled lace-ups but they are spit-shined.
But those who have been on the receiving end of his powers of persuasion might say it shows something else: that he is an impresario of the implied threat, the figurative show of force.
In the year since he took the helm of New York City's police union, Mr. Matarazzo has wielded a blend of political polish and street smarts to push through his union's biggest legislative victory in 20 years. Descending on lawmakers' offices with or without an appointment, he and his platoon of union leaders last month helped persuade the Legislature to override Gov. George E. Pataki's veto of a bill that would strengthen the hand of the city's police officers in contract disputes.
The victory only escalated tensions with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in what Mr. Matarazzo now calls a war. The Mayor had strenuously opposed the bill, now law, under which contract disputes involving the city's police and firefighters will be arbitrated by a state board considered to be more generous than the city board.
Mr. Giuliani has since declared that talks on the police officers' new contract are at an impasse and his aides have warned that the city will consider a range of cost-cutting measures for the Police Department, including one-person patrol cars and limits on overtime pay.
Mr. Matarazzo has retaliated by saying he would not endorse Mr. Giuliani in the next mayoral election. Recently, he has floated the prospect that he might endorse someone else, like Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx, the City Comptroller, Alan Hevesi, or City Councilman Sal F. Albanese of Brooklyn.
"The Mayor made up his mind and I made up my mind," Mr. Matarazzo said. "It'll never get patched up as long as he keeps fighting us."
Even those who question whether Mr. Giuliani needs the backing of the P.B.A. president or the union's 28,000 members to win a second term acknowledge that the square-jowled 56-year-old union leader could prove a tough sparring partner.
"The Mayor and Matarazzo, they both dig in," said Michael Julian, who retired last year as chief of personnel for the Police Department. "If he wasn't as strong on these points, he would probably be replaced by a more vocal and militant president."
Unlike his more patrician predecessor, Phil Caruso, who preferred behind the-scenes jockeying, Mr. Matarazzo has embraced hands-on lobbying. In Albany, he took to carrying two pieces of paper with him: a stub from his police paycheck and a pay stub belonging to Police Officer Thomas Barbieri of Nassau County.
Officer Barbieri happens to be married to Mr. Matarazzo's daughter, Annamaria. He also happens to make $63,000 after nine years with the Nassau department, in contrast to the maximum pay of $47,000 for a New York City police officer. (Mr. Matarazzo actually makes twice that, because the union matches his police salary.)
"He is absolutely passionate about it, and personal," said James Lysaght, the P.B.A.'s chief counsel and lobbyist in Albany.
If, as Hugh Mo, a deputy police commissioner from 1984 to 1988 says, the P.B.A. "is the proverbial 800-pound gorilla," Mr. Matarazzo is its gregarious handler. With its millions in dues, the union wields its power through campaign contributions and the influence that comes from the reluctance of elected officials to appear anti-police (read "soft on crime").
 
Political Muscle In the Suburbs
Many New York City officers also have political muscle in the suburbs, where most live. This afternoon, Mr. Matarazzo is scheduled to receive a visit from Mr. Pataki, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey and other dignitaries, when he will announce the union's endorsement of Senator Bob Dole in the Republican Presidential primary.
While Mr. Matarazzo is clearly bent on using all lobbying tools at the P.B.A.'s disposal, he seems to think he may be his own best weapon.
"I was seen more in Albany in the last few months than they'd ever seen any P.B.A. president," he said. "No one wants to see it on paper. They want to see you tell them. They have a right to see me in person and see how I present myself."
He presents himself as rough cut, earthy but earnest, the kind of man who takes satisfaction in the two Webster's dictionaries he received from union officers jokingly comparing Mr. Matarazzo with his urbane and articulate predecessor.
Two days after the Governor's veto, Mr. Matarazzo was back in the capital, urging legislators to override the veto, and to do it fast, before the newspaper editorial writers that Mr. Matarazzo calls "the boo birds" persuaded them otherwise.
"People looked at me and said, 'I don't believe you,' " he said. "Most of them thought I would accept the veto. I think I took them by sneak attack."
The son of a shoemaker from Avellino, Italy, Mr. Matarazzo grew up in an East Harlem apartment with no telephone or television. When he was 15, his family moved to the Patterson housing projects in the South Bronx.
A star third baseman and catcher at James Monroe High School, Mr. Matarazzo said sports helped keep him out of trouble. That and the Boys Club of New York, where he sold towels after school and eventually became an athletic director.
"At Christmastime, I was given an apple, a bag of candy and a flannel shirt," he said.
When it became clear that he would never make it to the New York Yankees, he became a police officer, walking a beat in Long Island City's 108th Precinct.
Barely six months after he started, Officer Matarazzo was deployed to Harlem to keep order during the riots in summer 1964. "I remember standing in Mount Morris Park during the riots and we didn't have helmets," he said. "I thought this was crazy."
He went to some Con Edison workers in Queens and borrowed as many hard hats as he could, spray-painting the orange utility helmets blue.
Five years later, Mr. Matarazzo became the P.B.A. delegate from the 108th Precinct. In the 1970's, when a lieutenant offered to put him up for detective, "I said: 'Don't bother. I'm going to get on the P.B.A. board,' " Mr. Matarazzo said. In 1977, he became the union trustee for Queens, and in 1991, he was elected recording secretary and then treasurer.
When Mr. Caruso announced his retirement in January 1995 after 15 years as president, Mr. Matarazzo won his endorsement over higher-ranking union officers. "I felt I was the most qualified for the job," he said. "We were in very difficult times. I did not want to see this union destroyed."
 
Union Is Powerful But Suspect
The difficulties went beyond the city's economic troubles and the labor contract, which expired as he took over in March 1995. Mr. Matarazzo inherited leadership of a union that is powerful but suspect, accused by the Mollen Commission of being "a shelter for the corrupt cop," tipping off corrupt officers to investigations and encouraging a secretive "us versus them" environment.
Last year, senior Police Department officials accused union delegates of trying to thwart major corruption inquiries by explaining in detail how to spot undercover operations. Other blemishes on the P.B.A. include the 1988 forced resignation of the union's chief lawyer after he took millions from union funds to pay his gambling debts, and the rowdy and profane behavior by officers at a 1992 rally at City Hall.
Mr. Matarazzo says these are isolated incidents and that he has taken small steps to distance the union from officers who appear clearly guilty of crimes. But he continues to defend officers like Francis X. Livoti, who was charged with choking 29-year-old Anthony Baez to death in the Bronx last year. Mr. Matarazzo said Officer Livoti, who has been charged with criminally negligent homicide, "was doing his job."
"He got involved with a 5-foot-6, woefully out of shape, 270-pound asthmatic who happened to die when he wrestled him to the ground," Mr. Matarazzo said.
Mr. Matarazzo said he was cooperating with the Police Department's efforts to fight corruption. But he said the union did not need to take a more aggressive anticorruption role because officers get adequate back room lectures, where they are told, among other things, that "Internal Affairs will have programs out there to try to entice you."
"Police officers can get into trouble for thinking they're doing the right thing, like quote unquote perjurious statements," he said. "They might get overzealous. Police officers are not allowed to make a mistake, a legitimate honest mistake, but the defendant can."
 
Keeping in Touch With the Troops
Starting his day at 5 A.M. -- "I don't even need to use an alarm clock," he said -- he often stops at a precinct in one borough or another on the way from his Nassau County home to the union's high-rise near the Fulton Fish Market.
One day last week, he breezed in to the Midtown North station house on West 54th Street in time for the 3 P.M. shift change. In the back room, 35 men and a few women in uniform listened with arms crossed or hands on hips, peppering him with questions about health benefits, pay raises, the arbitration bill.
Here, too, Mr. Matarazzo was a lobbyist, telling the crowd how hard he was working on their behalf, how stunning his victory was in Albany. He slapped a lot of backs, gabbing with one officer about her recent marriage and kidding a short officer that he was lucky the department no longer had a height requirement.
He reminded them of a voter registration drive he started for officers and their families, telling them that the union was putting legislators' voting records on computer and would eventually give members a list of the union's endorsements.
"When you go out in November, you'll know who to vote for," he said.
For now, the Giuliani-Matarazzo face-off shows no sign of ebbing, with the administration filing a legal challenge to the new arbitration law and shrugging off the endorsement question.
"What he's doing is putting a price tag on his endorsement, and that's a big mistake," said the First Deputy Mayor, Peter J. Powers. "Anybody who takes that endorsement now is very tainted. It's a poison pill that's going to blow up in their stomach."
But some say the Mayor won't have such an easy time of it. "If you want to take on the P.B.A., you are really going to go to the mat," Mr. Mo said. "Giuliani is one of the few guys who wants to take them head on, but he's in for an eye-opener."

HEADLINE: Senate Approves Compromise Bill Tightening Curbs on Cuba

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
The Senate moved today to punish the Cuban Government for its downing of two American private aircraft last month, passing legislation that would tighten the embargo on American trade with Cuba and punish other countries that insisted on continuing trade on their own.
The vote, on the final compromise version of legislation first approved by the House and Senate last fall, was 74 to 22. The compromise now goes to the House, which is expected to approve it later this week. 
 Canada, Russia and the European Union all condemned the proposal, and its foes in the Senate, all but three of them Democrats, denounced it as overwrought and almost certainly ineffective.
But President Clinton has already promised to sign the bill. Many Democrats and moderate Republicans like Senator Nancy Kassebaum of Kansas, said Cuba and its leader, Fidel Castro, had nobody to blame for the measure but themselves.
The chief sponsor of the measure in the Senate, Jesse Helms of North Carolina, took the floor "in a friendly sort of way" to admonish Canadians for their objections to the bill. "Let me remind them that Castro has had a murderous regime from the very beginning," he said. "I suggest that they be ashamed of themselves."
What angered the Canadians, Russians and others were provisions that seek to force other nations to toe the American policy of isolating Cuba economically.
The compromise bill would codify current executive orders that impose an economic embargo on Cuba, meaning the embargo could not be eased without Congress's approval. It would deny entry to the United States to foreigners who traffic in any confiscated American property. And it would give Americans a new legal right to sue foreign companies that make use of confiscated American property in Cuba.
A Republican aide on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee who demanded anonymity said the clause, which covers about 200 confiscated American assets, aims more to discourage future foreign investment in Cuba than to spur lawsuits over old investments.
The legislation also seeks to break ties between Cuba and the former Soviet Union by linking American financial aid to the abandonment of trade and military relations with the Castro Government. The Russian Foreign Ministry was quoted as calling the measure "contrary to international law," saying Russia would expand its trade and economic relations with Cuba "strictly on the basis of equality and mutual benefit."
Meeting in Grenada, Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada and 14 leaders of Caribbean nations urged President Clinton to reconsider his support. After meeting with the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, Canada's Trade Minister, Art Eggleston, called the bill a "dangerous precedent."
The measure was first passed by Congress last fall and seemed bound nowhere, hamstrung by a White House veto threat, until Feb. 24. On that day Cuban Air Force jets downed two planes off the Cuban coast, killing four members of an anti-Castro group. Four days later a House-Senate conference produced a compromise bill and the Clinton Administration dropped its objections after legislators modified language dealing with confiscated property.
The Senate majority leader and current favorite to oppose Mr. Clinton in the fall, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, praised the President today for supporting the bill. "There can be no doubt that the signal from the U.S. is stronger when the Democratic White House and Republican Congress speak with the same voice," he said in remarks on the Senate floor.
