HEADLINE: Denver Airport Nestles Into Its Lair

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: DENVER, March 5

 BODY:
Depriving cartoonists and television talk show hosts of a staple food, Denver International Airport has emerged in its first year as the nation's most efficient cold-weather airport.
Before its opening a year ago, Denver's $5 billion airport offered a steady source of national amusement with its on-again, off-again openings, its cost overruns and a baggage-handling system that chewed up suitcases with more abandon than a teen-ager with a mouthful of bubble gum. 
 But after a year of operation, Denver's airport ranks only after those in Honolulu and Las Vegas, Nev., for the fewest flight delays, according to a Federal Aviation Administration study of the nation's 20 busiest airports. And in sharp contrast to those balmy climes, Denver's airport last year had Arctic temperatures, 75 mile-an-hour winds and four feet of snow.
In addition, confounding predictions that the airport would go bankrupt in a year, airport officials calculate that they made an $8 million operating profit in the first year.
Slowly, revisionist attitudes are creeping into comments about the soaring tentlike glass structure that is still lampooned as the Taj Mahal of the high plains. As the first major airport built in the United States since the 1970's and the ninth-busiest one in the world, Denver International has seen its every shortcoming held under a magnifying glass.
"Any new airport takes a hit at the outset," said Jon F. Ash, managing director of Global Aviation Associates, a consulting company in Washington. "Ten years from now, everybody will using it. People will forget that it had a difficult birthing."
This month's spring break will present new tests to Denver International. With Easter often being Colorado's heaviest ski season, the equivalent of about 1 percent of the nation's population is expected to travel through.
Veteran East Coast skiers may wax nostalgic about the intimate feel of a youth hostel at Stapleton International, the old airport, when they were socked in on a Sunday evening too snowy for planes to take off. But skiers snoozing on couches are a rare sight at the new airport because with five runways to allow three simultaneous take-offs, the airport has cut delays, eliminating four of five previously experienced at Stapleton. Now, an average of 3 flights in 1,000 fail to take off within 15 minutes of leaving its gate, according to the Federal Aviation Administration.
By contrast, Newark International Airport posts more than 10 times as many delays, with 35 per 1,000.
Contributing to the airport's overall efficiency, last year United Airlines, the dominant operator here, diverted only 26 of 100,000 planes it sent to Denver. And with fewer planes having to wait to land, United's flights to and from Denver are shorter now, by an average of seven minutes, allowing an annual savings of $13 million in crew time and jet fuel.
Local newspapers still pounce when the baggage system eats a bag in a particularly spectacular way. For example, two weeks ago, the automatic system mangled a $7,500 computer, a company's demonstration machine that had logged 150,000 air miles and was protected in a special case made of the same plastic used for football helmets. But statistics show that baggage loss and damage in Denver is well below the national average.
In December, a prime ski month, United handled 1.2 million bags here. The airline registered only 367 complaints. This ratio, 1 complaint for every 3,270 bags, is far better than the industry standard of 1 for 2,000.
"In Geneva, they just throw the skis out in a pile," David Brown, a 37-year-old skier from Edinburgh, said on Thursday as he watched an automated system pump skis out of the airport's bowels, each pair in its own standup bin. "This spoils you."
The new airport's profits have come, in part, from concession sales doubling the forecasts. The terminal and concourses have 100 stores, and some visitors say flying into Denver is like flying into a mall.
More money has also come from a surge in parking revenues. Denverites, it turns out, are not inclined to drive friends and family out to the airport, which is in wheat fields 25 miles northeast of downtown. So instead, travelers are driving themselves and parking.
But the new airport's first year shakedown flight has had its share of air bumps.
The number of people flying in and out of Denver dropped last year by 6 percent, to 31 million. This two million drop is largely attributed to a five million drop in passengers registered here by Continental Airlines, which abandoned its Denver hub in late 1994. The other big airlines registered increases in Denver traffic -- United up 8 percent; Delta, 9 percent; American, 10 percent; Northwest, 14 percent, and TWA, 17 percent.
But to the relief of travelers, United's high fares spawned discount airlines. In a fare war last month, it was cheaper to fly to Salt Lake City -- $19 than to take a taxi from downtown Denver to the airport -- $35, plus tip.
Because of United's dominance, Denver International has not become a truly international airport. United prefers to send its international passengers from here to coastal hubs, and foreign airlines are reluctant to fly here if United will not feed them passengers. So overseas flights are scheduled only to Mexico and Canada.
But after United States authorities initialed an "open skies" agreement with Germany last month, Denver city officials decided to lobby Lufthansa for a direct flight from here to Frankfurt.
Noise complaints have also soared, despite the fact that the isolated airport occupies 54 square miles, an area twice the size of Manhattan. Last week, a citizens group, Colorado Coalition Against Aircraft Noise, resorted to what is a serious scare tactic here: hiring "a New York lawyer."
Throughout the year, the new airport has produced enough picturesque incidents to keep local radio talk show hosts alive.
In mid-January, Bea Romer, wife of Colorado's Governor, Roy Romer, had her wallet picked from her purse while riding a train from a concourse to the terminal. Later that month, Denver's 1996 telephone books were issued without any listing for the airport, the regions's largest public works project in memory. There was a "Denver International Airport" listing but it was for a model plane airport.
Tired of cab drivers grousing about a dearth of fares, city officials first tried sending them to "charm school" -- classes that featured a video on the new airport's wonders. When that did not work, one official proposed planting city spies to monitor cab drivers' enthusiasm levels.
"Snitches to rat on cabbies dissing D.I.A.," screamed the city's tabloid, The Rocky Mountain News. Denver's Mayor, Wellington Webb, quickly killed the proposal, calling it "a stupid idea."
While Denverites love to grumble about their new airport, visitors are often more boosterish than locals.
"I love it: The big risk of D.I.A. is that you miss your connection because you get embroiled in one of the bookstores," said George Gilder, the technology writer, on Thursday night after arriving here with two of his daughters for a cross-country ski vacation. "Colorado has a high-tech economy. The airport is an investment in the future."
On Friday, Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, gushed to a skeptical audience at the Denver Press Club: "I think you've got a great airport. From where it's located, you get a great feeling of what it must have been like to be a pioneer crossing the plains."

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1568 words

HEADLINE: Business Advice From the Sidelines;
It's Management By Game Theory

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
Can an N.B.A. coach offer an M.B.A. anything besides entertainment?
Phil Jackson and Pat Riley think so. Mr. Jackson, coach of the Chicago Bulls, the leading team in the National Basketball Association, turned his hardwood lessons into a new book, "Sacred Hoops." His debut on the management bookshelves follows the motivational success of Mr. Riley, author of "The Winner Within" and the former coach of the Los Angeles Lakers and New York Knicks who now leads the Miami Heat. 
 The business-as-sport metaphor seems to have reached another cyclical peak. Mr. Riley and Mr. Jackson are best sellers among coaches-turned-management-gurus, a group that grows every year. Publishers churn out new titles like "Everyone's a Coach," by Don Shula, (who actually isn't, having resigned his post with the National Football League Miami Dolphins), and "Game Plans for Success: Winning Strategies for Business and Life from 10 Top N.F.L. Head Coaches."
"The profusion of books comparing macho-coaching to maestro-management has become a heavy industry," said Warren Bennis, a professor of business administration at the University of Southern California who has written many books on leadership.
Publishing and management experts say the appeal of these successors to popular motivational icons like the late Vince Lombardi and George Allen is that they talk the language of leadership, one of the prevailing buzzwords of an increasingly fast-moving economy in which business executives are often required to reinvent systems rather than run existing ones and to push more responsibility onto their employees rather than control them.
"Managers spend much more time thinking about coaching and building teams," said Noel Tichy, a business professor at the University of Michigan who has written on the subject. "The new game of business is one that requires engaging each individual in personal, intellectual and emotional excellence, while paradoxically being a superb team player."
These are more abstract concepts than follow-the-rules management, so many business people are turning to less traditional books for advice, from "Jesus C.E.O.: Using Ancient Wisdom for Visionary Leadership," to "Make It So: Leadership Lessons from Star Trek, the Next Generation."
But coaches appear to have an edge over Capt. Jean-Luc Picard of the Starship Enterprise. They are familiar leadership figures to anyone who has ever played organized sports. The language of business is infused with sports terms. And the seats at sports events are often filled with upper-income managers who enjoy second-guessing a Phil Jackson or a Pat Riley.
But is it all hooey? In an attempt to assess whether coaches can really offer business people useful advice, Mr. Bennis, Mr. Tichy and Charles Farkas, co-author of a new book on leadership and a director at Bain & Company, a management consulting firm, were asked to critique the books by Mr. Jackson and Mr. Riley.
The three experts said that "Sacred Hoops" (Hyperion Press) and "The Winner Within" (G. P. Putnam's Sons, hard cover; Berkley Books, paperback) cover familiar themes -- the importance of goals, teamwork, pride and learning from mistakes, as well as the art of knowing when and how to motivate workers or criticize and discipline them.
But they added that the two coaches -- who said through spokesmen that they were too busy to be interviewed for this article -- did find new and compelling ways to flesh out these old truths. "People learn best through stories," Mr. Farkas said. "We capture those images in our mind, replay them and remember the lesson to be learned. Both Riley and Jackson paint very interesting and memorable portraits of leadership."
To be sure, others believe the basketball-as-business metaphor is entirely inappropriate.
Rick Wolff, a senior editor at Warner Books, a former sports psychologist for the Cleveland Indians and author of 15 books on both sports and business, noted that it is easy to get rid of an unproductive player by cutting or trading him. But in business, dismissing an employee often requires extensive documentation and carries the threat of a wrongful-termination suit. Playing ball, he added, is just that: playing. Athletes are easier to motivate than employees grinding through jobs with no off-season.
"In the long run, sports and coaching is about fun, entertainment and excitement," Mr. Wolff said, "In contrast, work is about, well, work."
A less debatable observation, however, is that the two coaches have very different styles of leadership.
Mr. Farkas described Mr. Jackson as a "human assets" manager, the type of executive who focuses on managing people and the relationships between them, in part by fostering certain attitudes and values in an organization. This is the style, Mr. Farkas said, of Herb Kelleher of Southwest Airlines and Wayne Calloway at Pepsico.
Mr. Jackson, for example, writes that creating a successful basketball team or sales force is "essentially a spiritual act."
"Most leaders tend to view teamwork as a social engineering problem: take X group, add Y motivational technique and get Z result. But working with the Bulls, I've learned that the most effective way to forge a winning team is to call on the players' need to connect with something larger than themselves."
Mr. Jackson regularly offers his players books to read, tailoring his choices to broaden each player's horizons. He takes his team on field trips. He encourages his players to study meditation. He prefers a light management touch, sometimes interspersing game films with clips from movies like "The Wizard of Oz" (in one meeting, a game tape showed Horace Grant falling for a fake, followed by the Scarecrow wishing he had a brain). Early in his Bulls coaching career, he convinced his superstar, Michael Jordan, that to win championships, he must help raise his teammates' performance.
Mr. Jackson writes that he strives to be "an invisible leader" by giving players increasing responsibility to shape their roles on the team.
Mr. Riley, by contrast, employs the "box approach" to leadership, Mr. Farkas said. In this widely used style of leadership, a chief executive establishes rules, structures, values and performance measures and clearly defines what is expected of every employee.
For example, Mr. Riley developed a statistical approach -- similar to the benchmarking practices used at many businesses -- for measuring his players' performance against that of their peers. Mr. Riley also offers readers plenty of rules for living and winning: "Shoulda, coulda, and woulda won't get it done"; "Giving yourself permission to lose guarantees a loss."
The reviewers said Mr. Jackson's ruminations were more original than Mr. Riley's motivational exhortations but that Mr. Riley's book would be somewhat more practical for most readers. So far, Mr. Riley's book has been the better seller. In its first several months in bookstores, sales of "The Winner Within," which was published in hard cover in 1993, outpaced the early sales of "Sacred Hoops," published last year, 2 to 1, according to the Ingram Book Company, a book wholesaler.
In many ways, the two coaches' outlooks are distilled in their views on winning.
To motivate his Los Angeles Lakers team before facing the Boston Celtics in the second game of the 1985 championship finals, Mr. Riley told his players a personal story of the last words his father said to him years earlier after he was cut from the San Diego Rockets and invited to the Portland Trailblazers' training camp. Paraphrasing that advice, Mr. Riley wrote: "Every now and then there comes a day where someplace, sometime, you simply have to plant your feet, stand firm and make a point about who you are and what you believe in."
For Mr. Jackson, there is more to basketball than basketball, and there is more to life than winning. He disagrees with Lombardi, the legendary Green Bay Packers coach, who once said, "There is no room for second place. There's only one place, and that's first place."
"How can anyone," Mr. Jackson writes, "from sports figures to entrepreneurs, possibly maintain their self-esteem when this attitude dominates our cultural mindset?"
Clearly, each coach knows how to win, but how would they fare running a corporation?
Not so well, according to Mr. Tichy, Mr. Bennis and Mr. Farkas, who said that for all their leadership skills, Mr. Jackson and Mr. Riley would lack the "business literacy" to run a large corporation.
Mr. Tichy said leaders must increasingly spend time teaching their views on leadership and how to grow and change a business to nurture future leaders among their employees.
Mr. Bennis said that top executives these days must be experts in corporate finance to excel. "All the successful C.E.O.'s I know know their numbers," he said, "and, more important, they understand how those numbers are derived and what they mean in the specific contexts in which they work."
But Mr. Farkas, who is based in Bain's Boston office, said that if he had to choose either coach to be a chief executive, he believes Mr. Riley would be the better leader for a company in need of a rapid turnaround, while Mr. Jackson belongs in an organization that has already mastered the basics.
"Personally, I would rather play for Phil Jackson," Mr. Farkas added. "But my home-team Celtics could use a dose of Pat Riley."

NEW YORK
 
A Race for Votes in New York
 
The three major Republican Presidential candidates raced their campaigns across New York. Senator Bob Dole began the campaign day on a traditional note, paying tribute to New York's politicians and culture. It fell to Patrick J. Buchanan to end the day on a more strident note, attacking Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. Steve Forbes moved his campaign to the highways. [Page A1.]
 
Mr. Buchanan raised the possibility that he would not endorse Bob Dole for President if Mr. Dole wins the nomination. [B6.]
 
Senator Dole beamed in the bosom of one of the most formidable political machines, the Nassau County Republican organization. [B8.]
 
Street Smarts and Pin Stripes
 
In the year since he took the helm of New York City's police union, Lou Matarazzo has wielded a blend of political polish and street smarts to push through his union's biggest legislative victory in 20 years. He helped persuade the Legislature to override Governor Pataki's veto of a bill that would strengthen the city's police officers in contract disputes. The victory escalated tensions with Mayor Giuliani in what Mr. Matarazzo now calls a war. [B1.]
 
Loss of a Jewish Symbol
 
The murder of Abe Lebewohl not only ended the life of a much-beloved figure in the life of the Lower East Side, but was also a symbol of the diminished Jewish presence in a neighborhood that served as a Plymouth Rock for newcomers from Eastern Europe. [B1.]
 
More than 200 people gathered at a synagogue on East Sixth Street to mourn for Mr. Lebewohl. [B4.]
 
Judge to Reconsider Drug Rule
 
A Federal judge who was widely criticized for throwing out drug evidence agreed to listen to prosecutors' arguments that he should change his mind, saying that a rehearing is "in the interests of justice." [B1.]
 
Rebuilding After the Floods
 
Six weeks since Walton, N.Y., sustained some of the worst hits in the worst flooding along the Eastern seaboard in 60 years, many merchants along Delaware Street are back in business. Our Towns by Evelyn Nieves. [B1.]
 
Witness Tells of Gotti Plot
 
The courtroom saga over the sanity of the suspected mob boss Vincent Gigante took another bizarre turn. This time the focus was on John Gotti, inset, who was called so desperate to get out of prison that he considered bribing the President of the United States. [B4.]
 
Alarm Over Health Policy
 
Governor Pataki's proposed mental health budget marks a dramatic shift in direction from recent policy. The Governor would take the state out of the administration of community mental health services, turning the planning and management of such services over to counties through a system of block grants. The plan has been called "devastating" by mental-health advocates and others. [B5.]
 
City Sued Over Job Offer
 
A man is suing the city, saying it withdrew its offer of a job as a Housing Authority tenant organizer because he wrote an opinion article for New York Newsday that was harshly critical of Mayor Giuliani's cuts in social-service budget. [B5.]
 
Drug Defense Is Discounted
 
In a closing statement, prosecutors disputed that a dangerous combination of drugs that drove Edward J. Leary to place firebombs in the New York City subway system, as his defense lawyers have suggested. [B2.]

The New York State Insurance Department approved a request by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield to establish two wholly owned for-profit units that could eventually take over most of the troubled insurer's business. Business Day. [D2.]

Indictment Over Arms Sales
 
A small New Jersey company that manufactures electronic parts for the military and two of its top executives were charged in a 13-count Federal indictment with illegally sending plans for equipment for weapons and communications systems to companies in Russia and the Ukraine. [B5.]
 
Escaped Patient Turns Up
 
A patient with a violent history who escaped from a New Jersey state psychiatric hospital two months ago was found at Bellevue Hospital Center, officials said. [B5.]

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Dispute Over U.S. Exports Of Poultry to Russia Settled

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
A trade dispute between the United States and Russia was apparently settled today when Washington received formal assurances that American poultry shipments to Russia would continue without interruption.
Vice President Al Gore announced this evening that he had been assured by Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia that a stoppage of poultry imports from the United States, threatened March 16, would not take place. 
 The Vice President's statement said the Prime Minister's message was relayed through the Russian Minister of Economics, Yevgeny Yasin, in a meeting at the White House today.
"We're certainly very pleased with the announcement," said George Watts, president of the National Broilers Council. "This is what we had asked for and hoped for all along."
Russia is the No. 1 export market for United States chicken parts, and bought around $550 million worth last year. Some estimates are that American-grown chicken now accounts for more than half the poultry eaten in Russia.
Last month, Russia unexpectedly acted to halt all imports of American chicken beginning March 16 due to concerns about American poultry industry standards and the quality of the chicken. That prompted swift action by the Clinton Administration to avert any trade stoppage. Administration officials said such a move would be unacceptable, especially for a country that wants to join the international trading community and the World Trade Organization.
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said last week that he was deeply concerned by any barriers to American goods going into Russia. "We'd consider it to be unfortunate and we would react in a very strong manner," he said.
Several American poultry producers have announced cutbacks in production because of the threatened slowdown of sales to Russia, as well as because of higher costs as a result of high grain prices. They include the nation's biggest poultry company and the top supplier to Russia, Tyson Foods Inc., and Pilgrim's Pride, the fifth-largest chicken producer in the United States.
American officials have said Russia's concerns are nonsense and part of a protectionist attempt to restrict imports. Some said the action was a bid by President Boris N. Yeltsin to gain the favor of the pro-Communist and pro-agriculture factions.
United States and Russian mid-level officials and scientists have been meeting since last month in technical talks to resolve some concerns, and Mr. Gore said the Administration would continue to work with Russian officials to resolve remaining poultry issues.
Mr. Gore also said he had accepted an invitation from Mr. Chernomyrdin to send senior United States officials to Moscow for discussions of outstanding issues related to the poultry exports.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Rises 42.27 Points To Year's 17th Record
A renewed optimism in the stock market propelled the Dow Jones industrial average to its 17th record of the year. Surging in the last half-hour of trading, the Dow jumped 42.27 points, to 5,642.42, bringing its three-day gain to 156.80 points, or 2.8 percent.
Gains in I.B.M. and Philip Morris fueled the advance, and other major market indicators joined in it. [Page D10.]
 
Senators Cite 'Corporate Welfare'
A bipartisan group of Senators pushed for an independent commission to help slash subsidies and tax breaks for business. Senators as ideologically diverse as John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, called for sweeping cuts in "corporate welfare." Fierce resistance is expected. [A1.]
 
Auto Sales Up 5.6% in Month
Auto sales rose 5.6 percent last month, assuaging industry and Wall Street fears that the industry was heading for a stiff downturn. Ford reported nearly flat February sales, and in a striking development, Honda surpassed Toyota in car sales in the month. [D4.]
 
The U.A.W. went on strike at two General Motors plants in Ohio, an action that could force the closing of other plants. [A19.]
 
Factory Orders Beat Expectations
Factory orders jumped unexpectedly in January, and backlogs surged, offering evidence that manufacturing might be picking up after months of weakness. The orders rose five-tenths of 1 percent. [D4.]
 
Prices of Treasury bonds slumped, as hopes for a quick cut in interest rates were weakened by the report on factory orders and by comments from Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.38 percent from 6.33 percent. [D9.]
 
Business Week Wins Suit
An appeals court threw out a ruling blocking Business Week from publishing sealed court documents from a suit between Procter & Gamble and Bankers Trust. In language that at times bordered on the incredulous, the three-judge panel ruled 2 to 1 that a circuit judge erred in barring publication of an article based on the documents. [A15.]
 
Empire Blues in Profit Plan
The New York State Insurance Department approved a request by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield to establish two wholly owned for-profit units that could eventually take over most of the troubled health insurer's business. But financial experts saw little chance that Empire could attract investors until it reversed its operating losses. [D2.]
 
Russia Settles Chicken Dispute
A growing trade dispute with Russia was apparently settled when Washington received formal assurances that American poultry shipments would continue to go to Russia without interruption. Russia is the No. 1 export market for U.S. chicken parts. [D5.]
 
S.E.C. Eliminating Many Rules
The S.E.C. took the first steps toward eliminating hundreds of rules and required forms in an attempt to simplify corporate offering procedures and make it easier for small companies to raise capital. It accepted a 94-page report of an internal study group, which also urged that corporate prospectuses be written so that they could be easily understood. [D2.]
 
Tax Offer on Contract Workers
The Internal Revenue Service plans to offer discounts on the payroll taxes owed by employers who improperly paid employees as independent contractors. [D4.]
 
An AIDS Blindness Drug
Chiron won approval by the Food and Drug Administration to market a device that can be implanted in the eyes of AIDS patients to fight blindness. [D10.]
 
Japan's Banks Offer Help
Japanese banks agreed to shoulder a bit more of the burden in the very unpopular Government rescue of mortgage companies. But the banks' plan is so vague that it is not clear whether the banks will actually have to put up any more money. [D5.]

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;
DOLE, SWEEPING 8 PRIMARIES, CALLS FOR PARTY TO UNITE; ALEXANDER READY TO QUIT

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole won a clean sweep of eight primaries spanning New England, the Rockies and as far South as Georgia yesterday, leaping far ahead of his rivals in the biggest test thus far of the Republican Presidential primary season.
In a string of triumphs in politically and geographically diverse states that he said demonstrated his ability to unite the Republican party, Mr. Dole handily won in Georgia, Massachusetts, Colorado, Connecticut, Maryland, Vermont, Maine and Rhode Island. 
 The results apparently claimed two casualties, Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana and former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee. Aides to both said they would announce their withdrawals from the race on Wednesday.
Two of Mr. Dole's rivals who have never held elective office -- Mr. Buchanan and Steve Forbes -- vowed to press on even though they competed for a distant second or third place in most of the contests yesterday.
At a boisterous victory rally last night on Capitol Hill, Mr. Dole set his sights on President Clinton rather than dwell on the intramural competition. After buoyantly reciting state after state where he had won, Mr. Dole declared: "Tonight we're proving the pundits wrong -- and pretty soon we're going to unite and beat Bill Clinton in 1996."
Calling on the party to rally around him only weeks after his lead seemed to be jeopardized by chaotic early primaries, the Kansas Senator added: "All my life in politics, I've been trying to bring America together. And I'll do the same as the Republican nominee. And I'll do the same as the President of the United States."
Mr. Dole claimed a majority of the 208 national convention delegates that were selected yesterday; 996 are needed for the nomination.
In light of the daunting numbers, Mr. Alexander met with his closest advisers tonight to consider his future course. He cancelled campaign events scheduled in Florida today and aides said he planned to travel home to Nashville and pull out of the race. This was not a complete surprise because on Monday he had vowed to withdraw if he did not defeat Mr. Dole in Florida on March 12, when that state and Texas are up for grabs. In yesterday's voting, Mr. Alexander was a distant third or fourth.
Mr. Lugar, who had barely managed to register in the voting results from earlier contests, also planned to announce that he would drop out, campaign aides said.
"I have no Don Quixote idea here of competing endlessly with no prospects," Mr. Lugar told reporters in Vermont earlier in the day.
Mr. Buchanan vowed that he would fight all the way to the convention in San Diego, but he acknowledged while campaigning yesterday in New York State: "We hope to do well up here in New York. We know it's an uphill battle here. It's an uphill battle everywhere."
Mr. Forbes's fortunes have alternately plummeted and soared, as he lost the first votes and then won a few smaller contests. In theory at least, he can run as long as he wants, if he is willing to keep spending from his personal fortune.
Mr. Forbes made clear last night that he had no plan to drop out. Referring to Harry Truman's saying if you can't stand the heat get out of the kitchen, he said: "This chef has no intention of leaving the kitchen."
According to surveys of voters leaving the polling places yesterday, economic issues were foremost on voters' minds. Either the economy and jobs or the deficit were more frequently selected as the most important issue. Mr. Dole drew most of those votes, as well as among voters for whom taxes was the overriding concern. For example, a fifth of the voters in Massachusetts selected taxes of the most important issue, and a third of them voted for Mr. Dole, compared to 4 in 10 for Mr. Forbes.
Mr. Dole scored his success last night by drawing from a broad-based Republican coalition.
He also made inroads into Mr. Buchanan's natural constituency. Surveys of voters leaving their polling places yesterday conducted by the television networks and The Associated Press found that Mr. Dole did well among self-described religious conservatives and among voters who said the nation's most serious problems were moral rather than economic.
In addition to breaking ground in Mr. Buchanan's core base of support, Mr. Dole continued to do well among mainstream Republicans, including those who say they are concerned about the deficit and those who are looking for a candidate who can defeat Mr. Clinton in November.
Mr. Buchanan, by contrast, was not able to build on a narrow base of support among the most conservative voters. Most of his supporters described themselves as very conservative and said they supported a Constitutional amendment prohibiting abortion. And Mr. Buchanan failed to make inroads with other groups, like self-described moderates.
Explaining Mr. Dole's performance after his jolting losses in the New Hampshire, Delaware and Arizona primaries, Scott Reed, his campaign manager, dismissed polls that showed the Senator had not inspired the Republican electorate. Instead, he pinned the blame on Mr. Forbes, the publishing magnate, and his television advertising.
"I'll tell you exactly what happened," Mr. Reed said in an interview last night. "We moved out of the states where Steve Forbes had spent $25 million running negative ads tearing Bob Dole down. He almost got us."
While the candidates competed in a mix of primaries spanning the South, New England and the West, the heaviest competition was in Georgia, with the day's biggest trove with 42 delegates. Mr. Dole's advisers said they were most concerned about that state, which had led the Senator to add to his schedule an election-eve visit to Atlanta on Monday.
Also yesterday, Republicans in Minnesota and Washington began selecting more delegates in party caucuses.
The voting in Georgia was a particularly harsh setback for Mr. Alexander, who has staked his campaign on performing well in his native region. Even before the polls opened yesterday, he said he would withdraw if he did not beat Mr. Dole in Florida next Tuesday.
As Mr. Alexander and Mr. Buchanan concentrated in the South, Mr. Forbes chased hopes of an upset in Colorado, while Mr. Lugar pinned his chances with the tiny state of Vermont, where he had campaigned for days.
From the day that Mr. Dole announced his candidacy last April, he was widely viewed as the candidate to beat for the Republican nomination. In addition to raising millions of dollars early, he amassing the most extensive ground organization and roster of endorsements, including those of most Republican governors. And for months, he held a commanding lead in the polls.
But Mr. Dole received a scare in the Iowa caucuses, when Mr. Buchanan placed a close second. And his campaign was knocked completely off balance a week later when Mr. Buchanan defeated him in the New Hampshire primary. Mr. Dole stumbled further when Mr. Forbes beat him in Delaware and Arizona.
But Mr. Dole regained his footing when he decisively won the South Carolina primary on Saturday.
In yesterday's voting, Mr. Dole did particularly well in Massachusetts among women, half of whom voted for him, while one in five backed Mr. Buchanan. Men split their votes, giving Mr. Dole and Mr. Buchanan about a third each.
Asked whether the country's main problems were mostly economic or moral, most voters in Massachusetts, as in other states, said they were moral. That generated no momentum for a particular candidate, with Mr. Dole and Mr. Buchanan splitting the voters of this group.
Unlike in Georgia and Maryland, the exit polls showed that Mr. Buchanan won the votes of conservatives of all stripes, both those who call themselves somewhat conservative and those who call themselves very conservative.
About one sixth of the voters identified themselves as religious conservatives, and three-quarters of them backed Mr. Buchanan.
Most voters in the states that held primaries yesterday said they were opposed to a Constitutional amendment banning abortion, and most of them backed Mr. Dole.
But Mr. Dole was already looking to November, as if the primary season were already over. Asked by reporters yesterday about how strong he would be against Mr. Clinton, the 72-year-old Senator replied: "He's a little taller than I am, but I've got lower blood pressure and lower cholesterol -- and I'm not going to make health an issue in the campaign."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Daily Briefing;
Gambling Study Is Approved

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The United States House of Representatives approved a bill yesterday to create a Federal commission to study gambling, the first step in what some Atlantic City casino executives see as a crusade to impose stricter regulations and higher taxes on casinos. 
 Under the bill, the panel would conduct a two-year investigation into gambling and its effect on state budgets, economically depressed areas and political corruption.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE OUTLOOK;
Finding the Formula

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, March 5

 BODY:
Through two campaigns and the start of a third, Bob Dole was the man who could hardly win a Presidential primary. Now, presto change-o, he has turned into the man who can hardly lose one.
His clean sweep of the most closely watched of today's contests -- in New England, the Rockies, a Border State and the Deep South -- demonstrated broad geographic appeal. Exit polls indicated broad demographic and ideological appeal. The results made him the strong, if not overwhelming, favorite to win the Republican nomination unless he stumbles in the New York primary on Thursday, which now seems much less likely. 
 Harold Wilson, the British Prime Minister, once observed that a week is a long time in politics. Bob Dole knows better. In the turbocharged world in which he is competing, a couple of days can be a lifetime. Less than a week ago, the oddsmakers were writing the Kansas Senator off after a series of lackluster performances; now, at least for the moment, he looks almost as inevitable as the sunrise.
Asked by reporters this afternoon whom he considered his chief opponent, the suddenly sanguine Mr. Dole replied, "Bill Clinton."
Mr. Dole's triumph in South Carolina on Saturday marked the turning point, but he ran much less powerfully in winning Georgia today. Here he had neither strong organizational support (the Democrats control the Statehouse) nor a powerful intermediary with the religious right like Gov. David Beasley of South Carolina, who filled that role there.
In the simplest terms, Mr. Dole is succeeding by taking some of Patrick J. Buchanan's natural supporters away from him, because they think he has a better chance of defeating President Clinton, because they find Mr. Buchanan too extreme, because Mr. Dole has finally started to play to his strengths, or for some other reason. The defections are substantial.
The religious right had been considered Mr. Buchanan's strongest constituency, for example, and so it proved early on, but not in South Carolina. In Georgia, Mr. Buchanan recovered a bit among such voters, but Mr. Dole did respectably, according to a survey of those leaving the polls by the television networks and The Associated Press. And in Maryland, a Border State often receptive to protest candidates like George C. Wallace in 1972, Mr. Dole outpolled his rival 5 to 3 among Christian conservatives.
In most states voting today, more than half of the voters interviewed said they considered Mr. Buchanan too extreme, which is an electoral burden that no candidate could carry.
Mr. Dole did especially well in most states among women, older voters and those concerned about the deficit and beating President Clinton in November. But he did well enough among almost all kinds of people, except implacable opponents of abortion and voters younger than 30.
Again, about one-third of the voters surveyed said they thought that the Senator's age, 72, would hurt him as President -- an issue that could cost him in the fall if he is nominated.
Among voters who think the country's problems are moral rather than economic in character -- two-thirds of the electorate in Georgia -- Mr. Dole, the pragmatic legislative craftsman, did better than Mr. Buchanan, the moralist and sermonizer.
If any of Mr. Dole's rivals are to mount last-ditch efforts to stop him, they will have to hustle. He already has twice as many delegates as all his rivals combined.
By a week from today, 43 percent of the delegates will have been chosen, and by two weeks from today, 54 percent will have been chosen. Then California votes on March 26, and all 165 of its delegates go to the statewide winner.
There was not much in today's returns that implied that Southern and Southwestern states voting next Tuesday would vote much differently from South Carolina and Georgia. Texas, Florida, Mississippi, Oklahoma, perhaps even Lamar Alexander's Tennessee seem likely to follow the pattern.
Once again, in Georgia, Mr. Buchanan failed to move much beyond his constituency of very conservative voters, though he exceeded 30 percent of the vote for the first time in what must have seemed an achingly close-run thing to him.
Mr. Alexander, the only Southerner in the field, had hoped to make a strong stand here. He spent $230,000 on Atlanta television alone, far more than any other candidate, according to a tabulation by The Atlanta Constitution, and still got less than one-sixth of the vote. He had already said he would withdraw if he lost in Florida, where advertising is far more costly, and today's voting might bring an even quicker exit.
If Mr. Dole is to be the nominee, as seems much more likely now, his successes in the South have long-term implications.
This is the Republican heartland, a region where the party must score in November if it is to win the Presidency. The Kansan, laconic where many Southerners are loquacious, tightly wound where they tend to be laid back, has never been very comfortable here, and his success in the primaries will help to make him a better political fit.
Another of those who has siphoned off votes from Mr. Dole, Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, had his best showing of the campaign in Vermont, where he fought it out with Mr. Buchanan and Steve Forbes, the magazine publisher, for second place. But even there Mr. Dole was an easy winner, and Mr. Lugar decided to fold his campaign, aides said.
Soon, it seems, Mr. Forbes and Mr. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, will be Mr. Dole's only major rivals. Beaten today by more than 2 to 1 in Connecticut, a state where he had some hopes, Mr. Forbes is now concentrating on New York to revive a campaign that was riding high after his Arizona victory a week ago.
As for Mr. Buchanan, he has budgeted only one day for Florida, preferring to husband his resources for a big push in Texas, which will have 123 delegates at the convention in San Diego in August, the second-largest bloc. But even before today's voting, he was calling attention to Texas's proportional representation system, apparently counting more on winning delegates for bargaining purposes later than on taking the state.
Neither Mr. Forbes nor Mr. Buchanan has much incentive for pulling out, even if the men conclude in their heart of hearts that they have no significant chance to win the nomination. They are the two most ideological candidates in the race. Each has a program he would like to see imbedded in the party platform, and each feels he is bringing new voters into the party.

HEADLINE: BOMBING IN ISRAEL: THE WHITE HOUSE;
U.S. Is Sending Technology To Help Intercept Bombers

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
President Clinton sent Israel sophisticated bomb-detection equipment today, a shipment that senior Administration officials said had been held up for several months in a dispute over who would pay for it.
In sending the equipment, the President vowed to help Israel combat what he called a "campaign of terror" that "must not succeed." 
 The nine specialized bomb sensors, together with American technical experts to help operate them, will be used in an effort to intercept terrorists at border crossings. At the same time, the White House said it would encourage its European allies and other Governments to maintain financial aid to the Palestinian Authority to compensate for economic losses to Palestinians prevented from working when Israel closed its borders to deter further attacks.
"The United States has always stood with the people of Israel through good times and bad, and we stand with them today," Mr. Clinton said in a speech to county officials from around the nation meeting here. He said the recent bombings in Israel were "desperate and fanatic acts" aimed not just at killing innocent people, "but at killing the growing prospects for peace in the Middle East."
Mr. Clinton also ordered American technical support, training and equipment to help improve and coordinate anti-terrorism efforts in the region. The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said Mr. Clinton would take additional steps soon.
"We'll be assembling some more assistance in the coming days," he said.
The two Governments have been discussing the advanced sensors as part of a package of anti-terrorist equipment worth about $40 million "for several months," a senior Administration official said. He denied that the equipment was held up out of concern over the transfer of technology, saying, "It was a question of how to pay for it."
But under the pressure of the bombing attacks, he said, the United States was providing the sensors out of anti-terrorism funds.
One White House official said that materials transferred today were worth about $3 million and that additional gear expected to be sent this week could bring the total to $15 million.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher, in a telephone interview, said Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel asked for the sensors in a telephone conversation with President Clinton. "When these bombings focused the issue, we responded very quickly," he said.
For months American officials have criticized Iran as the prime sponsor of Middle Eastern terrorism and as an open opponent of peace.
On Monday night, American officials said they would use the bombings as a means to try to isolate Iran further and to convince other countries that Iran should not be dealt with, but contained.
Today, Mr. Christopher and his aides emphasized the Iran connection. "Hamas receives its greatest support from Iran," Mr. Christopher said, referring to the group that took responsibility for nearly all the most recent bombings in Israel. "It provides financial backing, tactical advice, and we see the Iranian hand in the conduct of the various terrorist groups."
"The trouble we've had with Iran over the last several years is their export of terrorism, their encouragement of terrorism -- their providing support for terrorism comes to a head at a point like this," he said later. "It is a good lesson -- ought to be -- for the world as to why we've been so strongly opposed to Iran."
But when pressed, Mr. Christopher refused to make a direct connection between Iran and the four recent bombings in Israel. His aides said there was as of yet "no direct chain of evidence" tying Iran to the bombs.
The American specialists will work to "improve coordination" on anti-terrorism and intelligence efforts among the United States, Israel and the Palestinian Authority, which governs territory until recently occupied by Israel.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, who is the majority leader as well as Mr. Clinton's would-be Republican rival, said that Congress should rethink financial aid to the Palestinians, which has totaled about $180 million during the last two years.
"We've had enough drivel out of Washington, D.C., about what's happening in Israel," Mr. Dole said while campaigning in New York. "It's about time that Yasir Arafat exerted some leadership. I think he wants peace. I know the Israelis want peace."
But Mr. Christopher said, "We all need to press Arafat and the Palestinian Authority to take the firmest possible action against Hamas."
Other officials said that Mr. Arafat had been trying to negotiate with Hamas, to bring it in politically and to put an end to the bombings.
"Now Arafat is going out after Hamas," the senior official asserted. "And we are prepared to help My own judgment is that it would be self-defeating and shortsighted to cut off aid of any kind. It wouldn't enhance Israel's security to do that, and that's our prime concern right now."
It took the recent bombings, Mr. Christopher acknowledged, for Mr. Arafat to understand that his strategy with Hamas had failed.
"Arafat has to root out whomever in Hamas is involved, Mr. Christopher said. "This is a new realization on Arafat's part."
The Administration also seemed to signal that any strike by Israel against Hamas would be understood, if not countenanced, by Washington, Mr. Christopher told news service reporters. "There is understanding on the part of the United States that Israel has to take strong action to defeat the terror," he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Slap on the Hand Brings Colombia Out Punching

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, March 5

 BODY:
Fanning nationalist discontent over President Clinton's formal declaration that Colombia was not cooperating in the fight against drugs, this country's embattled President has moved to cool relations with the United States further, apparently as a means of relieving pressure on him to resign.
The declaration, known as "decertification," was announced on Friday, and it leaves Colombia ineligible for any United States aid with the exception of assistance linked to fighting drug trafficking. 
 The action and the harsh accusations against President Ernesto Samper that accompanied it were interpreted as signs of Washington's distrust of Mr. Samper rather than as disapproval of the country's efforts to combat drugs.
Mr. Samper has been fighting accusations that he financed his 1994 presidential campaign with more than $6 million from drug traffickers. The day after the declaration, El Tiempo, a highly influential Bogota daily, crystallized the prevailing view in a banner headline: "Decertified for Narco-Corruption."
Almost as a mass reflex to the national insult, even groups that had been critical of the President lashed out at the United States for interfering in Colombia's internal affairs.
On Monday the national police chief, Gen. Rosso Jose Serrano -- who was singled out for praise by the United States -- said the President had requested a report on the extent of cooperation by the two countries in fighting drug trafficking. General Serrano said the report would "analyze a possible suspension of cooperation with the United States in the fight against drug trafficking and study the participation of American agencies in running radar stations granted on national territory."
In the past, General Serrano has said that last year's achievements -- which included record coca crop eradications and the arrest of six of the seven most powerful drug cartel leaders in the drug center, Cali -- would not have been possible without United States assistance.
[The third-ranking member of the Cali drug cartel, Jose Santacruz Londono, was shot to death late Tuesday in Medellin, The Associated Press reported, citing General Serrano. Mr. Santacruz fled from prison in Bogota in January after about six months in jail. United States officials had said last week that the escape would have a negative effect on the certification process.]
Diplomats here said they did not expect Colombia to suspend all forms of cooperation with the United States intelligence and drug enforcement agencies because Washington could still retaliate with economic sanctions.
At a meeting of his Cabinet, the President requested reports from the Foreign Ministry on the extent of Colombian cooperation with the United States in other areas as well and instructed Colombian Embassies to seek out new forms of cooperation with other countries.
The President has held open the possibility of increasing cooperation with Britain, though diplomats here say they doubt Mr. Samper would go as far as ending cooperation with the United States.
In a lengthy statement on Monday, the President of the Senate, Julio Cesar Guerra, decried the American decision, invoking the Colombian "blood that flowed" to fight narcotics trafficking.
"Decertification is not a holocaust for Colombia," he added. "We have to overcome it and work for the good of the country."
Juan Tokatlian, an independent economic analyst, said he thought the President could rally support for reining in, if not suspending completely, American intelligence and drug enforcement operations in the country. "In the country, I do not see an actor who, in the short term at least, would be opposed to more control or hardening on this issue," said Mr. Tokatlian. "Many feel the U.S. is intervening in Colombian affairs."
The blow from Washington, analysts here predict, is not likely to prove fatal to Mr. Samper immediately, though it may well erode his standing over time.
Jaime Ruiz, a former senator for the Conservative Party and a newspaper columnist, noted that a string of setbacks that once would have been considered decisive -- the President's abandonment by business leaders, the withering of his news media support, public accusations by his lifelong friend and former campaign manager and charges against him by the chief prosecutor -- had all struck without the President's having surrendered to the gathering calls for his resignation. There was no reason to think decertification itself would be different, he said.
"If you ask me, all they're doing is buying time," said Mr. Ruiz. "And time is on Samper's side."
This week, Mr. Samper has put off an appearance at the National Electoral Council, which is looking into allegations that his presidential campaign exceeded the legal spending limits. His attorney, Luis Guillermo Nieto Roa, said he wanted the President to be able to respond to any questions from the Council in writing rather than in person.
Mr. Nieto, in an interview, acknowledged that in the court of public opinion, Mr. Samper was seen with suspicion and doubt. The lawyer said he would request that the proceedings of the Committee of Accusations, which determines whether to recommend impeachment, be held publicly. Many predict that Mr. Samper will be cleared, given that many of the committee's members, including its chairman, are under investigation for improprieties. If that happens, the President would leave the door open to a referendum, his attorney said.
"It has nothing to do with the law," he said. "It has nothing to do with the evidence. It has to do with who's judging." He argued that for the proceedings to carry any credibility, the committee chairman and several members would have to recuse themselves.
Some analysts here predict the crucial factor for Mr. Samper's survival will be the economy. Last month, inflation rose 3.9 percent, dangerously outpacing the country's projections for an annual rate of 15 percent.
"In the short run, this will not weaken Samper," Mr. Tokatlian said. "This firmness gives his mandate the mark of legitimacy." But he predicted that in the long run, the anger at the United States will subside and the President will be pressured anew to step down. The assessment was echoed by American officials in Washington and diplomats here.
"I think in two weeks, maybe even less, we'll begin to see editorial pressure on the President," a diplomat said.
Javier Fernandez, president of the National Association of Financial Institutions, said he did not expect Mr. Samper to remain in office for long.
"He could have if the U.S. had certified him," Mr. Fernandez said. "But now, I don't see how he can."

HEADLINE: Panel Votes for Worker Visas for 250,000

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
Bowing to big farming interests in California, Florida and Texas, the House Agriculture Committee today approved an amendment to the House immigration bill that would grant temporary work visas to as many as 250,000 foreign farm workers, even though many senior Republicans say this will only encourage a new flood of illegal aliens.
Among those favoring the guest-worker program at today's packed hearing were many of the same House members who have clamored the loudest for tighter restrictions on illegal immigration, as well as many lobbyists for farmers and ranchers who fear that cutting off the migration of workers across the border would leave them without the help they need. 
 The overall bill the committee is considering would strongly crack down on illegal immigration, which has become a major theme in the Presidential campaign, and several representatives today condemned the amendment for allowing undocumented aliens into the United States, even with temporary visas.
"Once you admit hundreds of thousands of people like this, why not just pull the Border Patrol off the border and let people in?" asked Representative Lamar Smith, the Texas Republican who is the main author of the bill. "This undercuts everything we're trying to achieve."
Six of the Republicans who voted for the amendment belong to a House committee appointed by Speaker Newt Gingrich that last year recommended tough restrictions on illegal immigration.
What large farmers and ranchers fear, their lobbyists say, is that the new immigration bill might work too well and that additional border guards and the need for employers to use advanced new systems to confirm an alien's legal status would dry up a large part of their labor market. Crop growers estimate that up to 50 percent of their 1.6 million seasonal workers are illegal aliens who hold false identification papers, but the Labor Department says the real figure is closer to 25 percent.
Today, lobbyists from the National Cotton Council, the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association, the American Farm Bureau Federation and many of the 48 other agricultural organizations favoring the guest-worker amendment darted in and out of the corridor outside the committee room to buttonhole lawmakers before the final votes.
"The combination of electronic verification, interior and border control puts pressure on our labor market," said Monte Lake, a lobbyist for the National Council of Agricultural Employers.
Representative Richard W. Pombo, a California Republican who sponsored the visa amendment, said: "We have an opportunity to address the serious concerns of the farmers and ranchers of America. It is vital to accommodate the legitimate interests of farmers and ranchers."
The amendment passed 25 to 13, largely along party lines, after lawmakers agreed to make the program a three-year pilot program rather than a permanent part of immigration law.
The lobbyists have been making their case for weeks.
"All we're asking for is that if there are worker shortages, we can get temporary workers to get through," Michael J. Stuart, executive vice president of the Florida Fruit and Vegetable Association, said in a recent interview.
Opponents of the amendment, including the Clinton Administration and many farm-worker organizations, say that there is no farm worker shortage and that big farming interests are just trying to insure a surplus of cheap, docile labor. The Labor Department estimates that at any given time, 12 percent, or at least 190,000 domestic farm workers, are out of a job.
President Clinton said last year that a new guest-worker program was unwarranted because it would increase illegal immigration, take jobs from American citizens and lower wages and work standards for American workers.
Moreover, the United States already has a guest-worker program that allowed in about 17,000 temporary workers last year. Growers contend that the program is snarled in bureaucracy.
The new program evokes memories of the Bracero program of 1942-64, which brought in more than four million laborers from Mexico. The House narrowly approved a guest-worker program in 1984, but the bill died in the Senate.
Proponents of the latest guest-worker amendment said that under their plan, 25 percent of foreign workers' wages would be withheld until the workers returned to their home countries.
But critics of the proposal said that provision would not be enough to prevent temporary workers from remaining in the United States.
Lawmakers focused today on the apparent contradiction between wanting a new guest-worker program and cracking down on illegal immigration. The debate provoked several sharp exchanges, including one between Representative Earl Pomeroy, Democrat of North Dakota, and Representative John T. Doolittle, Republican of California.
"You can't have stepped-up calls for enforcement on the border and then contend guest workers aren't going to wander off to become illegal aliens once they are here," Mr. Pomeroy said in the exchange. "Mr. Doolittle, you can't have it both ways. It's absolutely illogical."
Mr. Doolittle shot back: "We're doing this so we can accommodate people who want to work, and can work and then can go back to their country. I've got no interest in immigrant-bashing. If you think this is so illogical, I think you're being uninformed."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: CONNECTICUT;
Dole Gains Easy Victory, But Doubts Are Cast, Too

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

 BODY:
In a state known for its moderate brand of Republicanism, Senator Bob Dole won the Presidential primary in Connecticut yesterday by an impressive margin.
Mr. Dole had long been considered the front-runner in this state, endorsed by Gov. John G. Rowland and almost all of the state's Republican leadership. His message of "experienced leadership for unsettled times" seemed to be tailor-made for Connecticut Republicans, many of whom feared a victory by Patrick J. Buchanan. 
With 99 percent of the districts reporting, Mr. Dole had 54 percent of the vote, while Steve Forbes had 20 percent, Mr. Buchanan had 15 percent and Lamar Alexander was at 5 percent.
"We have a new candidate on our hands," Governor Rowland said last night. "The Bob Dole that showed up here on Friday was not the Bob Dole we heard about. He's focused. He's appealing to people. He's invigorated. People are starting to realize that he's the candidate to run against Clinton and that he can run on integrity questions and win the day."
Still, there were indications that some of Mr. Dole's support was less than enthusiastic. An exit poll showed that about 4 of every 10 Dole voters in Connecticut would like to see another candidate enter the Republican field. A similar trend could be seen in the exit poll results from Georgia, Maryland and Massachusetts.
Indeed, the desire for another candidate could be seen among voters for all the candidates. About half said they wished there was another choice in the race.
"The only reason I'm voting for Dole is because I can't stand the other guys," said Jim Kinne, a 74-year-old retired farmer in South Glastonbury. "Buchanan's off the wall, and Forbes is no more qualified than I am. Anyone can be President if they inherited $400 million."
The apparent dissatisfaction with Mr. Dole raises questions about whether he can win back the state that President Clinton carried in 1992, the first Democrat to do so since Hubert H. Humphrey in 1968.
Mr. Rowland dismissed such doubts and said that, once the contest was over, the party would enthusiastically unite behind Mr. Dole.
This was the fourth Republican Presidential primary ever held in Connecticut, and the three previous ones were won by George Bush, who grew up in Greenwich and whose father represented the state in the United States Senate.
The Secretary of the State, Miles S. Rapoport, the state's chief election official, said voter turnout appeared likely to exceed 25 percent, an increase of four percentage points from 1992.
The state has 8 of the nation's 538 electoral votes, and it elects 27 of the 2,010 delegates to the Republican convention. As the winner, Mr. Dole receives all the delegates.
The primary campaign provided little opportunity for Connecticut voters to see the candidates up close. Mr. Dole appeared briefly in Hartford on Friday, and Mr. Forbes campaigned across the state Saturday and Monday. Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Alexander, the former Tennessee governor, never visited.
Voters largely learned about the candidates through news coverage of events in other states and advertising, with Mr. Dole running television commercials since last week and Mr. Forbes conducting a media blitz in the final three days of the campaign. For instance, on Monday night, Mr. Forbes bought a half-hour on the NBC affiliate in New Britain, and yesterday, he had two commercials airing every hour on one local radio station.
With the support of the state party, Mr. Dole was the only candidate with an extensive statewide organization -- one that actually drove some voters to the polls -- and Mr. Rowland put his reputation on the line by guaranteeing a Dole victory.
The race appeared to turn on several factors. In the exit poll, most voters said their main concern was the economy and jobs, taxes or the deficit. Only a small minority listed foreign trade, Mr. Buchanan's major economic theme, as the "one issue that mattered most," and a majority of them backed Mr. Dole. In general, Mr. Dole was the choice of voters who were most concerned about the economy and the deficit.
About one of every five voters said that "experience in Washington," a key theme in Mr. Dole's campaign, was the most important quality they were looking for in a candidate, and almost every one of these people voted for Mr. Dole.
By contrast, the exit poll showed that 1 in 20 voters wanted someone who was "not a career politician" and most of them chose Mr. Forbes.
"Dole's been in politics too long," said Denise Aguillera, a 30-year-old lawyer who voted for Mr. Forbes. What she likes most about Mr. Forbes, she added, is his proposal for a flat tax.
About half of the Forbes voters said that taxes were their top concern, and State Senator Kevin F. Rennie, Mr. Forbes's Connecticut campaign chairman, noted that polls showed that Mr. Forbes's support doubled in the last five days as he began advertising.
But among voters who listed taxes as the most important issue, Mr. Dole did almost as well as Mr. Forbes, according to the exit poll.
In turn, Mr. Buchanan, who concentrated most of his energy in Georgia, said he knew he had "an uphill battle in Connecticut," and he failed to match his performance of four years ago, when he won 22 percent of the vote against Mr. Bush.
This time around, two-thirds of the voters considered him "too extreme," according to the exit polls.
This may have worked to Mr. Dole's advantage. "In Connecticut, there developed an imperative to stopping the Pat Buchanan juggernaut and Bob Dole was perceived as the one to do it," Mr. Rennie, the Forbes campaign representative, said. 

CORRECTION-DATE: March 7, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the Republican Presidential primary in Connecticut misidentified the winner of the 1968 Presidential election in that state in some copies. It was Hubert H. Humphrey, not Lyndon B. Johnson, who did not seek re-election.

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Dole's Troubled Horizon

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
Bob Dole is not quite there yet. He lost a pair of adversaries today, but two others hang on, notably Patrick J. Buchanan, who is apparently determined to harry him, the same way J. E. B. Stuart harried McClellan, all the way to the Republican convention in San Diego in August.
Gone are Lamar Alexander and Senator Richard G. Lugar, and the Presidential nomination will be within Mr. Dole's reach if he can defeat Steve Forbes in the New York primary on Thursday. Given his huge organizational edge, that should be relatively easy, despite the endorsement of Mr. Forbes this afternoon by Jack F. Kemp, a member of George Bush's Cabinet and a champion of supply-side economics. 
 "I know it's late," said Mr. Kemp, a former quarterback for the Buffalo Bills. Indeed, most politicians think it is far too late for Mr. Forbes or Mr. Buchanan to deny Mr. Dole the nomination after the Senator's clean sweep of primaries in eight states on Tuesday.
But even with a big victory in New York, Mr. Dole will face major challenges. Looming just ahead is the threat that Mr. Buchanan's sniping from the right will delay the tactical move to the center that Mr. Dole would like to make before the general election, as Richard M. Nixon always counseled. Beyond that lies the threat that the convention will make Houston 1992 look like a lawn party, with disruptive battles over abortion and other social issues -- another outbreak of the debilitating cultural warfare that Mr. Buchanan likes to foment.
And at the end of the trail there lurks the biggest threat of all: Bill Clinton, a campaign-aholic who thrives on the blarney and flesh-pressing that the Kansas Senator shrinks from, and who begins with a big lead.
Although he stipulated, old pro that he is, that he must avoid overconfidence, Mr. Dole talked about restoring party unity even before two of his rivals, humbled, stepped back from the contest today. He described himself as a unifier and said the party was not "spinning out of control."
Mr. Forbes, Mr. Lugar and Mr. Alexander all struck positive notes.
But amid the symphony of Republican reconciliation, Mr. Buchanan sounded a discordant and unreconciled note. "I'll be here awhile, talking and carrying on," he said, describing Mr. Dole as part of "a calcified group" in Washington with "no ideas, no fire, no passion, no conviction." The commentator said his supporters were full of the kind of zeal the Republicans will need if they want to beat President Clinton.
There is ample evidence of that, and not only in the fervor of the crowds that turn out for Mr. Buchanan's rallies. In state after state, he has taken from 25 to 30 percent of the total, even with numerous candidates in the field.
Figures from exit polls conducted by the television networks and The Associated Press on Tuesday make it look unlikely that Mr. Buchanan can win a significant number of future contests, even if Mr. Forbes does not stay the course. But either Mr. Forbes or Mr. Buchanan might stage an ambush or two. In past races, candidates who had seemed clearly spent pulled off upsets (Gary Hart over Walter F. Mondale in California in June 1984, for example, and Edmund G. Brown Jr. over Mr. Clinton in Connecticut after Super Tuesday in 1992).
Both Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Forbes will continue to accumulate delegates in states with proportional representation, like Michigan, Oregon and possibly Texas (if no candidate gets an outright majority there), and in the many states where the candidate who carries a Congressional district gets that district's delegates.
With his delegates, Mr. Buchanan can bargain for things that matter to him and his backers. He wants a platform plank calling for a constitutional amendment banning abortion, for example, and he wants a Vice-Presidential nominee who opposes abortion, unlike Colin L. Powell, whom Mr. Dole has often mentioned as a potential running mate.
Mr. Forbes wants to make the case for what he calls his "pro-growth agenda," centering on the flat tax. He has the money to do so. His friends doubt, however, that he will resort again to attacking Mr. Dole in the process.
But as long as he remains active, Mr. Buchanan will keep before the nation his critique of Mr. Dole as a worn-out Washington insider with no vision of the future, criticism that can only hurt the Republicans. Gov. Jim Edgar of Illinois, a pivotal state, said that the quicker Mr. Dole "can end this internal party battle, the better for us going into the fall," and other party leaders agree.
The trick for Mr. Dole is to assuage Mr. Buchanan's ardent followers on social issues and economic anxieties without alienating other parts of the potential Republican coalition. Many of Mr. Dole's current backers, officeholders and ordinary voters alike, support him because they fear Mr. Buchanan. In Tuesday's exit polls, more than half the electorate in each state that voted said Mr. Buchanan was too extreme to be President, so Mr. Dole cannot afford to seem to kowtow to him.
Mr. Dole must also work to overcome lingering problems with his own image among Republican voters. As with any candidate, his first priority will be solidifying his partisan base, but the primaries have revealed major weaknesses.
One is his age. He will be 73 by November, older than any previous President when first elected to the office. In every primary state so far except South Carolina (which remains fond of its 93-year-old Senator, Strom Thurmond), one voter in three has said his age would hurt his performance in the White House. He consistently does better among older voters than the more numerous young ones.
Another obstacle is Mr. Dole's difficulty in exciting the electorate -- even Republicans, even those who have voted for him in the primaries. In Georgia, for example, almost half of those taking part in the primary said they wished other candidates were in the race; 40 percent of his own supporters said so.
Mr. Dole has prevailed so far, it might be said, more because of his opponents' frailties than his own strengths. For all his money, Mr. Forbes was unknown. Mr. Lugar's innovative themes did nothing to pierce his reputation for dullness. Mr. Alexander's scenario depended on Mr. Dole's collapsing. Mr. Buchanan seemed too extreme. By sheer grit, Mr. Dole hung on until he got to South Carolina, a state with a strong party machine committed to his candidacy, where Mr. Forbes spent very little.
Its primary last Saturday proved to be the turning point. To borrow an analogy from physics, the Dole campaign reached critical mass, allowing a chain reaction to carry him through the geographically and politically diverse tests he faced on Tuesday.
Georgia was the big prize on Tuesday, with the most delegates at stake (42) of any of the day's eight primaries and the greatest strategic significance leading into the Super Tuesday contests on March 12 in six Southern and Southwestern states. Bob Dole took it and made himself the prohibitive favorite elsewhere in the South, but he had a closer contest there than anywhere else on Tuesday.
Mr. Buchanan has a strong natural constituency in Georgia, especially in rural areas. He won at least 65 of the state's 159 counties, remobilizing the rural base that helped George C. Wallace take the state in the 1968 Presidential election. But the Atlanta metropolitan region has grown explosively since then, along with smaller cities, and Mr. Buchanan did much less well in urban areas.
By any measure, the commentator failed in his bid to turn his campaign around in Georgia, which was almost certainly his last best hope.
Unable to unify the religious right behind him, unable to win significant support in his party's center, he was left again to ponder the might-have-beens and to decide how much damage he was willing to inflict upon Mr. Dole prior to the fall election. In 1992, as Republicans recall without pleasure, he kept the focus on President Bush's weaknesses all year, then helped divide the party in the general election with his hotly combative oratory at the Houston convention.
