HEADLINE: In the Class of '70, Wounded Winners

SERIES: THE DOWNSIZING OF AMERICA: In a College Class, Success and Insecurity -- First of seven articles.

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: LEWISBURG, Pa.

 BODY:
The faces of the Bucknell University class of 1970 gaze out from the yearbook with a wide-eyed hopefulness untarnished by time. Though their hairstyles and clothes may look ever more dated, the class members remain forever 22 years old and unbowed, captured by the camera at a singular, ascendant moment of their youth.
They came here in 1966 from farm country Pennsylvania, from the suburbs of New York City and from the shores of Chesapeake Bay, children of America's middle class and of the great post-World War II economic boom. Born mostly in 1948, they had known nothing but prosperity, and it had imprinted upon them a pattern of belief and behavior as profound as the one that the Great Depression had left upon their parents. 
 If anything, the tumult of the 1960's only deepened their convictions about themselves and their future. Many grew their hair and protested the Vietnam War, but their campus never became violent, and the 1960's presented, in the end, another affirmation of hope: there were shelters from life's storms. People were essentially civilized. The great American promise still held, and if it ever faltered, they would be there to help set it right.
"Everything was on the upswing for us," said Mark S. Harris, a biology major in 1970, now a pediatrician in northern Vermont. "We were going to do a pretty good job by the world because the world was going to do a pretty good job by us. There was a confidence bred into us."
Twenty-five years on, a lot of those great expectations have been fulfilled. The 618 men and women of Bucknell 1970 have achieved and prospered. The vast majority are professionals, administrators and managers. Many are at the heights of their careers, and some are millionaires. This is their lion phase.
So what is most striking about these exemplars of middle-class success is what they have lost: their belief in the future and their faith in the rules of hard work rewarded. In the new economy of layoffs, limitation and job insecurity, their expansive confidence has eroded. The world that once seemed rich and ripe with potential has become, for many, a place full of fear -- for their jobs, for their retirement and, especially, for their children.
"There's an uncertainty at 25 years after," said Shirley A. Trauger, an English major who now runs a community arts center outside Philadelphia. "Just when we should be at the most stable time of our lives, we're not."
So here is their journey. One college class from one year: Bucknell 1970. It is not meant to be a microcosm of the nation, but a significant slice: one middle-class cohort on the cusp of change and what became of them.
They left here on diverse paths, celebrating the sense of infinite possibility. But in middle age they have seen those paths converge. Some believed they could discover alternative ways to live, work and prosper free of the lock-step compromises of corporate life, only to find that ideal corroded in a time of scarcity and cost-cutting. Many of the women, inspired by the nascent feminist movement, created new roles in the 1970's and 80's, only to find that they had to reinvent themselves all over again as their jobs, or their spouses' jobs, changed or simply disappeared.
But most of all, whatever life they chose, the men and women of the class of 1970 were believers -- in the system and the old social contract binding companies and their workers. Now, that system is being torn down, and if they are not victims, they feel like accomplices. They are the survivors, and, often, the executioners.
Richard A. Baumbusch, an electrical engineering major at Bucknell, was already a corporate veteran in 1985. He was working for CBS in New York, as a manager in a division that was going to be closed. The secret clock was ticking away to the surprise mass layoff. Then a co-worker approached. He was thinking of buying a house. Did Mr. Baumbusch think it was a good time to get into real estate?
The man's job was doomed and Mr. Baumbusch knew it. But spilling the secret, he believed, would violate his integrity as a corporate officer and doom the company to a firestorm of fear and rumor. There was no way to win and no way out.
"I considered it my fiduciary responsibility to the business to keep my mouth shut, and yet here was this person coming for advice as a friend and a business acquaintance and I had material information that would affect him," Mr. Baumbusch said. "For someone with a sense of empathy and sympathy, which I like to think I have some of, it was very, very hard."
In the end, Mr. Baumbusch swallowed his anguish and kept silent. The man bought the house and lost his job. The secret held. But 10 years later, all you have to do is watch Mr. Baumbusch tell the story to see how many times he has relived it, and second-guessed what he did that day.
The school that produced Mr. Baumbusch helped build the old economic order. Founded on the west bank of the Susquehanna River in 1846 by Baptists and equidistant to the great cities of the Midwest and Northeast, it is a place of hard-headed practicality and bucolic beauty, of Federalist brick buildings and rolling hills where violets creep to the roadside's edge in spring.
The school's core strengths, the basis for much of its sense of heft and quiet competence, are the engineering and business schools. Bucknell has produced few truly famous names. The writer Philip Roth is one exception -- he studied here in the 1950's and has become a sort of poster boy for the recruitment office. But it has produced many substantial ones. The Ivy League, from the Bucknell point of view, is where you go if you have arrived -- Bucknell is for those on the way.
"Hollywood would cast Bucknell as the vice presidents' school," said Scott G. Nichols, an economics major in 1970 who is now the dean for development at Harvard Law School. "They're going to be the quiet upper end. They really run the infrastructure."
But as that infrastructure has changed, so, too, have the school and its students. In their unrelenting focus on career goals and on the outsize efforts they believe are needed to achieve them, today's Bucknell seniors can seem like modernized re-creations of the Depression-era parents of the class of 1970.
At Bucknell today, taking time off to find yourself feels dangerous. Caught between the pressure to commit to careers earlier than the class of 1970 ever imagined and the fear that those choices may turn out to be terribly, joylessly, wrong, seniors say that pragmatism rules. The class of 1970 had dreams. The class of '96 has ambitions.
"The class of 1970 knew that great poetry would be written and great music composed and great novels written and it never occurred to them that they wouldn't be the people who might do it," said Douglas K. Candland, who has taught psychology here since 1960. "The current students know that these things will happen, but they don't have the faith that they might be the ones who accomplish those tasks -- in short, we've cut out hope."
The men and women of 1970 knew they would win. It wasn't even something they could articulate, they said, it was just there, a given, like the air itself.
Gerald M. Brown got a half-dozen job offers after graduation and took the best, from Eastman Kodak, in his hometown.
Peter Louthis and Robert P. Justman rejected the mainstream and became carpenters in Aspen, Colo., at a time when a carpenter's wage could still pay the rent.
Christine Dotterer invented herself. Shortly after graduation, she met a female physician for the first time and realized in a flash what her own future could be. Shelby H. Diefenbach entered a corporate world that at last seemed promising for women.
They came of age as a new economic order was taking shape, with its corrosive costs, its compromises and, yes, its opportunities. Their experiences show how broadly and deeply America has been affected by that economic restructuring, and that while mass layoffs may be the most dramatic expression of the new era, little has been left untouched and unchanged.
"In 1970, I wanted to fight to change the world," said Gilbert L. Panitz, the 1970 class president, now an engineer for a major military contractor that has shed two-thirds of its employees in the last five years. "It's ironic that now I'm fighting to keep my job."
 
Hollow Victories
The guarantee that once came with a Bucknell diploma, of a life insulated from economic instability, has been breached: about one in five households in the class of 1970 has lost a job permanently over the last 15 years, according to a New York Times survey of the class. Many of these people tell stories of emotional and financial hardship.
But the damage has spread far wider, to those who have inflicted the pain and to those who have been forced to remain and watch. There are victims who look like winners, and winners with secret, silent wounds.
When he was growing up in Rochester, N.Y., Gerald M. Brown always wanted a house on Canandaigua Lake. His father, a bulldozer operator, would take the family there on summer days, but then they had to pack up and drive the 30 miles back home. For Mr. Brown, a lake house, and a Bucknell education, became symbols of the life his parents never had.
The Kodak job, begun in the summer after graduation, has taken him through more than 25 years now, and from his front window he can gaze out every day onto the shimmering jewel of Canandaigua. He is still in the department where he started out as a programmer, information services, and he has risen in the hierarchy, to senior systems analyst.
But he feels lost. The company that he grew to respect and even love is gone, transformed by downsizing into a place that he says he barely recognizes. Kodak has shrunk by a third, to about 96,000 employees, over the last five years. The last round of downsizing, in early 1994, wiped out 10 percent of Mr. Brown's department.
"When I have lunch with my peers, we all have the same sense of hollowness," he said. "You're always left with the feeling, each time around, 'I'm dispensable, I'm not a vital cog in the machine.' Even though you're a survivor, even though you win, it's a hollow victory. It doesn't make you feel valuable when they say, 'I know you're doing three projects, Jerry, here's another one.' "
Mr. Brown once hoped his oldest son, David, who is 16, might someday become a Kodak man. Now he has no idea what advice to offer.
"The paradigm I taught my son -- work hard, take the A.P. courses, get into a good school and you will get a good job in corporate America like I did -- that corporate America isn't there anymore," Mr. Brown said. "I can't steer him that way. What are the odds that anyone will ever again get 25 years at Kodak?"
Richard Baumbusch, the CBS manager, laughs at the idea of 25 years anywhere. Ultimately, he, too, was laid off by CBS, and he was laid off yet again. But he shrugs off those experiences.
Each time, he got enough of a severance package to tide the family over. He bounced back. His adaptability and his agility are hallmarks of the new corporate man.
He now is an executive director at U S West Communications, a unit of the telecommunications corporation U S West, and lives in a walled enclave called The Preserve, just outside Denver, in a beautiful home of wood and plants.
True, he never feels remotely secure in his job and never will again. But that's the way it is, he says. Sometimes, having survived thus far, he even relaxes.
"Sometimes I think I'm a little too relaxed," he said.
But he is not the man he was. He has seen too much.
Like a third of the class members and their spouses, he has helped lay off people himself. He still remembers pretty much verbatim what he said to his home-buying colleague that day in 1985, the way he tried to convey a message of caution, a signal across their secret divide.
"I said something like, 'Gee, if it was me, I'm not sure I would,' " he said. But the warning was vague, and the man's heart was set on the purchase. "I wanted to say, 'Can't you read the handwriting on the wall?' "
Mr. Baumbusch believes that the changing economy, in the end, has made him more compassionate in some ways, though he still probably would do the same thing and, if anything, feel even more torn.
"I'm more aware of the pain involved in layoffs and relocations than I was," he said. "I'm more prone to spend more time helping people look for work than I was -- it's easier for me to picture myself in that situation, losing self-confidence, sitting at home. It's an extremely lonely experience."
 
Every Man for Himself
Peter Louthis still remembers the opening line from the platoon leader's manual he was given in his Army Reserve Officer Training Corps class at Bucknell: The mission comes before the men.
That one sentence, so loaded with implications about human expendability, became an obsession for him and eventually led him to change the course of his life. Two months short of graduation, the former American Legion Boy of the Year from Rhode Island, the Bucknell football captain and business major who had made all the right moves, dropped out of school and failed to appear for his preinduction draft physical. He went underground and ended up in Aspen, Colo., living with no last name. He got work as a carpenter.
In 1970, Aspen symbolized escape -- from the war, from parents, from the middle class itself. Robert P. Justman, an electrical engineer at Bucknell, also heard the call. He drifted there after graduation and took up carpentry, too, planning to stay perhaps a year. After his second day on the job, he knew he would never go to law school or business school or do anything requiring suits and ties and life indoors. He had found home. By early 1971, two dozen members of the class had arrived in town.
That old Aspen is mostly gone now. The new Aspen is about money. Range Rovers, known locally as Colorado Cadillacs, slink up to the curbs, and teen-agers with just-so haircuts stalk the boutique-choked streets. With housing costs and demand soaring, the bargain-basement shared homes of 1970 are a thing of the past. The idea of Aspen as a left-leaning, egalitarian, alternate universe has been eclipsed.
Mr. Louthis, who ultimately got a draft deferment that allowed him to come out of hiding, is now a construction superintendent for a small company that specializes in multimillion-dollar mountainside mansions. The smallest home he has built since the late 1980's is 16,000 square feet, and some have been larger than 40,000. All are custom designed at a cost of up to $500 a square foot. He and his workers wear white paper slippers over their shoes to protect the floors.
And like business owners and managers all over the country, he has found that the mission, in the new economy, very often does come before the men. Two years ago, his company went through its first downsizing, cutting the staff of 110 by about 10 percent, using temporary workers and subcontractors instead. The old elements of his company's founding culture -- the family-like feeling, the shared purpose and enthusiasm -- are alive, he says, but they are struggling.
So is Mr. Louthis. He believes in his company, Hansen Construction, and wants it to prosper, but the impulse that brought him to Aspen is also still there, and sometimes the two are at war. Although he did not have to lay anyone off himself, he said, he is more acutely aware of being one of "them" than he ever was before.
"I know I've become part of the system I rejected, to an extent," he said. "But I feel that I have still kept my individuality."
So he encourages his employees to quit if they show even the smallest amount of initiative. Set yourself up as an independent subcontractor, then come back, he tells them. You'll keep more for yourself and have a chance to build something. The company, Mr. Louthis tells workers, "may not stand by you as long as you expect it to."
He tries to hold out the same model for himself: draw a line beyond which the incursions and compromises of the business are too much, and be ready to walk away. Just as he did in 1970.
"Right now we still have a family, we still do the raft trips and the picnic," Mr. Louthis said. "But the new world is more computer-like, and I can see us beginning to go that way, being cleaner and colder and more calculated. We have to stay competitive."
Robert Justman also became a successful custom-home builder, in Austin, Tex., using what he earned from his first two Aspen houses as seed money. But the self-made road has led him to become a pillar of the new social contract.
He hires mostly Mexican immigrants for $6 an hour. He realizes that probably drives down the pay scale, maybe even contributes to homelessness, and that those wages alone will not support a family as they could in the 1970's. But he believes native-born Americans have lost the work ethic.
The Mexicans who work for him, he said, are "dream employees. At $6 they're thrilled and honest and hard-working. Try and find a black or white American who will work like that." Besides, he says, "Just because a guy didn't have the good fortune I did to be born north of the 40th parallel or whatever, I should punish him? Anyway, that's my rationale."
 
Feminism Compromised
When the class of 1970 arrived at Bucknell in 1966, the ideal of female behavior was a mythical being called the "Bucknell Lady." She had perfect poise and charm and always wore a skirt downtown, never pants. She needed to be sheltered.
Women in the class were required to eat separately from the men, and their dormitories were locked earlier, at 11 o'clock, even though the library was open until midnight. By 1970, as the women's movement was being born, the student body had voted for coeducational dormitories, and the other old restrictions had been trashed. The Bucknell Lady was dead.
The story of the Bucknell woman is still being written. Many women from the class of 1970 were at the front lines in shattering the dichotomy between work and home, asserting themselves in professions and institutions once all but closed to them. Now, economic forces have compromised those feminist ambitions in ways the women never expected.
Shelby H. Diefenbach never remotely imagined that in her late 40's she would be a self-employed businesswoman, mother and the primary breadwinner for her family. An English literature major in 1970, she took the corporate road after graduation. She went into marketing research, first for Campbell's soup, then R. J. Reynolds, then Apple Computer in California.
In 1992, it all unraveled. Her husband's export business went soft in the recession. She had two small children, and the rising financial burden and ever-longer hours at the office filled her with stress and guilt. Then she got laid off.
It was a turning point. Feeling alienated by the grind, then burned because the opportunities that had been promised were ripped away, Ms. Diefenbach refused even to look for a new job. Instead, she set up shop as an independent marketing research consultant and found herself, to her surprise, on the winning end of a downsizing trend: companies were eliminating their research departments and contracting out the work.
She gets no benefits, and her husband is now working as a consultant, too, but she says she is happy in a way she never was before. She is more confident of herself and her abilities, but more relaxed too. She laughs more now.
"We're struggling basically, when we should have a nice retirement stashed away," she said. "But we'd have to be in a homeless shelter before I'd go back. I have a great personality now. I never had a personality before."
Ann M. Morrison, a psychology major in 1970 and co-author of "Breaking the Glass Ceiling," a how-to book for rising female executives, said that in many ways, Ms. Diefenbach's story had become a new model. Companies that were flush in the 1970's and 1980's have retrenched.
For women inside organizations, she said, the 1990's have been a disappointment. Advancement has been blocked and workloads have increased, even as many women need their jobs more than ever because of family pressures. But, she added, "More women are also going and making it on their own. That's a very encouraging factor."
Still, independence by itself has provided no immunity either.
Christine Dotterer's graduation from Bucknell marked the continuation of a tradition: she represented the third generation of women in her family to be educated here, beginning with her grandmother in the class of 1916. She also began a tradition on her own: she took a career after graduation.
She stumbled on it, actually. She went to New York in November 1970 to be a social worker and met, for the first time in her life, a female physician. A new world suddenly opened. This was something she could be, something she could make all her own.
She has done that, achieving a precise and layered vision. She wanted the autonomy of a small-town family practice, in Selinsgrove near her family's roots in central Pennsylvania, and she wanted to run it with what she thought of as a woman's sensibility.
"It's not hierarchical," she said. "It's a female-oriented office, just me and two nurses, and we're all soft touches. If somebody is in financial trouble, we charge for a brief office visit even though it wasn't."
In the last few years, though, Dr. Dotterer has seen her work transformed by the same forces of cost-cutting that are behind the layoff phenomenon, as more and more of her patients get their medical coverage through managed-care companies. The increased paperwork, she says, has forced her to computerize her practice and raise her rates. Worse still, she points out, her autonomy as a physician is being whittled down as insurers second-guess her treatment decisions.
"The system can't pay attention to the needs of people, and paying attention to the physical and emotional needs of people was the feminist vision of my practice," she said. "It's being a mother hen, for lack of a better word, to my patients and to my employees, but the more I see the iron stamp of managed care on the practice of medicine, the more those wonderful things are being lost.
"I used to think I would be one of these people wandering around practicing medicine at 85 and having a good time. I can't imagine that anymore. I can't imagine working to 65."
 
Self-Determination
 Glen B. Maynard still has the 1969 Datsun 2000 two-seater convertible in which he drove west in 1975 after graduating from Boston University Law School. In fact, he just had it repainted last fall.
His law office, right above the Silverheels Grill in downtown Golden, Colo., has a view of Table Mountain and the exuberant "Howdy Folks!" banner that stretches across the main drag, Washington Avenue. He walks eight blocks to work. He can live on $2,000 a month if need be. He has one associate, and never went in much for possessions or family commitments.
"I never acquired a wife," he said.
In the last few years, more Americans have been "downshifting," discovering new tracks out of the consumer culture, and away from the complexity, stress and anxiety of modern life. Mr. Maynard simplified his life long before it became trendy, and in an economy that rewards the self-reliant, that has been a formula for victory, or at least a way to fight to a draw.
Mr. Maynard's college years were so overshadowed by the Vietnam War and the draft, which to him symbolized all the forces of life over which he had no control, that the driving force of his life ever since has been autonomy, never to be under the thumb of a boss, never to be in debt.
"I don't know what trade-offs have been made to stay independent," he said. "I'm sure some are economic. My choice is that I don't like to take direction from other people. I like to do things my way."
So does Janice E. Thomas; it just took her longer to realize it. A conservative math major at Bucknell, the daughter of a career military man, she worked for AT&T for 18 years after graduation as a computer programmer before deciding about seven years ago to throw it all over and do what she really wanted to do.
"When I went into the business world, I thought there would be rewards," she said. "But you're like a widget -- you're a programmer and you sit at a desk and this is what you're supposed to do. I began to get the feeling that the work I was doing wasn't making a difference -- for me, or the world."
Asked to explain just what it is she does now, she struggles, settling finally on a label she invented: a mind, body, spirit healing facilitator. She works from her home in Norwalk, Conn., helping people through a combination of nerve-muscle relaxation, meditation, psychology and spiritual counseling. Her basic premise is that everyone has a mostly untapped interior reservoir of regenerative power, a kind of will to heal that mainly needs encouragement and training.
Ms. Thomas believes that all the old systems are breaking down, and that the changing relationships between people and their jobs are simply one manifestation. She believes that a new era is dawning that will be more open to self-fulfillment than any before. What we are experiencing, she says, with all its thrashing and turmoil, is the death rattle of what we knew. "The world," she says, "is being destroyed so that it can be rebuilt."
Now, as the members of the class of 1970 approach the precipice of their 50's, there is also a sense of mortality in many of their voices. Losing a job in your 50's is easier in the new economy, and finding one, especially a good one, is harder.
"As you go forward and more and more people will have lived through this, you get more resilient and not so scared," said David L. Hall, a bank executive who has been laid off, and who has laid off others. "But the most dangerous 15 years for our class is now approaching -- the 15 years to retirement."

HEADLINE: A Trial Without Witnesses

BYLINE: By Theodor Meron 

 BODY:
The International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague is being undermined by a lack of cooperation from most of the combatants in the former Yugoslavia -- the Serbs, Bosnian Serbs and Croats. Unless the United Nations and the Western powers use all their leverage to help the tribunal, the rule of international law and the legacy of the Nuremberg trials will be in danger.
So far, 53 people have been indicted: 7 Croats, 3 members of the Serbian Army and 43 Bosnian Serbs. Yet only two, both Bosnian Serbs, have been apprehended and sent to The Hague (along with another Bosnian Serb suspect who has not yet been indicted). The primary reason is that the governments and militaries have been sheltering the suspected war criminals. 
 But there is another worrisome trend. Many of the victims and witnesses that the prosecution needs have refused to cooperate. This is probably due to pressure from their governments, which could use a lack of witnesses as an excuse to claim that the accused cannot receive a fair trial and must be released. When Dusan Tadic, a Bosnian Serb charged with raping, killing and torturing Muslims in a concentration camp, comes to trial in May, his lawyers may try to have the charges dismissed for this reason.
The indictment last week of Gen. Djordje Djukic, one of the Bosnian Serbs in custody, for indiscriminately bombing citizens of Sarajevo, was good news. But it will only partly relieve the growing disappointment in the West that the tribunal, in which it has invested heavily, has produced only two defendants. Public support of the trials is vital to the future of international law.
Given the military muscle that the NATO-led international force now has on the ground in Bosnia, it would be a disgrace if Mr. Tadic and Mr. Djukic remain the only defendants.
What can we do? The Clinton Administration appears to be less reluctant than Congress -- which is apparently haunted by memories of Beirut and Somalia -- to have the international force play a more active role.
Under its operating procedures, the international troops are allowed to arrest indicted war criminals but not to seek them out. Still, they could be more aggressive without breaking those rules. If intelligence agencies improved the way they share information with the international force, the troops would have a better chance of finding indicted criminals without appearing to hunt for them.
Then there is the diplomatic approach. As a part of the Dayton peace agreement, if either the civilian coordinator, Carl Bildt of Sweden, or the the NATO force's commander, Adm. Leighton Smith of the United States, informs the United Nations that the Serbs "are failing significantly to meet their obligations under the peace agreement," economic sanctions are to be reimposed within five days (unless the Security Council disapproves). This threat has yet to be used.
Of course, such sanctions would have no effect on Croatia, which has also been unhelpful. Fortunately, Franjo Tudjman, the Croatian President, craves international legitimacy and a place in the European Community. It should be made clear that no such acceptance will be forthcoming until he fully cooperates with the tribunal. Should the Bosnians cause trouble, their assistance can be best insured through American influence, perhaps by threatening to end military training and other aid.
The tribunal could enhance its own prospects by vigorously investigating notorious Serb paramilitary leaders who have not been indicted. It must also look into Muslims suspected of atrocities; since most of those currently indicted are Bosnian Serbs, questions about the tribunal's impartiality have been raised. The Hague needs a guarantee from the United Nations that it will be given adequate financing to broaden its efforts.
The tribunal's chief prosecutor, Richard Goldstone of South Africa, has done an excellent job despite the lack of cooperation. But he needs more help from the United Nations and the international community as he strives to uphold the rule of international law.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
TV Airwaves Becoming Issue In Budget Battle

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
The television airwaves are becoming part of the budget wars in Congress, with Senate Republicans taking a hard look at proposals to raise billions of dollars by auctioning off a part of the radio spectrum earmarked for advanced TV services.
The newest effort comes from the Senate Budget Committee, where lawmakers are looking harder for money to cut the deficit and have cast an eye on television licenses that are estimated to be worth tens of billions of dollars on the open market. 
 Broadcasters and television equipment manufacturers have already begun publicity and lobbying campaigns to stop any auction proposal. On Thursday, a group called Citizens for HDTV (high-definition television) will hold a news conference that is intended to convey the views of consumers and labor unions.
But the group's main organizer is a trade association for the consumer electronics industry, whose members hope to make a lot of money on the sale of new digital TV sets and related equipment.
Television broadcasters have also started buying full-page newspaper ads and have begun pleading their case in visits to members of Congress.
Broadcasters argue that they need the licenses to make a transition to new digital technology, which was originally developed for high-definition television but can also be used to send data or to beam as many as six shows at a time over the frequencies now used for just one.
The effort in Congress could split top Republican lawmakers. Some, like the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, have made it clear they would like to auction off the airwaves. But the television industry also has powerful supporters, including the Senate Republican whip, Trent Lott of Mississippi.
Republican Congressional officials say that fight is heating up again for two reasons.
First, they say, members of the Budget Committee, headed by Senator Pete Domenici of New Mexico, have become increasingly excited by the sky-high prices being bid in the auction of wireless telephone licenses that is under way at the Federal Communications Commission.
Bidding in that auction, which was reserved for companies that qualify as small businesses, has soared well beyond expectations and has topped $7.9 billion.
Second, according to members of the Republican staff, lawmakers have become worried that sluggishness in the economy will force them to revise their economic assumptions downward and make it even more difficult to trim the deficit.
"Those issues have taken on added importance because of the latest economic growth numbers," said one Republican staff member. "That's causing trouble for both the White House and the Congressional leadership."
Senator Domenici surprised many of his colleagues last Friday, scheduling a Senate Budget Committee hearing for next week to analyze the value of different auction proposals. Analysts from the Congressional Budget Office, the White House Office of Management and Budget and perhaps from industry are expected to testify.
The hearing upstages hearings scheduled for later this month by both the House and Senate commerce panels. These hearings are expected to be broader and probably inconclusive because those committees are far more divided and the House panel is openly sympathetic to the TV industry.
No one, however, can more than guess about what the television frequencies might be worth. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that an auction would yield about $12.5 billion. The F.C.C. has produced estimates ranging from $11 billion to $70 billion. Some independent analysts believe the figure could be as low as $5 billion, given practical limitations on the frequencies under debate.
Supporters of digital television say that an auction would derail the new broadcasting technology because television stations could not carry out a transition from today's system to one that would transmit to an entirely new generation of sets.
Auctions "would set back the whole technology, in which the United States has the leadership," said Richard E. Wiley, a former chairman of the communications commission and now head of an F.C.C. advisory group that guided development of an advanced TV system. "From many public policy standpoints, auctioning the digital television frequencies would be a mistake."
Senator Dole, who protested that giving or even lending the broadcasters new licenses amounted to "corporate welfare," said little today but remains sympathetic to auctions.
"Senator Dole's view is that the spectrum is a valuable resource and that that taxpayers should be fairly compensated for its use," said Clarkson Hine, spokesman for Mr. Dole.
Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, who has campaigned for auctions, said he was increasingly optimistic about prevailing.
"I would never underestimate the power of the broadcasters, but over time, I believe that these things will turn out in the interest of the average citizen," he said.

HEADLINE: Boeing, in Rosy Forecast, Says Industry Is Recovering

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
The Boeing Company said yesterday that a recovery is under way in the commercial airplane industry, as it issued a new 20-year forecast for the industry.
Boeing said it expected airlines would buy 15,900 planes worth $1.1 trillion in the next 20 years, up modestly from 15,462 in its 1995 forecast, with two of every three planes going to carriers outside the United States. 
 "Traffic growth and sustained airline profitability are beginning to result in airplane orders," said Nancy Bethel, vice president of marketing for the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group. "Our industry appears to have made it through the bottom of the cycle."
Boeing's optimistic forecast coincided with the $2.8 billion order from the International Lease Finance Corporation, a unit of the American International Group, for 18 of its midsize 777 airliners. The agreement brings to 24 the total number of 777's that International Lease has on order. International Lease, based in Los Angeles, also ordered 38 airplanes worth about $3 billion from Airbus Industrie, the European consortium, including the first orders for the new A330-200 wide-body planes. The Boeing and Airbus orders announced yesterday were reported in The Wall Street Journal on Tuesday.
Shares of Boeing shares fell 50 cents, to $80.75. The shares rose to a record $83.625 on Feb. 23.
"There's a modest recovery under way," said Howard Rubel, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company. "The market is not as frenzied as in some previous recoveries, but it has tightened. It's not quite at the point where there's a shortage of aircraft, but it's approaching it."
Although deliveries by domestic and foreign manufacturers declined to 481 aircraft in 1995, compared with 522 in 1994, orders for new airplanes more than doubled to 714 in 1995, compared with 347 in 1994, Boeing said. It was the first time since 1990 that orders exceeded deliveries.
"Unlike the boom years of the late 80's, however, airlines today are focused on profitability -- not market share," Ms. Bethel of Boeing said. "We foresee rational new-airplane acquisitions, and continued efforts to enhance revenues and reduce costs."
The order from International Lease confirms the strength of the 777 in the market, analysts said. Questions about the jetliner's performance, raised in a letter from United Airlines to Boeing , were played down by officials of both companies. In the letter, which was disclosed in an article in The Wall Street Journal yesterday, Joseph O'Gorman, United's executive vice president of fleet operations, wrote that the reliability of the new plane is "a major disappointment."
Donna Mikov, a spokeswoman for Boeing, said yesterday that "We're obviously aggressively addressing these concerns. We understand the problems and they're being fixed."
She added that that the 777 had a reliability rate of 97.5 percent in 1995. "Our goal for 1996 is 98 percent," she said.
In a statement, Mr. O'Gorman of United Airlines, which is owned by the UAL Corporation, said yesterday: "The 777 is an excellent airplane; we just want to make it better. The 777 is outperforming all other new airplanes we've introduced into our fleet."
Analysts said airlines often used frank, even blunt language in their confidential correspondence with aircraft makers, and said that no concern raised in United's letter involved safety.
"If you looked in the files of any of the manufacturers you would find many letters like this," said Wolfgang Demisch, an analyst with BT Securities. "Nothing they are saying is safety- or flight-related -- it's niggles." He said that the 747-400, an upgrade rather than an entirely new airplane like the 777, had a lower reliability rate in its first year.
Though International Lease split its order between Boeing and Airbus, that is common for a leasing company, which must serve airlines of many different sizes and nationalities, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Life and Death Reports From a Chicago Project

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 6

 BODY:
At 16, LeAlan Jones is full of ambition and dreams of playing college football and pulling his family out of the ghetto.
But first he wants to go prison. 
 His uncle is already there, along with who-knows-how-many-other young men from LeAlan's hard-luck, no-job neighborhood on Chicago's South Side.
For many of LeAlan's peers, a stay in jail or prison has become a rite of passage. But LeAlan, a high school junior, only wants to deliver a message there. He gives motivational and anti-drug speeches for a social service agency, No Dope Express. He fits in these talks around homework, football practice and reporting about life and death in the inner city for National Public Radio.
LeAlan and his reporting partner, Lloyd Newman, 17, are part of the silent majority of urban America -- decent young people trying to do the right thing, even in places where the good as well as the bad often die young in the crossfire of the streets.
"It's easy to do wrong around here," Lloyd said the other day as they walked through their neighborhood. "It's easy to get caught up by mistake."
LeAlan nodded in agreement, and a sad shadow crossed his face, a face caught between chubby and lean, boyhood and manhood.
"All most people need is a push and they'll do right," he said. "But around here there aren't a lot of people pushing. They're too tired."
But three years ago, the two lifelong friends got a big push. Under the direction of a radio producer based in New York, David Isay, the boys wandered the streets of the South Side with a tape recorder and turned their travels into a 30-minute, award-winning documentary of their lives and families for National Public Radio. It was called "Ghetto Life 101."
Now, the teen-agers are putting the finishing touches on another project for N.P.R., the story behind the death of 5-year-old Eric Morse and the two boys -- ages 10 and 11 at the time -- who in 1994 dropped him to his death out of a 14th-floor window at the Ida B. Wells public housing development. In January, the two boys became the youngest in the nation to be sentenced to maximum-security juvenile prison. Mr. Isay is producing the show, with money from the Chicago Community Trust, a charitable group.
LeAlan and Lloyd did not have to go far to do their reporting for their piece, "Remorse: The 14 stories of Eric Morse," which is scheduled to be heard on March 21 at 4 P.M. Eastern standard time. Lloyd has spent his entire life in the Ida B. Wells project and LeAlan lives one block away. The teen-agers are like war correspondents who never get to leave the front.
"Around here there is so much killing that you got to harden yourself from within," LeAlan said. "If you don't, you'll be sobbing every day."
Lloyd, who looks more like 12 than 17 with his hairless face and his too-big-for-him coat, ticked off the most common ways to die in their world, and natural causes were not on the list.
"People get thrown out of windows, drowned, stabbed, shot," he said. "But a lot of that killing would stop if the Government would make it livable around here. We don't have no parks. The swings are broken. There's nothing for people to do. There's no fun. Life isn't worth living without some fun."
"That's where he landed," LeAlan said, pointing at the mud at the foot a 14-story building. "That's where Eric's world stopped forever."
Neither reporter claims to know why the two boys dropped Eric out of a window. Lloyd, who knew the older boy's family, said it was probably an accident, that they only wanted to scare the child. The police said the boys did it because Eric refused to steel candy for them. LeAlan and Lloyd said they did not believe that the candy was the only reason.
"Those boys probably didn't get enough love at home," LeAlan said. "That's probably the main reason all this happened."
In putting together their report, LeAlan and Lloyd walked up and down the building where Eric died and had plenty of doors shut in their faces, an experience common to even veteran reporters.
"People in the projects are suspicious," Lloyd says on the audiotape.
But they kept going back, and the result is a moving documentary of a world of sad children forced to grow up much too fast.
Among those interviewed was the younger brother of one of the boys who dropped Eric. They asked him whether he had ever stolen candy, and he said yes, "because I be hungry."
LeAlan and Lloyd climbed to the top of the building from which Eric was dropped and looked down. Le Alan asked Lloyd on the tape what would have gone through his mind as he had been falling 14 stories.
"I don't know," Lloyd responded. "I'd be thinking about how it is in heaven."
"Do you think they got a playground in heaven?" LeAlan asked.
LeAlan lives with his mother, June, and his grandparents in a worn-out row house. Lloyd lives with his two sisters, Diana, 23, Sophia, 22, and brother, Michael, 18, in another row house. Diana Newman has been in charge of the family since their mother died five years ago.
"It's real rough around here," Ms. Newman said. "We tell Lloyd there's no reason for him to join a gang because he has his family to love him. He listens. We're very proud of him."
Michael plays football and basketball for nearby Dunbar High School. Sports, he said, has keep him out of trouble. Like his brother and LeAlan, both of whom plan to pursue journalism after graduation, he hopes to go to college.
"My mother lived long enough to teach me right from wrong," he said as the boys and some friends sat around the kitchen table in the Newman home. "But I got more fears than hopes right now. I stay awake thinking about all the things that could happen to me."
"No, man," Lloyd said, "you got to put your dreams before your fears."
"Not around here," said Shemauro Gibbs, 18, a friend. "You can't be walking around here dreaming. You might not see the bullet coming your way."
Fears of violence and early death haunt these young people but they say the streets are worse now than they were when they were children or "shorties," like "the brothers who dropped Eric out of that window," LeAlan said.
Michael said he was more worried about politicians and their message. He said he was afraid that what little Government help poor neighborhoods now received would be cut off "because the Republicans already control Congress and they might get the White House, too."
"I'm studying politics real hard now," he said. "I'm going to vote this year for sure."
"I'm voting, too," Shemauro said. "I have to for my people."
"I wish I was old enough," Lloyd said.
LeAlan was quiet as his friends talked, and then the sad shadow crossed his face again.
"The only time young black men get on the news," he said, "is when they score a lot of points playing basketball or when they get arrested. That's not right and now that I'm a journalist I'm going do something about it. That's not a dream. That's a promise."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Sandoz and Ciba Of Switzerland to Merge
Sandoz and Ciba agreed to merge, subject to shareholder approval, forming a new company, Novartis, "based on the concept of a merger among equals."
The Swiss merger, which one analyst called "a stunning move," would create an entity with 4.4 percent of the global pharmaceuticals market, making it the world's second-largest drug company, after Britain's Glaxo and ahead of Merck. [Page A1.]
 
Murdoch Plans European Pay TV
Rupert Murdoch and his British Sky Broadcasting Group have joined with three of Europe's largest media groups -- Bertelsmann of Germany and Havas and Canal Plus of France -- in a $1 billion plan to offer digital pay television. [D5.]
 
Stock Prices Slump Broadly
After rising for three days, stock prices slumped on signs of slower economic growth. The Dow industrials fell 12.65 points, to 5,629.77, and the Nasdaq composite index slid 4.99 points, to 1,091.82. [D8.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities fell for the second straight day, as investor hopes of another rate cut continued to fade. [D15.]
 
Texas Instruments Says Chips Weak
Texas Instruments said prices for memory chips were falling because they were in oversupply with personal computer demand slowing. The report pounded semiconductor stocks, with Texas Instruments shares falling $2.75 each, to $47.625. [D8.]
 
I.B.M. to Raise Drive Output
I.B.M. said that it would spend $500 million over the next two years to increase its output of sophisticated hard disk drives. [D8.]
 
Even the Prosperous Worry
The Bucknell class of 1970 had great expectations, and for many, those expectations have been met. But even they have lost confidence in their jobs, their retirement, and, especially, in their children's future. [A1.]
 
House G.O.P. Quits Tort Plan
House Republicans dropped plans for a sweeping overhaul of the nation's civil litigation system, backing instead a narrower effort by Senate Republicans. [A1.]
 
A Sporting Chance for ITT
ITT may gain control of SportsChannel New York, which has cable TV rights to Mets, Islanders, Devils and Nets games. In 1994 ITT and Cablevision Systems jointly purchased Madison Square Garden, which already has the MSG Network. It telecasts games of the Yankees, Rangers and Knicks. [D5.]
 
Boeing Issues Rosy Forecast
In a rosy 20-year business forecast, Boeing said a recovery was under way in the commercial airplane industry and that it expected airlines would buy 15,900 planes worth $1.1 trillion over the next 20 years. [D6.]
 
Piper Jaffray Fined by N.A.S.D.
Piper Jaffray was fined $1.25 million by the N.A.S.D. for selling a mutual fund without disclosing fully that it had volatile mortgage-backed derivatives. [D3.]
 
Productivity Fell In Last Quarter
The productivity of American workers declined in the fourth quarter at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent as the hours workers spent on the job rose at a faster pace than their output of goods and services. For all of 1995, productivity rose 1.1 percent. [D2.]
 
A Campaign Worthy of P. T. Barnum
Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey is hailing its 1996 star, "Airiana the Arrow," in a $15 million campaign that could have been conceived by P. T. Barnum. Advertising. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Traditional Family Stabilized in the 90's, Study Suggests

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
After two decades of social pressures that caused many to fear that it might dissolve, the traditional American family is making a comeback in the 1990's, a Washington research group said today in issuing a profile of the country's population.
The report, by the Population Reference Bureau Inc., said increases in the number of two-parent households with children, decreases in the divorce rate and other changes suggested that the American family was stabilizing. 
 "We don't look and we don't function anything like we did 20 or 30 years ago," Carol J. De Vita, author of the report, said today at a news conference. "And it's true that the American family has undergone some very radical changes in the past 25 years. But what I want to emphasize is that the major changes in the family structure are probably passed."
The group is a private, nonprofit research organization that uses Census Bureau data and other information to periodically paint demographic portraits of the country.
Although it is highly respected and its former director of policy research, Martha Farnsworth Riche, is now director of the Census Bureau, some demographers and sociologists questioned the report, saying its conclusions were overly optimistic.
In the report, "The United States at Mid-Decade," Ms. De Vita said, the number of two-parent households with children increased by 700,000 from 1990 to 1995, reversing a 20-year decline. She also said that the divorce rate slowed to 20.5 divorces per 1,000 married women in 1994 from 23 divorces per 1,000 in 1980 and that the increase in the number of births to unmarried women slowed to a 2 percent annual average increase in the early 1990's, down from a 6 percent annual rise in the 1980's.
Ms. De Vita attributed these changes to the fact that the baby-boom generation, which makes up a third of the country's population, has entered middle age. After delaying marriage, and then often divorcing and marrying again, baby boomers are beginning to settle into the task of raising families.
"Middle age is the time of life when family responsibilities come to the fore," Ms. De Vita said.
But Reynolds Farley, a sociologist at the University of Michigan, said: "The numbers I have looked at don't show any reversal of these trends. There may be some moderation, but the overall trends remain the same."
Mr. Farley said, for example, that the continuing increase in the nation's population means that there are more and more people reaching marriage age. That, he said, would account for the increase in the numbers of two-parent families. But he added that the decline in the percentage of two-parent families as a proportion of all households had not changed.
While the report painted an optimistic outlook for the traditional American family, it also provided evidence of other recent economic and demographic trends that have fueled anxiety in some segments of the population and helped propel the Presidential candidacy of politicians like Patrick J. Buchanan.
While the report noted that the number of legal immigrants was declining, it said 9 percent of the population was born in a foreign country, the highest level of foreign-born residents since the end of World War II.
The report also indicated that nearly 32 million people spoke a language at home other than English, a 40 percent increase from 1980.
Moreover, the report noted that as a result of higher birth rates and immigration, the country's minority population grew by 15 percent in the first five years of the decade, compared with 3 percent in the non-Hispanic white population. The Hispanic population grew by 20 percent, Asian 31 percent and black 8 percent.
Indeed, the report said that if current trends in immigration and fertility continued, the minority population and the non-Hispanic white population should be roughly equal by the middle of the next century.
In addition, the report showed that while the country had pulled out of recession, median household income was 6 percent below its 1989 pre-recession peak, though it acknowleged that the measurements of income included only cash wages and not benefits like health insurance provided by employers.
The report is also striking in its depiction of the continued increase in the overall America population. The United States is the fastest growing country in the industrialized world, the study says. Fueled by immigration and a mini-baby boom as the baby-boom generation has had children, the United States grew by an annual rate of 1 percent in the first half of the 1990's, up slightly from the 0.9 percent growth in the 80's.
In contrast, Western Europe grew by an average of 0.4 percent annually and Japan's by 0.3 percent. At this rate, the United States population of 262.8 million could reach 300 million by 2010 and nearly 400 million by the middle of the next century.

HEADLINE: House Panel Approves Bill Easing Rules On Insurance

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
A House committee today approved legislation that would make it easier for small employers to band together and buy health insurance, but the bill would allow such health plans to avoid all state insurance regulation.
The vote, in the Committee on Economic and Educational Opportunities, followed party lines. Twenty-four Republicans voted for the bill and 18 Democrats opposed it, saying it would undermine state efforts to adopt more comprehensive health insurance measures. 
 The committee chairman, Representative Bill Goodling, Republican of Pennsylvania, said the bill could make it possible for half of the nation's 40 million uninsured to obtain coverage through employers.
"Members of a national association, such as the Chamber of Commerce or the National Federation of Independent Business, could join with other small businessmen to gain greater economies of scale and command greater clout in the health insurance marketplace," Mr. Goodling said.
Some trade associations help employers band together to buy health insurance for workers now. But Representative Harris W. Fawell, Republican of Illinois, chief sponsor of the bill, said it was difficult to arrange such coverage because regulations on benefits varied from state to state. Mr. Fawell said these requirements had raised costs to the point that many small employers decided not to offer health insurance.
Mr. Fawell's bill is one of several incremental health insurance measures put forward in Congress since the demise of President Clinton's plan to guarantee coverage for all Americans. Another measure, a bipartisan bill that would make it easier for people to retain insurance coverage when they change or lose jobs, is pending in the Senate.
The Fawell bill includes similar provisions, but goes further. Under Mr. Fawell's bill, "multiple-employer health plans" would be treated like big corporations that serve as their own insurers, paying claims from corporate assets. More than half of all employees in the United States now work for such self-insured companies. There is virtually no state regulation of their health plans, and a self-insured company is exempt from state taxes on insurance premiums.
The National Federation of Independent Business, representing 600,000 small business owners, supports Mr. Fawell's bill. But Representative Major R. Owens, Democrat of Brooklyn, said Democrats had voted against it because it was "a phony piece of legislation designed to make it appear that Republicans are concerned about an issue when they are really not."
The National Governors' Association, the National Association of Insurance Commissioners and the National Conference of State Legislatures also criticized the bill, saying it would undermine state authority to regulate health insurance and would leave consumers with fewer protections. In a joint letter to Congress, the insurance commissioners and the state legislators said the bill "would hamper states from going further than the Federal standards."
Representative William L. Clay, Democrat of Missouri, said, "It's ironic that Republicans, who claim to be the protectors of states' rights, are usurping the power of states to regulate health insurance." State officials said the bill could deprive them of tax revenue used to finance coverage for people who cannot obtain affordable health insurance in the private market.
President Clinton, Democrats in both houses and many Republican senators support the Senate measure, sponsored by Senators Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, and Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts. Representative Marge Roukema, Republican of New Jersey, has introduced an identical bill in the House.
The House Democratic leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, said today that he and 170 other Democrats intended to sign up as co-sponsors of Mrs. Roukema's bill, which is also supported by many business and consumer groups.
Mrs. Roukema said her bill and Mr. Fawell's were not irreconcilable. "There can be a marriage of the best parts of the two," she said.
The measure approved today is one of many legislative initiatives that House Republicans want to tack onto the Kassebaum-Kennedy bill. They say they also intend to add provisions dealing with medical malpractice, antitrust law, medical savings accounts and tax deductions for health insurance costs of people who are self-employed.
Mr. Goodling recalled the failure of Mr. Clinton's health plan in 1994, saying: "That bill ultimately sank of its own weight. By trying to do too much, we ended up doing nothing at all."
Democrats said they feared that House Republicans would have a similar experience this year.

HEADLINE: Texas Instruments Cites Surplus of Computer Memory Chips

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: DALLAS, March 6

 BODY:
Texas Instruments Inc. said today that an oversupply of memory chips was hurting prices as demand for personal computers slowed.
As a result, growth in the worldwide semiconductor industry this year is likely to be less than expected, the company said at its annual meeting here with analysts. 
 "Business is just not good," said Tom Kurlak, an analyst with Merrill Lynch who attended the meeting.
The gloomy assessment followed price slashing by top United States computer makers and Micron Technology's halting of construction of a Utah chip plant until demand improved.
The Texas Instrument news pounded semiconductor stocks. The company's shares fell $2.75 each, to $47.625. Micron's share price fell $2, to $29.125, and shares of the Intel Corporation lost $2.125, to $53.25.
Texas Instruments, which reported a 27 percent sales rise last year to $13.1 billion, expects the increase to level off at about 20 percent during the next several years, Bill Aylesworth, the company's chief financial officer, said. The company derives about $2 billion of annual revenue from dynamic random-access memory chips.
The company said the price of the benchmark four-megabyte D-RAM dropped to between $6.50 and $7 a unit, from about $12 in December.
"People are going to have to rethink their numbers," said Daniel Niles, an analyst at Robertson Stephens Company.
Texas Instruments said that while current market conditions showed a slowdown in demand and prices, it was temporary and would turn around as the economy picked up in the second half. It said prices might rebound in the third quarter.
"The economy is weak right now, but we see a U.S. economy that will strengthen in the second half," said Vladi Catto, the company's chief economist.
Mr. Catto also predicted that over the next few years, the compound annual growth rate for personal computers and semiconductors would increase to 20 percent a year from the 15 percent average growth rate over the last 10 years.
The company expects the chip industry's sales to reach $350 billion by 2000, compared with $140 billion last year.
Texas Instruments itself expects to increase capital spending to $2.5 billion this year from $1.4 billion in 1995.
Memory prices have been steady over the last two years as demand outstripped supply. For that reason, Micron, Intel and other chip makers disclosed plans to add new capacity.
D-RAM's were in short supply last year because of the increasing amount of memory needed in personal computers to run multimedia applications and Microsoft's Windows 95 operating system.
However, Compaq Computer and I.B.M. have said that demand for personal computers from corporate customers is declining. They and others -- including Hewlett-Packard and Digital Equipment -- have slashed prices over the last few days.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Fall Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for the second straight day, as investor hopes of another rate cut by the Federal Reserve continued to fade on fears of more strong economic data that could lead to inflationary pressures.
Despite the widespread sentiment, there was little economic news on the calendar. The only official report yesterday was revised fourth-quarter productivity from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Market participants viewed the modest upward drift in wage pressures in the report as inflationary. 
 The 30-year bond dropped 30/32, to a price of 94 2/32 to yield 6.45 percent, up from 6.38 percent on Tuesday and its highest level in nearly a week. For a bondholder it meant a loss of almost $10 for every $1,000 of bonds held.
Josh Stiles, senior bond strategist at IDEA, a British financial consulting firm, said, "It appears that a modest upward drift in wages is running above the 2.7 percent Consumer Price Index year-over-year, unit labor costs of 3.3 percent year-over-year, average hourly earnings of 3.5 percent and the employment costs index of 2.9 percent year-over-year, which suggest that further C.P.I. declines are not likely in 1996." Rather, he said, the bias is to inch up.
"This trend," Mr. Stiles said, combined with "the strong car sales and factory order resiliency makes the case for a March easing by the Fed even weaker, barring a very weak payroll report. Our forecast is for a gain of 400,000.
"We expect first-quarter G.D.P. will be about 2 percent, which is above the early consensus of about 1 to 1.50 percent, with the yield spread between a two-year maturity and the Federal funds rate of 5.25 percent gradually widening," he said. "The yield for the 30-year bond is more likely to see 6.70 percent before re-establishing a trading range that would keep the yield between 6 percent and 6.25 percent."
Another factor that encouraged market participants to adjust positions yesterday rather than take new ones was the February employment report due out tomorrow. However much of the damage had already been done overnight before the day session got going, traders said.
"Traders might refer to the price chart formation today as looking like a bowling ball going down the stairs," James Hale, a fixed-income analyst with MMS International, San Francisco, said. "There have been plenty of bounces, but the general direction is pretty clear."
Yesterday states, cities and agencies sold about $1 billion in new debt securities through negotiated and competitive bidding, as municipal bond prices fell on concern that even more issues are being made ready for sale. According to The Bond Buyer's most recent count, about $7.4 billion of new bonds will be up for sale next month.
Should the jobs report tomorrow show fewer new jobs than expected, bonds could gain in price. That would lower the yield on Treasury bonds, which helps determine rates on everything from mortgages to corporate and municipal borrowing.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Prospect of Cut in German Rates Lifts Dollar Across-the-Board

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar edged up against leading currencies yesterday, finding strength against the German mark on news that suggested that German interest rates might come down.
"The only real news of the day, which sort of got muddled by some profit taking earlier in the day, was the German employment report," said Randolph Donney, director of research at Pegasus Econometric Group. 
 News that Germany's unemployment rate rose in February to 10.3 percent from 10.1 percent may prompt the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, to cut interest rates to stimulate growth, traders said.
Lower interest rates generally hurt currencies as investors tend to put their money elsewhere seeking a higher rate of return.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar rose to 105.40 Japanese yen from 105.25 yen on Tuesday. The dollar was changing hands at 1.4770 marks, up from 1.4758 marks. The British pound slipped to $1.5295 from $1.5300.
Traders were focused on profit taking from overnight gains abroad and gave little notice to the German employment report until afternoon New York trading, Mr. Donney said.
The only other news that aided the dollar against European currencies was a decision by Denmark to lower interest rates, supporting the argument that some other key European rates may be coming down.
Against the yen, the dollar advanced largely as a result of technical factors, particularly so-called cross-trading between the yen and mark, which can affect dollar-yen transactions. Generally positive sentiment about the dollar also helped it advance against the Japanese currency.
Many market participants continued to be reluctant to make any large bets on the dollar before tomorrow's release of the United States employment report for February.

HEADLINE: U.S. Productivity Level Fell 0.5% in the Fourth Quarter

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
The productivity of American workers declined in the fourth quarter as the hours they spent on the job increased at a faster pace than their output of goods and services, the Government reported today.
Nonfarm productivity -- a measure of the time, effort and cost of providing goods and services -- declined at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter, reversing much of the third quarter's increase of 1.7 percent. The third-quarter gain was previously reported as 1.4 percent. For all of 1995, productivity rose 1.1 percent, compared with a gain of five-tenths of 1 percent the previous year, the Labor Department said. It was the largest annual increase since 1992, when productivity advanced 3.2 percent. 
 "Going into periods of weaker growth, productivity falls because demand slackens in the economy, yet it takes time for businesses to respond by laying off people," Raymond Stone, managing director of Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J., said before today's report.
Slower growth may already be prompting some companies to step up job cuts, suggesting future improvement in productivity figures. The number of planned layoffs announced by American employers rose 9.3 percent in February from a year earlier, according to a survey released today by Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., a Chicago employment firm.
If the economy rebounds later this year, so will productivity, analysts said. "Associated with a pickup in economic activity in the second half, productivity will advance," said Robert Barbera, co-chairman of Capital Investments International Inc. in New York.
Today's report showed that manufacturing productivity rose 2.7 percent in the fourth quarter and 3.7 percent in all of 1995.
Unit labor costs, which make up about two-thirds of American business costs, rose 3.5 percent in the fourth quarter, after a 2.5 percent rise in the third quarter. For all of 1995, unit labor costs rose 2.5 percent.
Hourly wages adjusted for inflation, meanwhile, increased six-tenths of 1 percent, lower than the 2.2 percent gain in the previous quarter. And the implicit price deflator, a measure of price increases tied to the productivity report, rose just nine-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter, after a 1.8 percent rise in the previous quarter.
Worker output advanced by 1.1 percent, after posting a 4.7 percent gain in the third quarter.
Today's figures reflected the Government's new weighted measure of output, which makes economic growth and productivity gains look lower than under the old system.
Using the old method for gauging productivity and growth in economic output, the Government was locked into a system of comparing price changes with products from a base year -- even if products vastly changed over the years.
Though the revised statistics cast doubt on the existence of a "productivity revolution" caused by increased use of computers and pared-down work forces, most analysts are confident technology and layoffs have contributed to efficiency.
Analysts point to surging corporate profits. Because competition and consumers have made it hard to raise prices, only better use of labor and raw materials could be responsible for higher profit margins, they say.

Southwestern Public Service Co., Amarillo, Tex., is selling $60 million of first-mortgage bonds due in 2006 through Dillon, Read & Co. The bonds are priced at 99.94 to yield 6.508 percent. The issue is rated Aa2 by Moody's and AA by both S.& P. and Duff & Phelps.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Prices Go Over $20 a Barrel As Crude Stockpiles Fall in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices surged above $20 a barrel yesterday after a report showed that stockpiles in the United States had fallen to their lowest levels since an oil crisis caused gasoline rationing in 1977.
Heating oil and unleaded gasoline prices also rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange. On other commodities markets, corn and soybean prices advanced after Russia lifted a ban on American chicken imports. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities rose 0.73 point, to 243.90, its first gain in six sessions. 
 After the market closed on Tuesday, the American Petroleum Institute reported that crude stocks fell 2.7 million barrels last week to 297.5 million -- the lowest American stockpile since mid-1977, when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries nearly doubled the price of oil.
Most traders had expected stocks to rise by two million barrels.
"We're in a squeaky-tight stock situation," said Tim Evans, an analyst with the Pegasus Econometric Group in New York, "and consumers are going to feel it."
Crude oil for April delivery rose 65 cents, to $20.19, the highest price for the contract closest to delivery since Feb. 20. The April heating oil contract rose 1.22 cents, to 54.22 cents a gallon, and April unleaded gasoline rose 0.66 cent, to 59.75 cents a gallon.
American oil refiners have been importing less oil this year and refining for deliveries just in time for use in a bid to cut storage costs.
Corn and soybeans were bolstered after Vice President Al Gore announced that Russia had decided against banning chicken imports from the United States. The ban was to begin March 19. Corn and soybean meal are used in chicken feed.
Traders ignored announcements later in the day that Tyson Foods and Hudson Foods would hold to plans to cut production by 7 percent. Pilgrim's Pride also said it would keep an 8.5 percent production cut.
Most traders viewed the announcements as efforts by the nation's largest chicken processors to force grain and soybean prices lower, said Victor Lespinasse, an analyst with Dean Witter, Discover & Company.
"It's to their advantage right now not to talk prices up, and nobody is taking what they say at face value," he said.
Corn prices have run up to 15-year highs recently as supply nears 22-year lows. May corn rose 1 cent, to $3.81 a bushel, and May soybeans rose 3 cents, to $7.265 a bushel.

HEADLINE: Piper Jaffray Is Fined Over Data on Fund

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The National Association of Securities Dealers fined the Piper Jaffray Companies $1.25 million yesterday, saying that the firm had sold a mutual fund without fully informing investors that it contained volatile mortgage-backed derivatives.
The settlement, one of the largest in the association's history, comes months after Piper paid $67.5 million to settle lawsuits brought by investors who had contended they were misled about the risks of the fund, Institutional Government Income Portfolio. It was the largest settlement ever disclosed between a mutual fund company and its investors. 
 Piper also agreed to hire an independent consultant to review its mutual fund sales practices. The firm agreed to the fine and disciplinary action without admitting wrongdoing.
Piper, based in Minneapolis, also reached an agreement with the Minnesota Commerce Department, which investigated the fund's marketing. That brought the total to $1.9 million, which included fines, charitable contributions and reimbursement for investigation costs.
The N.A.S.D. said that between 1991 and 1994, Piper recommended and sold the Piper Jaffray Institutional Government Income Portfolio without telling clients, or disclosing in its advertising and sales literature, that the holdings in mortgage-backed derivatives, and its use of leverage, increased the riskiness of the portfolio.
The fund was begun in 1988 and at first invested primarily in Treasury bonds. Beginning in 1991, it increased its purchases of interest-rate-sensitive mortgage-backed derivatives, the association said.
Those notes gained value in 1993, making the fund one of the top short-term government funds.
As the returns of the fund increased, so did its riskiness as an investment, the association said, and Piper failed to give investors adequate warning about the increased risks. By 1993, derivatives represented 51 percent of the market value of the portfolio.
When interest rates began to rise in early 1994, the value of the fund's mortgage-backed bonds eroded. The fund lost 30 percent of its value in 1994.
