HEADLINE: Market Place;
Money Keeps Pouring Into Market Funds

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Despite the heavy volatility in the stock and bond markets in February, mutual fund investors remained unshaken, continuing to pour plenty of fresh cash into funds investing here and abroad, according to estimates released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute.
Equity mutual funds recorded an estimated $21 billion of net inflows in February, down from $28.9 billion in January but still the second-largest monthly total ever. The combined $50 billion of net inflows to equity mutual funds in the first two months of this year exceeds by 30 percent the net cash invested in stock funds in all of 1991. 
 Bond funds, meanwhile, recorded estimated net inflows of $1 billion last month. While that figure was down from $4.4 billion in January, it was the eighth consecutive month in which bond funds took in more money from investors than they paid out -- particularly impressive in a month in which long-term interest rates jumped four-tenths of a percentage point, to 6.47 percent.
While mutual fund investors remain steadfast, the stock and bond markets continued the wandering pace they have followed for much of the last four weeks. Stock and bond prices both fell yesterday as investors looked ahead nervously to tomorrow's monthly report of employment statistics, perhaps the single set of data that investors watch most closely for clues about the strength of the economy.
The price of the 30-year Treasury fell nearly a point, and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.45 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.65 points, to 5,629.77, its first decline after three consecutive gains. General weakness in technology stocks pushed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index down 3.79 points, to 652.00. [Page D8.]
The amount of cash flowing into mutual funds was expected to fall in February from January's extraordinary inflows, because the first month of the year benefits from annual payments to corporate retirement plans and, in many cases, company distributions of yearly bonus checks.
But the fact that last month's inflows to stock funds were the second largest ever confirms that United States investors have maintained an abiding faith in the long-term strength of the market.
To longtime watchers of investment trends, the monthly cash flow data from the Investment Company Institute have taken on an ethereal quality. "Wow!," exclaimed James W. Paulsen, senior managing director of Investors Management Group, a Des Moines investment adviser and money manager. "$50 billion in two months is unheard of."
Indeed, after being repeatedly bombarded with the message that they might not be saving enough for the future, Americans have embraced savings plans so far this year. At the FMR Corporation's Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund company, sales of individual retirement accounts are 14 times stronger so far this year than in the first two months of 1995, said Robyn Tice, a spokeswoman.
In addition, net inflows to all types of retirement accounts -- I.R.A.'s and 401(k) and 403(b) accounts -- are up more than 70 percent in the first two months of 1996 over a similar period last year, she said. Retirement programs account for about half of all new mutual fund sales at Fidelity.
That behavior is even more impressive considering that much of that money was invested as the stock and bond markets gyrated wildly. The Dow Jones industrial average, for example, gained roughly 200 points in the first two weeks of February, then fell 150 points in the next week. That was followed by a further 150-point gain and another loss of more than 100 points.
The bond market, meanwhile, hardly provided a refuge from the turmoil. Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services, which also tracks mutual fund flows, noted that several bond sectors recorded net outflows of cash in the last half of February, including high-yield funds, international bond funds and those specializing in mortgage-backed securities.
Investors continued to shuttle some money overseas, where foreign equity markets have, in general, been tracking or outperforming their American counterparts. Inflows to global and international stock funds in February fell slightly from the previous month, said John Rea, chief economist at the institute, which was their biggest month of inflows in two years.
The estimates reported yesterday by the Investment Company Institute are based on a survey of long-term funds that account for about 97 percent of long-term mutual fund assets. Last month, the first under the institute's new format of twice-monthly data release, the trade group's estimates fell 21 percent short of the actual totals, which are reported approximately four weeks after the end of each month.

HEADLINE: Lord Jay, 88, Laborite Gadfly Who Defied Leaders on Europe

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Lord Jay, an iconoclastic British Labor politician and former Cabinet officer who was such a fierce opponent of economic ties with Europe that he railed against Britain's entry into the Common Market even as his own Prime Minister, Harold Wilson, was aggressively campaigning for membership, died yesterday at his home in Oxfordshire. He was 88. Known as Douglas Jay until he received a life peerage in 1987, Lord Jay was an Oxford-trained economist who worked for The Economist and other publications before entering politics.
A protege of Clement Atlee, Lord Jay served as his personal assistant when Mr. Atlee became Prime Minister in the Labor sweep of 1945. 
 The next year, at Mr. Atlee's urging, he resigned and won a by-election to the House of Commons from the North Battersea area of central London, a traditionally safe Labor seat he held until his retirement in 1983.
He held two Cabinet posts in the Atlee Government, Economic Secretary and Financial Secretary. Then, after the Conservatives regained power in 1951, he spent 13 years in vocal opposition, becoming closely allied with Hugh Gaitskell, an old school chum who was the leader of the Labor Party until his death.
When Labor returned to office under Wilson in 1964, Lord Jay, who had served in the post in the shadow government, was made Chairman of the Board of Trade, the rough equivalent of the American Secretary of Commerce.
If the Prime Minister was dismayed when Lord Jay spoke out openly and sometimes scathingly against British membership in the Common Market, doing so even on one occasion when Mr. Wilson was on a tour of Europe to promote the idea, he should not have been surprised.
Never one to keep his views to himself, Lord Jay had shocked many of the Labor faithful in 1959, after the party's third successive electoral defeat, when he made an impassioned plea for Labor to drop its traditional support for nationalization of industry and even to change its name to the Democrat Social Party.
Mr. Wilson tolerated his public dissent on the Common Market, at least for a while. But he was abruptly dismissed in 1967 on the ostensible ground that he had turned 60.
Lord Jay was a brisk and highly efficient administrator who generally limited appointments to 30 minutes on the ground that no business should take longer than that. And for all his aversion to international travel, in 1964 he became the first senior government official to visit Communist China.
A tall, gaunt figure in rumpled clothes, he was also something of a darling to the British press, an endearing eccentric of such renowned frugality -- or xenophobia -- that when required to attend meetings in Paris he carried a good English sandwich in a plastic bag rather than submit to French cuisine.
During his years in the Cabinet, Lord Jay's nondescript clothes and ascetic ways were portrayed in stark contrast to the trendy tastes of his twin teen-age daughters, Helen and Catherine, who were photographed so often in Mary Quant miniskirts and Courreges boots they seemed to be the ultimate incarnations of Carnaby Street chic.
The son of a lawyer who gave up his practice to do social work in the East End of London, Lord Jay, who traced his own social leanings to his first sight as a toddler of poor children in tatters, was deeply committed to his version of the socialist ideal.
"Socialists believe in equality as an end," he once wrote. "Any and every human being has as much right as anyone else to whatever gives value to human life."
He was also inconoclastic in his private life. Having told his fiancee that he regarded monogamy as a sin, he proceeded to live up to his own marital ideals during a 39-year-marriage that didn't lead to divorce until 1972, the year he married his secretary, Mary Lavinia Thomas.
In addition to his wife and daughters, he is survived by two sons: Peter, who was Ambassador to the United States in the 1960's, and Martin; and 14 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Maputo Elephant Reserve Journal;
Thinking Big ($800 Million) to Rescue Big Game

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: MAPUTO ELEPHANT RESERVE, Mozambique, March 1

 BODY:
In this remote and beautiful corner of the world, representatives of a conservative Louisiana millionaire used to hand American cash to a rebel movement so cruel that it kidnapped children for its assassination squads.
Today, a representative of the same man is handing children little American and Mozambican flags. Mozambique's flag is the only one in the world with an AK-47 assault rifle on it, and the socialist Government the businessman was trying to undermine won the war and the elections two years ago. 
 But that's ancient history. Now James Ulysses Blanchard 3d wants to build an $800 million ecotourist's paradise here in this wilderness of lakes and savannas edged by 60 miles of crystalline sands and Caribbean-blue waters. His plans include a floating casino, thatched game lodges perched high over watering holes, a marina, a golf course with hippos in the water hazards, and an antique steam train that would pull rolling hotels made of Orient-Express-style sleeping cars through herds of noble elephants and leaping antelope.
He may succeed in building his Disney World in the bush. Biologists consulted by the Frelimo Government, his old foe, seem favorably inclined toward his plans for the 4,000-square-mile area. And it may be the only way to save the ecosystem, which the 1992 Rio summit conference on biodiversity named as one of the 200 most remarkable on the planet.
Mozambique's unspoiled coastline, as long as the stretch from Seattle to San Diego, was once the playground for generations of white Rhodesians and South Africans.
Now, after 17 years of destructive civil war, this desperately poor country is helpless to resist the hordes rushing in to exploit its natural wealth and beauty: South African tourists zipping up the beach in Land Rovers, running over the nests of leatherback turtles and plundering the reefs of coral and tropical fish. Dirt-poor war refugees sneaking back in to slash and burn tiny cornfields out of the rare vegetation. Mozambican military officers arrogantly hunting the reserve's last few elephants.
"My budget is $50,000 U.S.," said Mateus Chambal, the director of the elephant reserve, who lives in a half-burned-out compound in the middle of the park and whose near-dead Land Rover leaks water he draws by hand from a well. "It came from American and European organizations because of the biodiversity conference, and it will run out in June. If we don't get more, we will have to abandon the reserve."
The irreplaceable flora of the park is largely intact. But its mega-fauna suffered badly during the war between Frelimo and Renamo. About 500 of the 600 elephants are dead. All the rhino were poached, One local environmentalist claims to have seen the last one mowed down in the dunes by a Cuban helicopter, which then swooped in to saw off the horn. "Pretty much everything else went into people's pots," said Donald Beswick, who runs the Mozambique desk for the Endangered Wildlife Trust. The trust, an environmental organization, doesn't outright endorse the Blanchard plan "but we certainly aren't anti-it," Mr. Beswick said.
Animals are the first step in the five-year plan, which was drawn up by the same consultants who created the Pilanesberg wildlife reserve and Sun City casino complex 100 miles from Johannesburg. The $9 million budget for game restoration reads like a cargo manifest for Noah's Ark: 500 zebras at $500 each plus 30 white rhinos at $21,800 apiece, shipping included, in Year 1, plus assorted giraffes, wildebeest and other animals. In Year 2, the first predators, 10 brown hyena, are to be introduced.
Not until Year 4 does the item that worries the locals appear -- 25 lions at $4,070 apiece. The footnotes remind potential investors that endangered species, including wild dogs and black rhinos (at $58,000 apiece), may be donated, which would save money.
John R. Perrott, the project's general manager in Mozambique, actually wants the first restocking to be of crocodiles in the Maputo River, the area's western boundary. "Great game scouts," he says "Real tough on poachers."
Mr. Perrott, a burly former pipeline engineer and big-game hunter who has worked everywhere from Alaska to Tanzania, has some ideas even more radical than the plan's. He wants to import the last remaining Bushmen from the Kalahari Desert.
"People make fun of me for that," he says. "But I'm not talking about just a tourist attraction. I say let the little guys in and let them hunt. Their homeland in Botswana is being wiped out by cattle fences."
Mr. Blanchard foresees raising the $800 million over at least five years, at first from investors he knows and millionaires who want private homes inside a Big Five game park. Then he hopes to offer stock to emerging market funds and attract hotel chains like Club Med and Sheraton who see potential in a "beast and beach" package. The displaced subsistence farmers and fishermen -- who probably number fewer than 10,000 -- will also get shares of the corporation and first crack at the 12,000 projected jobs as game trackers, construction laborers, chambermaids and the like.
The architect of all this, Mr. Blanchard, is a 52-year-old man of many interests -- prominent among them gold, guns and right-wing politics -- and of unquestionable daring. He buzzed President Richard Nixon's 1973 inauguration in a Cessna trailing a "Legalize Gold" banner. "That was fun," he says. "They flew jets up to chase us out."
The author of "Confessions of a Gold Bug" made his fortune dealing first in gold coins he bought at $35 an ounce, then in newsletters, $1,000-a-head conferences and mutual funds appealing to the kind of investors who gravitate toward hard assets on the assumption that the world is going to hell. Despite being in a wheelchair since a teen-age car accident, he took his 8-year-old son, Anthem (named after the Ayn Rand novel loved by libertarians), on a weeklong flying trip to the North Pole.
He was also part of the circle of rich Americans who helped Oliver North funnel aid to guerrillas they believed were fighting Communism everywhere from Afghanistan to Nicaragua to Angola. Mr. Blanchard supported the Renamo rebels in Mozambique, not with guns, he says, but with radios, medical supplies and cash.
Even though Renamo fought a dirty war, killing whole villages and destroying everything that kept the economy afloat, from power lines to cashew nut farms, Mr. Blanchard defends his support for the rebels. Renamo's leader, Afonso Dhlakama, he said "was a Christian-educated guy in the bush who believed in democracy and anti-Communism and free-market capitalism."
"He was reading a life of George Washington when I met him."
But above all else, Mr. Blanchard is a salesman. In 1991, Forbes magazine cited the Blanchard mutual fund family as an example of funds that did only middling well, often under-performing the market, but made money charging high fees, much of which was spent on direct mail marketing.
"That's the key to this," said Mr. Perrott, who attended several of Mr. Blanchard's investment conferences before meeting him on the North Pole trip. "Jim's got the greatest mailing list in the world."

HEADLINE: U.S. Finds China Guilty of Wide Rights Abuses

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration issued its annual human rights report today, declaring China guilty of "widespread and well-documented human rights abuses," and announced that the United States would again co-sponsor a critical resolution on China at the coming meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva.
The State Department had held out the possibility that better Chinese behavior would be rewarded at the Geneva meeting, which convenes on March 18. But China's human rights record has worsened rather than improved, the Administration said today, making public its annual report on human rights in 194 countries around the world. 
 China has been guilty of human rights abuses including torture, arbitrary detention, coercive family-planning practices and organ transplants from executed prisoners, the report said. Toward the end of 1995, it said, "almost all public dissent against the central authorities was silenced."
In its overview, the report implicitly challenged the Clinton Administration's strategy, supported by many business interests, of strengthening economic ties with China regardless of Beijing's human rights record.
"The experience of China in the past few years demonstrates that while economic growth, trade and social mobility create an improved standard of living, they cannot by themselves bring about greater respect for human rights in the absence of a willingness by political authorities to abide by the fundamental international norms," the report said.
Senior officials were concerned about the release of this sensitive report, delayed because of the Government shutdown over the budget, as they try to improve a difficult relationship with Beijing. In recent months the United States has accused China of violating agreements on the spread of nuclear and missile weapons, of trying to intimidate Taiwanese voters who are electing a President on March 23 and of breaking its pledge to crack down on the flagrant pirating of American music, videos and computer software.
A senior Chinese Foreign Ministry official, Liu Huaqiu, is now in Washington for talks with Secretary of State Warren Christopher, the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, and other officials charged with finding a consistent policy toward China.
Despite the strong language in today's report, human rights advocates remain critical of Administration policy. Mike Jendrzejczyk, Washington director of Human Rights Watch Asia, said: "Overall it is an accurate, hard-hitting report, and probably more critical than last year."
"But it underlines the glaring disparity between the Administration's analysis and its policy," he added, calling the overall approach too soft on China.
Although the United States will co-sponsor the human rights resolution in Geneva, Mr. Jendrzejczyk said, the Chinese are pushing Washington not to lobby hard for the resolution, which could lead to its easy defeat when a vote comes in late April. Even John Shattuck, the Assistant Secretary of State for Democracy, Human Rights and Labor who is in charge of compiling these reports, said today the American vote in Geneva would depend on Chinese behavior at the time.
While saying little that American officials have not regularly discussed, these annual human rights reports carry the weight of an American political judgment that many countries, especially in Asia, reject as hypocritical.
In the report Russia was criticized for abuses of human rights in its effort to put down an armed revolt in Chechnya.
The Administration said abuses had decreased in Turkey and in Israel, where the redeployment of most Israeli troops from large areas of the West Bank and Gaza Strip had reduced the incidents of abuse. In Turkey, however, the improvement came against "a continuing pattern" of abuses, including restrictions on expression, torture and excessive use of force against the Kurdish population in the battle against terrorism. Similarly, Egypt was criticized for excessive force, including torture and extrajudicial killings, in its campaign against Islamic militants.
There were "familiar patterns of abuse" in countries like Mexico, Saudi Arabia, Colombia, Indonesia and countries in crisis, like North Korea and the Sudan, the department said.
Over the last 20 years, Mr. Christopher said, the reports also "tell a vivid story of how much the world has changed."
Latin America, he noted, had greatly improved, with a strong movement toward democratization throughout the hemisphere. But displaying how the reports are used for current political purposes, Mr. Christopher sharply criticized Cuba for stifling dissent and shooting down civilian airplanes. He also touched on other countries that he called "rogue states that possess the greatest threat to America's security -- states like Iran, Iraq and Libya -- that are among the greatest violators of human rights." And he mentioned Nigeria and Burma as abusers of human rights as well as protectors of the drug trade.
As the State Department focused today on human rights, Mr. Lake, the national security adviser, gave a speech at George Washington University about America's security challenges in a post-cold war world.
While listing the promotion and defense of democracy, "which enhances our security and the spread of our values," Mr. Lake spent little of his speech discussing human rights. Instead, following the new tone of a Clinton Administration encouraged by its relatively successful use of the American military in Haiti and Bosnia, Mr. Lake concentrated on "the use of force" and "the example of our power," in addition to "the power of our example."
"Until human nature changes," Mr. Lake said, "power and force will remain at the heart of international relations."

HEADLINE: THE DOWNSIZING OF AMERICA;
For Bucknell's Class of '96, Pressure to Focus, and Fast

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: LEWISBURG, Pa.

 BODY:
Every generation has its pressure cooker. For the Bucknell class of 1970, it was Vietnam and the draft. Lives and goals were transformed as men sought escape from an increasingly unpopular war, or dealt with the prospect of fighting in it.
But while many in the class of 1970 had a hard time even thinking about plans and goals in those chaotic times, the class of 1996 faces the opposite problem: how to avoid being swallowed alive by premature certainty. 
 At Bucknell today, corporate recruiters connect with sophomores and even freshmen, encouraging students -- or pushing them -- to identify goals earlier than the class of 1970 ever imagined. Anxious parents preach practicality. "Focus," as a noun and a verb, sprinkles conversation after conversation, like an early line on one's state of grace, a mark of success or failure to come.
Priscilla Stack is a bright, articulate 21-year-old psychology major from Mendham, N.J., who is distinctly lacking in focus. In 1996, it would seem, that is a serious problem.
There is pressure all around her, she complains, to choose and commit. It comes from friends, from parents, from potential employers, all of them beating the same maddening drum: competition is everywhere. You must dive in and start swimming. Stragglers lose. But what if you just don't know? And what if you choose wrong, plunging into a career only to find yourself trapped later in something you hate?
"Everyone has a direction," Ms. Stack said. "My dad is pounding on my head every time I talk to him. I feel like I have to make some kind of decision and pounce into it, but I just don't know."
Even taking time off to grow up a little more -- one of the great escape hatches for members of the class of 1970 -- seems closed to her. Future employers, she said, might think her a slacker.
"I know it's not good if you take time off after graduation," she said. "It doesn't look like you're very motivated."
For many students, pressures like that have profoundly changed the college experience. The old model of college as a broad intellectual adventure, they say, just does not make as much sense as it did a generation or two before.
"From what I see of the world in general, and especially for people my age, we're a little more realistic about our goals than our parents were," said Karim Abdul-Matin, 21, a biology major from Brooklyn who is planning on a medical career in New York City. "We can't become anything we want anymore. We have a set number of options."
Professors who have seen the shift of generations say the pressure to be practical is so overwhelming that for many students, even choosing a major has become an identity crisis: more than one in five people in the class of 1996 are pursuing two degrees at once.
"English because they love it, economics to get a job," said Marilyn R. Mumford, who has taught English at Bucknell since the late 1950's. This is hardly, she said, a sign of confusion.
"Students today are much more self-conscious," she explained. "They have to ask themselves more questions than the class of 1970 ever did, and I think they have a better total picture of the role of education in their lives."
Corporate recruiters are helping to sharpen that inquiry. Over the last five years, career placement officials here say, companies have dramatically stepped up their efforts, competing for the loyalties of students long before graduation.
An executive at Andersen Consulting, which has become one of the most aggressive of the new-style recruiters, said the change in approach arose from the same cost-cutting and efficiency pressures that drive the downsizing trend. According to Warren J. Dodge, a partner in the firm's New York office, Andersen recruits at fewer colleges than it used to, but focuses on its chosen schools with a new intensity -- grooming and developing potential employees beginning in their sophomore and freshman years, and, for promising minority candidates, even in high school. Mr. Dodge said Andersen tries not to pressure students. Other companies, he said, are the offenders.
"We want to be recognized not as a recruiter, but as a partner," he said.
One senior who is ready to be a partner is Mike Wickerham, a 22-year-old management major from Pittsburgh with a giant American flag on his wall and a firm belief that capitalism is a struggle in which he will prevail.
"I don't know where the country is going as a whole," he said. "But if there are only so many places, I'll have one of them."
Still, there are some rebels.
Alison Zampino would probably have more in common with the 1970 counterculture than with her own class. A psychology major from Belleville, N.J., with a pierced nose and a rough-edged style of dressing that owes nothing to J. Crew, Ms. Zampino, 21, said she is going to San Francisco after graduation with no job and no particular goal except to live in a place that she has heard is nice. She will worry about making a living when she gets there. She has no commitments at this point in her life, and she likes the feeling.
But this is not 1970, and Ms. Zampino is constantly on the defensive about her decision. Some of her classmates suggest that she is lazy, or too rich to care, or cluck that she is wasting her life, throwing away her main chance.
"They get this look," she said, "like, 'You just want to live?' "

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Freeing air routes to Japan will help travelers but won't be easy.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
AFTER an exchange of hard words last week, Tokyo and Washington apparently inched closer toward agreement on an expansion of air cargo flights across the Pacific. But that is just the overture to the main act: opening tightly restricted passenger service. American, Delta, Continental and Trans World Airlines, along with tourism businesses, have organized a group called Access U.S.-Japan to lobby their cause when President Clinton meets Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto in Tokyo next month.
A virtuous cause? Of course, said Clifford Winston, a specialist in transportation economics at the Brookings Institution. "The name of the game is serving more travelers at lower fares," he said. 
 But winning will not be simple. By linking the issue to a renegotiation of the treaty rights that United and Northwest now use to fly to Japan and beyond -- rights handed out in 1952, when America called the shots in non-Communist Asia -- Tokyo may be able to divide and conquer the American airline industry.
Under Washington's 44-year-old air pact with Tokyo, two American passenger carriers (Northwest and United, which replaced Pan Am) can fly as often as they like to Japan. They also have "beyond rights" -- the option to pick up passengers in Japan and fly them to third counties. This gives Northwest and United the ability to create hubs in Tokyo that offer one-stop links to the American mainland from a dozen Asian cities.
Washington negotiated limited access to Japan for other carriers in the 1980's, but both Delta and American are champing at the bit for more. And they have assembled an army of supporters from the Boston Chamber of Commerce to the Walt Disney Company.
The prize could be substantial. Dan Kasper of Coopers & Lybrand, the economic consultant for Access U.S.-Japan, estimates that a 25 percent cut in average fares could entice 4.8 million more people a year -- most of them Japanese tourists -- to make the long trip to Disneyland and other Sun Belt destinations.
American visitors to Japan would also get the benefits of the sort of competition that has made leisure travel within America the bargain of middle-class life. And since American carriers operate at lower cost than the Asian airlines, they would presumably hold their own in wide-open skies. So why is Washington apparently reluctant to press for more flights?
For one thing, Mr. Winston said, "the Department of Transportation worries about the airlines, not consumers." And since United and Northwest have no wish to rock the boat, Washington is playing politics as usual, balancing their influence against that of the new coalition.
A more justifiable concern is what Washington will have to give up to get Japan to approve more flights. Japan has made no secret of its opposition to the beyond rights of United and Northwest, which give them a cut of the juicy profits in the tightly controlled intra-Asian market. And it is very likely that Tokyo will insist on a reduction, or at least a guarantee against expansion of these flights, as payment for more competition between Japan and mainland American cities.
The question, then, is how to choose between second-best competitive outcomes when first-best is off the table. Michael E. Levine, executive vice president of Northwest, scoffs at the idea that a freer Japan-American mainland market would make a big dent in average fares. Revenues for a passenger mile, he said, are now only a few percent higher on these routes than on the hotly contested North Atlantic. In any case, he said, expansion of traffic into Japan will be severely limited for the foreseeable future by a shortage of runways at the two big international airports.
Mr. Kasper, by contrast, argues that beyond rights are not worth the fight since most of the beneficiaries are not Americans. And he speculates that longer-range versions of the new Boeing 777 will eventually make it practical for American carriers to bypass Japan and build new Asian hubs in, say, Hong Kong.
The most frustrating aspect of this issue is the anticompetitive reflex of the Japanese Government. Beyond rights, extracted at a time when Japan could not say no, obviously touch a nationalist nerve: Washington would react similarly if Air France proposed service from Chicago to Dallas. Fact is, though, the biggest losers from restraints on both Pacific and intra-Asian flights are the increasingly peripatetic Japanese.
One could even argue that the impulse of Tokyo to protect the Japanese carriers is myopic from its own business-first perspective. For just as Japanese competition eventually drove American auto makers to build better cars at lower cost, wide-open American competition would force Japanese airlines to prepare for the coming free-for-all in global air travel. But don't expect anyone to listen: In Japan, as in America, politics is the art of getting past the next election.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: ENDORSEMENT;
Kemp Supports Forbes in Bid to Salvage Flat-Tax Plan as an Issue in the Campaign

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 6

 BODY:
Never has the normally shy and retiring Steve Forbes come as close to gushing as he did here today when he stood shoulder-to-shoulder with Jack F. Kemp, the Republican Party luminary Mr. Forbes proudly described as "my guru-in-chief."
As Mr. Kemp endorsed Mr. Forbes's Presidential candidacy one day after Mr. Forbes took a drubbing in Tuesday's primaries -- six third-place finishes and a second-place finish in Connecticut -- the admiration flowed both ways between these pitchmen for the hope-growth-and-opportunity wing of the Republican Party. 
 "I want these issues to go forward and I believe Steve is a candidate of ideas and I'm endorsing those ideas here today," said Mr. Kemp, a former Congressman from Buffalo who was Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Bush Administration.
By Mr. Kemp's own admission, his better-late-than-never endorsement of Mr. Forbes's Presidential candidacy has as much to do with his determination to rescue the flat-tax message as it does with rescuing the messenger.
As he campaigns with Mr. Forbes in Florida, Texas, California and other states with big delegate prizes, Mr. Kemp argues that his role will be to help Mr. Forbes accomplish a goal they have in common: to salvage the flat tax idea and to present it at the San Diego convention in August as an idea whose time has come.
Their joint devotion to this mission was underscored by Mr. Forbes, who turned aside questions that he was about to drop out of the race because of his poor showing in Tuesday's balloting.
"A lot of you thought that I was going to be ready to throw in the towel," Mr. Forbes said today. "And I stated unequivocally the issues and principles of this campaign are bigger than a single candidate, bigger than the campaign, and therefore I was in for the duration."
The Forbes-Kemp alliance at this late stage of the compressed primary season suits the agendas of both men.
"They are trying to make sure the whole idea of a flat tax is not destroyed by Steve Forbes's candidacy," said Eddie Mahe, a Washington-based political consultant. "Jack wants the opportunity to go out and reframe the issue." He said Mr. Kemp was too good a politician to believe that his getting in this late would stop Bob Dole.
By coming to the aid of Mr. Forbes, even this late in the primary season game, Mr. Kemp can send Mr. Dole a message. Endorsing Mr. Forbes is a "symbolic gesture presumably driven by Jack's exasperation with the Dole campaign for attacking the flat tax," said William Kristol, the top editor at the conservative Weekly Standard and a former aide to Vice President Dan Quayle.
"What encouraged me to get into the campaign," Mr. Kemp said, "was the fear that the Republican Party was going into 96-slash-97 without the vigor, dynamism, growth, inclusiveness issue I believe Steve stands for."
The ties between Mr. Kemp and Mr. Forbes go beyond their shared views on supply-side economics. Both have been involved in Empower America, a conservative research organization in Washington that has served as a base for Mr. Kemp. In response to a question at their joint news conference today, Mr. Forbes said he had made a contribution to the group before entering the Presidential race that was "less than six figures." The group has been a vehicle for Mr. Kemp's views on urban policy and the economy and on influencing the direction of the Republican Party.

(Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Reject Myths;
On Trade With Japan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman (column, March 3) perpetuates myths about United States trade with Japan. First is that Japan is particularly closed to United States exporters. Japan has been the second-largest market for United States products after Canada. The United States runs a trade deficit with Japan because Americans like Japanese products. 
 A second myth is that the United States can solve its economic problems by focusing on trade balances with individual countries. While the overall trade balance is a concern, balance with a particular country is of no economic consequence.
A third myth is that trade protectionism affects trade balances. Given investment and savings, protection reduces exports by the same amount it reduces imports. Reducing the United States trade deficit requires the painful steps of raising United States savings or reducing investment.
 
JONATHAN EATON
Prof. of Economics, Boston U.
Boston, March 3, 1996

HEADLINE: Scenes of Rebirth at the Mall;
New Stores for Juniors Succeed by Moving Quickly

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Resnick, an asset management firm in Beverly Hills, Calif. "If you've made a mistake, mark it down and get it out of there. Merry-Go-Round kept denying this strategy and building inventory, and it killed them." The company went out of business this year.
Wet Seal/Contempo, a survivor of the 1980's shakeout, is trying to avoid the problems of Merry-Go-Round. Wet Seal started in 1962 as a bathing-suit company and became a big hit with teen-agers in the mid-1980's before falling on hard times in the early 1990's because of a bad mix of fashions and the troubled economy. 
 After losing more than $1 million in the fiscal year that ended in January 1995 -- and with the company's stock down to $6.75 from a peak of $18 in March 1991 -- Wet Seal executives say they concluded that to seize the juniors market, they needed to make faster decisions about fashion.
First, though, they moved to neutralize one of their main competitors by buying the 238-store Contempo Casuals chain last summer from the Neiman Marcus Group for $1 million in Wet Seal stock and renaming the company Wet Seal/Contempo. Analysts say that Neiman Marcus, which is owned by Harcourt General Inc., let the chain go cheaply because it wanted to unload it quickly and make sure it fell into the hands of a company dedicated to keeping it open.
Kathy Bronstein, who became Wet Seal/Contempo's chief executive in 1992, had instituted a policy of micro-managing inventory from the top. She was able to carry the policy through the following year, when Edward Thomas was hired as chief operating officer and she turned her attention away from the books and toward merchandising. "I sign every order that goes out of this company," she said. "Right down to the last earring.
"We'll take a runway trend and translate it quickly," she added. "We don't test and reorder. We buy and we move on to the next thing."
With the acquisition of Contempo, Wet Seal roughly tripled the number of its stores, to 364 in 34 states, and its revenues, to $103 million in the fiscal year that ended in January from $36 million a year earlier. In its fiscal third quarter, which ended in October 1995, earnings reached 15 cents a share, up from 2 cents a share in the comparable period a year earlier. The company's shares closed yesterday on Nasdaq at $10.625.
The acquisition increased the company's clout with suppliers, which is critical for fashion retailers who need such leverage to get large orders quickly as trends change. And they change fast. Cigarette pants, with their skinny legs, were all the rage last fall, for example, but yards had barely been raked before women switched en masse to low-slung hip huggers.
Another way that some companies are setting themselves apart from the crowd is in tailoring their products to local customs. The Rampage Clothing Company, a popular Southern California chain started in 1982 by Larry Hansel, a 21-year-old entrepreneur with a chunk of cash he had saved by detailing cars, plans to move into new markets this year, starting with New Jersey. But its guiding principle is to move with great deliberation, and with an eye toward matching its merchandise to regional tastes and traditions.
"In each market we learn about the psychographic mix," said Nancy Mamann, the marketing director for Rampage. "Like in Texas, those are meat-and-potato girls. We're not going to give them mini T-shirts."
Margaret A. Gilliam, a retail analyst at CS First Boston, said this might be a good way to increase profit margins. "In the 80's, there was no regional assortment," she said. "Everything was rubber-stamped. But if you assort yourself right for each market you're in, you'll be right on color and sizes and end up with fewer markdowns."
Rampage, like Wet Seal, is also trying to expand its customer base by aiming at slightly older women, those in their 20's and 30's. Executives at both companies said they did not think of the junior market as simply an age category.
For this approach to succeed, there needs to be a distinct fashion message to relay.
In the early 1990's, the fashion industry did not quite know what to do with an anti-fashion fashion called "grunge" that started in Seattle's coffee shops and soon captivated the nation's youth. In essence, it involved wearing old shirts, which appeared to have been reserved for painting the garage, on dinner dates. Seventh Avenue attempted to turn this trend into actual lines -- and few people bought them. The failure of that merchandising effort was a blow to the entire retail industry.
But finally, there are colors and specific looks to knock off.
Rampage and Wet Seal/Contempo stores feature things like coats that imitate the style of the Italian designer Gianni Versace and Gucci hip-huggers. There are also lots of outfits for career women, like a short black bolero jacket or a neatly fitted pistachio-green blouse. On a recent Sunday afternoon, lines were long at the cash register at a Rampage store in Beverly Hills, and big purple chairs were filled with fathers and boyfriends who sat sullenly in waiting, nodding occasional approval at a floral dress or a pair of loafers.
"It's young and inexpensive," said Daniella Akka, 20, a student. "The Limited is not as hip. Not as trendy."
Like Wet Seal, Rampage is expanding. It acquired the troubled Judy's chain for $2 million in 1993, adding 28 stores to its roster of 12 Rampage stores and six Friends shops, which offer Rampage miniskirts and trendy shirts for the pre-teen set. But it is growing more deliberately than many of the big chains that ran into trouble after adding a dozen stores in each market indiscriminately, year after year. It plans to have 65 stores by the end of the year.
Mr. Hansel, the founder, is a bit of a fanatic about moving the most up-to-date styles onto the racks, but in small enough numbers that they will sell quickly. Markdowns have been the downfall of the apparel trade over the last few years, and by keeping the fashions in demand and inventory tight, vanishing margins can be restored.
"You can't just put more and more garments on the floor and mark them down," he said. "We realized that the way to survive was to attract more customers with fashion and life style rather than price."
Mr. Hansel isn't content with just jazzing up his shelves with the latest styles. He also wants to inspire his employees with the latest empowerment nostrums. To that end, he requires them to read the best-selling how-to-succeed manual "Seven Habits of Highly Effective People," by Stephen R. Covey, and keeps a library of similarly inspirational guides at his corporate headquarters. "We encourage people to become more spiritual," he said in an interview in his spacious downtown Los Angeles office, cluttered with spiritual tomes as well as posters of women's legs.
Rampage is also trying to gain leverage from its role as a supplier and a retailer. It makes several lines for department stores, as well as items exclusively for its mall stores.
Rampage now does about a quarter of a billion dollars in business annually, and recently it decided it was time to hire a chief financial officer, in preparation for an initial public offering this year, Mr. Hansel said.
Other regional companies rolling out fashion-smart stores, but slowly, include the Gadzooks Inc. chain, based in Dallas, with 126 stores in 21 states, and Buckle Inc., based in Kearney, Neb., with 167 outlets in 22 states, analysts said.
"Most of these organizations are very lean today," said Walter F. Loeb, who has his own retail consultancy in New York. "With fewer players, the ones who are left are going to be real winners.
"I really believe that juniors are going to lead the trends in fashions now."

HEADLINE: Jobless Rates Change Little in New York Region

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
In a further indication of the local economy's continued sluggishness, monthly unemployment rates in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut region were virtually unchanged over the same period last year, according to Labor Department figures released yesterday.
The January unemployment rate in New York State, for example, was 6.2 percent, compared with 6.1 percent a year earlier. 
 In New Jersey, the January 1996 unemployment rate was 6.5 percent, down slightly from the 6.8 percent a year earlier.
In Connecticut, the rate was unchanged: 5.3 percent in January 1996 and January 1995.
"The economy simply doesn't have the momentum to make a reduction in the ranks of the unemployed," said John L. Wieting, the regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.
"You are also seeing the same type of picture nationally, where there has been little change in the unemployment rate since the spring."
The national unemployment rate for January was 5.8 percent, in line with its range of 5.6 to 5.8 percent since the spring.
According to the monthly report, New York City's unemployment rate was 8.1 percent in January, compared with 7.2 percent a year earlier. But Mr. Wieting pointed out that the January 1995 rate was the year's low, and he said the city's unemployment rate has been in the 8 percent range since July.
Mr. Wieting said, "In an economy such as this region's, which had a huge downturn in jobs from 1989 to 1992 and has lagged in recovery, part of the lower unemployment rate reflects that we haven't had substantial growth in the labor force, people actively in the job market."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Little Change For Treasuries As Gains Melt

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday, paring early gains made on a report showing a rise in weekly jobless claims.
Market participants limited their buying yesterday, preferring to await today's employment report for February. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 4/32 , to 9330/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.46 percent, from 6.45 percent on Wednesday. But prices of some shorter-term maturities rose.
"A combination of surprisingly strong January manufacturing data and nervousness ahead of Friday's payrolls report managed to undermine the Treasury market's new-found optimisim," said Carroll J. Delaney, director of research for Sties, O'Donnell & Company.
He said yearly statistical reconciliations might push the recent sluggish new jobs data sharply higher,
Bond prices rose in early trading after the Labor Department reported that the number of initial claims for state unemployment benefits rose by 6,000 last week, to 363,000, after declining by 25,000 the previous week. The report pointed to continued weakness in the economy, bolstering hopes for a cut in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
But the market then "elected to hunker down in the bunker until the smoke clears on Friday morning," Mr. Delaney said.
Economists expect today's employment report will show, on average, an increase of 326,000 jobs to the nation's payrolls. Still, economists' forecasts for the payrolls number range from 275,000 to as high as 450,000.
Mr. Delaney said the market would be looking at the averaging of the January and February payroll numbers. The market, he said, is nervous about any upward revision for January, which showed a decline of 200,000 jobs, a drop attributed largely to severe winter storms.
"If the number comes in lower than expected, with a gain of 300,000 or less, then the market will likely be encouraged, particularly the short end, because the weakness raises the odds for further interest rate cuts by the Fed," he said.
If the data come in higher, he said, that raises the average number of jobs created and almost virtually kills any chance of a rate cut this month.
In other economic reports yesterday, the Conference Board, a business research group in New York, said its index of leading economic indicators fell five-tenths of 1 percent in January. But the decline was primarily weather related, some analysts said.
Ken McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a research analysis firm, said the January decline by itself was not meaningful because of a blizzard.
"But the decline since the beginning of last year certainly suggest that there is potential for problems in the economy," he said. "While the economy may not be about to turn down, it clearly isn't running on all cylinders. That's why we expect the Fed to lower interest rates this year."

HEADLINE: In America;
A Job Myth Downsized

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Like a hit tune played incessantly on top-40 radio, we keep hearing that technological advances, especially computers, are throwing wages out of whack and otherwise making life miserable for American workers. It's a sad song. It tells us that the job crunch and the growing inequality in wages are, to a great extent, the natural result of the demand in a high-tech economy for highly educated, highly skilled workers. The dopes who can't cope are necessarily left behind.
"Once you lay out the hypothesis, it suggests certain pieces of evidence you ought to be able to find," said Jared Bernstein, an economist with the Economic Policy Institute in Washington. 
 You would expect, for example, increased job opportunities for highly skilled, highly educated white-collar workers. And you would expect to see increases in the absolute wages of those who work with computers, the folks with the technical skills that supposedly are so highly prized.
"Neither of those pieces of evidence is there," said Mr. Bernstein, who, with his E.P.I. colleague, Lawrence Mishel, has been studying the impact of technology on wage and employment trends.
Mr. Bernstein and Mr. Mishel believe the impact has been overstated. If high-tech workers are experiencing any sort of boom, they are keeping it carefully concealed.
"We are seeing wage declines for the vast majority of workers," said Mr. Mishel. "Workers in every industry you look at, including those that are the most technologically advanced, have been losing ground."
Common sense tells us that technology has had some effect. Newspaper printers have gone the way of the buffalo, and telephone operators are not far behind. Children chatter on the Internet and automatic teller machines are ubiquitous. But technology has always displaced workers, and it has always demanded more highly skilled workers. What Mr. Bernstein and Mr. Mishel are finding is that technology is entering the workplace at roughly the same rate that it always has. There has been no surge in technology, no technological shock, that has coincided with the sharp increase in wage inequality that began in 1979 and has not let up.
Those who argue that there is some kind of panacea in simply upgrading the skills of the technologically inept are deluded. The most startling thing about the so-called downsizing phenomenon is the high level of talent that is being shown the door.
The United States already has the best-educated work force in the world. Twenty-five percent of all workers are college graduates. But no amount of college or sophisticated technical training has provided an adequate defense for workers in an era when nearly all of the workplace clout rests with the corporate powers that be.
Since 1979 the corrosive shadow of falling wages and underemployment has crept from one socioeconomic group to another -- from the low-skilled and least educated to those with high school diplomas to those with some college, and now those with degrees and high levels of technological skill.
Many factors were involved, including the downward tug of a devalued minimum wage, the drastic weakening of labor unions, the continuing effects of globalization and the shift to service employment, and the impact of immigration, legal and illegal.
But hovering over all of that was the ability of corporations to squeeze profits out of the wages of workers who, battered from many directions, felt powerless.
Said Mr. Mishel, "If everyone is afraid that the job they now have is the best job they can get, because if they lose it they go to a worse job, then no one -- white-collar worker, blue-collar worker, union or nonunion -- is able to put any pressure on the employer."
It is not a skills deficit that is killing the American worker, it's the wholesale loss of clout. Fearful workers are quietly taking whatever employers dish out. And employers are dishing out lower wages, fewer benefits and no security. Productivity improvements, like all other benefits, go automatically to the corporate side of the table, where they are turned into profits. There is no longer any need to spread the wealth. The folks at the top of the pyramid, at least for the time being, have won.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Fraying of Hope

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Newspapers are an imperfect in strument. But at their best their rare best -- they can illuminate a profound problem that society has not perceived or understood. That is what The New York Times is doing this week in a series of extended articles called "The Downsizing of America."
The series has put human faces on those large, abstract figures of jobs eliminated at AT&T, the Chase Manhattan Bank and so many other companies. It has shown us not just individual pain but the social consequences of the ruthless new economy: the loss of community, the rootless family, the fraying of hope. 
 Here is James E. Sharlow, a $130,000-a-year plant manager for Eastman Kodak, 26 years with the company until he was laid off six months before he would have been entitled to a full pension. Or here is Steven A. Holthausen, once a $50,000-a-year bank officer, now a $12,000 tourist guide whose wife and children left him as a loser.
Some of the stories of ruined lives brought tears to my eyes. But the people described did not seek sympathy; they struggled to survive. And the point is not a sentimental one.
Since 1979, more than 43 million jobs have been lost in this country. More new ones have been created. But middle-class people have been laid off in larger numbers than before, and the new jobs tend to be lower-paid. A generation ago most of those laid off got other work that paid as well; today two-thirds work for less.
The struggle to stay in the middle class exacts a high price. Husbands live 1,000 miles from their families because that is where a job is. A highly skilled machinist, confronting the fact that this layoff is permanent, goes without health insurance for his family.
A particularly significant phenomenon is the weakening of community life -- of the private associations that everyone from de Tocqueville on has seen as a crucial factor in American society. People desperate for work do not have the time or the will to volunteer for churches or Boy Scouts or the United Way. Fewer and fewer people feel attached to any community.
The Times series should provoke fresh reflection on where our society is going in a world driven by market economics. What social and economic policies might reduce the damage to individuals and communities?
One thing seems plain. We cannot look to the magic of the market for solutions. A culture provides the values of community and caring; if the society does not supply them, the market certainly will not. If the society does, the market adjusts to them; thus Japanese companies have resisted layoffs despite several years of recession.
In the whirling economy of America today, hardly anyone can expect lifetime employment with a single company. It follows that people cannot look to companies for lifetime security -- health care, for example. But people must have that security in order to move from one job to another with a degree of confidence.
Government has to act to provide the needed assurance. That is why Congress is working on a proposal to make health insurance portable -- to guarantee that someone laid off in San Diego will not be turned down by the insurance company at his new job in Chicago because of a pre-existing condition.
Another evident need is to boost economic growth -- to overcome Alan Greenspan's shibboleth that anything more than 2.25 percent growth a year would be dangerously inflationary. And if we want to avoid the menace of social resentment, we must reverse the trend of enriching the very rich -- the trend that has seen the C.E.O.'s of some major American corporations go from 35 times the wage of the average worker 20 years ago to compensation that is today 187 times the average wage.
The irony is that we are confronted with these daunting new social and economic realities at a moment when the American public has had dinned into it the notion that government is evil and should be dismantled. The new realities are a dispositive answer to Gingrichism. We need a much bigger government commitment to education. We need more college scholarships, not fewer.
There must be, there will be government responses to the social costs of downsizing. Pat Buchanan has offered his unconvincing solution: Build tariff walls around the country. Will President Clinton offer better ideas?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Several New Reports Give A Mixed View of Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
Several new statistics gave a mixed reading on the economy today, as economists awaited the Labor Department's employment report on Friday.
Despite the January blizzard in the Northeast, consumers added to installment debt at a hefty annual pace of 12.1 percent in January, the Federal Reserve reported. This compared with a rate of 11.6 percent in December, revised upward from a 9.3 percent rate estimated a month ago. 
 The Conference Board, a business research group in New York, calculated that its index designed to signal turning points in the business cycle dropped five-tenths of 1 percent in January as the blizzard shrank the length of the average workweek to its lowest point in more than 12 years.
Still another report found that first-time claims for unemployment insurance climbed 6,000 in the week ended Saturday, retracing about a quarter of the preceding week's improvement.
Analysts said the latest data provided little solid information about the state of the economy, which they said seemed to be grinding out further meager gains.
"They suggest to me that we're still in the doldrums, especially the manufacturing sector," commented Evelina M. Tainer, chief economist at Indosuez Carr Futures in Chicago. "We're going to have a soft, sluggish first half and a rebound in the second half," she predicted, with total output expanding an average of 1.3 percent at an annual rate through mid-year and 2.8 percent thereafter.
The installment debt compilation, once regarded as a quite useful indicator of consumer behavior, is now denigrated by many analysts because of the rise of home equity loans, which are not included, and the increased use of credit cards for convenience rather than as a means to borrow. Moreover, the series does not show extensions or repayments, only the net change in the amount outstanding.
Still, analysts said, the economy is unlikely to be at risk of a significant downturn so long as installment debt continues to rise at double-digit annual rates. Revolving, or credit card, debt rose at a 16.1 percent pace in January, the fastest since June, today's report showed, while automobile credit slowed to a 9.3 percent rate of increase from 14.4 percent in December.
Interest rates on new car loans averaged 9.74 percent, down sharply from 10.52 in December.
The category of "other" debt, which includes loans for boats, college or vacations, expanded at a 9.8 percent pace compared with 2.1 percent in December, the Fed reported.
"The consumer's balance sheet is not yet as overextended as it was in the late 1980's," Joseph Liro, economist at Wood Gundy, advised clients last Friday. "Therefore we believe the consumer can sustain at least a moderate pace of spending through 1996."
The sizable decline in the recently privatized index of leading indicators, which has also lost esteem over the last several years, had little effect today not only because most of its components have been previously reported but also because of the blizzard's overwhelming effect in shrinking the workweek.
Excluding the workweek item, the index would have edged up one-tenth of 1 percent instead of falling five-tenths of 1 percent, the Conference Board said. Nonetheless, the index has moved lower in four of the latest five months and eight of the latest 12.
After the workweek, negative impacts were generated by lower building permits, a decline in consumer expectations, a rise in first-time jobless claims, quicker deliveries by suppliers and lower stock prices.
Positive contributions came from a rise in unfilled factory orders for durable goods (also reflecting the blizzard), higher prices for materials particularly sensitive to the business cycle, higher contracts and orders for new plant and equipment, more orders to factories for consumer goods and a slightly expanded money supply.
The companion index of coincident indicators fell three-tenths of 1 percent in January after rising that much in December, while the index of indicators that tend to move only after the economy at large was unchanged in January after rising three-tenths of 1 percent in December.
The Labor Department's report on jobless claims listed 363,000 last week, up from 357,000 in the Feb. 24 week, with the four-week average inching down by 1,000 to stand at 370,750. Some analysts found signs of marginal labor market improvement in recent claims figures but there was little correlation between them and the monthly figures to be published Friday.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies Against the Mark But Ends Lower in Profit Taking

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar edged lower yesterday on profit taking after an overnight rally fed by signs of German economic weakness.
The dollar surged to a five-week high against the German mark in Asian and European trading, bolstered by a report showing the German economy shrank by five-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter of 1995. That report fueled rising speculation that Germany would soon cut official interest rates, which would enhance the relative value of United States assets. 
 Hints of rate cuts by the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, also spurred dollar buyers.
"The rally in the dollar against the mark was predicated on the bad economic figures in Germany and anticipation of rate cuts," said Michael Malpede, senior foreign exchange analyst at the Refco Group.
By comparison, the American economy looks far stronger, and traders eagerly awaited today's employment report for February for confirmation of that view.
The Federal Reserve has reduced United States short-term interest rates three times since last July, but a strong gain in the number of jobs being added to payrolls may delay any further monetary easing.
"If the U.S. is not going to cut rates and Europe is, there's a fundamental reason to see movement into the dollar," Mr. Malpede said.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar slipped to 1.4763 German marks from 1.4770 marks on Wednesday. The dollar was quoted at 105.25 Japanese yen, down from 105.40 yen. The British pound was unchanged at $1.5295.
The dollar's advance failed to cross a key technical level at 1.4850 marks, which encouraged many investors to book profits rather than risk big losses should the currency sell off after the payrolls data.
"The fact that we tested, but did not fly through that level just gave the market the opportunity to lock something in ahead of the employment numbers," said Jim Blackwelder, vice president for corporate foreign exchange at NatWest New Jersey.
But most market activity revolved around the mark and its performance against currencies in Europe and Japan. The dollar remains a secondary trading concern, dealers said.
"It's been weak currencies that have been taking the dollar higher, rather than the market getting convinced that the tide has turned and the dollar should be making higher levels," Mr. Blackwelder said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Decision on Mexico Drugs Draws Opposition in Congress

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
Angered by President Clinton's decision to declare Mexico a cooperative partner in the war on drugs, lawmakers in the House and Senate are trying to overturn the decision on the ground that Mexico has done little to shut down the huge pipelines for cocaine and other illegal narcotics that stretch across the border into the United States.
A House International Relations panel summoned top Administration counternarcotics officials to Capitol Hill today to defend Mr. Clinton's decision. At the hearing, Republican lawmakers sounded incredulous as they cited reports that more than two-thirds of the cocaine used in the United States flows through Mexico. 
 "When you see that 65 to 70 percent of the cocaine coming into this country is coming in through Mexico or from Mexico, at that particular time it would make one wonder as to what extent the Mexican Government is cooperating with us," said Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., a Republican of Florida and a sponsor of the legislation disapproving of Mr. Clinton's decision on Mexico.
The proposed legislation reflects a deep strain of discontent among lawmakers who say that the Administration has adopted a unjustifiably lenient approach toward Mexico and other countries. For some Republicans the issue is a potential campaign theme charging that Mr. Clinton has put international trade and foreign policy goals ahead of the battle against drugs.
So far the Administration does not appear worried by the maneuvering in Congress. Today, Robert S. Gelbard, the top narcotics control official at the State Department, said Mexico has begun to show signs of progress under President Ernesto Zedillo.
Since Friday, when the White House announced its list of countries that are cooperating in efforts to combat illegal narcotics, a growing number of lawmakers have criticzed the decision on Mexico.
Many said that, narcotics issues aside, the Administration decided it could not find Mexico as uncooperative because such a step would have caused deep friction with a major trading partner and the recipient of a $20 billion American aid package to support the plunging peso.
Technically, Mr. Clinton made the decision under a law that requires the President to compile a report each year on which countries are trying to combat drug trafficking. The President can either certify a country as cooperative or decertify it, which can lead to economic sanctions.
Mr. Shaw's legislation would overturn Mr. Clinton's certification, a step that would force Mr. Clinton to repeat the entire certification process for Mexico or suspend economic aid to Mexico. Similar legislation was introduced in the Senate by Alfonse D'Amato, a Republican of New York.
President Clinton's decision followed weeks of fierce internal discussion over Mexico and Colombia, officials said today. The outline of the final decision was reached on Feb. 28 at a White House meeting with Presidential aides and top officials from the Departments of Justice, Treasury and State.
During these deliberations, the Mexican Government sent Clinton Administration officials a private note promising more aggressive efforts on narcotics issues, support for legislation against organized crime and money laundering, and swift enactment of the laws once they are passed.
The officials were unanimous in their support for certifying Mexico, but were convinced that a lenient gesture toward Mexico should be accompanied by stringent measures elsewhere, for example, in Colombia. Mr. Clinton decertified Colombia, which meant a cutoff of most American economic aid.

HEADLINE: Power Talks for Long Island

 BODY:
Obedient to Gov. George Pataki's initiative, the Long Island Power Authority, a New York State agency, has voted to open negotiations with the Long Island Lighting Company over a state takeover that could give some relief to Islanders, burdened with the highest utility rates in the continental United States. The decision is an important step but one that leaves wide open all the complex questions about Lilco's future.
The Governor's plan is to dismantle Lilco by selling its generators and gas facilities to other companies and holding its transmission and distribution lines in state hands so as to qualify for tax benefits that would lower rates by 12 percent. That much of the plan makes financial sense, but it would still leave Long Island with the highest electricity rates outside Hawaii. 
 The plan has acquired some hopeful if wary supporters in recent weeks. The Long Island Association, representing civic and business interests, has posed hard questions but applauds the momentum toward energy relief. Consumer and environmental groups are going along, pressing for new economies from technology and fuel conservation. Nassau and Suffolk counties retain their strong differences over the plan's tax consequences and how some of the rate relief should be allocated.
Negotiations will be tricky. Unless the plan can produce savings beyond the projected tax benefits, the result might not be worth the huge effort.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Russian Shepherd of Mutual Funds

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 7

 BODY:
When Dmitri V. Vasiliev was a student of Marxist economics, he was taught that the stock market was a casino for the super-rich.
"They stressed it served a narrow circle and was not in the interests of the broad masses of people," Mr. Vasiliev recalled with a smile. 
 Today, with an eye on those broad masses, he has a new passion: creating Russia's first mutual funds.
As the 32-year-old head of Russia's version of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the former Marxist is now an unabashed advocate of free markets. And he sees mutual funds as the key to building capitalism, energizing the anemic stock market and helping Russia raise the money that is badly needed for investment.
With many Russians deeply distrustful of investment schemes and the stock market experiencing growing pains, Mr. Vasiliev has his work cut out. But the potential payoff, he insists, is great.
According to Government estimates, Russians are sitting on at least $20 billion in household savings. And Mr. Vasiliev figures that if 10 percent or so could be drawn into the stock market, this could help the economy exceed foreign investment in Russia last year.
"There is a huge supply of money, including hard currency, for which there is no use," Mr. Vasiliev said. "It is money kept under the pillow or bed, as we say."
With his banker's business suit and studious manner, Mr. Vasiliev looks out of place in Russia's cut-throat political scene. By his own admission, it has been a long, strange trip.
As a student in St. Petersburg, Mr. Vasiliev was a confirmed Marxist. But as the cold war wound down, he began to study Western economics on his own.
Mr. Vasiliev served as a key aide to Anatoly B. Chubais, the free-market advocate, who rose to the rank of first deputy prime minister before being ousted in January by President Boris N. Yeltsin.
When Russia established its Federal Commission on Securities and the Capital Market in 1994, Mr. Vasiliev became the deputy chairman and executive director under Mr. Chubais, who served as chairman.
Now, with the Communists riding high in the polls, this is not the most auspicious time to be an economic reformer. Mr. Yeltsin's attempt to distance himself from controversial economic changes, and Mr. Chubais's departure, have led some to wonder if Mr. Vasiliev will be among the next casualties in Russia's political wars.
Still, he soldiers on. "I can say that my work was and is supported by the Prime Minister," Mr. Vasiliev said.
Even without the political considerations, his task would not be easy. With a capitalization of about $20 billion, the Russian stock market is tiny compared with that of major markets in the United States.
Mr. Vasiliev's commission completed a plan in December to protect investors' rights, which is still awaiting Mr. Yeltsin's signature. Some key elements, such as the strengthening of the law on securities fraud, require legislative approval.
Another big problem is attracting money from small Russian investors. Not only do they face prohibitively expensive brokerage fees and red tape, but also pyramid schemes -- like the one at the investment company MMM, have made investing synonymous with scandal for many Russians.
"The capital market today is imbalanced," said Bernard Sucher, managing director of Troika Dialog, an investment bank and brokerage dealer. "If you are a small Russian investor, there is no way of accessing the securities market here."
The scarcity of Russians willing to take the risks has made the market overly dependent on wary foreign investors.
"The market in Russia today moves on foreign money deciding to come or leave," said Christopher Smart, director of research for Pioneer First Voucher, which is planning to start a mutual fund. "Economically, the real long-term hope for this market lies in mobilizing domestic capital."
And this is where mutual funds come in. Last summer, Mr. Yeltsin signed a decree authorizing the creation of the funds, leaving Mr. Vasiliev to create the regulatory structure. Mr. Vasiliev hopes to issue licenses for the first mutual funds before the country's presidential election in June.
The funds are to be of two types: open, meaning that they are required to redeem shares within 15 days of a request, and interval, which will be obliged to redeem shares at least once a year. Foreigners will be able to invest in the funds.
Among the companies planning to set up mutual funds are Pioneer First Voucher, in which the Boston-based Pioneer Group has a controlling interest.
Other applicants include Russian investment groups like Asko-Kapital as well as Dubna, whose management includes former nuclear scientists. Major Russian banks and brokerage companies, like Troika Dialog, also plan to set up funds.
Mr. Vasiliev hopes to rehabilitate failed investment schemes and turn them into respectable mutual funds. But his commission has received only five applications from such unlicensed companies, and only one, Russki Dom Selengo, has been given temporary permission to proceed.
Some skeptics say the Government has been moving too slowly.
"There has been a lot of noise around this idea of mutual funds, but no result so far," said Sergei Skatershchikov, president of Skate Press, a financial data and research company. "In the short period, I do not really expect this industry to develop."
But other specialists argue that Russian stocks are undervalued and that Russians do not have a lot of investment alternatives. Even so, much may depend on politics.
"If the Communists win, I think Western investors will treat Russia quite cautiously, and there will be less domestic investment," Mr. Vasiliev said. "Our Communists are not Polish Communists. They are worse."
But, characteristically bullish, he quickly moved away from that thought. "If the elections have success, and I believe in Yeltsin's victory, we can expect a significant development of the market in the fall of 1996," Mr. Vasiliev said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dmitri V. Vasiliev, Russia's top securities regulator, is pushing for the creation of the country's first mutual funds. "There is a huge supply of money, including hard currency, for which there is no use," he says. (James Hill for The New York Times)
